webTitle: Robinson exit marks end of era at Anfield

fields.headline: Robinson exit marks end of era at Anfield
fields.trailText: Peter Robinson, the architect of the modern Liverpool and the club's executive vice-chairman, yesterday announced that he intends to leave this summer after 35 years' unbroken service at Anfield.
fields.body:
Peter Robinson, the architect of the modern Liverpool and the club's executive vice-chairman, yesterday announced that he intends to leave this summer after 35 years' unbroken service at Anfield.

The 64-year-old had been expected to retire within two years but the fact that he has indicated a willingness to listen to offers will prompt speculation that he may be the victim of a political spat.

"Although I have not yet decided anything definite, I am certain that one way or another they will include some involvement with football," he said yesterday.

Robinson, acknowledged to be among the finest administrators of his generation, may now be courted by Uefa but there remains a chance of him returning to Crewe Alexandra, where he began his career.

Liverpool have never gone in for traditional power struggles but, in the new media-driven age, it was perhaps inevitable that there would be friction. The club's new power-broker will be Rick Parry, the chief executive who arrived two years ago after a highly successful spell in a similar role for the Premier League.

Parry is believed to be anxious to extend his responsibilities. Only 12 months ago he was understood to be on the verge of returning to the Premier League after privately questioning his role at a club where Robinson has presided since the days of Bill Shankly.

"This is a very sad day for me," Robinson said. "I shall be leaving with many wonderful memories. I am extremely proud that during my time 27 major trophies were won."

 Ryan Giggs, 26, has been included in the Wales squad for the match with Finland in Cardiff on March 29. If Giggs plays, it will be his first friendly for his country

fields.headline: Phillips strikes £6m deal
fields.trailText: Kevin Phillips's prodigious scoring feats for Sunderland were reflected in the pay league yesterday when the Premiership's top scorer was rewarded with a new, five-year contract worth more than £6m.
fields.body:
Kevin Phillips's prodigious scoring feats for Sunderland were reflected in the pay league yesterday when the Premiership's top scorer was rewarded with a new, five-year contract worth more than £6m.

Phillips has rapidly confounded many pundits in scoring 25 goals in the top flight this season and there was a neat symmetry to the £25,000-a-week deal which makes the striker the highest earner in the Wearside club's history.

Sunderland's manager Peter Reid never had any doubts about the former non-league player he signed from Watford in 1997 for £650,000. Reid has been vindicated by Phillips's quarter-century already this season - as part of his astonishing 85 goals in less than three seasons with the club.

England recognition has followed but Reid's personal estimation of the 26-year-old player is even higher. "When I see Kevin in action two players come to mind - Ronaldo and Rivaldo. He has been a tremendous asset and he's still improving. We have not seen the best of him yet."

Phillips is now tied to Sunderland until 2005 and, despite inevitable interest by other clubs, he claims he could not see himself leaving the Stadium of Light. "I owe so much to the club, the players and the fans", he said. "It is incredible to hear 42,000 people singing your name. Nothing can begin to describe it. Why would I walk away from that? How could I?"

England's World Cup qualifier against Germany on October 7 will be played at Wembley, a decision which will satisfy tradition as well as huge public demand for this evocative fixture.

The Football Association said last night: "The closure of the stadium has been delayed by three weeks to enable the match to act as the finale in the present Wembley's 77-year history. The bulldozers are expected to move in soon afterwards."

Jorge Cadete's patience is already running out at Bradford City, only three weeks after he joined on loan before a proposed £1.5m summer deal.

The Portuguese striker has yet to start a game for the Premiership strugglers and yesterday he said: "If I'm not going to start games here, then maybe it's best that I should stay in Lisbon. I'm 100 per cent fit now and I want to play in all games."

Fulham have signed the American midfielder Eddie Lewis for £1.3m from San Jose Earthquakes. The manager Paul Bracewell said: "I've only seen him on tape but my chief scout, John Marshall, saw him play in the States and we think he will adapt well to the English game."

fields.headline: Gunners call all the shots
fields.standfirst:
Patience pays off as Henry and Ljungberg breach German defensive wall
Henry 21, Ljungberg 75
fields.trailText: Arsenal 2 - 0 Werder Bremen
fields.body:
They came, they saw but they failed to kill it. Werder Bremen's unadventurous approach got what it deserved last night when Arsenal's patience and perseverence earned them a two-goal cushion to take to Germany next Thursday.

After Thierry Henry had made a first-half breakthrough, Arsenal got the late goal they desperately sought as Freddy Ljungberg capitalised on a miskick by the substitute Kanu. They should be wary, though. Earlier in this competition Bremen lost 3-0 at Lyon but won the home leg 4-0.

The worry for the home fans had been which Arsenal would turn up; the team who destroyed Deportivo La Coruna 5-1 here in the previous round or the side who drew at Aston Villa three days later. Consistency has not been Arsenal's strong suit this season.

Arsène Wenger was doubtless aware that, despite their impressive win over Parma in the previous round, the German side arrived on the back of four straight away defeats and he could welcome back his inspirational captain Tony Adams.

On the flip side, injuries robbed Arsenal of Martin Keown and Emmanuel Petit. But even without his French accomplice, Patrick Vieira began in fine fashion, spreading passes and surging through to create his team's first opportunity in the eighth minute.

His excellent run and pass sent through Thierry Henry, who burst past his marker and stayed on his feet in the penalty area when others might have tumbled only to drag his shot off target.

Henry, though, did not have long to wait before opening the scoring with a well-taken goal. Vieira was the architect with a measured ball over the top of a static Bremen defence and, as the German side looked in vain for offside, Henry went through to beat Frank Rost with a low shot for his 15th of the season. It was not the last time his pace would cause problems.

That 21st-minute breakthrough was no more than Arsenal deserved for a positive opening.

With Marco Bode offering only sporadic support to the Brazilian Ailton up front and the experienced Dieter Eilts prowling in front of the back four, the German cup holders had clearly come to keep the score down.

Adams, whose domineering return settled an Arsenal defence which was rarely troubled, could hardly be blamed failing to score from his oportunity. When Dennis Bergkamp's corner fell to him at the far post his shot was brilliantly kept out by Rost. As the incessant Arsenal pressure continued Bergkamp carved out a chance for Ray Parlour. But the England international skewed his effort well wide.

Although Arsenal's performance lacked much of the sparkle of their recent Uefa Cup performances here, they were not entirely to blame Bremen, fifth in the Bundesliga, were as adventurous as Ken Bates believes Leicester are.

It was hard to believe they are Germany's second-leading scorers, though doubtless they are saving that for the return. David Seaman, for all he was tested, might as well have travelled to Germany already.

Henry's speed always looked Arsenal's best outlet but his chances to get behind the defence were limited as Wenger's increasingly frustrated players struggled to breach the Bremen wall.

Not surprisingly, Wenger threw on Kanu and Marc Overmars, calculating that Arsenal would need luck or a spark of brilliance to be able to approach next week's trip with genuine breathing space.

When Kanu created a chance for Henry, Rost saved with his legs. But Arsenal got the luck they deserved when Kanu's mishit shot enabled Ljungberg to score a potentially decisive second.

Arsenal (4-4-2): Seaman; Dixon, Luzhny, Adams, Silvinho; Parlour (Overmars,68 min), Vieira, Grimandi, Ljungberg; Bergkamp (Kanu, 67), Henry (Suker, 76).

Werder Bremen (4-4-1-1): Rost; Tjikuzu, Barten, Baumann, Wiedener; Frings, Eilts, Herzog, Dabrowski; Bode; Ailton.

Referee: C Colombo (France).

fields.headline: Players open door to women
fields.trailText: Women will make their debut at the Professional Footballers' Association annual awards dinner next month after 26 years of waiting on the sidelines.
fields.body:
Women will make their debut at the Professional Footballers' Association annual awards dinner next month after 26 years of waiting on the sidelines.

A group headed by the sports minister Kate Hoey, the England women's coach Hope Powell and Katherine Knight of the Football Association has been invited to the dinner on April 30 after the PFA abandoned its male-only rule following defeat in a sex discrimination case last year.

The legal defeat, after being taken to court by the football agent Rachel Anderson, cost the PFA £52,500. That setback, followed by a players' poll revealing no objection to women invitees, brought about the end of male exclusivity at the function at which the players' Player of the Year is announced.

Anderson, who was awarded £7,500 damages and £45,000 in legal costs, said yesterday: "Some of the women who have been invited phoned to say 'thank you' for what I have done."

Asked about next month's dinner, she said: "I don't think I have been asked to go and I would like to."

She sued after two rebuffs by the PFA over the annual dinner. In 1997 Anderson was asked to leave after being invited by Sheffield United players she represented. In 1998 she was refused admission after being invited by her client Julian Dicks "because of restrictions on space".

Hoey has already said she will attend this year's ground-breaking function and so has Powell, who said: "This is another indication of the growth in acceptance of the women's game. We have always invited men to our awards lunch and I will be accepting the reciprocal offer."

webTitle: United and Chelsea make case to end Italy's European reign

fields.headline: United and Chelsea make case to end Italy's European reign
fields.standfirst: Cool Blues and hot Reds show form to bring English fanfare to final
fields.trailText: Not so long ago the failure of Premiership champions to make a significant impact on the new Champions League was a major source of embarrassment to English self-esteem. The country's seven European Cup triumphs of the late 70s and early 80s were long gone. Italian clubs, it seemed, had a season ticket to the final.
fields.body:
Not so long ago the failure of Premiership champions to make a significant impact on the new Champions League was a major source of embarrassment to English self-esteem. The country's seven European Cup triumphs of the late 70s and early 80s were long gone. Italian clubs, it seemed, had a season ticket to the final.

How quickly things can change. Now two English teams, Chelsea and Manchester United, are in the quarter-finals and by next Wednesday Italy's interest could have vanished.

With Lazio in danger of being edged out by Feyenoord in Group D should they lose at Stamford Bridge next week, when United are in Valencia, and Fiorentina imperilled by Wednesday's 3-1 defeat at Old Trafford in Group B, the prospect of Serie A disappearing before the knock-out stage is real indeed.

Not that this will worry United or Chelsea. Already their main concern must be that they avoid one another until the final in Paris on May 24.

United and Chelsea will not be paired in the quarter-finals, for which the draw will be made a week today, provided both win their groups or both finish runners-up.

Chelsea can finish second only if they lose at home to Lazio next Wednesday and United will end up second only if Valencia beat them by at least three goals on Tuesday.

Sir Alex Ferguson, the United manager, has said that, whether his team finished first or second, it would make little difference to their chances of successfully defending the European Cup. Except that staying top would avoid an early confrontation with Barcelona or Bayern Munich, who have already won groups A and C.

On this week's evidence United and Chelsea both look well capable of reaching the Stade de France just over two months from now, though seldom can two sides from the same country have achieved impressive victories on successive evenings in such contrasting styles.

In Rotterdam on Tuesday Gianluca Vialli's team fixed Feyenoord with a cobra's eye before striking with lethal accuracy, apart from Frank Leboeuf's missed penalty that is. Gianfranco Zola, Dennis Wise and Tore Andre Flo each finished with the kind of flourish that is sometimes lacking in Chelsea's domestic games.

It was a supremely cool performance that had Feyenoord looking disheartened long before the end. True, the Dutch side are an inelegant parody of what they once were but they had just beaten Lazio 2-1 in Rome and it said much for Chelsea that Feyenoord were denied the opportunity to capitalise on that result.

At Old Trafford the following night only the evening air was cool. The 92-year-old Sir John Mills was a guest of United and, if the occasion was hardly a remake of Ice Cold In Alex, at least the performance of Ferguson's team recalled Mills's best-known line from the film as he at last downed a glass of lager: "Worth waiting for."

Indeed it was and the high drama of the first half produced some of the most entertaining football seen in the Champions League this season, although Arsenal's encounter with Barcelona at Wembley last October, when Arsène Wenger's side lost 4-2, edged it for sustained excitement.

The thunderous shot from Gabriel Batistuta, which scorched the hands of Mark Bosnich as the Argentine gave Fiorentina an early lead, jolted United out of their season's torpor and from then on Ferguson's players were like amnesiacs who had found sudden and total recall.

Andy Cole, playing in a slightly different role which involved linking with Ryan Giggs on the left, was United's outstanding player, quickly bringing the scores level before Roy Keane and Dwight Yorke completed a notable victory.

At half-time Kevin Keegan, wearing his television pundit's hat, thought that Keane was having a quiet game. Perhaps the England coach was watching the match on a small monitor.

webTitle: Budgeting for more money? Give us a break

fields.headline: Budgeting for more money? Give us a break
fields.trailText: It's the budget next week and accountants Deloitte and Touche are suggesting that the Premiership clubs should be given tax breaks as 25% of income is lost. So what?
fields.body:
As Gordon Brown pieces together Tuesday's Budget announcements, he will be preoccupied by the expectations of thousands of teachers, hospital workers, low-income families and hard-pressed small businesses who are waiting for a scrap of lifesaving good news.

Somehow the plight of the £1bn football industry may not be too prominent in his thoughts.

You may be amused, even shocked, to learn that the accountants Deloitte and Touche are suggesting that the 20 Premiership clubs should be given tax breaks by the chancellor, insisting that the current tax burden of £180m a year is outrageous. Many of you will be outraged at this barefaced cheek.

Deloitte and Touche published their latest missive on the football industry yesterday and revealed that the amount paid by the Premiership to the inland revenue has gone up by 18% during the past season. They argue that the government should pour more money back into the game at large and that the Premiership teams should not be penalised for their own success.

They point out that 25% of the Premier League's income disappears in tax. So what? Consider the case of someone who is earning a few quid over £28,000 as a result of dedication and hard slog and gets clobbered at 40%.

The turnover of the 20 leading clubs is approaching £1bn and they are hoping for at least that amount from the new television deal for 2001. Thanks to Sky's money and jazzy approach to their coverage, top-flight football is one of this country's boom industries with more staying power and tangible product than 20 dotcom companies put together.

Most clubs should be applauded for their investment in new grounds, better infrastructure and for raising the quality of the game itself with the importation of world-class entertainers. But, if the Premier League's accountants are calling for the chancellor to give them a collective break, the game at the elite level needs to take time for quiet reflection and count its blessings.

It must be stressed that the Premier League is not pushing for direct tax concessions. That sentiment has come from Deloitte and Touche, who have cornered the market in footballing facts and figures. However, what the league is demanding is that the government matches its commitment to grassroots projects.

The Premier League has agreed to pump £7m into the Football Foundation, the body which will take care of the grassroots game once it is officially launched in the next month or so.

Of far more financial significance, the Premier League has also agreed to give 5% of the new television deal to the foundation and it has received positive noises from the exchequer that the government will match that money.

That could be a combined total of £50m being pumped into producing home-grown talent for the future, the kind of money the Lawn Tennis Association has received from the All England Club at Wimbledon in recent years and which has managed to deliver just one world-class player.

This Budget will be the last with any realistic chance of influencing the economy before the next general election, so Brown will surely be aiming for broad appeal to middle England voters. The pound is strong, consumer spending is high but businesses are struggling to cope with overseas markets.

The National Health Service is on its sickbed and waiting to be moved into intensive care, and the mantra of "education, education, education" has been replaced by "desperation, desperation, desperation".

So, the chancellor needs to be at his creative best on Tuesday, delivering the mechanics for real change. Putting a smile on the already grinning faces of Messrs Edwards, Dein, Bates and Sugar will be the last thing on his mind.

One area of sport where he might be inclined to show more sympathy is the betting industry. Already significant chunks of telephone betting have moved offshore to escape the chancellor's greedy fingers and he has been told by customs and excise that, if all of it disappears into the black hole of tax exile, it would represent a loss for the government of £50m.

As a result, there is the possibility of a reduction in betting duty. But don't hold your breath.

Deloitte and Touche published their latest missive on the football industry yesterday and revealed that the amount paid by the Premiership to the inland revenue has gone up by 18% during the past season. They argue that the government should pour more money back into the game at large and that the Premiership teams should not be penalised for their own success. They point out that 25% of the Premier League's income disappears in tax. So what? Consider the case of someone who is earning a few quid over £28,000 as a result of dedication and hard slog and gets clobbered at 40%. The turnover of the 20 leading clubs is approaching £1bn and they are hoping for at least that amount from the new television deal for 2001. Thanks to Sky's money and jazzy approach to their coverage, top-flight football is one of this country's boom industries with more staying power and tangible product than 20 dotcom companies put together. Most clubs should be applauded for their investment in new grounds, better infrastructure and for raising the quality of the game itself with the importation of world-class entertainers. But, if the Premier League's accountants are calling for the chancellor to give them a collective break, the game at the elite level needs to take time for quiet reflection and count its blessings. It must be stressed that the Premier League is not pushing for direct tax concessions. That sentiment has come from Deloitte and Touche, who have cornered the market in footballing facts and figures. However, what the league is demanding is that the government matches its commitment to grassroots projects. The Premier League has agreed to pump £7m into the Football Foundation, the body which will take care of the grassroots game once it is officially launched in the next month or so. Of far more financial significance, the Premier League has also agreed to give 5% of the new television deal to the foundation and it has received positive noises from the exchequer that the government will match that money. That could be a combined total of £50m being pumped into producing home-grown talent for the future, the kind of money the Lawn Tennis Association has received from the All England Club at Wimbledon in recent years and which has managed to deliver just one world-class player. This Budget will be the last with any realistic chance of influencing the economy before the next general election, so Brown will surely be aiming for broad appeal to middle England voters. The pound is strong, consumer spending is high but businesses are struggling to cope with overseas markets. The National Health Service is on its sickbed and waiting to be moved into intensive care, and the mantra of "education, education, education" has been replaced by "desperation, desperation, desperation". So, the chancellor needs to be at his creative best on Tuesday, delivering the mechanics for real change. Putting a smile on the already grinning faces of Messrs Edwards, Dein, Bates and Sugar will be the last thing on his mind. One area of sport where he might be inclined to show more sympathy is the betting industry. Already significant chunks of telephone betting have moved offshore to escape the chancellor's greedy fingers and he has been told by customs and excise that, if all of it disappears into the black hole of tax exile, it would represent a loss for the government of £50m. As a result, there is the possibility of a reduction in betting duty. But don't hold your breath.

fields.headline: Bygone budgets: March 1999
fields.standfirst:
Chancellor: Gordon Brown
Government: Labour
fields.trailText: It was billed in advance as a boring, mid-term budget, but Gordon Brown's third effort met with a rapturous media reception. The once Labour-loathing Sun splashed "Everyone's a winner" on its front page after the chancellor dished out a 10p starting rate for income tax and a 10p starting rate of tax for companies.
fields.body:
It was billed in advance as a boring, mid-term budget, but Gordon Brown's third effort met with a rapturous media reception. The once Labour-loathing Sun splashed "Everyone's a winner" on its front page after the chancellor dished out a 10p starting rate for income tax and a 10p starting rate of tax for companies.

The Guardian called Mr Brown's budget "a political masterpiece" and speculated that it was the first move in the government's re-election strategy. A string of measures to appeal to the party's heartlands, including more money for children and pensioners, community computers, taxes on pollution and tougher action against monopolies, were married to distinctly new Labour aspirations, such as reducing income tax and corporation tax.

The applause from unlikely sources was even more unexpected given that it was a redistributive budget. Friendly commentators judged that the modest redistribution was not squeezing the rich, but was achieved thanks to the good performance of the economy in recent years. However, the Treasury was not pleased to find the independent Institute of Fiscal Studies supporting the Conservatives' claims that Labour had increased the overall tax burden on the country.

Income tax
Gordon Brown scrapped the 20p tax band and introduced a dramatic 10p bottom rate of income tax on the first £1,500 of taxable income. He also promised to reduce the basic rate of income tax by 1p to 22p in a year's time. The tax burden on typical family with children was calculated to fall below 20% for the first time in 20 years.

Duty
Duty on alcohol was frozen "this side of the millennium", said the zeitgeist-surfing chancellor. Tobacco excise duty was increased by 5% above inflation, with cigarettes up 17.5p for 20 and cigars up 7.5p per 5.

Pollution tax
A tax on business use of energy would be introduced from April 2001 to help meet Britain's agreed targets, Mr Brown announced. But in a slight departure from previous commitments, he said that the tax would be introduced only after further consultation with industry and would not be so large as to increase the overall taxation of business with the cutting of national insurance.

Entrepreneurs
The chancellor cut corporation tax by 1p to 30p and launched a new enterprise management incentive to provide tax allowances for entrepreneurs. Mr Brown also announced a new research and development tax credit to underwrite almost one third of research and development costs for small businesses.

webTitle: Lib Dems urge 50p tax on rich

fields.headline: Lib Dems urge 50p tax on rich
fields.trailText: A 50p in the pound tax on Britain's highest earners is proposed by the Liberal Democrats in an alternative budget intended to challenge chancellor Gordon Brown to choose between tax cuts and investment in public services.
fields.body:
A 50p in the pound tax on Britain's highest earners is proposed by the Liberal Democrats in an alternative budget intended to challenge chancellor Gordon Brown to choose between tax cuts and investment in public services.

An estimated 204,000 people with an annual income of over pounds 100,000 would fall into the new top bracket, raising £2.6bn a year, according to the document published by Lib Dem treasury spokesman Matthew Taylor.

The party would use the money to cut the tax burden for those on low incomes by abolishing the 10% tax band, taking 1.4m people out of tax completely. They would also reverse all further tax cuts introduced by Labour, including a 1p cut in the basic ratedue to come into force next month.

The Lib Dem leader, Charles Kennedy, yesterday accused the Conservatives and Labour of holding a `Dutch auction on who can cut taxes the most when the British people want better funding for public services''.

Mr Taylor will seek to portray Tuesday's budget as a `litmus test' of Labour's commitment to tax cutting or improving public services. Having cleared the £28bn deficit Labour inherited from the Tories, Mr Brown now had the chance to show his commit ment to delivering better healthcare and education. The Lib Dems would reverse the 1p cut to fund a £2.65bn increase in spending on education. At the same time they would dip into the chancellor's estimated £7bn `war chest' to boost spending on the NHS.

The basic state pension would be increased by £2 a week with higher rises for the over 75s, funded from unspent social security reserves due to the fall in unemployment.

Mr Taylor said his proposals represented a slight `tightening' of the government's fiscal stance, and would not cause the Bank of England to raise interest rates.

fields.headline: Brahms: Symphony No.4
fields.trailText: In our series on building a classical library, Andrew Clements selects the definitive recording of Brahms' Symphony No.4.
fields.body:
Even those of us willing to confess our antipathy to Brahms - all that repressed emotion hiding behind such stolid, backward-looking classicism - have to take a step back when confronted by the Fourth Symphony. Of all Brahms's orchestral works it is one in which the balance between structural control and expressiveness is most perfectly maintained, in which the form does not constrict the content but, on the contrary, liberates it. The finale is arguably the most perfect symphonic movement he composed, deliberately taking an "old-fashioned" form, the chaconne, and building upon it a series of variations of increasing intensity, but each of the movements is proportioned with the same miraculous exactness.

Needless to say, there are myriad versions on disc, from almost every leading conductor of the 20th century from Artur Nikisch to Riccardo Chailly. Among the historical, ie, pre-LP, versions, Arturo Toscanini's with the NBC Symphony (RCA) from the late 40s still stands out for its structural rigour, clean-limbed lyricism, and the electricity his conducting generates. It's a model for later interpreters to follow, although, even with modern transfer techniques taking the edge off its originally sour sound, the quality is never ideal, and misgivings about its age deprive the affectionate yet rigorously structured account under Bruno Walter (Sony Classical) of some of its impact too.

All the heavyweights of the post-war era have something to say about Brahms 4 - Otto Klemperer with the Philharmonia (EMI) is typically sure-footed with its structure, and grittily direct with its lyricism too; Herbert Von Karajan (Deutsche Grammophon) is lithe, beautifully moulded, and, just in the final analysis, lacking in definition. Carlo Maria Giulini (Deutsche Grammophon) with the Vienna Philharmonic sounds spacious to some, laboured and over-reverent to others; Georg Solti (Decca) drives the music as fiercely as expected, squeezing out the intimacy in the process; Christoph von Dohnanyi (Decca) takes a direct, slightly clinical approach that leaves too little room for imagination, while Daniel Barenboim (Erato) shapes the music with great expressive freedom, using the flexibility of Wilhelm Fürtwängler as his model, and Gunter Wand (RCA), revered now in some quarters, is straightforward to the point of becoming prosaic.

The earlier of Bernard Haitink's two versions, recorded with the Concertgebouw Orchestra in the 1970s is straightforward to the point of being noble; wonderfully spaced and rhythmically exact, it's available at mid price from Philips as part of a four-disc survey of all Brahms orchestral works which is consistently first rate.

The second account by Claudio Abbado (Deutsche Grammophon, with the Berlin Philharmonic), mellow and eloquent, is worth hearing, and, as an antidote to all these sumptuous modern orchestral versions, so too is Charles Mackerras's (Telarc), with the Scottish Chamber Orchestra reviving the scale of performance Brahms would have known. The recommendation, though, is one couched very much in the mainstream orchestral tradition - Carlos Kleiber's 1980 version with the Vienna Philharmonic generates more adrenalin than any other symphonic recording I know. After you've heard it, Brahms will never seem the same again.

Key recording: Kleiber, Deutsche Grammophon 400 037-2

webTitle: Minister orders inquiry into racism at prison

fields.headline: Minister orders inquiry into racism at prison
fields.standfirst:
Race issues in the UK: special report
Special report: Prisons
fields.trailText: A home office minister yesterday ordered an inquiry into a top security prison after evidence emerged of racism among prison officers.
fields.body:
A home office minister yesterday ordered an inquiry into a top security prison after evidence emerged of racism among prison officers.

The prisons minister, Paul Boateng, demanded the investigation after being shown copies of racist remarks officers had written down at Full Sutton prison near York.

Last night a Labour MP called for the suspension of Martin Narey, the director general of the prison service, who had personally decided not to suspend the officers but sent them on a training course instead.

Mr Boateng was said to be shocked by the evidence, seen by the Guardian, which came in a log of phone conversations made by an Asian inmate which was kept by two prison officers.

One remark said that the prisoner "talks in Paki". The investigation will come as yet another embarrassment for the prison service, after allegations of racism against inmates at Wormwood Scrubs and Wandsworth, in London.

The prison service said the two officers had admitted writing the remarks after an earlier short informal inquiry. But Mr Narey had decided the incident was not serious enough to warrant suspension.

John McDonnell, the Labour MP, who showed Mr Boateng the dossier, said: "It's unbelievable. If the use of racist language is not sufficiently serious for Mr Narey to determine that these staff should be suspended, I shall be calling on the home secretary to suspend him."

Full Sutton is the jail where Satpal Ram is being held. He claims to have suffered racism from officers during his 13-year imprisonment for murder.

He claims he was defending himself against a racist attack, and Ram's supporters last night said the dossier supported his claims of prison racism.

The officers are identifiable because their signatures are by their comments.

They also wrote "foreign crap, well dodgy", "foreign lingo, can't comprehend" and "talking in foreign lingo".

The prison service said that Mr Boateng had asked Mr Narey for the "immediate" inquiry, which would be carried out by a governor from another prison.

"The prison officers involved fully accept that the language they used was unacceptable and unprofessional. Since these comments were written the officers have attended race relations training.

"The director general has personally reviewed the case and does not consider suspensions are necessary.

"Sending them on compulsory race awareness training was sufficient, he felt."

Mr Boateng yesterday met supporters of Satpal Ram. When shown the dossier Mr Boateng stopped the meeting and left the room for five minutes, and announced the investigation on his return.

Mr McDonnell, also present at the meeting, demanded that the two officers be suspended pending the fresh inquiry. "This is evidence of racist attitudes if not racist behaviour, among people supposed to be trained not to be racist in their treatment of prisoners."

The prison service said that all its officers attended half a day's race training on joining, with another refresher course after three years.

Extra training was given to specialist teams.

Mr McDonnell said the dossier showed that the training was not enough.

"The training system needs reviewing as does the assessment of officers after they finish training."

webTitle: Sex and race bias claim a non starter

fields.headline: Sex and race bias claim a non starter
fields.standfirst:
'Technicality' bars action by British athletics team manager

Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: Britain's athletics team manager for the Sydney Olympics, former hurdling gold medallist Lorna Boothe, has been barred from pursuing a wide-ranging sex and race discrimination claim by a legal clause which disqualifies people working regularly overseas.
fields.body:
Britain's athletics team manager for the Sydney Olympics, former hurdling gold medallist Lorna Boothe, has been barred from pursuing a wide-ranging sex and race discrimination claim by a legal clause which disqualifies people working regularly overseas.

The judgment has far-reaching implications for a huge range of professions, where people face losing the protection of equality laws if job opportunities take them out of the country for more than half their working time.

Five stints with the country's top athletes at international tournaments put Ms Boothe, the most senior black woman in the sport's management, beyond the scope of an industrial tribunal in Birmingham where she was due to make a series of allegations about the "white male world of British athletics."

Tournaments in Australia, the far east, South Africa and eastern Europe took up 56% of Ms Boothe's time, against 44% spent on preparation in Britain. The collapse of the case was described by equality campaigners as a disastrous setback for attempts to encourage role models for women or black and ethnic Britons representing the country overseas.

Athletics' governing body UK Athletics, which denied both racial and sexual discrimination against Ms Boothe, was also accused of "wriggling out of a proper hearing on a technicality." The former British athletics coach Frank Dick, who is now chairman of the European Coaches' Association, said yesterday: "Think what we're losing when we're prepared to hide behind legal technicalities to duck responsibility for actions and beliefs which violate the very values the sport pretends to champion."

Ms Boothe, who won a raft of international medals as a British athlete between 1975 and 1984, went to the tribunal after the failure of internal procedures at UK Athletics to resolve the dispute, including an attempt to persuade the president David Hemery to set up an inquiry.

She was ready to portray a world where panels made up exclusively of white men select women's teams and where a senior official allegedly asked the British team captain if Ms Boothe "only looked after the black players." The claims were denied by UK Athletics in its pre-hearing submission, but the agency's lawyers were instructed to argue that the case was inadmissible because of Ms Boothe's time spent outside the jurisdiction of the race relations and equal opportunities acts.

Ms Boothe, who is still senior team manager for British athletics, said yesterday: "We are being asked to represent our country and encouraged to do the best job we can, and then we find that our legal protection disappears. This isn't just a matter of my situation or even my world of sport. It is going to make potential role models for women and black and ethnic people in so many fields think twice about aiming for the top."

Sir Herman Ouseley, former chairman of the commission for racial equality, said that the clause was a weakness in the law which called for reform.

webTitle: 1,000 BBC jobs to go in Dyke's revolution

fields.headline: 1,000 BBC jobs to go in Dyke's revolution
fields.standfirst: The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: Greg Dyke, the director general of the BBC, is to scrap up to 1,000 jobs and remake the corporation as a flatter, leaner organisation under a secret plan to be approved by the BBC's governors next week.
fields.body:
Greg Dyke, the director general of the BBC, is to scrap up to 1,000 jobs and remake the corporation as a flatter, leaner organisation under a secret plan to be approved by the BBC's governors next week.

In response to a call by Chris Smith, the culture secretary, for the BBC to practice self-help and find £1.1bn in savings, Mr Dyke will banish the BBC's bureaucracy to put money back into programmes.

The corporation's legendary reliance on consultants and its convoluted pyramid management structure will be undone in a fundamental makeover. Mr Dyke's restructuring process will result in the loss of up to 1,000 jobs as its effects are felt throughout the BBC, according to a report in a trade newspaper yesterday.

Initially, it is thought, there will be several hundred redundancies, with the focus on senior management. One insider yesterday described that as a "bloodbath at the top". Mr Dyke is understood to be keen to lead from the top and to set an example by putting staff directly under his control.

Instead of having six directorates, each with its own chief executive, layers of management, administrative staff and auxiliary functions, Mr Dyke is expected to create up to 16 new departments, all answerable directly to him.

In Mr Dyke's BBC, programme-makers will, for the first time since his predecessor Lord Birt took over the corporation, answer directly to the director general.

As the news leaked out, Mr Dyke moved to reassure BBC staff, issuing a note explaining that he would make a full announcement in a couple of weeks. He described the reports as "speculation".

Signing the note, "yours, Greg", he confirmed that he had told MPs last week that he intended to cut the corporation's overheads to 15% of its budget, from the present 26%. He added that he would substantially improve the amount spent on programmes.

Sources said Mr Dyke intended to create a handful of "super departments" to control programme making, with each genre having its own programme development budget.

The sources added that he hoped this would ease pressure on the heads of BBC1 and BBC2, enabling them to take more strategic decisions and develop programmes in other media, such as the internet.

Non programme-making departments will be cut. The policy and planning and corporate affairs units are expected to be merged, as are finance and IT, with a large part of the savings expected to be made from cutting overlapping jobs.

Mr Dyke's plans have been constructed in strict secrecy, with only a handful of trusted aides, including the director of personnel, Gareth Jones, aware of his plans. Even press officers have not been briefed on the future structure, with that department said to be facing substantial rationalisation.

The news emerged yesterday as the committee charged with implementing the proposals moved into action.

A source close to Mr Dyke said: "It's about self-help and tough love - all the tough decisions that the government told us to take when they agreed the new funding. Greg has kept the details very close to himself."

Some of the BBC's longest-serving top executives face an uncertain future. While the director of radio, Jenny Abramsky is said to be highly thought of by Mr Dyke, other department heads face shunting sideways or a swift departure, including the chief executive of production, Matthew Bannister, whose job seems unlikely to survive in its current form.

The director of television, Alan Yentob, is also unlikely to stay in his job, insiders said, though they speculated he might be offered a role supervising the BBC's talent and there might yet be a deputy director general role.

In response to a call by Chris Smith, the culture secretary, for the BBC to practice self-help and find £1.1bn in savings, Mr Dyke will banish the BBC's bureaucracy to put money back into programmes. The corporation's legendary reliance on consultants and its convoluted pyramid management structure will be undone in a fundamental makeover. Mr Dyke's restructuring process will result in the loss of up to 1,000 jobs as its effects are felt throughout the BBC, according to a report in a trade newspaper yesterday. Initially, it is thought, there will be several hundred redundancies, with the focus on senior management. One insider yesterday described that as a "bloodbath at the top". Mr Dyke is understood to be keen to lead from the top and to set an example by putting staff directly under his control. Instead of having six directorates, each with its own chief executive, layers of management, administrative staff and auxiliary functions, Mr Dyke is expected to create up to 16 new departments, all answerable directly to him. In Mr Dyke's BBC, programme-makers will, for the first time since his predecessor Lord Birt took over the corporation, answer directly to the director general. He added that he would substantially improve the amount spent on programmes. fields.headline: Most...
fields.trailText: ...everywhere | ...popular | ...wanted
fields.body:
...everywhere: fat mags

Stuck for something to read on a long and tedious train journey? Never mind the blockbusters: a fashion mag will last you just as well. This month, your average glossy tome is thicker than a Jackie Collins novel: April's Marie Claire is 336 pages long, Elle is 386 and formerly svelte style mag i:D is a super-wide 338 (thick paper, see). These are sylph-like, though, compared with their US counterparts: the celebrity-obsessed In-Style weighs in at 514 pages, while March's American Vogue ("Biggest Spring Issue Ever!") notches up a hefty 566 pages. A long and satisfying read, then? Well, no. It takes a heinously long time to reach the first feature (page 104) because there are reams and reams of ads to flick through first. After that, editorial content is as scant as a Versace Oscar dress.

Fat mag of the month award must surely go to Italian Vogue: 664 pages plus a 200-page supplement. Spring issues are traditionally fat, as advertisers try to lure us into buying "The New Season" with long, lavish campaigns featuring moody models in the latest garb. But unless you enjoy studying six-page ads for Prada, Gucci, Versace and Armani (and some people do: me, for one), you'll find you have reached the back page fairly quickly. Was it really worth carrying all that weight around? Another argument for developing that website quick-sharp, everyone.

...popular: chocolates

The week's bestselling confectionery at Godiva chocolatier in Regent Street, London W1 (£9.50 for a 220g box containing 16 chocolates) 1 Chantilly (white chocolate, whipped vanilla cream) 2 Amandine Fondant (dark chocolate, roasted almond praline) 3 Autant Blanc (white chocolate, coffee cognac)

...wanted: George at Asda

Now that Top Shop is practically a designer label, the fashion flock have had to search elsewhere for cheapo-cheapo kudos. And what could be more fashionably cheapskate than buying your clothes in a supermarket? The newly crowned factory of chic is none other than George at Asda. Although the line is in its 10th year, this is the first season it has really scored. Don't be put off by society girl-about-town Shebah Ronay's cheesy pose: choose from such spring essentials as paisley frilled skirts (£12.99) and pale-wash denim jackets (£24.99). So cheap you'll still have change to buy your dinner on the way out.

fields.headline: Shih-tzus
fields.trailText: Backstage at last month's John Galliano show, the models, stylists and make-up artists had to contend with what seemed like a small pack of toy dogs. It was a clear illustration of the natural sympathy between small dog and model that is making the former such a fashionable, four-legged accessory.
fields.body:
Backstage at last month's John Galliano show, the models, stylists and make-up artists had to contend with what seemed like a small pack of toy dogs. There was yapping and snarling and demands for more attention - all of which meant (drum roll and cymbal, please) that the canines fitted right in: it was a clear illustration of the natural sympathy between small dog and model that is making the former such a fashionable, four-legged accessory. Minimutt-ism, we like to call it; it takes in all-comers from Japanese Chin to (Gisele's choice) Yorkshire terrier, but its star is the shih-tzu.

It was a shih-tzu, you will recall, that Geri Halliwell had under her arm while declaring her "love" for that other cur, Chris Evans, last autumn. The flouncy little fellas have been conspicuous in fashionista circles, too, because, "for the fashion-forward", as the gossip columnist of New York style magazine Paper recently wrote, "accessories like tiny teacup shih-tzus are on a par with shatooshes and inspiration bracelets".

Why should the shih-tzu be so favoured? Probably because of its heritage. Most toy dogs have been developed by the miniaturisation of full-size breeds, in most cases being bred as companions for wealthy women. However, the shih-tzu has a more mystical past; Tibetan Buddhism tells of a mythical small dog that could turn itself into a lion and Tibetans used to associate their Lhasa Apso breed with it. Centuries ago, a Dalai Lama presented a Lhasa Apso to a Chinese emperor, who crossed it with a Pekingese, called it shih-tzu or "lion-dog" and began a tradition of using them as guard dogs in the palaces of Imperial China. The Chinese still regard the dogs with reverence and are wary of exporting them; they have been available in the west only since the 30s, which explains their air of exclusivity.

We can't condone the use of dog as fashion accessory, of course, but will rest easier for knowing the wee hounds do comfort their put-upon mistresses. Psychologists have shown the presence of small companion dogs can counter depression and dispel loneliness. Which is more than you can say for, er, anything, really.

fields.headline: T time
fields.standfirst:
They're the ultimate no-fuss uniform: fashion editor Laura Craik gets in a sweat
The Shopping Unlimited clothes shop directory
fields.trailText: T-shirts are always big news for the simple reason that they're easy: they don't need dry cleaning, they don't need ironing, they won't make you look a chump.
fields.body:
I suppose I ought to write about pussycat bows, since everyone else is. But will you really wear one, whatever I say? Pussycat bows are one of fashion's "in" jokes: they only look good on Gisele. "Sincere chic" might be the buzzphrase of the season, but I wouldn't feel very sincere persuading you to wear one.

So here are some T-shirts instead. T-shirts are big news, too. T-shirts are always big news for the simple reason that they're easy: they don't need dry cleaning, they don't need ironing, they won't make you look a chump. There's something of the 70s American high school student about this season's most stylish sweats and Ts; washed-out, loose and comfy, they're best accessorised with a lazy smile. Logos are mandatory, only Lakers is better than Louis Vuitton: obscure baseball teams score higher than big designer names. Oddball logos like Reece's Peanut Cups, corporate brands like Ikea and old-skool sports labels like Gola are best, but you can be as daft as you fancy. One friend inexplicably cherishes his Guide Dogs for the Blind T: £2 from a charity shop.

Numbers are popular, too: Dolce & Gabbana, Iceberg, Givenchy and Sportmax have all done designer sports shirts for spring. For fabric, choose that sweatshirt classic, grey marl, and if it's too washed-out for you, then only a garish 70s colour will do. Purple, yellow and brown are fine; pastels look too twee and pretty.

And if any of you have tried pussycat bows and found you do look good in them, send us a photo and we'll print it. Your bravery might inspire others.

fields.headline: Comme again
fields.standfirst: A designer emporium that sells nothing but perfume? Mais oui: behind a plain-looking Paris shopfront lies heaven for scentophiles.  Molly Gunn follows her nose to find out more
fields.trailText: A designer emporium that sells nothing but perfume? Mais oui: behind a plain-looking Paris shopfront lies heaven for scentophiles. Molly Gunn follows her nose to find out more.
fields.body:
After 27 years as the driving force behind Parisian label Comme des Garçons, Japanese designer Rei Kawakubo is in a league of her own. She is the ultimate experimentalist, rejecting traditional notions of sexiness and femininity in favour of deconstructed, edgy clothes which are as difficult to wear as they are beautiful. In May, she is to be presented with a prestigious Excellence in Design Award from the Harvard Design School.

Kawakubo's perfumes are as original as her clothes: heady and highly unusual, in a market saturated with florals and musks, they stand out for their curious topnotes. So perhaps it is only natural that Kawakubo has taken the unprecedented step of opening a shop devoted entirely to them. For what better way to offer the customer pure, undiluted essence of Comme?

Up until now, the only places you could lay your hands on designer toiletries were hectic department stores, where your nose soon gets confused by the myriad scents on offer. "It is much easier to say what we want about perfume if we have our own space totally dedicated to that purpose. As with our clothes, the total environment is important," Kawakubo explains. "Perfume is more than just fragrance in a bottle."

The pink glass-fronted shop is a quiet haven away from the hustle and bustle of Parisian streets. Kawakubo may be referred to as the designer who "invented" black, but the shop she has designed is small, airy, minimalist and completely white.

"It was created to explore the seven sensations," says Aurore Besson, PR manager for Comme fragrances. "Light, sight, touch, air, smell, sensibility and memory." The white walls and concrete floor are bare, with two moulded shelves on one side, upon which are carefully positioned one bottle of each size of perfume: "So they have their own identity," Besson explains. There's no clutter and no fuss, just a reverential kind of spareness.

It was Coco Chanel who, in 1921, first saw the potential of creating a fragrance that would appeal to the masses and be affordable to more people than the elite who bought her clothes. Chanel No 5 was the first perfume ever to bear the name of a fashion label: before this, they were two separate industries. These days, any designer with an ounce of business sense has launched a fragrance or few. It's big business: the UK market alone was worth £688m in 1999.

Kawakubo's shop isn't a money-making venture, though: she is doing it for love. Those of you unfamiliar with Comme des Garçons perfumes may be interested to know that, Christmas limited editions aside, they have only four fragrances to their name: Odeur 53, Eau de Parfum, Eau de Cologne and last year's Comme 2. Even with Kawakubo's penchant for minimalism, this makes for a pretty sparse range of products. Which is why she has created a new range of distinctive fragrances to be sold in the shop and in only eight other key places in the world, including Liberty in London.

Series 1, which is in-store now, comprises five new scents under the collective title of Leaves: Tea, Lily, Mint, Shiso and Calamus, priced from £17.50 to £30 and in bottles of plain plastic. "We wanted there to be a clear distinction between Series 1 and our previous fragrances," Besson says. Series 2 is being worked on at the moment; new series will simply be added to previous ones, thus building up the shop's stock until, presumably, it resembles something like a regular store.

To avoid the multiple-smells-on-wrist problem, Kawakubo provides individual white paper cones to spray each fragrance on. Small bean-filled dolls are also on offer for a more tactile experience. "We tried to achieve a space where all kinds of sensorial experimentation is possible, where research, technology, discovery and creation are at the forefront," Kawakubo says.

It is the unpromisingly-named Odeur 71 which she is really excited about, though. To be introduced in May, the fragrance will be an extension of Odeur 53, with the added ingredients of wood-shavings, pepper, ginger and Chinese ink. These are extracted through a new method called Solid Phase Micro Extraction, with which a fibre needle is placed near an object to extract its smell. "Through this method, the world becomes full of smells to analyse and recreate. You could even extract the smell of a hot rubber tyre from a car," Besson explains excitedly. Odeur 71, she says, will evoke a feeling of hot and cold, as if you were smelling the ingredients individually.

Odeur 53 has 53 ingredients - but there are apparently more than 71 in the new fragrance. So why the name? "Well, eight is a good number. Five plus three equals eight, and seven plus one equals eight, so that is the reason." Which best sums up why Rei Kawakubo's perfume shop will undoubtedly be a success: quirky it may be, but there is method in its madness.

webTitle: Democrat victory in Taiwan could force Beijing's hand

fields.headline: Democrat victory in Taiwan could force Beijing's hand
fields.standfirst: As presidential election day looms in Taiwan, John Gittings examines the political ramifications of a win for a candidate sympathetic to independence from China
fields.trailText: Taiwan's politics could take a dramatic turn tomorrow - if the voters have not been frightened off by Beijing.
fields.body:
Taiwan's politics could take a dramatic turn tomorrow - if the voters have not been frightened off by Beijing.

The favourite to win the presidency by a narrow margin is Chen Shui-bian, backed by the opposition Democratic Progressive party (DPP). Victory for him would end the domination of the Chinese Kuomintang (Nationalists) who fled to Taiwan in 1949 and have ruled there - as dictators for most of the time - ever since.

Chen has tried to appease Beijing by saying that he would not actually declare independence, but the election comes at a sensitive time. The Chinese were enraged last year when the current Nationalist president, Lee Teng-hui, said that the mainland and Taiwan are two separate states. China fears that Taiwan is slipping away for ever, although with Hong Kong and Macau returned to China, "the time is ripe" for reunification.

Taiwan is also a sore issue between China and the US because Washington still supplies it with weapons. It would have been taken back by Beijing in the early 1950s if the US had not protected it.

Last month China said for the first time that it will take military action if Taiwan delays reunification forever. The Chinese armed forces are pressing hard and President Jiang Zemin wants to get results.

Most experts think China realises that Taiwan cannot be won by a conflict that would create the biggest crisis in Asia since the Vietnam war. But China's premier, Zhu Rongji, insists that China "will not stand idly by."

Beijing hopes that Taiwanese voters will back off support for the DPP. But the Nationalists are split between the official candidate, the current vice-president Lien Chan, and the former leader, James Soong. If Chen wins, will Beijing feel obliged to follow up its words with at least a token hostile move? As the votes are counted tomorrow, everyone will wait anxiously to see.

webTitle: New organ scandal forces hospital chief to quit

fields.headline: New organ scandal forces hospital chief to quit
fields.standfirst: Parents unable to hold funeral after son's body parts removed and lost
fields.trailText: The chairman of the trust running Liverpool's Alder Hey hospital, where the organs of 893 dead children were removed without their parents' consent, was sacked yesterday after staff admitted they had lost the organs of a baby boy after his death eight years ago.
fields.body:
The chairman of the trust running Liverpool's Alder Hey hospital, where the organs of 893 dead children were removed without their parents' consent, was sacked yesterday after staff admitted they had lost the organs of a baby boy after his death eight years ago.

Stephen White died aged 10 days in 1992. His heart, brain and lungs were to have been buried today. But on Wednesday night hospital officials told his family that the funeral could not go ahead because the organs were missing.

Hospital officials last night described the loss as "a terrible mistake". They apologised and explained that the organs were very small and had been "mistakenly disposed of".

The admission outraged the health minister, Lord Hunt, who demanded an instant report and the resignation of Frank Taylor, chairman of the hospital trust.

Lord Hunt said: "I was shocked and angered when I was told about how Alder Hey hospital had dealt with Stephen White's family. They have my deepest sympathy. The way they have been treated has been totally unacceptable.

"I will not tolerate this kind of poor management in any NHS hospital. I have asked the trust chairman, Frank Taylor, to tender his resignation immediately. I have also asked for a report into this specific issue to be on my desk within 24 hours."

Mr Taylor said he had not hesitated before resigning. "What happened to Stephen White's family was tragic and unacceptable," he said. "I feel deeply sorry for what they have had to go through."

The boy's family discovered only last year that the organs had been removed after his death. Details came to light during a public inquiry into baby deaths at Bristol Royal Infirmary.

The inquiry was launched by the health secretary, Alan Milburn. The chief medical officer, Professor Liam Donaldson, is investigating the whole issue of organ retention.

Theresa White, the boy's grandmother, said yesterday: "My son phoned Alder Hey to see if they could have the organs released so that we could bury them. They said the organs had been disposed of."

In a statement, the hospital confirmed "with great regret" that it had not been able to find the organs. Hilary Rowland, the hospital's chief executive, and a chaplain had broken the news and apologised.

"We deeply regret the distress that this has caused the family and we sympathise with them in their grief," said Ms Rowland last night. Louise Ellman, MP for Liverpool Riverside, said the case of Stephen White was "incompetence piled on tragedy".

She said: "It is absolutely unacceptable and it is disgraceful. I am horrified by what has happened."

Rex Makin, solicitor for many of the families, said Mr Taylor's resignation was long overdue. "The whole board should resign - let the others follow his example," he said.

His son Robin, who represents the White family, said: "This illustrates that even after this whole scandal has blown up, they are still not dealing with it in a satisfactory manner.

"We are extremely concerned about the way Alder Hey is dealing with the matter, about the way the NHS executive is dealing with the matter and we are extremely concerned with the way the inquiry is dealing with the matter."

He said he would write to the department of health on behalf of the families to express his concerns.

Solicitor Ian Cohen, who represents support group Pity II and more than 200 families, spoke of his "grave concerns" about Alder Hey. "I am concerned that it takes the involvement of the health minister before Alder Hey recognises and accepts the errors that they have been guilty of," he said.

"What has happened to Stephen White is probably the worst case. I'm not aware of other cases where organs have been lost - but I am aware of other serious errors."

Joan Wheeler, chairman of Pity II, said: "Alder Hey has made blunder upon blunder throughout the whole case and although I am saddened that this child's family have been put through yet another trauma, it does not surprise me that the organs have been lost. fields.headline: George to force the draw
fields.standfirst: Mike Hodgkinson, our man with the subscription to Racing and Football Outlook (honestly), casts an eye over the weekend's activities
fields.trailText: Arsenal will struggle to beat Spurs on Sunday. The visitors have only lost one of their last seven matches at Highbury and this fixture throws up a goalless stalemate more often than not (three 0-0s over the last four seasons). Arsene Wenger's defence - at least the one forged during the George Graham years - is all over the shop at the moment. Martin Keown has just had a pin inserted into his broken hand and Tony Adams is having bother with a hernia and his right foot. So it looks like another makeshift number involving the likes of Oleg Luzhny and Gilles Grimandi.
fields.body:
Arsenal will struggle to beat Spurs on Sunday. The visitors have only lost one of their last seven matches at Highbury and this fixture throws up a goalless stalemate more often than not (three 0-0s over the last four seasons). Arsene Wenger's defence - at least the one forged during the George Graham years - is all over the shop at the moment. Martin Keown has just had a pin inserted into his broken hand and Tony Adams is having bother with a hernia and his right foot. So it looks like another makeshift number involving the likes of Oleg Luzhny and Gilles Grimandi.

As far as George Graham's current charges are concerned, Steffen Iversen should be flying after last week's hat-trick, and there's absolutely no way the Spurs XI will want to let their gaffer down at Highbury. It's practically the match of the season for Graham, so expect his men to raise their game to an unprecedented level. They have already proven they can beat the elite, with victories over Manchester United, Liverpool and Arsenal this season. Those were all on home soil but they should show enough to force the draw at Highbury. One goal apiece sounds right if you fancy a correct score prediction.

Wimbledon have held Leeds to a draw at Elland Road three times over the last four seasons in the Premiership. Not at all bad, but Leeds 2000 will give them plenty more to think about, provided that the Slavia Prague match leaves them in a reasonably fit condition. Harry Kewell returns from suspension, and makes a good case for taking first scorer honours. Despite the slim odds, the Yorkshire side should feature in your weekend accumulator as banker material.

Duncan Ferguson is Newcastle's best weapon at Goodison on Sunday, and stands a good chance of doing a number on his former team mates. Both sides have improved considerably this season, with Everton's transformation marginally more impressive. Old man Mark Hughes made a pleasing midweek debut for the Toffees against Coventry and despite the narrow defeat appears to have a fair bit of life in his old legs. His presence could compensate for the loss of Francis Jeffers (injury) and Don Hutchison (money wrangles).

A quick scan of the gambling press reveals that pundits' opinions oscillate wildly from home banker to away certainty on this one. What's beyond doubt is that both sides have got plenty going for them. There will be blood and thunder on a Biblical scale and it'll be tight - so stick with the draw.

Over the rest of the card, you might like to consider the following. Aston Villa have won their last four at the Dell, where Southampton made a habit of derailing bigger names in recent years. Current form makes the away win look likely. Boro tend to play well at Sunderland, having peeled of a hat-trick of wins there, and West Ham have enjoyed entertaining Chelsea at Upton Park, notching up two wins and a draw in East London over the last three. Take the away win and home win respectively.

Finally, Portsmouth's loose cannon Steve Claridge, who writes an eye-opening gambling column for the Racing and Football Outlook, kindly revealed that he would be spending part of this week at the Cheltenham festival. A big midweek day at the races with the lads was scheduled to finish up in a karaoke club, so it may be worth chancing Crewe to do a number on Pompey on Saturday - on the grounds that the south-coast side will venture north feeling a little jaded.

Leeds v Wimbledon - home win
Everton v Newcastle - draw
Southampton v Aston Villa - away win
Sunderland v Middlesbrough - away win
West Ham v Chelsea - home win
Crewe v Portsmouth - home win

webTitle: A result Labour will find hard to spin

fields.headline: A result Labour will find hard to spin
fields.standfirst: Guardian columnist Kirsty Scott examines the fall-out for Labour following their third-place humiliation in the Scottish parliament's historic first byelection
fields.trailText: Coming second could have been spun. Coming third is harder to explain.
fields.body:
Coming second could have been spun. Coming third is harder to explain.

As the Conservative Party celebrate their first directly elected seat in the Scottish parliament today, the postmortem for Labour begins in earnest.

A disillusioned Ayr electorate voted them into a humiliating third place in the parliament's historic first byelection yesterday, behind the victorious Tories and a resurgent Scottish National Party. And although the constituency is small, the results are making waves beyond the boundaries of this small market town, some 30 miles south of Glasgow.

Fresh questions are being raised about the first minister, Donald Dewar's, leadership; the performance of the ruling Labour-Liberal Democrat administration at Holyrood; and the general direction of Tony Blair's New Labour.

Mr Dewar has been quick to blame "distractions" - such as the high profile advertising campaign against the repeal of section 28 - for the failure of their candidate, Rita Miller.

Opposition parties say the message sent by voters is unequivocal. Labour is not delivering; for Ayr, for Scotland, for the UK.

The Conservatives, meanwhile, have found it difficult to contain their delight. "It's a bloody good result for us," said the party's Scottish chairman Raymond Robertson this morning.

The Tory candidate, John Scott, a well-known local farmer, has impressed voters with his emphasis on local concerns and his unwillingness to use Ayr as a proving ground for broader national issues such as section 28 or the state of the Scottish parliament building.

The Scottish National Party, meanwhile, say their second place finish, after a strong, slick campaign, is a building block for the push towards independence.

The Liberal Democrats, Labour's coalition partners in the Holyrood administration, are not saying much at all, having been pushed into fifth place by the Scottish Socialist Party.

But all eyes are now on Labour to see how they handle the message from Ayr. However they play it, it will be almost impossible to spin their way out of this one.

fields.headline: The round-trip refugees
fields.trailText: Friday, 5.30pm: Derek Brown on the scandal of the Romanian asylum seekers sent on an 800-mile trip because of a bureaucratic blunder.
fields.body:
Home Office minister Barbara Roche has demanded an urgent report from officials, after more than 60 Romanian asylum seekers were subjected to an 800-mile round-trip ordeal.

First, they were resettled from London to Glasgow as part of the government's pet project for dispersing would-be refugees around the country. Then they were bussed back to the capital when it was found that they were legally obliged to report to the police in London every week.

While local government officials in Glasgow and the London borough of Wandsworth are busily blaming each other for the bureaucratic blunder, the Home Office has unveiled the latest weapon in its campaign to prove that Britain is not a "soft touch" for asylum seekers.

A detention centre is about to open at Oakington in Cambridgeshire. It will accommodate up to 13,000 refugees a year while they are investigated. The Home Office claims that bogus cases will be weeded out in a matter of days, though Ms Roche insists that all those detained will be thoroughly investigated and will be given legal advice.

Up to 400 people at a time, families as well as individuals, will be detained in Spartan conditions on the former RAF base. They will not be locked up, though they will not be allowed to leave the site.

The government is anxious to be seen to act after a spate of press and opposition criticism. Anne Widdecombe, the Conservative home affairs shadow minister, typically seized on the Glasgow fiasco to launch a sharp attack on the Home Office.

Instead of finding out what went wrong, she suggested, Ms Roche should ask why 70,000 refugees were arriving in Britain every year, and why there was a backlog of 105,000 asylum applications waiting to be processed.

Refugees and asylum seekers are high on the news agenda, following a collection of tabloid campaigns focussing on the allegedly aggressive behaviour of some east European beggars.

The case of the Romanian refugees who were unceremoniously turfed out of Glasgow came to light after local residents complained that some of the women were begging door to door. Police picked them up, and immigration officials discovered from their papers that some of them were obliged to stay in London and report regularly.

The entire group was then rounded up and put on a bus back to London. Officials in Wandsworth said they were warned about it only after the bus set off. They had less than eight hours to arrange emergency bed and breakfast accommodation.

fields.headline: Return of the Idiot
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: An intriguing serio-comic film with some very nice performances
fields.body:
Sasa Gedeon's Return of the Idiot is an elegant, pleasingly realised movie which takes as its springboard the novel by Dostoevsky. Frantisek (Pavel Liska) returns to a small Czech town in which he has family connections, having undergone hospitalisation and electro-convulsive therapy, which leaves him with bad dreams and a tendency to nosebleeds at moments of emotional crisis.

By chance, he stumbles into a fraught complex of hidden love affairs; he stays the night with Anna (Anna Geislerova), a young woman whose beauty has transfixed him on the train. She is having a relationship with Emil (Jiri Langmeyer), whose mother is Frantisek's only friend in the world, having once known his mother. In all this, Frantisek finds himself gawping and blinking and unsure how to process the information he has accidentally gleaned, or indeed how to gauge the sexual influence he is beginning to exert.

It is an intriguing serio-comic film with some very nice performances - and there is also a brilliant sight-gag about an ice-cream yoghurt being accidentally dropped out of a train window. I won't give it away here, but I think Hollywood directors might well feel the need to steal it in the future.

fields.headline: Women in lav
fields.trailText:
Sitting down with Lawrence
Anyone who has read one of his novels will be aware how much effort it takes to get to grips with DH Lawrence. Now it appears that his books aren't the only thing about the writer that require hard work: his lavatory too is causing more than its fair share of headaches.
fields.body:
Sitting down with Lawrence
Anyone who has read one of his novels will be aware how much effort it takes to get to grips with DH Lawrence. Now it appears that his books aren't the only thing about the writer that require hard work: his lavatory too is causing more than its fair share of headaches.

The lavatory in question is an outdoor one, in the back yard of the house in which Lawrence was born in Eastwood, Nottinghamshire. Tourists visiting the house have been popping into the lavatory to take photos and experience the great man's aura. Unfortunately, once in, many are unable to get out again.

"It's the latch that's the problem," explained Mary Robertson of English Heritage. "It's perfectly simple: you just put your thumb on the lever and press. A lot of people can't work it out, however, and end up getting trapped."

The latch has, apparently, proved particularly baffling to Japanese tourists, including one poor woman who, unable to speak a word of English, was reduced to hammering on the door and shouting "Women in Love!" until she was rescued. A permanent guard has now been positioned outside the troublesome toilet to assist those trapped within.

"It's not just the loo that's causing confusion," admitted one insider. "We had a bloke who came all the way from America because he was a Wild West fan and thought Eastwood was where Clint was born."
Kimberley and Eastwood Advertiser

From bad to verse
Wife of 49 years dies, distraught husband pens book of romantic poems, local church agrees to sell book to raise money for charity. A typically heartwarming tale of enduring love and community support for a bereaved pensioner. Or so it seemed, until parishioners in Quedgeley, Gloucestershire, took a closer look at widower Ray Holmes's 65-page anthology. It emerged that of the 300 poems only one related to his recently deceased wife. The other 299 were dedicated to the wife of Mr Holmes's best friend, with whom he had become infatuated following his bereavement.

"It seemed like a good cause and I was only too happy to buy a copy," said a member of St Barnabas's church. "But then I started to read through it and realised it was basically a series of poems about this other woman, some of them really quite steamy. It's particularly outrageous because her husband's ill and has only got a few months left to live."

The one poem in the collection that actually refers to the author's deceased wife concludes with the none-too-flattering couplet: "It happened so quietly this stamp of approval/Perhaps in time we can call in the removal."

The anthology has now been withdrawn from sale, with one wag suggesting they erect a sign in the church bookshop explaining: "This book has no place in a house of God/Because it was written by a dirty old sod."
Gloucestershire Echo

Essex virgins?
We've had Essex girl, Essex man, Essex boy racer. Now the county has spawned yet another human sub-species : Essex pagan. Pagans from Colchester, Braintree and Clacton have recently come together to form the Colchester pagan council, a steering committee for the county's apparently burgeoning pagan population.

"We are trying to revive and discover the ancient British religion that existed before Christianity came to convert people," explained a spokesperson. "A lot of people laugh at us, but we're getting a lot of support as well." More than 40 people attended an inaugural meeting, and the council is hoping to attract many other members with its message of religious toleration, respect for the environment and love of wildlife.

Not everyone, however, is comfortable with the idea of Essex paganism. "These people are an abomination," fumed one Home Counties vicar, who wished to remain nameless for fear of reprisals. "They sacrifice young girls and drink human blood." "A typical Saturday night out in Romford, then," quipped one local man.
Essex Online

Post traumatic
Postmen are attacked by dogs so frequently that it rarely makes the news. An exception to this rule, however, is Huddersfield postman Simon Healey, 35, the victim of perhaps the most distressing dog-on-postman assault of recent years.

Bachelor Mr Healey, a postman for 13 years, was delivering mail on his usual round in Cleckheaton, when he entered the garden of Ms Beverley Watkins. As he walked up the path towards her postbox, Ms Watkins's springer spaniel Toby sped from the front door, leapt up and sank his jaws into the mortified mailman's crotch.

"The dog just hung there like some enormous sporran shaking its head from side to side ," said one appalled eyewitness. "It was agonising to watch, so God knows what it must have been like for him."

The dog's jaws were finally prised apart and Mr Healey taken to hospital. He made a full recovery, although the psychological scars will no doubt take longer to heal. He subsequently won substantial damages from the dog's owner. "Stories like that really give you the willies," said one fellow postman.
Huddersfield Daily Examiner

Letter of the week
"I really feel I must apologise to our generous government! For months I have been complaining that my state pension increase was going to be only 75p. Then, however, on picking up my new pension book last Thursday, I was delighted to note that my increase was actually 80p - an extra £2.60p per year on top of the magnificent £38 I was expecting. How on earth will I manage to spend it all?

"It must be difficult for our poor MSPs. I hear they're only getting an extra £7,000 for their annual increase. I bet they envy us pensioners!"
Tom McCallum,
Dumfries
Aberdeen Press and Journal
