"But then I started to read through it and realised it was basically a series of poems about this other woman, some of them really quite steamy. It's particularly outrageous because her husband's ill and has only got a few months left to live." The one poem in the collection that actually refers to the author's deceased wife concludes with the none-too-flattering couplet: "It happened so quietly this stamp of approval/Perhaps in time we can call in the removal." The anthology has now been withdrawn from sale, with one wag suggesting they erect a sign in the church bookshop explaining: "This book has no place in a house of God/Because it was written by a dirty old sod." Gloucestershire Echo Essex virgins? We've had Essex girl, Essex man, Essex boy racer. Now the county has spawned yet another human sub-species : Essex pagan. Pagans from Colchester, Braintree and Clacton have recently come together to form the Colchester pagan council, a steering committee for the county's apparently burgeoning pagan population. "We are trying to revive and discover the ancient British religion that existed before Christianity came to convert people," explained a spokesperson. "A lot of people laugh at us, but we're getting a lot of support as well." More than 40 people attended an inaugural meeting, and the council is hoping to attract many other members with its message of religious toleration, respect for the environment and love of wildlife. Not everyone, however, is comfortable with the idea of Essex paganism. "These people are an abomination," fumed one Home Counties vicar, who wished to remain nameless for fear of reprisals. "They sacrifice young girls and drink human blood." "A typical Saturday night out in Romford, then," quipped one local man. Essex Online Post traumatic Postmen are attacked by dogs so frequently that it rarely makes the news. An exception to this rule, however, is Huddersfield postman Simon Healey, 35, the victim of perhaps the most distressing dog-on-postman assault of recent years. Bachelor Mr Healey, a postman for 13 years, was delivering mail on his usual round in Cleckheaton, when he entered the garden of Ms Beverley Watkins. As he walked up the path towards her postbox, Ms Watkins's springer spaniel Toby sped from the front door, leapt up and sank his jaws into the mortified mailman's crotch. "The dog just hung there like some enormous sporran shaking its head from side to side ," said one appalled eyewitness. "It was agonising to watch, so God knows what it must have been like for him." The dog's jaws were finally prised apart and Mr Healey taken to hospital. He made a full recovery, although the psychological scars will no doubt take longer to heal. He subsequently won substantial damages from the dog's owner. "Stories like that really give you the willies," said one fellow postman. Huddersfield Daily Examiner Letter of the week "I really feel I must apologise to our generous government! For months I have been complaining that my state pension increase was going to be only 75p. Then, however, on picking up my new pension book last Thursday, I was delighted to note that my increase was actually 80p - an extra £2.60p per year on top of the magnificent £38 I was expecting. How on earth will I manage to spend it all? "It must be difficult for our poor MSPs. I hear they're only getting an extra £7,000 for their annual increase. I bet they envy us pensioners!" Tom McCallum, Dumfries Aberdeen Press and Journal

fields.headline: Venture capital companies
fields.standfirst: Alchemy, a venture capital firm based in London, has bought parts of the Rover car company. It is expected to sell the unprofitable parts of Rover and keep the money-making MG brand. Mark Tran looks at venture capital companies.
fields.trailText: Alchemy, a venture capital firm based in London, has bought parts of the Rover car company. It is expected to sell the unprofitable parts of Rover and keep the money-making MG brand. Mark Tran looks at venture capital companies.
fields.body:
What is a venture capital firm?
An investment company that invests its shareholders' money in new companies and other risky but potentially very profitable ventures. Alchemy Partners, a private capital venture fund, uses money from private investors such as Chase Capital Partners and the British Aerospace pension fund. Set up just three years ago, Alchemy invests in most business sectors, but has specialised in brewing, pubs, restaurants and hotels.

Alchemy says it will not asset-strip Rover. What is asset stripping?
Analysts believe that Alchemy will keep the profitable MG sports car brand and eventually get rid of the loss-making Rover cars - the 25, 45 and 75 models. In the jargon of high finance, Alchemy is stripping Rover of its money-making parts and getting rid of the rest.

Isn't this similar to the activities of 'corporate raiders'?
Yes. In the 1980s, or the decade of greed, figures like Carl Icahn and Ivan Boesky achieved notoriety and wealth by buying up companies, getting rid of the loss-making parts and then selling what was left for a hefty profit. They were reviled as corporate raiders who were out to make a quick buck instead of staying with a company for the long haul. But they did serve a purpose. They put the fear of God into bloated and inefficient companies, forcing them to become more competitive.

Is Alchemy a typical capital venture firm?
What Alchemy is doing with Rover is quite unusual. According to the British Venture Capital Association, most - 50% - of venture capital finance projects are for expansion, specifically to help existing businesses grow and compete. A lot of US venture capital has arrived in the UK in the past two years, fuelling and taking advantage of the internet boom here and in Europe.

How big is the venture capital market in the UK?
The UK industry is the largest and most developed in Europe, accounting for nearly 50% of total annual European venture capital investment, and is second only to the US. The UK venture capital industry has invested over £28 billion (nearly £23bn in the UK) in up to 18,000 companies since 1983. A record £4.9bn was invested in 1998, in over 1,300 companies, 26 times the amount invested in 1984.

Are venture capital companies regulated?
Unlike banks, venture capital companies do not accept deposits from customers so their investment activities are not regulated. In the case of Alchemy, the company would only come under the purview of financial regulators in so far as it invests money from a pension fund. The regulators would intervene if they thought the pension fund was putting too much money in Alchemy. But as far as Alchemy is concerned it can invest in what it likes and the people investing in Alchemy cannot expect any help if they lose their shirts. Minimum investments are £3m.

Shouldn't venture capital companies be more closely scrutinised?
There were calls for tighter regulation when Long Term Capital, a US hedge fund (investment group), nearly collapsed in 1998, threatening to destabilise the financial system. It had borrowed huge amounts of money to invest, but was caught in a financial squeeze when its bets went awry. It if had gone bust, it could have dragged major financial institutions with it. It survived thanks to a rescue package orchestrated by the US federal reserve. The crisis came and went and hedge funds remain fairly unregulated. As capital venture funds deal in much smaller amounts of money, they will probably be left to their own devices.

British Venture Capital Association

webTitle: Livingstone probe triggered by former Phillips aid

fields.headline: Livingstone probe triggered by former Phillips aid
fields.trailText: The complaint which led to a Commons censure of Ken Livingstone for failing to declare his outside earnings was triggered by a Labour party activist, it emerged today.
fields.body:
The complaint which led to a Commons censure of Ken Livingstone for failing to declare his outside earnings was triggered by a Labour party activist, it emerged today.

Rob Smeath, a former aide to Trevor Phillips, Frank Dobson's running mate for London mayor, admitted to orchestrating the letter of complaint to the committee.

Mr Livingstone claimed he was the victim of a "dirty tricks" campaign after Loughborough university research student John Jones denied having anything to do with the complaint made to the Commons standards and privileges committee in his name.

Mr Smeath, a lawyer, said that he had asked his friend, Mr Jones - his friend - if the letter could be sent in his name as he was "absolutely disinterested" in politics and therefore seemed the perfect person to prevent any controversy.

He said that Mr Jones had agreed "albeit reluctantly". But when the student was approached by journalists earlier this week, he denied responsibility saying: "Why have I got caught up in this?"

Mr Smeath insisted that he was acting on his own, and not working on behalf of the official Labour Party candidate in the contest, Frank Dobson. He said he had not told Trevor Phillips what he was doing either.

"I wanted to get the issue of MPs not declaring earnings discussed. I was so incensed," the lawyer said. "I had been involved in the Trevor Phillips campaign and I wanted to be distanced from any idea that Trevor was making me do this."

Mr Smeath was Mr Phillips' campaign treasurer before the latter gave up his own campaign to become Labour's mayoral candidate and backed Mr Dobson instead.

The standards and privileges committee's report, which censured Mr Livingstone for failing to declare more than £150,000 in earnings from after-dinner speaking and writing newspaper articles, was widely viewed as a setback for his mayoral campaign, denting his "man of the people" image.

"We knew that it was organised from someone of the Millbank tendency," said Mr Livingstone, speaking at Kensington town hall in London this morning, where he was opening an Animal Aid campaign.

"We were just surprised that it was someone so close to Trevor and Frank. There will be lots more dirty tricks, but I don't think the public is drawn in."

Commenting on the standards committee report, Mr Livingstone continued: "In a year, the company [Localaction] may have an income of £98,000 through public appearances and talks.

"Fifty-three thousand [pounds] is invested in employing people, paying them and on items like computers. Then we are left with a company profit of just about £50,000 and a lot of tax before spending on any campaign."

fields.headline: Actor's mission on Mir cancelled
fields.trailText: Actor Vladimir Steklov was supposed to blast off to the Mir next month to play a renegade cosmonaut who won't leave the space station, but Russia won't let him leave Earth, a space official said Thursday.
fields.body:
Actor Vladimir Steklov was supposed to blast off to the Mir next month to play a renegade cosmonaut who won't leave the space station, but Russia won't let him leave Earth, a space official said Thursday.

The movie in which he was to star was one of a series of unorthodox proposals for resuscitating the dormant space station with private money. But Konstantin Kreidenko, a spokesman for the Russian Aerospace Agency, said that "actor Vladimir Steklov will not go to Mir as earlier planned because of the failure to meet the terms of the contract." He declined to give details.

Cosmonauts Sergei Zalyotin and Alexander Kaleri are tentatively set to blast off to Mir on 4 April, he said. The station has been unmanned since August. Zalyotin and Kaleri are expected to spend 45 days on board Mir. They will take a movie camera with them and possibly shoot some footage for the movie, Kreidenko said.

The movie, tentatively called The Last Journey, was to have told the story of a renegade cosmonaut who refuses to leave Mir, insisting he'll orbit the Earth for the rest of his days. Ground controllers decide to send up a woman to lure him back.

British producer John Daly and Russian director Yuri Kara said they hoped to involve big box-office names like Robert De Niro, Gary Oldman, Sean Penn and Catherine Zeta-Jones.

Although the film-makers claimed that they made an initial payment to get the project underway, Russian space officials complained they haven't even been paid for Steklov's training, let alone the multi-million dollar bill for the flight.

Steklov meanwhile complained that his investment of time for training came to nothing.

"Now I am a jobless actor, a hobo," he said, according to the Interfax news agency. "Deep disappointment and bitterness that I could not get what was within reach is too mild a description."

The state-controlled RKK Energia company that built and owns the 14-year Mir has made frantic efforts to keep it aloft by raising private funds.

The cash-strapped government had said it would abandon the station this month unless private investors came up with funds, but then changed its mind and kept Mir in orbit after the Amsterdam-based MirCorp agreed to pay $10-20 million to lease commercial rights on the station. Ownership of the station remains with the Russian government.

MirCorp hopes to make money by offering rides to space tourists, satellite repair and production of materials in weightlessness. Details of the deal are sketchy and Energia has refused to say precisely how much money they received.

webTitle: Row over car firm sale as Ford buys Land Rover

fields.headline: Row over car firm sale as Ford buys Land Rover
fields.trailText: The break-up of the Rover motor company was completed today with the sale of Land Rover to the US car giant Ford for £1.85bn. Ford promised to unleash "the full potential" of Land Rover as a row erupted between Rover's former owners BMW and the British government over the strong pound and uncertainty over whether the UK would join the euro.
fields.body:
The break-up of the Rover motor company was completed today with the sale of Land Rover to the US car giant Ford for £1.85bn. Ford promised to unleash "the full potential" of Land Rover as a row erupted between Rover's former owners BMW and the British government over the strong pound and uncertainty over whether the UK would join the euro.

Ford, which had tried to buy Rover once before to acquire the luxury four wheel-drive vehicles, said the Solihull-based Land Rover was "a terrific global brand with a wonderful heritage". Ford already owns a range of premium brands - Jaguar, Volvo and Aston Martin. Yesterday the London-based venture capitalist company Alchemy Partners took on most of the rest of the loss-making Rover business. BMW chairman Professor Joachim Milberg said that the decision to sell Land Rover was not easy but was necessary because of the strong pound, falling sales and the British government's uncertainties over the euro. "[It] made the situation at Rover even more of a problem," he said.

A Downing Street official telephoned BMW today to register the prime minister's anger at the break-up of Rover, a spokesman said.

He said that the government's policy on the single currency had been set out by chancellor Gordon Brown in October 1997 and should have been well known to the company.

Regarding the strength of the pound the spokesman said: "The government is not going to devalue artificially because that route has led in the past to economic failure and boom and bust."

Land Rover has a workforce of 9,500, who produce Land Rover, Discovery, Range Rover and Freelander off-road vehicles. Last year, the Solihull plant turned out 166,000 vehicles.

Union leader Bill Morris, general secretary of the Transport and General Workers Union, welcomed Ford's decision to buy Land Rover but said he would have preferred the entire Rover group to stay with one owner.

Alchemy Partners, the new Rover owners, today offered some consolation to the 9,000-strong workforce at Longbridge. Managing partner Jon Moulton said that there were two groups of workers at the Birmingham plant: those who would keep their jobs and those who would not. "Those that are left will have real, viable jobs and won't be spending their lives looking over their shoulders awaiting termination and redundancy," added.

The Rover marque, however, will be allowed to "wither on the vine". Alchemy will take over the MG brand as "medium volume business" and develop a range of sports cars and saloons for a premium "niche" market, the first of which could start production within 18 months. Mr Moulton said that fewer than 100,000 cars a year would be built by the new MG Car Company - a fraction of the previous output.

John Edmonds, general secretary of the GMB union, condemned the move. "Rover has become a corporate car boot sale," he said. "I will be asking for some straight answers from the Department of Trade and Industry. Surely during the negotiations with BMW last year, the DTI asked for guarantees that Rover would not be broken up? If guarantees were given by BMW, what is the DTI going to do to enforce them? "The strong pound has had a big part to play in this chaos. It is high time the government realised that this continuing overvaluation can and will lead to more job losses," he added.

Workers arriving this morning at Longbridge remained pessimistic about the future. The main BMW sign outside Gate Q of the Longbridge factory had been daubed in graffiti with the words "Stabbed in the back".

fields.headline: Mr Benn makes it big
fields.trailText: Seventies TV favourite Mr Benn is to become the star of a full-length feature film
fields.body:
Seventies children's TV favourite Mr Benn is poised to be turned into a romantic hero in a new £4 million live action big screen movie. Last April, we reported that the project, long under development, had collapsed due to insufficient funding, although John Hannah and Ben Kingsley remained attached. Production company Erinfilm have now taken it on, and are currently gathering finance.

John Hannah will play the bowler hat-wearing cartoon character who held youngsters spellbound when he stepped through the door of a fancy dress costume shop into a series of fantastic adventures.

Unlike his televisual forerunner, the cinematic Mr Benn will fall in love. The film will follow his adventures as sets off in pursuit of his tragic lost love, Monica McBride, played by Jane Horrocks.

Mr Benn will be prompted to approach the fancy dress shop owner (Ben Kingsley) for help after Monica is tragically taken from him.

Prospective director Jevon O'Neill, said: "Monica will be the leading lady in the film, and there's a hint of romance for Mr Benn, though it would not be right to call her a romantic lead."

He added: "We've been working closely with the original TV show's creators and rights owners, and they are happy with the script At the moment, we are in the process of finalising funding for the project, but in an ideal world we could start pre-production in a couple of months' time.

"The film will be set in England, and it will have a very quirky British feel to it, but until all the funding is in place we will not know exactly where it is going to be filmed.

"We are putting the money together piecemeal at the moment, as is always the way with British-made films. The film will be a fantasy and we've found that we are so unadventurous in this country when it comes to making movies. It's either got to be social realism or films with chocolate box scenery and costumes."

fields.headline: Germany lifts British beef ban
fields.trailText: Germany will lift its controversial ban on British beef after a majority of federal states in Germany's upper house today voted in favour of ending the 1996 measure.
fields.body:
Germany will lift its controversial ban on British beef after a majority of federal states in Germany's upper house today voted in favour of ending the 1996 measure.

It means that British beef will be back on sale in Germany early in April, although Britain's beef exports to the country amounted to less than 2% of German consumption before the ban.

Most of Germany's 16 states had previously opposed lifting the import ban, saying they wanted safeguards to make sure British beef would be clearly identifiable, but chancellor Gerhard Schröder's government had long urged the states to vote for lifting the ban, warning that the EU could impose heavy fines if it were not lifted.

The centre-left government came up last month with a compromise plan to soothe the states' concerns about labelling the beef.

Meanwhile, British scientists have established tests which for the first time will allow them to diagnose people with the human form of "mad cow disease" before they die.

Until now doctors could only be sure a person had new variant CJD once they had died and a brain biopsy could be carried out.

But medical advances and new research mean experts have established criteria which enable them to say CJD is the "probable" cause of someone's illness.

Living, "probable" CJD victims will be included in the department of health's monthly figures for the first time from April.

Victims normally suffer from the progressively debilitating disease, which has no cure, for an average of 14 months but some live for more than three years.

webTitle: Harry Potter author sued for plagiarism

fields.headline: Harry Potter author sued for plagiarism
fields.trailText: An American author is suing the writer and publishers of the Harry Potter books, claiming that plots and characters in the wildly popular children's series originated with her
fields.body:
An American author is suing the writer and publishers of the Harry Potter books, claiming that plots and characters in the wildly popular children's series originated with her.

Three books about Harry Potter, a young orphaned wizard, have sold 19 million copies in the United States, and a fourth is due for release in July.

The author, J.K. Rowling of Scotland, has become a cult figure in her own right among the novels' readers. A movie based on the first book, "Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone" is in the works.

But Nancy K. Stouffer of Camp Hill, Pennsylvania, argues in her federal lawsuit that ideas for the Potter series were lifted from her 1984 book "The Legend of Rah and Muggles," which includes a character named Larry Potter.

"I think coincidences happen, but I still say if it looks like a duck and acts like a duck, it's a duck," said Stouffer, who also claims she owns the trademark to the word "muggle."

In Stouffer's book, muggles are little people who care for two orphaned boys who magically turn their dark homeland into a happy place. In Rowling's books, "muggles" is the word wizards use for humans. Stouffer's book has a character named Lilly Potter; Rowling's books have a Lily Potter. The Stouffer book has characters identified as "Keepers of the Gardens"; Rowling's books have a "Keeper of the Keys."

Stouffer filed the lawsuit in US District Court on March 6 against Rowling and Scholastic Inc., the US publisher of the Harry Potter books. Her lawsuit also names Time Warner Entertainment Co., which owns the film rights to two of Rowling's Potter books, and Mattel and Hasbro, which have licenses to create and market related merchandise.

Scholastic, Rowling and Time Warner filed their own lawsuit in November in New York, asking a judge to rule that the Harry Potter books do not violate Stouffer's trademark and copyright. That suit was filed after attempts by Stouffer to negotiate an out-of-court settlement apparently failed.

Stouffer's claims are "completely meritless," said Judy Corman, a spokeswoman for Scholastic. "Unfortunately, success often leads to frivolous claims, and we're confident the court will find in our favor."

After its publication in 1984, Stouffer's book was sold mostly on the East Coast of the United States. Stouffer believes Rowling may have come across it when she was on a work-study exchange in Baltimore in 1987 and 1988.

fields.headline: Tories 'humiliate' Labour in Ayr byelection
fields.standfirst:
15.97% swing from Labour to Tory since 1997 could worry the government
Comment: downbeat Labour hands Ayr to Tories
fields.trailText: The government was dealt a mid-term blow today after the jubilant Tory party won its first seat in the Scottish parliament in yesterday's Ayr byelection.
fields.body:
The government was dealt a mid-term blow today after the jubilant Tory party won its first seat in the Scottish parliament in yesterday's Ayr byelection.

The Conservative candidate and local farmer John Scott, 48, overturned a Labour majority of 25 to snatch the seat by a margin of 3,344 votes over the Scottish National party. Labour was pushed into third place.

"We have seen the Labour party humiliated," said Conservative party chairman Michael Ancram this morning.

"A seat they held by 6,500 votes in the general election in 1997 they have now lost, they have come third, it's a humiliation for them, it's a humiliation for John Reid, it's a humiliation for Tony Blair, and it's a humiliation for the executive in Scotland," Mr Ancram told BBC Radio 4.

The Scottish secretary, John Reid, acknowledged that the result was a poor one for Labour, though he argued that it was a poor result for all the parties.

"I certainly look at the result with a little humility, I don't for a moment deny that it is very disappointing for us.

"But it is a poor result for all the parties... we lost the election, and there are no medals for losers. The Tories absolutely failed to move off their percentage vote, and fell in their absolute vote. So they haven't moved forward at all, we have moved downwards. The SNP will be disappointed as well."

The result in the previously marginal seat, from a turnout of 56.96%, increases the pressure on first minister Donald Dewar's embattled coalition administration.

It will also worry Labour party officials and Tony Blair's government, which could be little more than a year away from a general election.

If the 15.97% swing from Labour to Tory since 1997 recorded at Ayr was repeated across the whole of Britain at a general election, William Hague would sweep into Downing Street.

Mr Scott, who polled 12,580 votes, said in his victory speech: "This result signals the revival of the Scottish Tory party is well and truly under way.

"The election has sent a very strong message to Donald Dewar and Tony Blair demanding that they stop and listen to the priorities of the electorate.

"I will start my work tomorrow delivering my promise to put the Scottish parliament on the right track."

The result of the byelection, caused by the resignation of Labour's Ian Welsh - partly over frustration at backbench life - was hailed by backers of the campaign to keep Section 28, which bans councils from "promoting" homosexuality.

Keep Clause 28 campaign director Jack Irvine said: "Donald Dewar did not listen to the people of Scotland and his party paid the price at Ayr."

But international development minister George Foulkes said the campaign had also been obscured by the Keep the Clause campaign, funded by Stagecoach millionaire Brian Souter.

Mr Foulkes said: "Every time we tried to return to the main issues, we returned to that [section 28].

"That has been a distortion of democracy," said Mr Foulkes, who added that the anti-repeal campaigners had spent more than all the other candidates put together.

"The circumstances of the byelection were not good for us, the mid-term of a government, traditional Tory territory, which until Sandra Osborne won the seat spectacularly in 1997 had been Tory for 100 years, the smallest Labour majority in the whole of the UK, and the MSP resigning in difficult circumstances.

"This was a unique result which cannot be extrapolated anywhere else."

Ayr was the Scottish parliament's most marginal seat, with Labour winning a majority of just 25 votes in last May's elections for the Scottish parliament, compared with 6,543 in the 1997 general election.

The byelection result, which gives the Tories their first directly-elected Scottish parliament member, marked a swing of 8.7% from Labour to the Tories since last year's elections. It is also the Tories' first parliamentary byelection success in Scotland since 1973 when they defended Edinburgh North.

Alex Salmond, leader of the Scottish National Party, which had the biggest vote rise of 9.5%, said: "The SNP have done astonishingly well. To come anywhere near winning this byelection would be the most sensational result."

If the vote share changes since last May's election were repeated across Scotland next time, the SNP would become the largest party in the Edinburgh assembly.

fields.headline: The morality of taxes
fields.standfirst:
As
         the budget looms, William Hague's bold tax-cutting claims have
         electrified opinion
fields.trailText:
As
         the budget looms, William Hague's bold tax-cutting claims have
         electrified opinion.
fields.body:
William Hague has hit exactly the right note on taxation. Pleas for lower taxes have been derided as "simply greed'' by those who prefer to spend other people's money. By basing his case on the moral ground, Hague has opened up a clear gulf between his party and New Labour. What he offers is an alternative vision of the relationship between the individual and the government, a more equal relationship, and one which promotes moral growth.

The chancellor's preference for stealth taxes turned out to bring only a temporary reprieve from public disquiet. We now know that the average taxpayer is £1,500 worse off each year, a rise of 2.5 per cent. Brown denies this, assuming that all growth belongs to him, rather than to those who made it. His plea that company taxes should be excluded rather reminds one of Marion Barry, when Washington's mayor, claiming that his city actually had a low crime rate "if you didn't count the murders".

Of course company taxes fall on people. They pay the higher prices which taxes bring about, and they achieve less return on their investment. Whether the taxes are levied directly on people, or by stealth, the effect is the same. People have less to spend themselves because government is spending more of it instead.

Herein lies the immorality of taxation. Taxation means compulsion. Our habit of clothing it in fine words often conceals the brute fact that taxation is the confiscation of our property by people who prefer to spend it on their priorities rather than ours. Higher taxation means more compulsion. It forces further retreat by individuals from the area of their lives in which they can make decisions and assume responsibilities.

At the heart of the debate is the question of whether people are to live by their own values as adult citizens, or made to live according to the values of their government. Hague has opted for the former, and holds out the prospect of a more equal relationship in which citizens meet the government eye to eye and freely contract with it to discharge their obligations.

The United States has just seen its annual list of the top 100 lifetime benefactors. In the number one slot is George Soros, who has given away $2.65bn. The list includes Bill and Melinda Gates, rapidly making their way up its ranks, and even the actor Paul Newman, whose supermarket sauces pay every penny to charity. The US can be generous with its private charity because government leaves space for its citizens to do so. It takes 28 per cent of their income each year, as against the 40 per cent which our own treasury takes. Further, US tax laws allow full deduction for charitable gifts. This helps to explain why we give pounds 7 a month, versus the equivalent of pounds 17 given by Americans.

It is not just charity which is crowded out by the state. Whenever it undertakes a responsibility, it denies us the chance to assume it. If people are less inclined to care for their elderly relatives than before, it is because the state has convinced them that it is its job, not theirs. If people do not save enough to meet their future needs, it is because the state has spent decades telling them that it will take care of them instead.

Wherever government has advanced, individual responsibility has retreated. Now Hague is telling us it can be rolled back for moral reasons, to create a space in which people can grow. His guarantees are spot on.

By pledging that the overall tax burden will diminish, he tells us that we will undertake responsibility for a larger part of our lives. We will have the resources to make better provision for our relatives and for own own future. We will have the means to contribute to charitable causes, and to support those less fortunate than ourselves.

By pledging an end to stealth taxes, he is telling us that he intends to take away some of the cynicism and dishonesty which discredit government. If we are to pay taxes, he says, let them be open and understood and accepted. Gordon Brown has made it his style to rack up taxes by keeping them concealed and keeping taxpayers confused. William Hague plans to expose taxation, probably in the belief that if people know what they are paying, they will be less tolerant of the high tax culture, and the arrogant assumption that it will plan and organise our lives better than we can do it ourselves.

 Madsen Pirie is president of the Adam Smith Institute

webTitle: Can Clinton restart the peace process?

fields.headline: Can Clinton restart the peace process?
fields.standfirst: On St Patrick's Day, Ireland correspondent John Mullin looks at progress on the talks
fields.trailText: On St Patrick's Day, Ireland correspondent John Mullin looks at progress on the talks.
fields.body:
For an Irish celebration, St Patrick's Day is a distinctly US affair. Just as the patron saint drove snakes from the Emerald Isle, so he is also banishing almost all politicians from Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic in favour of a White House hooley.

President Bill Clinton is to blame. His interest in Irish politics borders on the fanatical, and it was his decision in 1994 to grant Gerry Adams, Sinn Fein president, a visa to visit America before the first IRA ceasefire that paved the way for Washington to become the focus of St Patrick's Day. As nationalists and republicans poured in over the next couple of years to appeal to the Irish-American lobby, Ulster Unionists realised they could not afford to be left behind. Even the Democratic Unionist party, staunch opponents of the Good Friday agreement, are attending this year. But Ian Paisley Jnr, son of the party's leader, insists he will be avoiding the green beer, a key element of American tackiness today.

All the main leaders of the pro-agreement parties are there, each for at least three days. They are joined by no fewer than 20 ministers from Taoiseach Bertie Ahern's cabinet. With the peace process deadlocked, people back home are furious. Two-thirds of respondents to BBC Radio Ulster's Talkback programme complained about what they saw as graft.

The politicians are at pains to claim this is no party. But they also admit there is unlikely to be any breakthrough during meetings with President Clinton on the fringes of the celebrations, leaving those left behind pondering why they are going.

President Clinton made an emotional appeal last night at a $500-a-head fundraising dinner for Irish-Americans, urging Northern Ireland's politicians to get the peace process moving again before another life is lost.

The expected thrust of the fresh round of talks is to find a way of reframing the decommissioning issue, which has long threatened political progress. But the most that can be hoped for is the beginning of rapprochement after the vicious fall-outs following Northern Ireland secretary Peter Mandelson's decision to suspend the fledgling institutions of government last month. Next month, back on home soil, politicians would try again to map a way through the impasse.

President Clinton, though, is keen to leave his eight years at the White House with the triumph of resolving the Troubles. His has been a key role, and he has 10 months more yet to succeed.

fields.headline: The guzzler
fields.trailText: Cheapskate ... where to eat out for under £15 | Quick bites ... where to eat out in under 15 minutes | Cheat's kitchen | On the menu | Food on the net | The taste test
fields.body:
Cheapskate ... where to eat out for under £15

(fitz)henry, 19 Shore Place, Leith, Edinburgh. Tel: 0131 555 6625

Proprietor David Ramsden and chef Hubert Lamort represent a culinary breath of fresh air with their selection of essentially central European peasant food smartened up a bit, majoring on forgotten gems such as rabbit (stuffed with boudin), pike (in gratin with langoustine sauce), and mackerel (seared, with piccalilli). They have the nerve to break with the northern penchant for tedious blanched side veg and substitute a melting, herby, oven-roast alternative. You can easily sneak under £15 for three courses, even with "Crespaou", a kind of omelette cake, a starter of ox tongue with sauce piquante and a saffron rice pudding with roasted plum compote.

Quick bites ... where to eat out in under 15 minutes

Kalpna, 2-3 St Patrick Square, Edinburgh. Tel: 0131 667 9890

Edinburgh's Groucho Club for academics and time-honoured place of pilgrimage for Scottish vegetarians. Each day when proprietor Ajay Bhardwaj lays on his daily £5 buffet lunch, the Kalpna can be mistaken for the social science canteen. The three-course formula usually starts with pakoras or other fried variations on that bazaar snack theme and salad with tamarind and mint sauces. Then there is always brown rice and spiced basmati or warm paratha with about four curries. Sexy, soothing milky Indian desserts feature the subcontinent's take on bread and butter pudding, buttery semolina halva and cardamon-scented rice with pistachios.

Cheat's kitchen

Stuffed mushrooms, serves three

Six mushrooms about 6cms across

One pot of pesto

1 Place mushrooms on microwaveable dish, stalks upwards.

2 Cut out stalks.

3 Plop a meagre coffee spoon of pesto into hole where stalk was (or sun-dried tomato paste or small lump of Stilton cheese).

4 Pop into microwave and cook at full power for two minutes (If you don't have a microwave, cover the dish with foil and bake in oven 180C/350F/Gas4 for 15 minutes).

 Oonagh Lahr, Muswell Hill, London.

Food on the net

www.simplyfood.co.uk

The online arm of the Carlton Food Network, this is one of the best - and most extensive - food sites around, covering news, features, recipes and wines. If Antony Worrall Thompson's musings aren't your thing, try instead the reviews of everything from new restaurants to microwave lasagnes.

Pros: Excellent links to other foodie sites and especially to online shopping. For those who can't square food with simplicity, there's an ingredients glossary and cook's conversion tables.

Cons: OK, so there's an ulterior motive - plenty of plugs for Carlton Food Network, and a television guide that's limited to just one (guess which. . . ) channel.

On the menu: ras el hanout

What is it? The grocer's head.

Pardon? Sorry. The Middle Eastern equivalent to India's many masalas or the Chinese five-spice powder. A blend of spices used to add zip and zap to tagines and what have you.

Which spices? Each grocer in North Africa has his own personal blend.

Of? Legend has it, up to a hundred spices. In reality it's usually about 12.

And they are? Cinnamon, nutmeg, dried rosebuds, ginger, cloves, cubebs, different peppers, and, if you're lucky, Spanish fly, which, it is said, has aphrodisiac properties.

Ah, love my ras el hanout, love me. Something like that.

The taste test: canned tuna in oil

Where would we be without it? Tuna and sweetcorn for the baked potato. Tuna and mayo for sandwiches. Tuna for salade niçoise (forget this faddish nonsense of making it with fresh tuna). The best is Spanish and taken from the belly of the fish. I would guess the supermarket versions are neither of these. All in sunflower oil unless specified.

75p/185g. * * * Tenderfoot tuna; shards rather than hunks, but lightweight oil suits it.

Co-op

49p/185g. * * * Tactical tuna; good for sandwiches.

Tel: 0131 555 6625 Proprietor David Ramsden and chef Hubert Lamort represent a culinary breath of fresh air with their selection of essentially central European peasant food smartened up a bit, majoring on forgotten gems such as rabbit (stuffed with boudin), pike (in gratin with langoustine sauce), and mackerel (seared, with piccalilli). They have the nerve to break with the northern penchant for tedious blanched side veg and substitute a melting, herby, oven-roast alternative. You can easily sneak under £15 for three courses, even with "Crespaou", a kind of omelette cake, a starter of ox tongue with sauce piquante and a saffron rice pudding with roasted plum compote. Quick bites ... where to eat out in under 15 minutes Kalpna, 2-3 St Patrick Square, Edinburgh. Tel: 0131 667 9890 Edinburgh's Groucho Club for academics and time-honoured place of pilgrimage for Scottish vegetarians. Each day when proprietor Ajay Bhardwaj lays on his daily £5 buffet lunch, the Kalpna can be mistaken for the social science canteen. The three-course formula usually starts with pakoras or other fried variations on that bazaar snack theme and salad with tamarind and mint sauces. Then there is always brown rice and spiced basmati or warm paratha with about four curries. Sexy, soothing milky Indian desserts feature the subcontinent's take on bread and butter pudding, buttery semolina halva and cardamon-scented rice with pistachios. webTitle: Shoe-shop.com on an unsure footing as it takes its first steps

fields.headline: Shoe-shop.com on an unsure footing as it takes its first steps
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: First came internet firms with no profits or dividends. And this week's flotation of Lastminute.com has seen the first big online shop with little in the way of sales either.
fields.body:
First came internet firms with no profits or dividends. And this week's flotation of Lastminute.com has seen the first big online shop with little in the way of sales either.

A couple of days is a long time in the fast-moving business of e-commerce and the world now has the first online retailer with no stock.

Yesterday saw the launch of Shoe-shop.com - "Europe's largest online shoe shop", it boasts, "selling more than 10,000 different shoes from every major footwear brand in the UK".

The two businessmen behind the website have plans to crack the American market next year and are already counting their millions: "A flotation is already mooted, Shoe-shop.com licensed to thrill the stock market - with an initial listing hoped for by the end of the year and a full stock market listing by the end of 2001."

"The only way for an e-commerce business to succeed is to be the dominant force in its category, and Shoe-shop aims to be the category killer in the footwear market, i.e. the Amazon.com of the footwear market," says the firm's launch literature.

"It will do this by giving the consumer a new option to look and buy from thousands of shoe brands in one place, with guaranteed delivery and total internet security."

There are two problems with this. First, on launch day the website was littered with warnings that security was not quite up to scratch - or not exactly secure.

And as for the thousands of shoes - there are lots of sections to choose from - what about some sports shoes? Something for tennis, golf or walking, maybe? Nothing. No slippers, no socks, no sandals. What's available from the decadent designer section? Nothing. Shoes for clubbing girls - one pair. Womens' court shoes - one pair.

"In addition, Dorothy Com, the site's online personal shopper, is on hand to offer advice from shoe styles and fittings and has a comprehensive database of all shoes and footwear terminology," says the PR-babble. Obviously, she had failed to turn up for work yesterday.

Steve Cochrane, one of the Shoe-shop.com backers and managing director of fashion firm Psyche, believes shoe retailing has a big future online. "Conventional retailing is limited by the amount of people that can enter the store," he said. It is also generally limited by the range of merchandise on the shelves.

Yesterday an official denied that the launch of Shoe-shop.com was like a store opening on the high street with nothing in the window and yet boasting it will be Wal-Mart within the year.

She said the shoes would be arriving soon. "The brands have signed up. But it will take a little while to get it all logged and catalogued."

Footwear retailer Stuart Paver, Mr Cochrane's partner, insists there are 12,000 products in stock - though that has to be divided by the number of colours in each range and up to nine sizes.

The categories we have investigated are out of season - summer sandals? ladies' court shoes? - and "our worst lines", he says. The firm evidently has "loads" of nice wide fitting shoes for ladies, but "we have been waiting for the younger, trendier designer stuff".

Eventually, he conceded: "I agree with you it was too early to launch. We have got to get the message across that this isn't the final offer."

But isn't the company already bragging about being an Amazon.com-style player with stock market status - and obviously multi-millionaire founders - within eight months? Well, "maybe it is early", Mr Paver said.

webTitle: In the art of the city

fields.headline: In the art of the city
fields.trailText: When Judith Cheeks' erotic postal art Penetration by Mail gets together with Judith Levins' delicate floral oils commissioned by Harrods, the result is strangely invigorating for creative young garret-dwellers everywhere.
fields.body:
When Judith Cheeks' erotic postal art Penetration by Mail gets together with Judith Levins' delicate floral oils commissioned by Harrods, the result is strangely invigorating for creative young garret-dwellers everywhere.

Artists' muscle may be puny compared with the clout of dot.com entrepreneurs or venture capitalists, but in Leeds - the famous 'happening city' where not a lot seems to have been happening lately in visual arts - it is now being flexed to excellent effect.

Bouncers of the type more familiar at the city's clubs, all body armour and walkie-talkies, had to control queues this week for f.k.a.a. - formerly known as art - an exhibition which is shining a sudden light on contemporary young painters like the Judiths, Lisa Penny and Simon Margison.

"It's extraordinary," says Penny, literally blinking at the unaccustomed public interest in her slabby canvases depicting katabolism, the process by which living things break down assimilated matter and liberate energy. "I've been struggling along in Leeds for ten years after turning down the chance to take an MA in Barcelona, and at last everyone¹s coming to have a look. "

Katabolism is a good enough word for the process in Leeds, where long-assimilated indifference to the young painter hordes - literally; there were 800 applications this year for place on Leeds Metropolitan University's fine arts course which itself is second to the one at Leeds University - has been broken down by a sustained and sparky campaign by the artists themselves.

Old weapons were used, including envious comparisons with Manchester which are still a sure way to trigger action in Leeds; and so were new ones, such as the internationally-famed antics of the Leeds 13 art student hoaxers.

They are there at f.k.a.a., manning a predictably jokey stall of souvenirs related to their brilliant pretend jaunt on the Costa Brava in 1998 (you can buy one of the Guardian's articles on it for a mere £113 including plastiwrap), and attracting some flak over the way their critique of consumer art and dealers' prices is beginning to disappear deep up its own bottom.

But their zing has played an important part in attracting bigger players to the rescue of the visual artists in the city, notably Jude Kelly of the West Yorkshire Playhouse.

Her personal liveliness and theatrical track record, just bolstered by the West End transfers of Spend! Spend! Spend! and Singin' in the Rain, has made her a great local enabler. Any glimmer of rivalry between the different arts, competeing as they do for public subsidy and paying customers, has been quashed in Leeds by exhibitions in the Playhouse, plays in galleries and a general attitude of: we're all needy artists so let's pool our strengths.

The f.k.a.a. show is the liveliest example so far, using - free - the Playhouse's airy top floor rehearsal rooms above the new Leeds jazz club The Wardrobe, which brings in another important local partner. One of the wine-clutching guests at the exhibition's opening 'do' was the Wardrobe's creator Peter Connolly, one of Britain's few successful property developers who was in the International Marxist Group in the Sixties and remains a radical socialist.

"We've made a Leeds art center here almost by stealth," he says, carefully avoiding a beautiful but spikey glass sculpture by Paddy Hartley, an artist who modestly puts his inspiration down to "the particular breed of artists who have made Leeds their home and who have an inter-action and dialogue the likes of which I have never encountered before."

Connolly helped to negotiate the rehearsal room deal and also organized a sort of curtain-raising show on a smaller scale, Absolut Leeds, in the jazz club itself over Christmas.

The other essential partner, which would come as a surprise in many other parts of Britain, is Leeds city council, which is embracing the young artists' renaissance with all the vim its fifty-something seniors showed when the city's club scene took off in the early Nineties.

Then it was the Lord Mayor Lorna Cohen who bopped until the small hours and helped to win over the crucial magistrates' permission for late night licences. Now it is Bernard Atha, the Lord Mayor-elect, whose energy has helped to ringfence budgets (£10,000 for f.k.a.a. alone) to match the input of Connolly, Kelly and Co.

As with the clubs, the money is unlikely to attract too much grunging from the mend-the-potholes/build-more-hospitals brigade, because of the obvious energy it sustains among the artists, especially in their wooing of the private sector. One of the most significant things about f.k.a.a. - whose name is intended to suggest innovation and radicalism as well as having the obvious French Connection UK resonance - is its raft of related visual art activities.

Like some sort of short-lived glow-worm, the exhibition above the Wardrobe lasts only three days (Playhouse rehearsals have to go on), but its offshoots will keep Leeds buzzing until the summer. The Playhouse is hosting f.k.a.a. talks (or more probably shouts), there are exhibitions at Borders and Waterstones (spurred by the artists into proper capitalist competition), smaller shows in numerous cafes and bars and a range of one-off beermats designed by some of the 16 artists featured in the main exhibition.

Sprinkled across the city, where art is also spreading to Leeds United's stadium and even the For Sale boards of estate agents in Headingley which now feature contemporary work and Old Masters, the mats recall another reason for optimism about this Northern resurgence.

Between 1903 and 1923, Leeds Art Club was one of Europe's great Bohemian gatherings, influencing many young members such as Herbert Read to make the city their base, which in turn encouraged the generation of Henry Moore and Barbara Hepworth.

Critics will in due course help to decide the commercial winners among the crop of creative young Leeds artists, but those who fail to land big prices will at least have shared in one of those periods of partnership and buzz which can only benefit the arts.

Judith Levin, self-taught and successfully earning a living for the last 12 years from private commissions, says: "I suppose I'm really an ivory tower artist, but you can¹t fail to be inspired by getting together like this."

Judith Cheeks, in reality a bearded mischief-maker called Kevin O'Hare, agrees fulsomely that: "Leeds' position as the center of the British Isles makes it the ideal nucleus from which to radiate my artistic philosophy of Engrossing Love."

f.k.a.a. main exhibition continues through Saturday March 18 until 6pm at The Wardrobe, St Peter's Buildings, Leeds.

Bar Talks at the Wardrobe, Saturday March 18, 1-3.30pm.

Details of many other related events at the Leeds City Council website.

fields.headline: Today's other news
fields.trailText: Miramax and Bridget Jones Diary, Angelina Jolie prepares for Lara Croft role, and John Cusack on the casting couch
fields.body:
 Screendaily reports that Miramax Films is in talks to handle the US distribution of Working Title Films' upcoming Bridget Jones' Diary. In return, John Madden would be released so that the Shakespeare in Love director can shoot Working Title's forthcoming Captain Corelli's Mandolin. Madden came on board the adaptation of Louis de Berniere's best-selling novel after illness forced Notting Hill director Roger Michell to drop out. Filming is due to begin in May; Nicolas Cage and Penelope Cruz will star.

 Angelina Jolie, who is to play the screen version of Tomb Raider Lara Croft, has told UK site Popcorn how she will be preparing for the challenge of making flesh cyberspace's favourite babe. Her plans include coming to England and apparently training with the SAS, in whom she became interested through her ex-husband Jonny Lee Miller. "He loves the SAS. He's fascinated with everything to do with that world and he's got me hooked," says Jolie.

 New Line Cinema has purchased the remake rights to Forbidden Planet, the 1956 MGM sci-fi classic loosely based on Shakespeare's The Tempest.

 Shooting is scheduled to begin on April 17 on the world war two drama Enigma, starring Kate Winslet and produced by Mick Jagger's film company. Michael Apted directs, and Dougray Scott also stars.

Casting couch

 John Cusack, currently gracing our screens as the slacker puppeteer in Being John Malkovich has signed up to Miramax's romantic comedy Serendipity. He will play half of a couple who reunite a decade after the night they first met, fell in love and separated, convinced that one day they'd end up together.

Cusack will next be seen in the Stephen Frears-directed adaptation of Nick Hornby's High Fidelity. The movie opens in the US on March 31 and in the UK in July; but you can get a taster at the official <A HREF=""website, and even the chance to question Cusack himself in a live webchat on Monday night.

 The Hollywood Reporter says that Halle Berry is withdrawing from the Warner Brothers futuristic comedy Pluto Nash just weeks before the flick goes before cameras. Berry was to co-star opposite Eddie Murphy as a street-smart moll.

webTitle: No St Patrick's Day party at the White House

fields.headline: No St Patrick's Day party at the White House
fields.trailText: For an Irish celebration, St Patrick's Day is a distinctly US-affair. Just as the patron saint drove snakes from the Emerald Isle, so he is also banishing almost all politicians from Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic in favour of a White House hooley.
fields.body:
For an Irish celebration, St Patrick's Day is a distinctly US-affair. Just as the patron saint drove snakes from the Emerald Isle, so he is also banishing almost all politicians from Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic in favour of a White House hooley.

President Bill Clinton is to blame. His interest in Irish politics borders on the fanatical, and it was his decision in 1994 to grant Gerry Adams, Sinn Fein president, a visa to visit America before the first IRA ceasefire that paved the way for Washington to become the focus of St Patrick's Day. As nationalists and republicans poured in over the next couple of years to appeal to the Irish-American lobby, Ulster Unionists realised they could not afford to be left behind. Even the Democratic Unionist party, staunch opponents of the Good Friday agreement, are attending this year. But Ian Paisley Jnr, son of the party's leader, insists he will be avoiding the green beer, a key element of American tackiness today.

All the main leaders of the pro-agreement parties are there, each for at least three days. They are joined by no fewer than 20 ministers from Taoiseach Bertie Ahern's cabinet. With the peace process deadlocked, people back home are furious. Two-thirds of respondents to BBC Radio Ulster's Talkback programme complained about what they saw as graft.

fields.headline: Woody Allen goes solo
fields.trailText: One of the most prolific pairings in the film world is coming to an end. Woody Allen and his long-time producer Jean Doumanian are parting ways on apparently cordial terms
fields.body:
One of the most prolific pairings in the film world is coming to an end. Woody Allen and his long-time producer Jean Doumanian are parting ways on apparently cordial terms.

Allen's last seven features, including the recently completed Small Time Crooks, were financed by Doumanian's Sweetland Films.

Allen has worked with Doumanian since 1993 and they have been close friends since meeting while Allen was on the standup circuit in Chicago almost 40 years ago. While they remain friendly the partnership is history.

Over the course of their relationship, Sweetland financed and Doumanian produced Sweet and Lowdown, Bullets Over Broadway, Mighty Aphrodite, Deconstructing Harry, Celebrity and Everyone Says I Love You. They are also in business on a performance of two one-act plays that Allen will direct and which will open in London in spring 2001. They wrap their working relationship with Small Town Crooks, a comedy starring Hugh Grant, Tracey Ullman and Allen.

webTitle: Affleck and Damon look for indie auteur on internet

fields.headline: Affleck and Damon look for indie auteur on internet
fields.trailText: Oscar-winning duo Ben Affleck and Matt Damon are setting their sights on TV production
fields.body:
Oscar-winning duo Ben Affleck and Matt Damon are setting their sights on TV production. Sources say that the pair have been shopping around a reality show that takes viewers behind the scenes of an indie movie. Along with their Miramax-based production company they plan to recruit an indie auteur via the internet who would then allow cameras to capture his vision coming to life.

"They were pretty passionate about the idea," says a source. "I think they wanted to do it based on their experience [making] Good Will Hunting. They want to give somebody else that kind of shot."

Meanwhile, Ben Affleck has posted information on his official site www.affleck.com about his next project, Pearl Harbor. "It's one I'm really thrilled about," writes the actor. "In fact, I haven't been this excited to do a movie in a long time... When I got the script I was fully expecting the kind of saccharine, popcorn that was Armageddon. I was shocked, to say the least. It is uncompromising, true to the accounts of survivors and striving to be the definitive epic on the day that "lived in infamy" and ultimately proved to be the definitive moment in the greatest conflict of the last century."

fields.headline: Section 28 deal faces new attacks
fields.standfirst:
Sex & Relationship Education Guidance (Dept of Education site)

Section 28 (Stonewall site)

More about section 28
fields.trailText: A government attempt to defuse the row over promoting homosexuality in schools was close to collapse last night as an alliance of Conservative peers, crossbenchers, Muslims and Christian fundamentalists rejected a deal agreed between the government and church leaders.
fields.byline: Patrick Wintour, Stephen Bates  and John Carvel
fields.body:
A government attempt to defuse the row over promoting homosexuality in schools was close to collapse last night as an alliance of Conservative peers, crossbenchers, Muslims and Christian fundamentalists rejected a deal agreed between the government and church leaders.

The Conservative education spokeswoman in the Lords, Baroness Blatch, rejected the amendments to the learning and skills bill, as well as new sex education guidance, claiming they presented marriage as morally equivalent to other stable relationships, including those between homosexuals, transvestites and transexuals.

Baroness Blatch and other Tory peers also met the Archbishop of Canterbury to criticise him for allowing his bishops to accept the deal negotiated with the education secretary, David Blunkett.

One Conservative frontbencher said William Hague was quite prepared to break with the church over the issue. The amendment to be put before the House of Lords says the education secretary must issue guidance to ensure that pupils in state schools:

 Learn about the nature of marriage and its importance for family life and raising children

 Learn about the significance of marriage and stable relationships as key building blocks of community and society

 Learn to respect themselves and others

 Are given accurate information for the purposes of enabling them to understand difference and of preventing or removing prejudice

 Are protected from inappropriate teaching and materials.

Pupils over 11 should also:

 Learn to understand human sexuality.

 Learn the reasons for delaying sexual activity and the benefits to be gained from such delay

 Learn about obtaining appropriate advice on sexual health.

Baroness Blatch said she was asking the government to defer the vote on the deal and warned that if ministers did not cooperate, her party would reject the package next Thursday.

Mr Blunkett will meet crossbenchers and dissident Labour peers early next week in an attempt to explain the 10,000-word guidelines and the new legal duty on teachers to portray marriage and permanent relationships as key building blocks of community and society.

However, critics claimed the amendments tabled by the government put marriage on a par with "stable relationships", including by implication relationships between unmarried parents and homosexuals.

Laying out the case he will put to wavering peers, Mr Blunkett said: "Section 28 is a total anachronism now that we have set in place new guidelines on sex education. Section 28 was passed at a time when local councils had a responsibilty for sex education in schools.

"They no longer do so, and we are setting in place clear and balanced guidelines on the future of sex education."

However, Baroness Blatch claimed Labour dissidents such as Lord Cocks remained solidly opposed to section 28 and predicted a backlash in the church.

Peers rejected the repeal of section 28 on February 7 by 210 to 165.

While the current legislation imposes a general ban on promotion of homosexuality by local authorities, the new guidance will apply directly to the conduct of lessons by teachers.

Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers, said it was "insulting, patronising, superfluous and bureaucratic".

Ministers still hope to push through the learning and skills bill amendment in the Lords next week, then use their Commons majority to reinstate the repeal of section 28 in the local government bill before throwing the gauntlet down to the Tory peers to vote against the government again.

webTitle: Byers humiliated by being left in the dark about BMW plans

fields.headline: Byers humiliated by being left in the dark about BMW plans
fields.standfirst: Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: The ruthless behaviour of BMW has served as a rude awakening to the ultra-Blairite Stephen Byers, who has often displayed a wide-eyed admiration for big business since taking over as trade and industry secretary.
fields.body:
The ruthless behaviour of BMW has served as a rude awakening to the ultra-Blairite Stephen Byers, who has often displayed a wide-eyed admiration for big business since taking over as trade and industry secretary.

In the past 48 hours, Mr Byers has suffered the humiliation of being caught off guard when rumours first surfaced in Germany that Rover was in danger of being broken up.

As speculation intensified throughout yesterday morning, Mr Byers was forced to tell the weekly cabinet meeting that he had no idea about BMW's precise intentions. Hours later BMW made its announcement, showing that Mr Byers had as little insight into the company's plans as thousands of distraught Rover workers at Longbridge.

The Tories wasted little time in seizing on his difficulties yesterday. Angela Browning, the shadow trade and industry secretary, told an emergency Commons debate that Mr Byers was so disorganised he "could not even run a whelk stall".

Mr Byers' supporters argued last night that any trade and industry secretary would been placed in his position. "This is all about factional fighting among BMW board members," one of his friends said. "The anti-Rover group, which was in the minority, has triumphed in the past week."

However, the Rover crisis will weaken the position of Mr Byers who has recently endured a series of embarrassing setbacks.

Earlier this month, his department appeared to be in disarray when he dropped the telecommunications and water industries from his utilities bill. The u-turn was forced on Mr Byers by Downing Street which had come under pressure from the industries' regulators.

The cross-party Commons trade and industry committee underlined its impatience with Mr Byers last month by reprimanding him for what it called his "regrettable habit" of repeating announcements and dressing up press notices with potentially misleading figures.

Mr Byers's highly publicised "Rip-off Britain" campaign also rebounded in spectacular fashion. Reports, which were commissioned amid hype that consumers were paying more in Britain than on the continent, found that price levels were the same.

Mr Byers's appointment to the DTI in December 1998, in the wake of Peter Mandelson's resignation over his home loan, was hailed as the promotion of another moderniser who would carry on the reforming work of his predecessor.

However, Labour critics believe that Mr Byers has left himself short of friends by making the mistake of seeking to "out-Blair the prime minister" in his admiration for large corporations.

But as Mr Byers ponders his future, there is at least one crumb of comfort. Mr Byers has been pressing Downing Street to step up its efforts to join the euro, an argument which is strengthened by BMW's claim that its hand has been forced by the strength of the pound.

webTitle: Oscars stolen, but the show will go on

fields.headline: Oscars stolen, but the show will go on
fields.trailText: A shipment of Oscars that were to be handed out at this month's Academy Awards ceremony have apparently been stolen from a loading dock of a shipping company near Los Angeles.
fields.body:
A shipment of Oscars that were to be handed out at this month's Academy Awards ceremony have apparently been stolen from a loading dock of a shipping company near Los Angeles.

"The statuettes have gone missing in the city of Bell and we believe they have been stolen," Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences spokesman John Pavlik said in Beverly Hills.

Academy President Robert Rehme told The Hollywood Reporter newspaper that the statuettes were being shipped from their manufacturer in Chicago when they disappeared.

Variety reported that about 40 statuettes were missing, but that the Academy would still have enough to present at the Oscars ceremony.

The theft comes just days after news of the loss, in the post, of thousands of Oscar ballot papers.

webTitle: Inflation fears drive up eurozone rates

fields.headline: Inflation fears drive up eurozone rates
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: Signs of inflationary pressure in the 11 member countries of the eurozone prompted the European Central Bank to raise borrowing costs yesterday for the second time in six weeks.
fields.body:
Signs of inflationary pressure in the 11 member countries of the eurozone prompted the European Central Bank to raise borrowing costs yesterday for the second time in six weeks.

The ECB raised all three official interest rates by 0.25%, taking its main refinancing rate to 3.5%. This is the first time the bank has changed rates at a meeting without a scheduled press conference, but the move had been well telegraphed and the markets were unmoved by the announcement.

"The reasons were fairly obvious even without a press conference," said Ken Wattret at BNP Paribas. "With growth accelerating, inflation pressures rising and the euro weak, policy is seen to be too accommodating."

The ECB said it was concerned about the rapid growth in the money supply and rising inflation pressures. "Most indicators and forecasts point to increasing upward pressures on consumer price inflation over the medium term," the bank warned.

Data released earlier this week showed Ireland's inflation hit an 11-year high of 4.3% in February, while Spain's rate reached a three-year peak of 3%, and Finland's rose to 2.7%.

Most economists expect inflation in the eurozone to reach 2.1% when the February figure is announced on Monday, taking the rate clearly above the ECB's 2% ceiling for inflation for the first time.

webTitle: In 1954 emotions ran high. Now, Australia hardly cares

fields.headline: In 1954 emotions ran high. Now, Australia hardly cares
fields.standfirst:
No hostility but little enthusiasm for royal visit

Australia and the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: Feted like a starry Hollywood couple, the newly-crowned young monarch and her dashing husband swept through Australia on wave of popular elation. People fainted in their hundreds, crushed in the stampede to touch the veil of their British heritage.
fields.byline: Christopher Zinn  in Sydney and  Matt Wells
fields.body:
Feted like a starry Hollywood couple, the newly-crowned young monarch and her dashing husband swept through Australia on wave of popular elation. People fainted in their hundreds, crushed in the stampede to touch the veil of their British heritage.

Now, as her reign passes into its evening, the Queen returns today to find the hysteria of 1954 faded, her cherished Commonwealth ideal forgotten. Few want to fly the flag for a monarch who they retain only by default.

Buckingham Palace, aware of the painful reality that the Queen remains Australia's head of state only because Australians rejected the republican model put forward by a staunchly monarchist prime minister, is determined to steer her away from the firing line. But with a federal government that sees the visit as a political opportunity, this most sensitive of her 13 Australian tours will place the Queen's renowned "studied neutrality" under unprecedented stress.

"I think that the temper of the Australian public is now republican," said the federal treasurer, Peter Costello. "The reality is we think ourselves republican and the monarchy does not symbolise our nation."

Despite 55% of the electorate having voted to keep the link with the crown in the referendum last year, opinion polls have consistently shown that about two thirds of Australians favour a republic in principle. It is a measure of the times that, with the exception of the prime minster, John Howard, almost every state and federal leader the Queen will meet in her 16-day tour favours an Australian president as head of state.

But apart from the two local councils in Sydney that have declined to fly any bunting to celebrate her first visit since 1992, it seems likely that Australian republicans will suffer her presence with polite restraint. Bob Carr, the Labour party premier of New South Wales and a committed republican, declared himself bound by the strictures of protocol. "The vote was held, the result was clear," he said. " We will be welcoming her as our head of state and it will be the warm welcome we Australians are justly famous for."

His government has invited the public to line the route of the Queen and Prince Philip's motorcade from the airport to the Sydney Opera House on Monday for the 21-gun salute and official harbourside welcome. But despite Mr Carr's diplomatic words, there is little evidence of much public enthusiasm.

Gerard Henderson, executive director of the Sydney Institute, said the low key response to the Queen's visit was not due to any antagonism. Simply, Australians consider her irrelevant.

"There's no hostility. It's just not particularly relevant to a majority of Australians - she doesn't affect our lives in any way and you wouldn't expect them to get unduly excited about it," he said. "Most of the business and the civic leaders she will meet voted for a republic and the country mostly feels republican but no one blames her for our predicament because no one holds anything against her."

The Australian Republican Movement, which is plastering over the wounds inflicted by November's humiliating defeat, is actually looking forward to the tour as being "good for business". James Terrie, the executive director, said comment about the visit had caused renewed interest in the organisation and an influx of new members.

"She is the head of state and she's welcome to come to see us. She'll be treated with due respect and protocol, but we see that as the problem," he said. "Her coming here will give Australians a chance to reflect on whether it is still appropriate to have a foreign person who is on the other side of the world as our head of state."

But the monarchists have attacked the republicans for refusing to concede defeat.

Kerry Jones, executive direc tor of Australians for a Constitutional Monarchy, said their outbursts were a disgrace. "The republicans should accept the umpire's decision and remain quiet during the tour," she said. "It would be a tragedy if the tour is spoilt by sour grapes."
