Thanks, SK. Got to go to the ceremony, it's non-negotiable. I mean, let's face it, if we didn't go and we won, it'd be embarrassing. I've no idea who I think deserves awards this year. I love Being John Malkovich, and Richard Farnsworth in The Straight Story is absolutely great, and I hope he wins Best Actor.

filmfan 101
Peter Bradshaw wrote in his Topsy Turvy review: "It is possible to spend two hours and 40 minutes waiting for this film to start, and I couldn't help wondering if we really needed every bit of those long rehearsal scenes". Has he just missed the point?

SpankTM
Which of the Fleet Street film critics do you respect, or otherwise? Or don't you pay any attention to them?

ML
Has Peter missed the point? I should say so. If he spent the film waiting for it to start and wondering if it was too long, then so far as I'm concerned it wouldn't have mattered if it was seven minutes or seven hours long, it's just not his type of film. His loss.

No names, but the critics I respect (no, not just the ones who like my films!) are the honest ones: ie the ones without a daft or negative agenda.

ollyf2
Do you ever get frustrated at being labelled an arthouse director, and would you prefer your films to be seen by wider audiences, seeing as they are accessible enough?

ML
I HATE being called an arthouse director, and I don't think I am one. Glad you think my films are accessible - of course they are.

sirharry
Do you think Marianne Jean-Baptiste was justified in complaining about racism in the British film industry a few years ago?

ML
Marianne was indeed justified in the sense that she was very frustrated after the success of Secrets and Lies in not being offered decent parts. There are, as yet, not enough good parts for black actors in British film.

withnail20
Where do you keep your awards? Pride of place on the mantelpiece, or are they just handy doorstops?

ML
Not on my mantelpiece, or holding the door open. They're all on a shelf in my office in Soho - all, that is, except the Palme d'Or, which is actually made of gold and is locked away somewhere. I'm not telling you where (and it isn't in my house).

withnail 20
How much of the Johnny character did David Thewlis bring to his character in Naked? Have there ever been problems with actors who couldn't get into your improvisational style of film-making?

ML
David Thewlis is the only actor in the world who could have played Johnny. All the actors in all my films work with me to create the characters. Therefore their input is hugely important. Very seldom, hardly ever, have there been actors who couldn't hack my sort of work.

withnail20
I thought that. In other films, Thewlis is at his best playing characters who are in some way like Johnny (eg Divorcing Jack), and not so good in roles that don't suit his style, eg Island of Dr. Moreau (bleuggh), and Restoration.

ML
I hesitate to agree too easily with what you say. At least if it is true, it isn't because David is limited as an actor - more a reflection on the limitations of the roles he is given, and probably of the quality of the films in question. So far as I'm concerned, he is an extremely versatile and talented actor. But it is true that he hasn't been able to pull out all the stops in any other film to the level he was able to in Naked.

Luce28
How do you feel when people accuse you of "patronising" the working classes. I am from a working-class background and occasionally I think you have been secretly filming my mother and her friends. People really aren't all "good" because they come from one background, just as they aren't all demons because they come from another, surely?

ML
Thanks, Luce! Couldn't agree more. And it does make me very upset when people do talk this continual nonsense about patronising the working-class.

Turnedoutn
Which story would you most like to tell?

ML
The one about the dog walking past the abattoir.

Nubby
You look a bit like Frank Dobson. As a well-known Londoner, who will you be voting for as Mayor of London?

ML
Frank Dobson is indeed very beautiful, but I should think I'll vote for Ken Livingstone.

Naomi2
Mike, I read in an interview that your films are particularly successful in France. Why do you think that is, and have you any plans to work over there? Also, are there any actors you would particularly like to work with? Why do you tend to use the same group of people?

ML
Secrets and Lies was particularly and phenomenally successful in France because it was the Palme d'Or winner at Cannes in 1996, and Palme d'Or winners are like Cup Final winning footballers in France. No plans to work over there, though the dinners are good. And your other question: Lots of actors I'd like to work with. Not true I tend to use the same group of people. Some of them are the same (if you get on with somebody, you work with them again), but there are always loads of new ones. See Topsy Turvy.

EDShane
Mr Leigh, I really enjoyed Topsy Turvy. Loved the script, especially Gilbert's rehearsal note-givings (which were very funny). What I've been wondering, though, is this: when Gilbert first announces that The Mikado's song will be cut, one lone voice - Miss Rosina Brandham - says what most of them are thinking: that it is not fair. The chorus (based on historical fact) subsequently revolt. What I would like to know is: was Miss Brandham really the first to voice everyone's feelings aloud to Gilbert or was that just invented for the script? If so, whose idea was it that she should be the first to speak out?

ML
Rosina wasn't the first person to voice the company's opinion. Or at least, if she was, it's a coincidence because I made it up. Somebody had to speak at that moment and I thought it's be good if it was her as she was the senior actress. Pure invention. Sorry!

Datta
How would you respond to the accusation that the characters in your films have a tendency to be a collection of tics and mannerisms rather than recognisable people? Why are the "professional" people in your films predominantly preposterous cartoons (I'm thinking primarily of the yuppies in Naked and Career Girls)?

ML
Well, here we go again. It's a ridiculous and stupid accusation. So is the one about "professional" characters. Why don't the accusers pay attention and actually look at the films? And, for that matter, why don't they pay attention and look at the people in the street?

Datta
Mike, I don't think that's a terribly useful answer, sorry. Why don't you try engaging with my question instead of becoming defensive? I have actually looked at the relevant films, and paid attention and looked people in the streets (and in the gutters, and in the city wine bars) and I don't think my questions are unwarranted. If a character in a Mike Leigh film wears a suit or drives a BMW, he won't be allowed anything approaching the degree of depth or complexity the other characters have: why is this uniformly the case? The thing about mannerisms and tics, I dunno, why don't you actually look at the films?

ML
I'm sorry too. But the truth is, I will never give you a useful answer. I can't. You have a view of my work which simply doesn't make sense to me, and somehow doesn't seem fair. It certainly isn't sympathetic. I can't change you opinion. I'm not being defensive, though I guess I am being helpless. Frankly, this kind of discussion makes me very sad, and frustrated.

Prawsfour
I think Datta is slightly missing the point about the BMW drivers. Whether you believe or not that Mr. Leigh is attempting to portray such characters one-dimensional or without depth is not necessarily that provocative a point to make, and your argument is a frankly sluggish and "depthless" approach to film and representation.

Withnail20
I do have to agree with Datta regarding the yuppie character in Naked. He didn't have much depth, just seemed like a stereotype.

Datta
Mike - in fact, I like a large number of your films a great deal. I merely sought to seek your opinion on what I (subjectively, of course) see as flaws in your work. I can't see how this is unfair, and if I felt your work was worthless I certainly wouldn't bring it up. It was certainly not my intention to cause you sadness or frustration, but rather to gain some insight as to why you do some things the way you do. Peace! Prawnsfour - to descend to your level for a moment: that's one of the stupidest and most meaningless things anybody's ever said to me.

Withnail20
Does it bother you at all that almost all your early BBC work goes unseen by virtually everyone under 30? I've managed to uncover Nuts in May, Abigail's Party and Meantime on video but very little else of your BBC work is available.

ML
Absolutely. What a shame the BBC sits on all those films lots of us made in the 70s. We'd love to persuade them to release them commercially, but then the BBC is a ridiculous organisation these days.

Withnail 20
Don't mean to scare you here but they may not even be around anymore! The Beeb has a bad reputation for erasing great programmes. They wiped out half of Spike Milligan's career, for flip's sake!

ML
Good point. I know what you mean. Actually, all my films are safely under lock and key in the laboratories, but you're absolutely right, and a half hour studio play I did in 1976 called Knock for Knock was indeed wiped by a crackpot committee because of a "shortage of space". Especially tragic as a) incredible and hilarious performance from Sam Kelly and b) experimental for the time, in that the entire play was done in one take (television studio take not one camera, that is). And because at that time video-taping had not yet really happened, there are no extant copies of Knock for Knock anywhere to my knowledge. Indeed, if anybody out there has one, I will pay very good money for it. Knock for Knock was screened on BBC TV in the Second City Firsts series in autumn 1976. But overall, beware of the BBC.

Hiskander
Mike, I am an actor and a huge fan of your films. Thank-you for such a fantastic contribution to the film industry. What can I do to work with you? Let's meet!

ML
Hello actor. If you want to work with me, then you have to pass 'The Actor's Intelligence Test'. Find out where I am and drop me a line.

Davek
Mr. Leigh, I recently saw Meantime for the first time on FilmFour and funnily enough it reminded me very much of Gary Oldman's Nil BY Mouth. Given his comments about how Nil By Mouth was very much autobiographical (and clearly the same goes for his performance in Meantime), it made me wonder how much of you is in your films. Are there many autobiographical influences? And another question about Meantime. How old was Tim Roth when the film was made? He looks about 12!

ML
Tim was, I think, 21 or 22 when we made Meantime. All my films are autobiographical in one way or another, though never really in the direct autobiographical sense that Nil By Mouth is for Gary - it was a dramatisation of his family experiences. For me, all kinds of experience, of people and relationships and atmospheres and moods and conflicts and good moments and bad moments and places and all kinds of stuff find their way out of my subconscious and into my films.

Mnorth
If you had to pick just one of your films to be judged on, which one would it be? From what you've said in the past, I have the sense that Naked is the picture you're most proud of.

ML
I don't know what I've said in the past, but it isn't true about Naked. Actually, I find it impossible to nominate one of my films in preference to the others. I get very close to these films when I make them, they take up a huge part of my life and they're very personal films. So in a way they're like children: you can't say which is your favourite. Honest!

Withnail20
Are there any you were a bit disappointed with, though? Career Girls got a pretty cool reception. I quite liked it, but it seemed pretty small-time next to Secrets and Lies.

ML
I was very disappointed to the general reaction to Career Girls. I don't see it as "small-time" although it is, of course, a smaller canvas than, say, Naked or Secrets and Lies or indeed Topsy Turvy. But that should not be confused with the notion that it was small in its emotions or subject matter. Interestingly enough, since Career Girls came out, I have frequently been stopped by people in the street saying how much they liked it and were moved by it. And these have invariably been women of around 30 or under. When Topsy Turvy was reviewed a fortnight ago in the national press, a number of middle-aged male critics were rude about Career Girls.

Neil0123
Do you ever suffer from excessive interference in post-production and as each film is produced, do you gain more or less control?

ML
I'm extremely lucky in having had absolute control over my films throughout my film-making career. I always have final cut. This means that in production, or indeed post-production, we are left to get on with it in a truly creative and proper way. Of course, there are times when other people - backers, etc - do make suggestions, and sometimes these are very useful. But for the most part, the freedom and the independence is a major element. All this is helped considerably by the extraordinary abilities of Simon Channing-Williams, who is my producer and who has a great capacity to protect the production from negative interference.

Horatio001
Your famous constructive rehearsals seem to enable you to get performances from actors that no other directors come close to. Do you have any plans to tell the world your secret and write a book that explains the dynamic?

ML
The secret recipe will go with me to my grave. Information as to the precise location of the cemetery will be posted here in due course. Please bring Wellingtons.

Horatio001
Will you be taking the recipe to your grave, a) because revealing the artifice might diminish your films?, b) Because you also like to keep the actors in the dark, and if they knew the recipe it might not work? Or c) Because you're a selfish bastard and you can't be bothered to write a book. And What colour Wellingtons would you prefer?

ML
Rumbled! I am indeed a selfish bastard, and I'd rather stay in bed all day with a ----- than write a book such as you want.

EDShane
Mike, I was reading a book on the history of the Unity Theatre and noticed how you were involved with a group called Dramograph. This prompts three questions:
How did you get involved with them?
Why did Dramograph allegedly (according to the book) not pay for hiring the Goldington Street Theatre?
Has your experience of the Dramograph group ever had any experience on your films?

ML
Dramograph was formed by me and David Halliwell specifically and exclusively to stage the original production of his play Little Malcolm and His Struggle Against the Eunochs in March 1965. He played Malcolm Scrawdyke (which Ewan McGregor did again recently), and I directed and designed the production. I would love to be able to claim that I was properly involved in the Unity Theatre, which was a great socialist movement, but the truth is that we simply hired the theatre for the Dramograph production. The show was a total flop - very good reviews but nobody came to see it, and the reason we took a long time to pay for the hire is because we didn't have any dosh.

Luce28
Mike, do you see your films as pure entertainment, or do you see them as being social commentary? The reason I ask is that I think some people get films (as an art form) mixed up with documentaries and make assumptions about "messages" that may or may not be there. I would guess that nine times out of ten the assumption is incorrect. Just how irritating is it when someone misses the point of a film you have made?

ML
If a film isn't entertaining, it's a turkey. I hope mine are entertaining. However, for a film to be truly entertaining - that is, really interesting - it has to be about things that the audience can relate to or care about. So it seems natural to tell stories about real life and the way we live it. I agree that some people confuse the notion with the concept of documentaries. I don't make documentaries, although there is a level at which I try in my films to aspire to the condition of documentary - that is, to make you feel you are watching something that really is as real as a documentary.

Davek
It occurs to me that Kathy Burke has never been in any of your films. Is she someone you would like to work with? I consider her to be as talented as people like Alison Steadman or Brenda Blethyn.

ML
I have worked with Kathy Burke. She played the main character, Nell, in It's a Great Big Shame!, which was my last stage production, done at the Theatre Royal, Stratford East, in 1993. She is one of my favourite actresses, although it is of course a total coincidence that I was on the jury at Cannes in 1997 when she was awarded Best Actress for her role in Nil By Mouth!

That's all folks. Sorry, I've got to go and talk to a man regarding a dog walking past an abattoir. (And the boys will be round later, Datta.)

Datta
I won't be answering the door to any hired goons tonight then.

Unanswered stragglers

Alison1234
What comes after Topsy Turvy?

AndyMoore
Are you able to offer advice on what to do with a 60-minute drama shot on Super-16 by a first time director that no festival seems to be interested in (due to its length, I suppose)? Seems a bit of a waste otherwise. An honest appraisal of it being that it's good, but not amazing. Yours wonderingly.

Ollyf2
He's gone.

SpankTM
Ladies and gentleman, Mike Leigh has left the building. Thanks for a very enjoyable hour, Mike.

Afterwords

Nac1
I like Mike Leigh's films, but I've come across very few directors who take criticism so hard. I was at the NFT interview in November and noticed how quickly he got angry, rounding on a few of his interrogators as if they were imbeciles (perhaps they were - but most creative people in the public eye have more tolerance for dumb questions). I think Naked is THE best British film of the last decade and one of the top ten worldwide, but the caricaturing of certain types is a weakness in that and other films.

Datta
I've re-read the thread, and I think I was out of order a couple of times (and I would have been less aggressive face-to-face). But I didn't expect Mike Leigh to treat my valid and pertinent questions as if they were the Tourettes outbursts of a trained attack-prostitute.

Withnail20
Yeah. Seemed like a jolly nice chap but a bit over-sensitive to criticism.

Has your experience of the Dramograph group ever had any experience on your films? ML Dramograph was formed by me and David Halliwell specifically and exclusively to stage the original production of his play Little Malcolm and His Struggle Against the Eunochs in March 1965. He played Malcolm Scrawdyke (which Ewan McGregor did again recently), and I directed and designed the production. I would love to be able to claim that I was properly involved in the Unity Theatre, which was a great socialist movement, but the truth is that we simply hired the theatre for the Dramograph production. The show was a total flop - very good reviews but nobody came to see it, and the reason we took a long time to pay for the hire is because we didn't have any dosh. Luce28 Mike, do you see your films as pure entertainment, or do you see them as being social commentary? The reason I ask is that I think some people get films (as an art form) mixed up with documentaries and make assumptions about "messages" that may or may not be there. I would guess that nine times out of ten the assumption is incorrect. Just how irritating is it when someone misses the point of a film you have made? ML If a film isn't entertaining, it's a turkey. I hope mine are entertaining. However, for a film to be truly entertaining - that is, really interesting - it has to be about things that the audience can relate to or care about. I don't make documentaries, although there is a level at which I try in my films to aspire to the condition of documentary - that is, to make you feel you are watching something that really is as real as a documentary. She is one of my favourite actresses, although it is of course a total coincidence that I was on the jury at Cannes in 1997 when she was awarded Best Actress for her role in Nil By Mouth! That's all folks. Sorry, I've got to go and talk to a man regarding a dog walking past an abattoir. (And the boys will be round later, Datta.) Datta I won't be answering the door to any hired goons tonight then. Unanswered stragglers Alison1234 What comes after Topsy Turvy? AndyMoore Are you able to offer advice on what to do with a 60-minute drama shot on Super-16 by a first time director that no festival seems to be interested in (due to its length, I suppose)? I was at the NFT interview in November and noticed how quickly he got angry, rounding on a few of his interrogators as if they were imbeciles (perhaps they were - but most creative people in the public eye have more tolerance for dumb questions). I think Naked is THE best British film of the last decade and one of the top ten worldwide, but the caricaturing of certain types is a weakness in that and other films. Datta I've re-read the thread, and I think I was out of order a couple of times (and I would have been less aggressive face-to-face). But I didn't expect Mike Leigh to treat my valid and pertinent questions as if they were the Tourettes outbursts of a trained attack-prostitute. Withnail20 Yeah. Seemed like a jolly nice chap but a bit over-sensitive to criticism.

webTitle: Tories take Ayr as Labour loses first Scottish test

fields.headline: Tories take Ayr as Labour loses first Scottish test
fields.standfirst: Devolution in Scotland: special report
fields.trailText: The Conservatives last night reclaimed Ayr in the first byelection for the Scottish parliament as Labour was pushed into third place behind the Scottish National party.
fields.body:
The Conservatives last night reclaimed Ayr in the first byelection for the Scottish parliament as Labour was pushed into third place behind the Scottish National party.

John Scott secured a 3,000 majority over the SNP's Jim Mather in what is a traditional Tory stronghold. The result is significant for the party, which had not had a straight win in any parliamentary contest in Scotland since 1992 and had not won a byelection there since 1967.

"The Scottish Conservatives are back in business in Scottish politics," said David McLetchie, the leader of the Scottish Conservatives.

The result is embarrassing for Labour, whose campaign suffered from growing disillu sionment with the performance of the executive and accusations that the party has lost touch with core voters.

Labour blamed the defeat on mid-term blues and the high profile campaign against its planned repeal in Scotland of legislation banning promotion of homosexuality in schools.

The count:

John Scott

Conservative 12,580

Jim Mather

Scottish Nationalist 9,236

Rita Miller

Labour 7,054

James Stewart

Scottish Socialist 1,345

Stuart Ritchie

Liberal Democrat 800

fields.headline: Cash in the piggy bank
fields.standfirst: The government has made a commitment to end child poverty within 20 years but to succeed the processes must be speeded up
fields.trailText: A year ago the prime minister said he wanted "ours to be the first generation to end child poverty. It is a 20-year mission". Thus Labour made cutting the number of poor children a central objective of its first term.
fields.body:
A year ago the prime minister said he wanted "ours to be the first generation to end child poverty. It is a 20-year mission". Thus Labour made cutting the number of poor children a central objective of its first term.

In 1997/8 more than 3m children were living below half the mean income level. That is one in four children and it is three times more than in 1979. In its first year New Labour did little to tackle the problem. Since then Gordon Brown has given it priority. First there was an attempt to alter income levels directly through tax and benefits. The aim: to give extra to those who need it most, through working families tax credit (WFTC), higher child benefit and child tax credit.

Second, Labour's New Deal promoted paid work, giving parents help and incentives to find it. Paid work is seen as the best long-term route to financial independence. The third focus has been to tackle long-term disadvantage, for example by reducing teenage pregnancy.

We found that the combined effect of changes in tax and benefit since 1997 (including the minimum wage) has been to increase incomes of the poorest more than those of the better-off and of households with children more than others. Nine out of 10 children are living in households where income has gone up compared with one in 10 who are worse off.

Overall the household income of the poorest fifth of children has increased by more than 8%. By 2002 the proportion of children in poverty (defining that as below 50% of mean income before housing costs) will fall by 6 percentage points. That is 840,000 children: 540,000 in two-parent and 300,000 in one-parent families.

The government is focusing on increasing the number of families (with children) who have paid work. At maximum, this could cut poverty dramatically - double the reduction achieved thanks to changes in taxes and benefits and the minimum wage alone. This strategy requires work to be made more financially attractive. But for many the gains from earning are modest and the impact of Labour's policies is not uniformly positive. Lone parents now returning to work and earning around £100 a week are certainly better off in work than not. But the increase in their income would be less than it would have been under the policy Labour inherited from the Tories in 1997. This result stems from the effects of abolishing lone parent benefit and interactions between WFTC and benefits.

Finding paid work for all families with school-age children would involve a major expansion of employment by 1.5m. Actual prospects for growth in the number of parents with paid work are uncertain. If, say, an additional 250,000 found jobs, this would reduce the number of children living in poverty by about 160,000. Labour would then have succeeded in cutting the child poverty total by 1m - one third of the number now.

Mr Brown's approach has been to concentrate resources on the poor by means of greater selectivity and means-testing. But more support for the poorest, which is then rapidly withdrawn as they earn higher sums from work, serves to extend the poverty trap - even if its extremes are smoothed out. The danger arises of creating a two-class world. One is inhabited by poor families with no or low pay who receive large amounts of income support or WFTC. The other contains not-very-well-off families who receive little state support. If the condition of the poorest families is improved but not that of other families with below-average incomes, then the incentive to self-help will inevitably decline. Thus, while the New Labour approach emphasises responsibilities and emphasises the desirability of more self-reliance, its selective strategy may be undermining what it seeks to encourage.

To make work pay more than it does now brings unpalatable but inescapable choices for the social security system. Income support levels for those not working might be cut in relative terms. This will happen over time if uprating is not in line with other incomes. This will of course add to child poverty. Alternatively, benefits to those in low paid work (such as WFTC) will be increased. If this is done only for those on very low earnings, the means-testing involved will exacerbate the poverty trap discouraging self-reliance; if higher benefits are spread to higher earnings levels, the cost to the exchequer will be greatly increased and can only be met by explicit redistributional tax policies.

The promotion of paid work is not, however, only a matter of financial incentives. It also involves child care, transport and family-friendly employment. The difficulties and stress - impinging on both parents and children - that result from combining paid work and childcare will only be marginally affected by Labour's reforms thus far.

Reducing child poverty by 1m will be a most significant achievement. But caution is necessary on several fronts. First, those raised out of poverty tend to be those closest to the poverty level. Second, for child poverty actually to fall by this amount depends on unemployment being kept down. Third, the extent of child poverty would remain extremely high by post-war British and European standards. Child poverty would still be twice as high as when Labour was last in office, as the chart shows. To abolish child poverty in a generation it will be necessary to accelerate change and achieve further transfers to families with children.

Nevertheless, by focusing on the income and opportunities of the poorest, a start has been made. In next week's budget the chancellor has to raise benefits in line with the increase in incomes at large - anything else puts the gains for poor families in jeopardy. Mr Brown has bravely said he will not rest "until we have banished child poverty from the face of Britain". There are still miles to go before he sleeps.

· David Piachaud is professor of social policy at the LSE and Holly Sutherland is director of Cambridge University's micro simulation unit. Details from CASE paper 38, at http://sticerd.lse.ac.uk/case

webTitle: Only the family veto can save BMW now

fields.headline: Only the family veto can save BMW now
fields.standfirst:
Damage limitation begins

Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: BMW's strategy lies in ruins. Its hopes of using the Rover group to achieve critical mass in the car industry have been reduced to looking for as graceful an exit as possible, a new Mini and a plan to build its own car at the top end of the lower mid-range.
fields.body:
BMW's strategy lies in ruins. Its hopes of using the Rover group to achieve critical mass in the car industry have been reduced to looking for as graceful an exit as possible, a new Mini and a plan to build its own car at the top end of the lower mid-range.

Even the future of Land Rover looks uncertain, given BMW's refusal - at least yesterday - to answer suggestions that it is to be sold.

All that after pouring billions of pounds into a business - yesterday's restructuring programme, which is little more than a damage limitation exercise, will mean a one-off charge of more than €3bn - it appears to be having to pay someone else to take it away.

Little wonder the internal battle over Rover claimed another three BMW directors yesterday.

So where are we now? The government must be relieved that at least someone else has stepped forward to take on the Rover car business.

The prospect of a Longbridge closure at a time when the government is being criticised for not doing enough for Labour's heartlands would be too much even for the Millbank spin doctors. But it will get plenty of flak all the same.

Alchemy has emerged as a timely white knight - but it now has to show it has the skills, resources, strategy and connections elsewhere in the motor industry to put the Rover car business on a sound, long-term footing.

There are harder tasks, no doubt but in the motor industry, at least, it is hard to think of one.

The strong pound will not go away and the new MG Car Company will have to cope with the consequences of a product offensive in the shape of the 25, 45 and 75 models which BMW itself acknowledged yesterday "was not as successful as we had hoped".

Alchemy will do well to achieve this goal - natural enough for a venture capital group hopeful of finding a profitable exit within the next five or six years.

As for BMW, its problems are far from over. Although yesterday's figures show the group's sales are doing well, the group had a tricky Rover exit strategy to manage and will need to rebuild confidence that - once Rover is off the hook - it has a viable strategy to remain profitable and independent.

On the basis of judging whether another company could manage BMW better than it has managed itself, the German car maker's days of independence would probably be numbered. Only the Quandt family's controlling shareholding stands between BMW and a posse of predators itching to get their hands on what is still one of the most sought-after marques in the business.

Fat cats' return

Not too long ago, news that a British executive had had his or her regular pay increased by close to a third to £1.5m, with an extra £2.5m in free shares due in a few months' time - together with £5m more in a couple of years' time - would have had us all gasping.

Steaming shareholders would have turned up at the annual general meeting with caricatures of the greedy recipient - remember Cedric the Pig? The unions would be banging on about fat controllers rewarding themselves for their ability to sack people. Pressure groups would be lobbying institutional investors to use their vote as a protest.

But not any more. One aspect of globalisation has been the quiet realisation that if we want British companies to compete, they need top-quality staff and top employees, executive or otherwise, cost top dollar.

So the guidelines on expected corporate conduct in terms of pay, built up over the years of the media's fascination with the fat cat trend, are now being ignored with increasing frequency.

Earlier this month, in its annual report, Reuters came out to say that, if it was going to compete in a sector that is changing at extraordinary speed, institutional shareholders - as represented by the likes of the Association of British Insurers - had better start rethinking their insistence that the award of share options in British companies should always reflect a substantial element of performance.

BP Amoco - where all the executives are now reaping the rewards from an extraordinary transformation of the group over the past two years - has not gone as far as Reuters in its latest annual report, out today.

But it has given its executive remuneration process a complete overhaul, with a view to any future awards reflecting what is going on elsewhere in the world rather than what is going on at home.

This appears to be an irresistible trend. But it is a trend that demands a much more proactive approach from large shareholders.

Big rewards for big success have never really rankled. But rewards for failure always have and always will.

webTitle: Longbridge  Deal will put Alchemy's Midas touch to severest test

fields.headline: Longbridge  Deal will put Alchemy's Midas touch to severest test
fields.standfirst: Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: Jon Moulton set up his own venture capital business, Alchemy Partners, in 1997 so he could be free to tackle difficult deals which other firms did not dare contemplate.
fields.body:
Jon Moulton set up his own venture capital business, Alchemy Partners, in 1997 so he could be free to tackle difficult deals which other firms did not dare contemplate.

He already had a reputation for taking companies with heavy losses or few prospects and turning them into money-spinners.

In this respect, at least, he is unlike the medieval alchemists after which his business is named. They failed to find a way of turning base metals into gold.

Mr Moulton claims to have created at least 200 millionaires during his career as a venture capitalist. He said yesterday that his first priority would be to cut costs as Rover - a move which will send a chill down the spine of the workforce which has already seen thousands of jobs axed over the last two years.

"We are are going to reduce the cost base to a level where the company generates cash rather than eats it."

Alchemy had ample finan cial resources and, contrary to rumours, Volkswagen was not involved. He declined to give any financial details but said he expected the deal to be completed within six weeks.

Mr Moulton's first big coup was a £50m management buyout of Parker Pens, which was floated seven years later for £312m. During that period Parker moved from losses of £20m a year to profits of £40m a year.

A Parker Pen advertisement, which states 'The pen is mightier than the sword' hangs on the wall behind Mr Moulton's desk. He also masterminded the management buyout of RJB Mining, which owns the rump of Britain's coal mining industry.

However, Alchemy's ambitious plan to take over Allied Carpets in 1999 ended in acrimony after talks broke down. Alchemy claimed it had not been given sufficient informa tion about Allied's financial position.

In 1997, in a move which has echoes of yesterday's deal with BMW, Alchemy relieved Boots of its loss-making Fads and Homestyle DIY chains for a token £1. It acquired assets worth £57m, changed the entire management team within weeks, installed new systems and cut overheads. The DIY business was back in profit within four months.

Mr Moulton believes that choosing the right management team is the key to success. Once that is done, he is keen to leave the managing to them and get on with the next deal.

He first worked in insolvency as an accountant with Coopers & Lybrand. Mr Moulton then moved into the venture capital business with Schroder Ventures, where he was managing partner for nine years before leaving in 1994 to join Apax Partners.

He set up Alchemy Partners in 1997, with offices in Covent Garden rather than in the City. The financial muscle is provided by City institutions.

Mr Moulton, who owns a Mini, eschews the trappings of the big financiers. He commutes from his home in a private road in Sevenoaks.

The Rover deal will catapult Alchemy into a completely different league. The firm has no previous experience of the motor industry. Making a success of Rover will be the making or breaking of Mr Moulton.

webTitle: Asset stripper? Not me, says the man who will scrap Rover

fields.headline: Asset stripper? Not me, says the man who will scrap Rover
fields.standfirst: Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: Thousands of car workers face redundancy after BMW carved up Rover, effectively paying venture capitalists £2bn to take a large part of the company off its hands and putting Land Rover up for sale.
fields.byline: Kevin Maguire  and Mark Milner  in Munich
fields.body:
Thousands of car workers face redundancy after BMW carved up Rover, effectively paying venture capitalists £2bn to take a large part of the company off its hands and putting Land Rover up for sale.

The German car company dismembered one of the most famous marques in British motoring as Downing Street admitted the government was powerless to intervene.

Tony Blair and Stephen Byers, the industry secretary, last night held crisis talks at No10 with union leaders amid fears of a political backlash in key West Midlands marginals.

On his way into the meeting, Bill Morris, the T&G transport union general secretary, said: "There are 50,000 people in the West Midlands tonight who are looking for some real answers as to how we got into this position. The workers have been bought and sold overnight - it could not happen in Germany."

After the Downing Street meeting, Sir Ken Jackson, of the Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union, said Mr Blair was "as angry as we are". He added: "He has given us an assurance that the government will do anything possible to safeguard as many jobs as possible in the Midlands. They will move heaven and earth to make sure this company has got the resources to do what it says."

BMW is to write off huge debts and pay Alchemy partners an undisclosed "sweetener" to take over the troubled Longbridge plant which makes Rover's 25, 45, MGF sports car and old Mini models.

The Munich-based company is to produce the 75 executive saloon under licence for Alchemy - which has named its acquistion the MG Car Company - at Cowley.

Union negotiators revealed that a "main player in the car industry" had already offered to buy the four-wheel drive Solihull plant, making Land Rovers and Range Rovers.

Industry sources and a West Midlands Tory MP named Ford as the would-be purchaser but there was no confirmation from that company.

Alchemy's managing partner, Jon Moulton, who rescued the Fatty Arbuckles restaurant chain and Fads DIY stores, angrily denied it would asset-strip Rover.

Bragging that he already drove a Mini, Mr Moulton admitted there would be cuts at the 8,500-job Longbridge plant but maintained it had a future. "We are going to be able to sustain a significant workforce at Longbridge. The workforce will be in rewarding and enjoyable jobs with some security," he said. "Not all of them will be in that position but a good number will be."

Union leaders who hope to speak to Mr Moulton today, however, fear it will be run down and be little more than a niche specialist MG sports car manufacturer when put back on the market in five or six years time.

The chief car negotiator for the T&G transport union, Tony Woodley, threatened industrial action as bitterness over BMW was fuelled by fears that Alchemy will impose huge job losses.

"We can see the loss of tens of thousands of British jobs and the break-up of the largest of the British car manufacturing companies. This is the bleakest day in British manufacturing industry," said Mr Woodley.

"They are proposing to completely break up and destroy Rover cars as we know it and they are proposing to sell off not only Rover cars but Land Rover as well, which leads ultimately to the complete destruction of a once great, proud, British car manufacturing company."

Fears that Alchemy will eventually pull out of the volume car market were fuelled by a statement suggesting that any research and development investment will be in new sports models.

"The new company will focus on development of a state-of-the-art British-built product range worthy of the sporting heritage of the MG name," said the company.

BMW is to transfer an assembly line for a new Mini from Longbridge to Cowley which it retains along with, at least for now, Solihull and the Swindon body plant.

Mr Blair's official spokesman, Alastair Campbell, admitted the government had "a difficulty in getting clear and reliable information from BMW" while Mr Byers, who will visit Longbridge today, admitted he had been kept in the dark.

BMW's chief executive, Prof Joachim Milberg, attempted to pin part of the blame on the high value of the pound as the company admitted defeat five years and £3bn after gazumping Honda to buy Rover.

"With exchange rates versus the pound continuing to decline, mass producers on the European continent have a growing advantage in competition," said Prof Milberg. "Precisely this is why the board of management has decided to take a clear and consistent step. Even with an extreme increase in productivity or through an extreme shift in sourcing into Euroland, we would no longer have been able to set off such burdens beyond our control."

The gloom of Longbridge's workforce was in sharp contrast to the relief at Cowley as BMW pledged to build the new Minis at the east Oxford plant.

webTitle: People are sick of Mugabe but unsure who else to vote for

fields.headline: People are sick of Mugabe but unsure who else to vote for
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: Most Zimbabweans are fed up with President Robert Mugabe's leadership and 63% believe "it is time for a change", according to a Gallup poll conducted last month.
fields.body:
Most Zimbabweans are fed up with President Robert Mugabe's leadership and 63% believe "it is time for a change", according to a Gallup poll conducted last month.

The poll found that 65% of people believe Mr Mugabe should step down as president. But while sentiment against his government is high, most people are uncertain who to vote for in parliamentary elections due in April. A core of 35% is committed to voting for Mr Mugabe's party, while only 17% say they will back the new opposition Movement for Democratic Change. The remaining 48% are undecided.

The issues that concern most people are the poor economy, 60% inflation rate and falling living standards, according to the poll, funded by the Helen Suzman Foundation of South Africa. Most people do not think land ownership or the role of whites is important. The poll interviewed 1,900 Zimbabweans around the country.

With so much discontent, the ruling Zanu-PF party might be expected to face a difficult time in the elections. But the fairness of the ballot is threatened by a partisan police force, the government's control of voting procedures and officially sanctioned threats of violence, according to a report released today by a human rights group based in London, Africa Rights.

The police have turned a blind eye to crimes committed by Mr Mugabe's supporters - including the invasion of white-owned farms - choosing instead to harass opposition supporters and press "spurious charges" against them, the report says.

The police actions "promote the belief among Zanu-PF members that they can act with impunity", African Rights warns.

The report, entitled Zimbabwe's 2000 Elections: Making and Breaking the Rules, states that Mr Mugabe and his supporters have used intimidating language that could discourage people from voting freely. The state media have promoted these statements.

This was dramatically illustrated yesterday in a front-page story in the Herald newspaper, in which a leader of the veterans' association, Andrew Ndlovu, stated that his group would "declare war and institute a military government" if the opposition were to win the elections. They had already declared war on white farmers, he added.

The director of African Rights, Rakiya Omaar, said it was "extremely disappointing to note that the government continues to try to make electoral capital out of the land issue, rather than implementing a viable and sustainable programme for land reform, which is so badly needed".

Ms Omaar went on: "The notion that the farm occupations might lead to a better life, either for the war veterans taking part or for the rest of Zimbabwe's poor, is plainly false."

fields.headline: Store beats PlayStation 2 export ban
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: It's not just the sushi bars that have brought a taste of Tokyo to central London. Last week saw the first signs of "PlayStation mania", repeating scenes in Japan of video game fans queuing overnight to be first to buy Sony's next-generation console.
fields.body:
It's not just the sushi bars that have brought a taste of Tokyo to central London. Last week saw the first signs of "PlayStation mania", repeating scenes in Japan of video game fans queuing overnight to be first to buy Sony's next-generation console.

But the crowd gathered last week was not in front of Sony's shop in Tottenham Court Road. It was around the corner, blocking the pavement in front of the smaller, less well-known Computer Exchange branch, which claimed to be first to sell PlayStation 2 to the British public.

Using contacts built up over years of importing Japanese games and equipment, the company managed to dodge Sony's ban on export sales of the new console. Four days after the official Japanese launch, the chain was offering its first batch of PlayStation 2s on its website (www.cex.co.uk) and in nine stores for £999 - £700 more than Sony is expected to charge when it starts sales in this country in September.

The new machine promises to be a big hit in the UK, judging by sales of the original PlayStation, which since launch six years ago has captured the lion's share of the £1bn spent on computer games every year. But the updated PlayStation offers more than just games. It has a DVD drive, allowing it to double as a home movie player, and the addition of a modem allows connection to the internet. No wonder software group Microsoft has identified Sony and the PlayStation as a big threat to its PC empire.

Even now what is at stake is Sony's grip on the UK's computer games market, a huge leisure industry; cinema attendances bring in a mere £570m, according to Screen Digest. The UK is by far the largest market for video games in Europe - twice as big as nearest rival France - with more than one in five households already owning a PlayStation console.

By the end of last year, 16.5m had been sold in Europe, 5m of them in the UK.

"It's a maturing market - it's not just kids any more," said Ciaran Barr, chief UK economist at Deutsche Bank in London. "The computer games market is going to continue to have growth rates well above the rest of the UK retail sector - especially when it goes online." Mr Barr owns a PlayStation, as well as its Sega and Nintendo rivals. So will he be buying the new PlayStation? "I certainly will."

Mark Lewis, Computer Exchange's director of controls, is cagey about how many PSX2s (as aficionados call the new console) his company has sold but suggests the figure is around 100, with more shipments from Japanese suppliers on the way. The company is coy about who is supplying the hardware from Japan because Sony has threatened retaliation against suppliers to the informal "grey market".

Mr Lewis stresses that its imports are legal but adds: "I think it's fair to say we're not much liked by Sony." He recalls gleefully that some of the crowd who came to see the new machine were from the Sony showroom around the corner.

Guy Pearce, PR manager for Sony Computer Entertainment Europe, said his company was resigned to grey market imports. He estimated as many as 10,000 consoles could be imported by the time official sales start. "There will always be a hard core who will pay almost anything to get one."

But not for long. At Computer Exchange the price has dropped already to £699.

fields.headline: Share offer
fields.standfirst:
Lane-Fox wants to promote e-commerce for Blair

New Labour in power: special report
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Martha Lane-Fox, the multi-millionaire co-founder of Lastminute.com, has proposed herself to Tony Blair as an agent to promote e-commerce.
fields.body:
Martha Lane-Fox, the multi-millionaire co-founder of Lastminute.com, has proposed herself to Tony Blair as an agent to promote e-commerce.

The revelation was made yesterday by Tim Jackson, non-executive director of QXL.Com, another leading e-company.

Mr Jackson referred to Ms Lane-Fox's offer to make herself available as a new government adviser when he spoke at a meeting in Downing Street on Wednesday night attended by Mr Blair, the Dutch prime minister Wim Kok and some of the leading internet start-up high fliers. Mr Jackson said Ms Lane-Fox had made the offer the last time he had been in Downing Street to see the prime minister.

No 10 refused to comment on whether it would take up the apparent offer from Ms Lane-Fox, 27, who has amassed a paper fortune of over £40m off the back of her still loss-making internet bucket shop. They conceded Ms Lane Fox had been to Downing Street for a business seminar and said they look at interesting ideas all the time.

Some have suggested that the serious internet entrepreneurs are jaundiced about the success of Ms Lane-Fox who does not come from a computer or business background.

Mr Blair has already appointed an e-envoy, Alex Allen, a former Downing Street civil servant, but his aides said they recognised the importance of the internet industry.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: • In all the speculation about who is behind the revelations of Ken Livingstone's earnings, you cannot escape the name of Shaun Woodward. A few weeks ago, the Blairite Express reported that - as a senior figure at Tory central office while dirt on Ken was being compiled - Shaun might be Mr Tony's "secret weapon". We can't be sure until the categorical denial from Downing Street, but the circumstantial evidence is interesting.
fields.body:
 In all the speculation about who is behind the revelations of Ken Livingstone's earnings, you cannot escape the name of Shaun Woodward. A few weeks ago, the Blairite Express reported that - as a senior figure at Tory central office while dirt on Ken was being compiled - Shaun might be Mr Tony's "secret weapon". We can't be sure until the categorical denial from Downing Street, but the circumstantial evidence is interesting.

The go-between who brought Shaun together with Mr Tony and facilitated the defection was Ann Keen, the Brentford MP who doubles as one of Dobbo's lieutenants (oooh, she's a grand lass!). It might equally be coincidence that Shaun was first quoted promising to shop Ken to the standards committee on December 1, when already planning to defect and two days before he first met Mr T. And a day after he formally joined Labour, the letter of complaint - which its alleged author John Jones denies writing - was sent. Ah well, perhaps we'll be able to see how helpful he's been by how safe a seat he gets at the election (unless there's a government job first).

 In the Mirror, meanwhile, thunderous prophet Paul Routledge pulls no punches. "The unpleasant truth is that he probably makes £200,000 a year - a staggering fourteen times the earnings of a London bus driver." Thank God that the Mirror continues to defend old-fashioned, socialist, puritan values, of the kind best expressed by lightning forays into volatile shares. And thank God that when someone needs a kicking for making loadsamoney, Routers - the man who once flashed his Skipton bank book (credit: £204,000) at Oofy Wegg-Prosser - is there to deliver it. Perhaps the real problem for Ken is that he, unlike some people, does not have a wife in whose name to put the assets.

 The Theatre Royal in Bath, most genteel of book tour locations, announces its line up of authors for early summer. What a distinguished bunch. Lord Bragg will be there in May, and soprano Lesley Garrett and Feargal Keane in June. But hark, who is this kicking off the season? Strike me pink, it's Jonathan Aitken! Not content with chatting with Frost and Paxo, he plans to titillate the gentle folk of Bath with tales from From Trading Arms To Trading Snout: How God's Love Cleansed My Soul (Mendax Books, £24.99). We may buy some £10-tickets for Friday May 5 at noon (£20 with a poached salmon lunch thrown in) for competition prizes - in the knowledge that every penny will go to creditors.

 I am sad to learn that Westminster Council persecutes that much abused minority, the naturist web surfer. The council has shut down a special "nude night" at Nutopia, a new Covent Garden cybercafe. Following complaints from neighbours, council officers were so disgusted by the theme night that they only visited on two further occasions before issuing the warning under some decency law. Have these luddite buffoons no idea how much time it wastes exploring cyberporn when clothed?

 Following Tuesday's item recapping Alastair Campbell's official designation of all Guardian staff (half are "Trots", half are "wankers", David Hencke is "a nutter", I am "a c***"), there is news of two shock refinements. My colleague Stephen Bates reports that, after he criticised government EU policy once, Ali told a third party: "Bates isn't a Trot or a wanker. He's just a tosser." Myself, I seem to have become a hybrid. A journalist elsewhere reports meeting Ali at a conference. "You're not from the f****** Guardian Diary, are you?" he began. "F****** wankers. I nearly sued that c***." Ah, the British civil service at its elegant best.

 Two days after it suffered that calamitous libel defeat to ITN, Living Marxism's latest edition arrives. "It is the best of times to be alive," reads the front page headline. "Ever." Mmm.

fields.trailText: Emap yesterday announced plans to spend £250m building an internet business around its magazine empire and suffered the ignominy of an attendant 12% slide in its share price.
fields.body:
Emap yesterday announced plans to spend £250m building an internet business around its magazine empire and suffered the ignominy of an attendant 12% slide in its share price.

The group, which publishes 150 titles including best-selling men's magazine FHM, music monthly Q and entertainment weekly Heat, is developing websites around both consumer and business brands. It hopes to drive revenues through advertising, sponsorship and e-commerce.

Emap shares fell 183p to £13.16 in stark contrast to similar announcements from the likes of BSkyB, Pearson and Reuters which have sent the companies' respective share prices soaring.

Analysts said Emap had been the victim of bad timing as market sentiment turned against internet and media stocks in general.

Emap's chief executive, Kevin Hand, said he was "absolutely confident" the price would come back after the City properly digested the media group's plans. The group intends to spend £75m this year largely on development costs, more staff and marketing with the rest of the cash funding the enterprises until March 2003.

A new division, Emap Digital, has been set up to house the internet business and the group has spent £10m or so establishing 42 websites, which have some 2.5m monthly users. The fund will also be used to invest in other online businesses.

Emap is attempting to create online markets for recruitment and supply chain management around some of its business titles in industries including construction and TV production. Staff will be offered share options in the wider Emap group, although some of the larger businesses may eventually be spun off on to the stock market.

"There are massive opportunities for a group like Emap in the digital environment and we fully intend to take them," said Mr Hand.

"We are extremely well positioned in certain markets. In music we have 50% of the sector's readership through magazines like Q, Smash Hits, Mojo and Select and can cross-promote on our radio stations and The Box on TV. We have fantastic marketing muscle."

Putting the businesses into a separate division would improve transparency and help in the establishment of joint ventures, alliances or access to capital markets he said.

One media analyst said the drop in Emap's share price was a reflection of the uncertainties gripping the market.

webTitle: Lib Dems urge 50p tax on rich

fields.headline: Lib Dems urge 50p tax on rich
fields.standfirst: Chancellor's pre-budget speech: special report
fields.trailText: A 50p in the pound tax on Britain's highest earners is proposed by the Liberal Democrats in an alternative budget intended to challenge chancellor Gordon Brown to choose between tax cuts and investment in public services.
fields.body:
A 50p in the pound tax on Britain's highest earners is proposed by the Liberal Democrats in an alternative budget intended to challenge chancellor Gordon Brown to choose between tax cuts and investment in public services.

An estimated 204,000 people with an annual income of over £100,000 would fall into the new top bracket, raising £2.6bn a year, according to the document published by Lib Dem treasury spokesman Matthew Taylor.

The party would use the money to cut the tax burden for those on low incomes by abolishing the 10% tax band, taking 1.4m people out of tax completely. They would also reverse all further tax cuts introduced by Labour, including a 1p cut in the basic rate due to come into force next month.

The Lib Dem leader, Charles Kennedy, yesterday accused the Conservatives and Labour of holding a "Dutch auction on who can cut taxes the most when the British people want better funding for public services".

Mr Taylor will seek to portray Tuesday's budget as a "litmus test" of Labour's commitment to tax cutting or improving public services. Having cleared the £28bn deficit Labour inherited from the Tories, Mr Brown now had the chance to show his commitment to delivering better healthcare and education. The Lib Dems would reverse the 1p cut to fund a £2.65bn increase in spending on education. At the same time they would dip into the chancellor's estimated £7bn "war chest" to boost spending on the NHS.

The basic state pension would be increased by £2 a week with higher rises for the over 75s, funded from unspent social security reserves due to the fall in unemployment.

Mr Taylor said his proposals represented a slight "tightening" of the government's fiscal stance, and would not cause the Bank of England to raise interest rates.

webTitle: The world will stop for World Online

fields.headline: The world will stop for World Online
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Europe's biggest internet flotation will be launched today - and World Online's debut on the Amsterdam stock exchange will bring the rest of the market to a standstill.
fields.body:
Europe's biggest internet flotation will be launched today - and World Online's debut on the Amsterdam stock exchange will bring the rest of the market to a standstill.

The high profile initial public offering (IPO), understood to be 20 times oversubscribed, led bourse officials to say yesterday that they would probably temporarily suspend trading in all other stocks this morning.

To help stop the system being overloaded, the bourse will allow exchange seat holders to net and cumulate all orders at the same price. Rather ominously, the bourse statement added: "Should the above measures prove to be inadequate, Amsterdam exchanges reserves the right to take additional steps."

World Online shares, which are expected to be priced at the top end of the 35 eurp to 43 euro (£21.60 to £26.50) range, are trading at 85 euro on the grey market and are said to have reached as high as 130 euro. The IPO price would value the company at about 12bn euro - more than twice the value expected four months ago.

There are also market fears that the price, which would raise 2.9bn euro for World Online, will not last. Some analysts believe the shares could follow lines this week's e-newcomers Lastminute.com and Norway's StepStone which have tumbled since their first-day surge.

That might be related to profit-taking, but investors and analysts think the company might not meet expectations since the business model for free ISPs is unproven and is likely to be undermined by lower telecoms rates and flat-rate schemes.

"You might win a fortune, you might lose a fortune," Philip Lakelin, senior analyst at telecoms consultancy Analysys, said. "Their business model depends a lot on kick back revenues which everybody knows will disappear."

The Rotterdam company, launched in 1996, offers 1.5m customers free internet access in 14 European countries and in South Africa. It also has portal, e-commerce and business services.

It gets revenues mainly from dividing up telephone ticks with telecoms operators for metered time online. Revenues rose 283% to 64m euro in 1999 with internet usage, but unmetered access is becoming increasingly important. Analysts also questioned other revenue streams, including advertising.

fields.headline: All taxes are immoral
fields.standfirst: Chancellor's pre-budget speech: special report
fields.trailText: William Hague has hit exactly the right note on taxation. Pleas for lower taxes have been derided as "simply greed" by those who prefer to spend other people's money. By basing his case on the moral ground, Hague has opened up a clear gulf between his party and New Labour. What he offers is an alternative vision of the relationship between the individual and the government, a more equal relationship, and one which promotes moral growth.
fields.body:
William Hague has hit exactly the right note on taxation. Pleas for lower taxes have been derided as "simply greed" by those who prefer to spend other people's money. By basing his case on the moral ground, Hague has opened up a clear gulf between his party and New Labour. What he offers is an alternative vision of the relationship between the individual and the government, a more equal relationship, and one which promotes moral growth.

The chancellor's preference for stealth taxes turned out to bring only a temporary reprieve from public disquiet. We now know that the average taxpayer is £1,500 worse off each year, a rise of 2.5%. Brown denies this, assuming that all growth belongs to him, rather than to those who made it. His plea that company taxes should be excluded rather reminds one of Marion Barry, when Washington's mayor, claiming that his city actually had a low crime rate "if you didn't count the murders".

Of course company taxes fall on people. They pay the higher prices which taxes bring about, and they achieve less return on their investment. Whether the taxes are levied directly on people, or by stealth, the effect is the same. People have less to spend themselves because government is spending more of it instead.

Herein lies the immorality of taxation. Taxation means compulsion. Our habit of clothing it in fine words often conceals the brute fact that taxation is the confiscation of our property by people who prefer to spend it on their priorities rather than ours. Higher taxation means more compulsion. It forces further retreat by individuals from the area of their lives in which they can make decisions and assume responsibilities.

At the heart of the debate is the question of whether people are to live by their own values as adult citizens, or made to live according to the values of their government. Hague has opted for the former, and holds out the prospect of a more equal relationship in which citizens meet the government eye to eye and freely contract with it to discharge their obligations.

The United States has just seen its annual list of the top 100 lifetime benefactors. In the number one slot is George Soros, who has given away $2.65bn. The list includes Bill and Melinda Gates, rapidly making their way up its ranks, and even the actor Paul Newman, whose supermarket sauces pay every penny to charity. The US can be generous with its private charity because government leaves space for its citizens to do so. It takes 28% of their income each year, as against the 40% which our own treasury takes. Further, US tax laws allow full deduction for charitable gifts. This helps to explain why we give £7 a month, versus the equivalent of £17 given by Americans.

It is not just charity which is crowded out by the state. Whenever it undertakes a responsibility, it denies us the chance to assume it. If people are less inclined to care for their elderly relatives than before, it is because the state has convinced them that it is its job, not theirs. If people do not save enough to meet their future needs, it is because the state has spent decades telling them that it will take care of them instead.

Wherever government has advanced, individual responsibility has retreated. Now Hague is telling us it can be rolled back for moral reasons, to create a space in which people can grow. His guarantees are spot on.

By pledging that the overall tax burden will diminish, he tells us that we will undertake responsibility for a larger part of our lives. We will have the resources to make better provision for our relatives and for own own future. We will have the means to contribute to charitable causes, and to support those less fortunate than ourselves.

By pledging an end to stealth taxes, he is telling us that he intends to take away some of the cynicism and dishonesty which discredit government. If we are to pay taxes, he says, let them be open and understood and accepted. Gordon Brown has made it his style to rack up taxes by keeping them concealed and keeping taxpayers confused. William Hague plans to expose taxation, probably in the belief that if people know what they are paying, they will be less tolerant of the high tax culture, and the arrogant assumption that it will plan and organise our lives better than we can do it ourselves.

 Madsen Pirie is president of the Adam Smith Institute

fields.headline: Biting that tax bullet
fields.standfirst: Chancellor's pre-budget speech: special report
fields.trailText: As the budget looms, William Hague's bold tax-cutting claims have electrified opinion.
fields.body:
Thank you, William Hague. At last he has contributed something useful to the bloodless politics of these times. His lecture on the morality of taxation flushed out the government, forcing it to admit that tax has indeed risen since 1997. Once it had been admitted, the government had to justify it - and be proud of it. High time, too. No more stealth taxes, no more slipping large backhanders to the poor while hoping the Daily Mail isn't looking. It means that at last Labour can start to boast about how much money has gone to the pockets of the poor - this government's honourable first spending priority when it came to power, ahead of more popular and visible spending on schools and hospitals.

As a piece of elegant sophistry William Hague's speech is a masterpiece of the genre. Its daring humbug takes the breath away - Uriah Heep meets Ebeneezer Scrooge. "High taxes mean less freedom, less responsibility, less community, more dependency, a less elevated human condition," he said. Preposterously, he claimed high taxes stop people spending their money on training, saving, books for children and care for elderly parents. Nothing here about the boom in bars, restaurants, holidays, designer clothes and the whole mighty whoosh of consumerism among Britain's under-taxed high spenders.

The moral tax-cut comes, like many British political ideas, from across the Atlantic where last week I heard George W Bush define "compassionate conservatism" thus: "It is conservative to cut taxes, it is compassionate to give people their money back." It was obvious that Hague would rush to imitate Bush's great anti-tax campaign with its huge bribe to the voters ($2,000 a head minimum, much more for the rich). Hague reiterated his impossible "tax guarantee" pledge to cut the overall burden come what may. Toying with the idea that charity might replace welfare, he claimed that people would give more to charity if they paid less tax - notoriously not the case in the selfish spirit of Thatcher's 80s when giving dropped like a stone. "We will make tax a key battleground of the next election," he promised. "We must show that it is our Conservative low-tax agenda that is not just the basis of a dynamic economy but also the foundation of a moral, compassionate, free and just society."

Into this battleground steps the chancellor on Tuesday. The question this time will not only be "What's in the budget?" but also "What does he want people to think is in his budget?" Politically the message will matter almost as much as the money. It is not just Labour's grumbling heartlands that must be appeased, but the great concerned majority who may uneasily agree with William Hague's (self-defeating) observation that "public services are not getting any better. The NHS is locked in permanent crisis. Police numbers are falling and crime is rising. Our roads are gridlocked". In other words people do make the link between paying higher taxes and getting better services. If they are constantly told that taxes are not going up, they may be inclined to think the government isn't doing enough to mend the devastation in public services left by 20 years of underfunding - and they would be right. They may suspect that if it isn't hurting their own pockets, it probably isn't working. You get what you pay for. So the symbolism of the penny cut in income tax may may perversely work against the chancellor and not for him after all. Now suffering the backwash of his two-year spending freeze, many Labour MPs wonder if it was really necessary to get elected? We shall never know, but the price has been high.

Budgets are not what they were now that treasury getting and spending is separated. Only the July spending review will reveal how much is to be spent over the next three years on all the pressing needs around us. We do know Gordon Brown has a pile of money to spend - some £10bn - without raising any extra tax. Is it enough? There will be a steady increase for schools and hospitals - higher growth than ever before, but not quite a spending revolution. (Can it hit Blair's NHS promise to meet the EU average?) For when it comes to public spending there is no "enough". For example, imagine replacing every dismal, uninviting school with gleaming state-of-the-art buildings filled with unstressed, well-paid, state-of-the-art teachers, enjoyable places not just for children but enticing local people in to use computers, swimming pools, gyms, evening classes, art rooms, cafes and theatres for pleasing leisure. It's not an impossible dream. But only higher taxes could see such a progressive leap in public facilities. So the question is not how far Gordon Brown's existing war chest will go but whether he dare raise tax to the maximum? That is whatever the economy and employment can bear, whatever voters will wear once they see what the money can buy. High taxes well-spent are virtuous, but the case for taxation would have to be made boldly.

It's time to counter the Tory "stealth tax" charge by exposing the "stealth welfare state" of the rich. Start with national insurance where the rich still don't pay their fair share. There is a ceiling which means the low paid pay a higher proportion than top earners. Taking the lid off would bring in another £4.5bn a year. The self-employed pay virtually no national insurance and that includes some of the very highest earners, such as partners in big law and accountancy firms who deem themselves to be self-employed. Taking that away would bring in about £2bn more a year. Inheritance tax is now almost non-existent. It only kicks in on estates worth over £233,000 and most of the rich hand over their money before they die to avoid death duties. The Fabian tax commission is considering a good inheritance reform that would bring in billions. Restricting the personal allowance to the basic tax rate would bring in another £2bn from top earners. Another £1bn a year can be collected from country land-owners who sell their acres to developers but pay no capital gains tax if they roll over the money to buy more land. The valuable signature of a local planning officer lets them make millions without paying any tax at all. All these are stealthy ways the rich pay too little tax. Does it make them more moral than everyone else?

Taxation is fiscally virtuous because it allows spending without inflating the economy. Taxation is a far better way to damp down over-heating than by constantly pushing up interest rates, which helps to keep the pound far too high for industry. Taxation is virtuous because when well spent it can buy everyone far more of the things conducive to contentment than they can ever buy from their own pocket. If William Hague is going to run on a "selfishness pays" platform, Labour will have to show how it doesn't. It is not necessarily a moral issue but one of enlightened self-interest. No doubt the chancellor will please many on Tuesday - he always does. But a paean of praise for tax would be a new defining moment for Labour, courtesy of Mr Hague.
