Taxation is a far better way to damp down over-heating than by constantly pushing up interest rates, which helps to keep the pound far too high for industry. Taxation is virtuous because when well spent it can buy everyone far more of the things conducive to contentment than they can ever buy from their own pocket. If William Hague is going to run on a "selfishness pays" platform, Labour will have to show how it doesn't. It is not necessarily a moral issue but one of enlightened self-interest. No doubt the chancellor will please many on Tuesday - he always does. But a paean of praise for tax would be a new defining moment for Labour, courtesy of Mr Hague.

webTitle: Benefit and job agencies in giant merger

fields.headline: Benefit and job agencies in giant merger
fields.standfirst: Welfare reform: special report
fields.trailText: The government yesterday stepped up its welfare to work programme by merging the employment service and benefits agency, heralding a potentially sweeping Whitehall shake-up in which the department of social security's responsibilites are handed to the treasury as well as the department of education and employment.
fields.body:
The government yesterday stepped up its welfare to work programme by merging the employment service and benefits agency, heralding a potentially sweeping Whitehall shake-up in which the department of social security's responsibilites are handed to the treasury as well as the department of education and employment.

The merger of the 400 benefit agency offices and the 1,000 jobs centres, together employing more than 105,000 civil servants, will also make it easier to trace benefit fraud and offer a more streamlined service to the 5m benefit claimants of a working age, including the unemployed, the disabled and single parents.

By concentrating help in one agency and one-stop high street offices, ministers believe they will be able to refocus the welfare state into advising people on benefits on job vacancies and training, rather than simply passively handing out the weekly dole.

The social security secretary, Alistair Darling, described the merger as "the logical conclusion of the government's welfare policy", but admitted it would require sweeping IT investment to marry the DSS and benefits agency systems. Ministers will later examine whether housing benefit, adminstered by local councils, can also be integrated into the new merged service.

Ministers had already piloted a merger of some benefit offices and job centres in 16 pilot schemes called the ONE service. This initiative will go nationwide shortly with the planned new agency announced yesterday up and running from 2001. It has not yet been agreed which of the two departments will be responsible for handling the new agency's budget or the policy oversight of the new high street offices.

The education and employment secretary, David Blunkett, said: "The new arrangements would be convenient for individuals offering a one-stop service rather than one based on a historical anachronism."

He said he had been working with Mr Darling on the marriage between welfare and work for many months.

He added: "The agency will offer working people a single point of access for advice on looking for work and accessing benefits. In a development of the new deal programme, the ONE Service pilots and the employment action zones, it will use personal advisors to provide an active and efficient service helping every person who is able to work to do so and ensuring proper support when they cannot."

He added that the reform would not herald a change in any benefit rules, saying ministers had already announced that from next month the disabled and single parents claiming benefit would be ordered to attend job and training interviews, but they would not be required to take jobs.

The unemployed aged under 24 would lose benefit however, if they refused to take three separate offers of a job or training.

One minister said that Tony Blair would have to decide on the future of the department of social security before the next election, but said ministers, committed to joined up government, were not fighting a Whitehall turf war over control of welfare to work.

Highlighting the decline in influence of the DSS, the shadow social security spokesman, David Willetts, said: "What is Alistair Darling for? Pensions are on their way to a separate ministry. The chancellor has taken over the working families tax credit. National insurance contributions have gone to the treasury. All that is left for Darling to do is to turn off the lights as he leaves the building."

fields.headline: Doctors 'cannot admit mistakes'
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: Doctors are shackled by a "culture of blame and guilt" from admitting their mistakes to patients and overhauling the way they work to improve the safety of the patients they treat, according to this week's British Medical Journal.
fields.body:
Doctors are shackled by a "culture of blame and guilt" from admitting their mistakes to patients and overhauling the way they work to improve the safety of the patients they treat, according to this week's British Medical Journal.

The BMJ, one of the world's leading medical journals, devotes an entire issue to medical accidents in the wake of a report from the United States revealing that 100,000 Americans a year die from preventable errors in hospital - more than deaths and injuries from motor and air crashes, suicides, falls, poisonings and drownings combined.

In a lecture to the Royal College of Physicians on the high toll of medical errors in hospitals, published recently, Sir Brian Jarman, professor of general practice at Imperial College school of medicine in London, said he thought the 3.7% death rate in the United States would at least be mirrored in Britain, suggesting that more than 33,000 die as a result of mistakes and accidents in UK hospitals.

Sir Brian, who is a member of the Bristol royal infirmary public inquiry into NHS failures behind the deaths of babies in open heart surgery, compared the health service unfavourably to the aviation industry. Airlines have improved safety by accepting that people make mistakes and encouraging pilots and other staff to recognise their own tiredness and fallibility. Doctors are expected never to make an error - and, if they do, the culture works against them admitting it.

A study in the BMJ makes the same comparison between airline crew and medical staff working in operating theatres and intensive care units. It finds that while aviation workers are taught to deal with fatigue, doctors and nurses tend not to believe they might make mistakes through tiredness.

"Much progress has been made to create a culture in aviation that deals effectively with error, whereas in medicine substantial pressures still exist to cover up mistakes... We found that susceptibility to error is not universally acknowledged by medical staff and many report that error is not handled appropriately in their hospital."

The researchers, J Bryan Sexton and colleagues from the University of Texas, suggest that poor teamwork can also contribute to mistakes. They point out that "surgeons are most supportive of steep hierarchies in which junior staff do not question senior staff".

An editorial by Lucian Leape, a professor of health policy at Harvard university and Donald Berwick, chief executive of the Institute for Healthcare Improvement in Boston, say there are some practical measures that could be put in place immediately - such as the end of the handwritten medical notes in favour of computer records. But they also call for cultural change on both sides of the Atlantic.

"Achieving the culture we need - one of learning, trust, curiosity, systems thinking and executive responsibility - will be immensely difficult. Harder still, we must now accomplish this cultural change under the spotlight of a newly aroused public that, given our track record, is understandably doubtful that healthcare can, on its own, do what needs to be done."

webTitle: One man's mission to bring Pakistan's corrupt to account

fields.headline: One man's mission to bring Pakistan's corrupt to account
fields.standfirst:
Military stakes its legitimacy on prosecutor general

Pakistan coup: special report
fields.trailText: Built by Nawaz Sharif as his official office in Islamabad, the huge Mogul-style building with its empty red-brick towers and green lawns speaks volumes for the deposed Pakistani prime minister's extravagant taste. Which makes the chief executive's secretariat, as it is known today, an odd place for the army to base its anti-corruption task force after seizing power in a coup last October.
fields.body:
Built by Nawaz Sharif as his official office in Islamabad, the huge Mogul-style building with its empty red-brick towers and green lawns speaks volumes for the deposed Pakistani prime minister's extravagant taste. Which makes the chief executive's secretariat, as it is known today, an odd place for the army to base its anti-corruption task force after seizing power in a coup last October.

Odder still is the army's choice as lead investigator for the high-profile operation. Farouk Adam Khan, the 54-year-old prosecutor general for accountability, sits under a portrait of Pakistan's founder, Mohammed Ali Jinnah, in the rather plain, octagonal room 401-D.

Trained at Sandhurst and decorated in Pakistan's 1965 and 1971 wars against India, his military career was brought to an abrupt end when he was court-martialled in 1974 after a group of army officers made a failed attempt to overthrow the prime minister, Zulfikar Ali Bhutto.

Now, working under a four-star general at the national accountability bureau, Mr Khan is responsible for chasing Pakistan's missing billions.

He has just returned from Europe where he asked Interpol to act on 40 arrest warrants. Those on the list include high-profile figures like Rehman Malik, the former chief of Pakistan's federal investigation agency, and Aftab Ahmad Khan Sherpao, the former chief minister of North-West Frontier province. "They are a gallery of rogues," said Mr Khan. More names will be added soon, he promised.

General Pervez Musharraf, who led the October coup, used the corruption of Pakistan as a justification for seizing power and set up accountability courts and extended sentencing powers.

In November, 50 people were arrested, including many senior businessmen, and more arrests will come in the next few weeks, Mr Khan said.

Although many welcome an attack on corruption, businessmen fear the arrests may discourage investors, and political groups are complaining about the slow pace of the work and questioning why the army is not also being investigated.

Two cases have been registered against Mr Sharif, who is on trial for his life in Karachi, charged with attempted murder and hijacking. He is accused of avoiding tax on his purchase of a £1.3m Russian Mi-8 helicopter in 1993, and one of his family businesses, the Ittefaq foundry, is accused of defaulting on a 729m rupee (£8.6m) loan.

At least 16 more cases are ready to be filed against the former prime minister, said Mr Khan. "This is one of the Sharif cases," he said, his hand resting on a two-inch thick green file. "There is so much work involved. We are not taking any chances.

"In the past there were a lot of allegations that prosecutions were politically motivated. We have made it a basic policy that none of our prosecutions are going to be politically motivated," he said.

Benazir Bhutto, a former prime minister living in London, is a "proclaimed offender". She and her husband were convicted in April last year of taking kickbacks from a Swiss firm and were sentenced to five years in jail, fined $8.6m and banned from politics for seven years.

Mr Khan is waiting for a Swiss court to unlock some of the money involved in the case. "We have got a lot of money expected from the proceedings in Switzerland," he said.

"I don't want the embarrassment of her back here and creating a martyr out of her. But where her assets were acquired through illegal means they should be returned to Pakistan. And I will get them."

Mr Khan is working in a country steeped in corruption. A small group among the elite has combined outstanding loans of an estimated 211bn rupees, a third of the national budget.

Then there are the kickbacks, tax evasion, embezzlement and money laundering. "By the time we're through we are going to try our utmost to eradicate the culture of massive corruption," said Mr Khan.

His young team of investigators has risen from a paltry 15 to more than 100, still barely enough to handle the workload.

"I'm not talking about a police inspector taking 100 rupees. I'm talking about massive corruption, the millions and the billions," he said.

Others have promised as much in the past and not delivered. But this time the military has staked its legitimacy on the work being done by Mr Khan in his red-brick tower.

fields.headline: The look-good factor
fields.standfirst:
Is there any point in the president's travels?

The India-Pakistan conflict: special report
Pakistan coup: special report
fields.trailText: The purpose of US President Bill Clinton's forthcoming visit to India and Pakistan was clearly set out by his secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, this week. It was the beginning, she said, of a "new chapter". Mr Clinton's objectives were to strengthen democracy, enhance security, combat terrorism, and boost economic ties. A big agenda for a six-day trip which also includes Bangladesh, one might think; but laudable, no doubt about that.
fields.body:
The purpose of US President Bill Clinton's forthcoming visit to India and Pakistan was clearly set out by his secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, this week. It was the beginning, she said, of a "new chapter". Mr Clinton's objectives were to strengthen democracy, enhance security, combat terrorism, and boost economic ties. A big agenda for a six-day trip which also includes Bangladesh, one might think; but laudable, no doubt about that. Noble aims are food and drink to the media-savvy US presidency, especially when venturing into foreign parts. And this historic hobnobbing, the first such since Jimmy Carter's trip to India in 1978, is noble with knobs on.

All the same, Ms Albright's "things to do" list requires a more mundane, pragmatic scrutiny. Take democracy, for example. In Pakistan, problematically, there is none to strengthen. Since seizing power last year, Gen Pervez Musharaff has closed down parliament, nobbled the judiciary, curtailed civil liberties, and put his elected predecessor on trial for his life. Despite the urgings of the Commonwealth, the EU, and assorted American and British envoys, he has stubbornly refused to set a timetable for a return to civilian rule. Mr Clinton's controversial lunch date in Islamabad may miraculously change all this. More likely the figs will be served with fudge.

Let us quickly move on to security issues, second on Ms Albright's tariff. Delhi, she stated sternly, must understand that only "significant progress" in curbing nuclear proliferation would enable the US and India "fully to realise the vast potential of our relationship". But both India and Pakistan are assiduously building nuclear weapons. Since well-publicised tests in 1998, they have come close to war over Kashmir, broken off the so-called Lahore dialogue, regularly threatened each other with Armageddon, and declined to sign key arms control treaties. India also rejects outside arbitration over Kashmir which it regards, quixotically, as an internal matter despite Pakistan's control of a large chunk of the territory. Both are guilty of continuing human rights violations there. Time for Mr Clinton to knock heads together? Apparently not. "The president is not going to mediate the Kashmir dispute... unless both sides ask," Ms Albright declared. She knows, of course, that India will not ask; and that while Kashmir smoulders and insults fly, neither country will rein in its nuclear programme.

Combating terrorism: item three on the tour inventory. A certain home run for Bill, for surely nobody can disagree with that? Actually, in Pakistan, currently harbouring the Indian Airlines Christmas hijackers, it is not quite so simple. Gen Musharraf's regime has close links to Afghanistan, home to Osama bin Laden, the CIA's most-wanted. Powerful fundamentalist groups have their own definition of terrorist, which translates as "holy warrior". And then there is Nawaz Sharif, Pakistan's deposed leader, who is charged with yet another, egregious form of terrorism: opposing Gen Musharraf. Memo to the president: keep remarks broad-brush, avoid ticking objects.

But when it comes to boosting economic ties, Ms Albright's final tick-box, Mr Clinton is on safer ground. Although penny-pinched Pakistan and Bangladesh will be hoping for inward investment, India's economy is expanding annually by 6.5%. Its "market" comprises over 1bn people; its hi-tech sector advances by leaps and bounds. This is Mr Clinton's kind of language. Even if the other stuff all proves a teeny bit difficult, trade deals will likely save the day. Plus historic photo-ops, naturally, in noble poses.

webTitle: China gives Taipei an expensive fright

fields.headline: China gives Taipei an expensive fright
fields.standfirst: Taiwan and China: special report
fields.trailText: Taiwan's stock market was shored up by funds from a special government reserve yesterday as politicians struggled to restore calm after threats issued against the island's separate status on Wednesday by China's premier, Zhu Rongji.
fields.body:
Taiwan's stock market was shored up by funds from a special government reserve yesterday as politicians struggled to restore calm after threats issued against the island's separate status on Wednesday by China's premier, Zhu Rongji.

With presidential elections in Taiwan tomorrow, the authorities drew on a stabilisation fund to prevent the market from sliding further. It had dropped 8% since Monday. The fund, which has $6.5bn at its disposal, has not been used before.

Beijing kept the pressure on by convening a panel of specialists to discuss its "timetable" for the reunification of Taiwan with the mainland.

"[China's deadline] could be three to five years, or there could be a change within 24 hours," said Beijing's top Taiwan expert, Li Jiaquan. One of the implications was that the timetacle could hinge on who is elected tomorrow.

Regional experts stressed that China's warnings of military action stemmed directly from fears that Taiwan's pro-independence opposition candidate, Chen Shui-bian, may win. All three main candidates have condemned Chinese pressure, while still hoping to persuade the voters that they could do business with Beijing if elected.

Mr Chen yesterday said he felt that he was "misunderstood" by China, adding that he was eager to visit Beijing after being elected - if only to "drink tea and eat sweets" - as a first step to mend relations.

"Beijing should realise that threats will only make the Taiwanese walk further away", he said, "and disrupt normalisation of cross-straits relations.

While urging Taiwan's voters to stand firm against "terror tactics", Mr Chen's Democratic Progressive party (DPP) argues that Beijing could learn to live with him as president.

Yesterday, the Nobel prize winner for chemistry, Lee Yuan-tseh, claimed that the DPP had a lot in common with the Chinese Communist party because many of their members believe in socialism. Mr Chen has said that Mr Lee, who has good contacts on the mainland, could become his peace envoy to Beijing.

But China regards Mr Chen's offers to negotiate as insincere because he refuses to accept its precondition of "one China".

The official candidate of the ruling Kuomintang (Nationalist) party, Lien Chan, sought to turn China's threats to his advantage by saying that he would seek immediate talks and not let the crisis drag on. He compared Mr Chen to an unruly child who should be dealt with by his own parents. But he also criticised Beijing for trying to discipline him from outside.

The third main candidate, breakaway Nationalist James Soong, took the middle ground by saying that "we don't want to rush into either unification or independence".

Though opinion polls are banned during the last 10 days before the election, unofficial reports indicate that Mr Chen has either a slight lead, or is on level terms with Mr Soong for the lead.

The pro-independence Taipei Times yesterday mocked Premier Zhu as being "panic-stricken, anxiety-ridden and exasperated".

"For all his talk about Taiwan's election being the Taiwanese people's business and about Beijing's non-interference, the tone of Zhu's scream was exactly the same as that of Beijing's missile threats in the run up to Taiwan's previous presidential election in 1996."

"The Taiwanese pricked China's air-filled balloon of threats four years ago," it concluded. "They will surely do it again [tomorrow]."

Mr Chen yesterday said he felt that he was "misunderstood" by China, adding that he was eager to visit Beijing after being elected - if only to "drink tea and eat sweets" - as a first step to mend relations. "Beijing should realise that threats will only make the Taiwanese walk further away", he said, "and disrupt normalisation of cross-straits relations. While urging Taiwan's voters to stand firm against "terror tactics", Mr Chen's Democratic Progressive party (DPP) argues that Beijing could learn to live with him as president. Yesterday, the Nobel prize winner for chemistry, Lee Yuan-tseh, claimed that the DPP had a lot in common with the Chinese Communist party because many of their members believe in socialism. Mr Chen has said that Mr Lee, who has good contacts on the mainland, could become his peace envoy to Beijing. But China regards Mr Chen's offers to negotiate as insincere because he refuses to accept its precondition of "one China". The official candidate of the ruling Kuomintang (Nationalist) party, Lien Chan, sought to turn China's threats to his advantage by saying that he would seek immediate talks and not let the crisis drag on. He compared Mr Chen to an unruly child who should be dealt with by his own parents. But he also criticised Beijing for trying to discipline him from outside. The third main candidate, breakaway Nationalist James Soong, took the middle ground by saying that "we don't want to rush into either unification or independence". Though opinion polls are banned during the last 10 days before the election, unofficial reports indicate that Mr Chen has either a slight lead, or is on level terms with Mr Soong for the lead. The pro-independence Taipei Times yesterday mocked Premier Zhu as being "panic-stricken, anxiety-ridden and exasperated". "For all his talk about Taiwan's election being the Taiwanese people's business and about Beijing's non-interference, the tone of Zhu's scream was exactly the same as that of Beijing's missile threats in the run up to Taiwan's previous presidential election in 1996." "The Taiwanese pricked China's air-filled balloon of threats four years ago," it concluded. "They will surely do it again [tomorrow]."

webTitle: Blunder means 800-mile round trip for refugees

fields.headline: Blunder means 800-mile round trip for refugees
fields.standfirst:
Refugees in Britain: special report
The issue explained: How to claim asylum
fields.trailText: More than 60 Romanian asylum seekers were on their way back to London from Glasgow last night - just a week after starting a new life in Scotland - after being arrested when they unwittingly fell foul of immigration orders.
fields.body:
More than 60 Romanian asylum seekers were on their way back to London from Glasgow last night - just a week after starting a new life in Scotland - after being arrested when they unwittingly fell foul of immigration orders.

It was discovered that they had been sent to Scotland when restrictions dictated that they stay in the capital. The 16 families were due back in London, after a 400-mile journey, in the middle of last night.

Glasgow city council and Wandsworth borough council each blame the other for the plight of the bewildered refugees. Officials in Wandsworth, south London, were last night hastily arranging bed and breakfast accommodation for the asylum seekers. The council claimed it was only told the families were on their way back half an hour after the bus left Glasgow.

The situation arose after 12 of the women were caught begging door to door in a Glasgow suburb. The women were part of a group of 19 families - Romanian and Somali - sent to Glasgow from Wandsworth as part of the home office's dispersal programme for asylum seekers. They were rehoused in the city's Sighthill tower block flats but were detained by police after residents of Bishopbriggs complained about begging. Police discovered that some of the women had papers ordering that they remain at an address in London and they sign on at a local police station every week.

Last night, a spokesman for Glasgow council said it had been left with no choice. Immigration officials had told them that some of the refugees were in breach of restrictions and must return to London. The spokesman claims the women were told they would be sent to Greenock prison and that the official responsible for them could also be arrested for harbouring.

A home office spokesman confirmed that two immigration officers had questioned the women's papers and advised them to return to London but told them it was ultimately their choice. He said: "The arrest threat is not substantiated on our side."

Glasgow claims it was not informed that restrictions applied to any of the families and had been assured that it would not receive any families with restrictions. A newspaper in the city reported that one of the women had three convictions for begging with a child.

The spokesman said: "We didn't know until last night that they were supposed to report to a police station. So, we had no choice but to sent them back. We deeply regret that these Romanian families have been forced to make a distressing journey up and down the country. This would not have happened had we been told in the first place that restrictions had been imposed."

A Wandsworth spokesman said: "Glasgow have not once said to us what the problem is. We don't know if it's true that some of the individuals sent to Glasgow were subject of restriction orders. If we had known that we would have told the home office and Glasgow.

"This is going to drive a hole through the dispersal programme. Some of these people were arrested for begging on the streets of Glasgow. Does that mean that everytime someone is arrested for begging you send them back?"

Glasgow was set to receive 500 more asylum seekers in the next month but that plan has been suspended until the issue of restrictions has been clarified.

A home office spokesman said: "We are aware that there's an issue. We will make sure that the immigration service doesn't set reporting conditions that obstruct dispersals."

webTitle: The Taiwan campaigner who has Beijing worried

fields.headline: The Taiwan campaigner who has Beijing worried
fields.standfirst: Taiwan and China: special report
fields.trailText: Pro-independence candidate Chen Shui-bian's commitment to justice and independence for Taiwan has deep roots in his own life.
fields.body:
Pro-independence candidate Chen Shui-bian's commitment to justice and independence for Taiwan has deep roots in his own life.

Mr Chen, the son of poor peasants, was a bright student and eventually studied law in Taipei. His political career began in the late 1970s when he volunteered to be a defence lawyer for activists imprisoned by the Nationalist party (KMT).

As an independent councillor in Taipei, Mr Chen exposed police and municipal corruption. He founded a magazine that was banned by this year's breakaway Nationalist candidate, James Soong, who at the time was the KMT's cultural chief, but now Mr Chen's main rival for president.

In 1985, he shocked the KMT by running for magistrate in his native country. He lost, and his wife, Chen Ah-jun, was punished for his audacity; after a political rally, she was run over by a truck three times.

Paralysed from the chest down, she campaigned the next year from her wheelchair and won a seat in the national legislature.

After becoming a national figure, he won his bid for mayor of Taipei in 1994, after which he purged KMT bureaucrats and promoted young officials. But his pro-independence stance began to cause concerns on the wider stage of "cross-straits relations" with Beijing, resulting in a lost bid for re-election in 1998.

Ironically, Mr Chen's defeat left him free to campaign for president this year.

It will be seen as another irony if China's bullying tactics turns the electorate his way tomorrow.

webTitle: Another year older, yet still none the wiser

fields.headline: Another year older, yet still none the wiser
fields.standfirst:
The lessons of Kosovo may take some time to implement

Kosovo: special report

UN Kosovo home page

NATO
fields.trailText: The temptation to reconstruct the past in the light of present troubles is often hard to resist. A year after the Kosovo war began, vengeance killings, increasing crime, political infighting, intimidation, and corruption in that territory make an unpleasant picture. James Rubin, the American state department spokesman, has been there this week to plead with local leaders not to provoke the Serbs at a time when the US government is desperate to avoid any risk to American lives during an election campaign. That there might be more fighting in the Balkans is a repellent prospect, and if it were to begin because a handful of young men were not checked by a leadership which has the means to do so would be appalling.
fields.body:
The temptation to reconstruct the past in the light of present troubles is often hard to resist. A year after the Kosovo war began, vengeance killings, increasing crime, political infighting, intimidation, and corruption in that territory make an unpleasant picture. James Rubin, the American state department spokesman, has been there this week to plead with local leaders not to provoke the Serbs at a time when the US government is desperate to avoid any risk to American lives during an election campaign. That there might be more fighting in the Balkans is a repellent prospect, and if it were to begin because a handful of young men were not checked by a leadership which has the means to do so would be appalling.

Kosovo is a mess, even if it is not as bad a mess as some charge. But to proceed from these difficulties to conclude that the intervention was mistaken is illogical. In some of the new accounts of the war there is a tendency to present it as a deeply foolish undertaking which succeeded only in replacing one kind of ethnic cleansing with another. Yet nobody ever pretended that the members of the Kosovo Liberation Army were angels, or that Kosovo Albanians were all somehow free from the faults that mark, to one degree or another, the peoples of former Yugoslavia, or, for that matter, from the faults which human beings everywhere display.

What the Nato countries set out to do a year ago was to defeat a negative - the oppression of Kosovo - not to defend an illusory positive, in the shape of the exceptional virtues of Albanian Kosovans.

It is also ahistorical to suggest that the KLA plotted to bring about a western intervention in a careful and coldblooded way. It is true that the KLA, insofar as its disparate nature allowed it to formulate a strategy, did want an intervention. How could it be otherwise, when Bosnia had shown that armed resistance would eventually produce a western response, while the non- violent path Kosovo leaders had followed until then had led only to Kosovo being shuffled to the bottom of the heap of Balkan problems? Those who first decided to take on the Serbian security forces in Kosovo did so here and there across the territory, without much coordination. To call them an "army" at that stage was a conceit on their part, or on that of journalists. Did they know any better than the Serbs where what they were doing might take them? To suggest they systematically embroiled the Nato countries is to assign to them a capacity for planning, and for manipulating the outside world, they surely did not possess.

The mania for revelation is one of the problems that make a proper understanding of these events more difficult. Simply because effort has been put into preparing new narratives of the war, and because there may have been access to new documents or interviews with actors who had not spoken before, the distorting idea grows up that there must be revelation. New material can be interesting and relevant without being revolutionary. Even if it does prompt some necessary revision, it almost never adds up to a plot. Yet the attraction of what the Indians call "the hidden hand" theory of events is perennial.

The Kosovo war has in fact been unusual in that post-war information has not added a great deal to the understanding of the conflict. There are some important gaps to be filled, particularly on Serbian motivation and Russian policy, and the story of how the war was ended diplomatically is not absolutely clear. But we already knew that the Nato countries banked on Milosevic backing down, either at the Rambouillet conference or after a few days bombing, and that when he intensified his attacks in Kosovo, and added mass expulsions, they were mightily surprised.

We already knew that the air war then lurched from strategy to strategy, from ineffective attempts to stop Serbian operations in Kosovo to attacks on key targets in Belgrade and finally to attacks on the country's economic infrastructure. We already knew that the war showed up serious defects in the military capacity of European countries, which could make only a limited contribution to the air campaign and would have been severely strained in the event of a ground campaign.

The evidence shows a war which could perhaps have been avoided if there had been a more forthright policy in the years before the conflict. Since such a policy was not followed, the point arrived at which a threat had to be made, and when the threat did not work, the conflict began. You can argue about how and why western countries allowed themselves to get to that point - and wish that they had not got to it - but not seriously about what had to be done when only two choices remained.

Those who criticise the war have to ask themselves what the state of Kosovo would be today had there been no intervention. Certainly there would have been great suffering in Kosovo, even if by now Kosovans, resigning themselves to continued Serbian rule, had given up physical resistance. Certainly there would have been huge numbers displaced from Kosovo, either forced out or choosing to flee. Certainly Serbia would have been a pariah nation just as much as it is today, and with less prospect for the Serbian people, because Milosevic would have been strengthened, of an end to that status.

Europe and America would have been shamed, and Nato would have been discredited. Some critics are dismissive of a war fought for Nato's "prestige", as if all that was involved was a silly pride in soldiers and heaped up hardware. But what can be scorned as "prestige" can also be properly called "collective security" - that collective security whose failure in the past led to such large disasters. It is the nature of collective security that it combines choices in a particular area of conflict at a particular time with general considerations of credibility. Both matter.

Opponents and supporters of the war may equally err in seeing the conflict as a more purposive affair than it really was. There is always the tendency to imagine leaders have more control over events than even gifted statesmen actually do. Tim Judah puts it pithily in his new book on Kosovo. Referring equally to the Serbs, the Kosovans, and the international community, he writes: "They all just got it wrong." He adds that the ponderous literature on the lessons of Kosovo "leaves one wondering whether the real truth was that there were no particular lessons."

It might be said instead that the lessons, which are to do with foresight and prevention in the wobbly politico-military coalition that is the west today, are fairly easy to grasp but infinitely more difficult to apply.

 Kosovo by Tim Judah is published by Yale University Press.

webTitle: Disappointment blueprint for industry and farms

fields.headline: Disappointment blueprint for industry and farms
fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: There was a lot of hand-wringing by the government yesterday. Long before Mr Byers explained how there really isn't anything much ministers can do about the sale of Rover, Nick Brown was explaining how there really isn't very much the government can do about the agriculture crisis either.
fields.body:
There was a lot of hand-wringing by the government yesterday. Long before Mr Byers explained how there really isn't anything much ministers can do about the sale of Rover, Nick Brown was explaining how there really isn't very much the government can do about the agriculture crisis either.

It is extraordinary. Farming and the motor industry both seem on the brink of oblivion, like that hotel on the cliff in Yorkshire, and there is nothing ministers can do except stand around saying how sad it all is.

Michael Fabricant is a man so steeped in the rural life that he used to take his mobile disco round the Brighton area, in gumboots. Mods and rockers would put aside their differences and rave to his Oi've Got a Brand New Combine 'Arvester, the club re-mix.

At agriculture questions, he said farmers were having to sell for 10p milk which cost 11p a pint to produce. How long could ministers remain complacent? he asked.

Mr Brown rose slowly to his feet. He slightly resembles the Mr Brown who took in Paddington Bear. I always vaguely expect to see a pot of marmalade beside him on the bench.

"I'm not complacent at all," he said mildly. "The remedy lies in the supply chain and the market place."

Later he added: "Of course, there are measures at the margin government could take to help. But the answer is to focus on the real problem, in the market place."

Tim Yeo, for the Tories, pointed out that supermarkets are actually raising the price of milk. Mr Brown was unfazed. "These are, of course, commercial arrangements. I think the opposition are not coming forward with remedies of their own."

Mr Brown talks about the farming crisis as if it were like a rain shower, which we can't do anything about, but which will soon pass over. "It is true that the current exchange rate between the pound and the euro exacerbates the problems," he mused at one point, as if the exchange rate were something beyond the ken of mere humans.

But he was active, engaged and hands-on compared with Stephen Byers, who had to face a last-minute Tory debate on the sale of Rover.

Mr Byers is lucky in his present opponent. Angela Browning, the Tory shadow, is not, on yesterday's showing, up to the job.

Once again we marvelled at the fact that she is on the frontbench, and John Redwood is not, for it was Mr Redwood who made the effective opposition to Stephen Byers.

(I'm told that Mr Hague may have been forced to get rid of Mr Redwood to please the supporters of Michael Portillo. If that's true, it's as if Sir Alex Ferguson had decided to replace David Beckham in midfield with, for example, me - on the grounds that Beckham wanted to be a manager one day.)

If Mrs Browning was feeble, Mr Byers was positively frail. There was a viable future for Longbridge, he said, or at least claimed that "many people believe there is".

He had "stressed" this point to the boss of BMW. He would be "raising this point" with the new owners, who must be trembling.

It was all a matter of great disappointment, he said. "We had an agreement with BMW. Today's decision goes against that agreement."

So he was disappointed. In fact, he was so disappointed he told us many times about his disappointment.

"There is a real sense of disappointment," he said again. "Today's action is regrettable. It is a great disappointment. In government we face many difficult questions. But we should never lose sight of the fact that these are human questions."

Any farmer or car worker who had been in the gallery must have felt like hurling himself over the balustrade to his doom.

fields.headline: Not fair
fields.trailText: Within weeks of the European court of human rights' decision that my right to a fair trial and appeal was violated because of the crown prosecution's failure to disclose evidence, the crown prosecution watchdog recommends that prosecutors should be more involved in deciding what should be disclosed to a defendant (Legal 'safeguard' risks injustice, March 3).
fields.body:
Within weeks of the European court of human rights' decision that my right to a fair trial and appeal was violated because of the crown prosecution's failure to disclose evidence, the crown prosecution watchdog recommends that prosecutors should be more involved in deciding what should be disclosed to a defendant (Legal 'safeguard' risks injustice, March 3).

Criminal law practitioners argue the 1996 criminal procedure and investigation act did not create a fairer disclosure regime. It made matters worse - returning to the state that led to the introduction of the 1996 act is unacceptable and an indictment that suppression of material in a democratic society cannot be compatible with the European convention of human rights.
Raphael Rowe
HMP Kingston, Portsmouth

It made matters worse - returning to the state that led to the introduction of the 1996 act is unacceptable and an indictment that suppression of material in a democratic society cannot be compatible with the European convention of human rights. Raphael Rowe HMP Kingston, Portsmouth

fields.headline: Oxfam agonises over asylum vouchers
fields.trailText: Oxfam has found itself in an appalling dilemma because of the "no change" policy contained in the government's asylum seekers' voucher scheme (Letters, March 15).
fields.body:
Oxfam has found itself in an appalling dilemma because of the "no change" policy contained in the government's asylum seekers' voucher scheme (Letters, March 15). The contract presented to Oxfam by Sodexho, the company contracted by the government to administer the scheme says no change can be given to asylum seekers shopping with vouchers "under any circumstances".

Oxfam runs 840 shops in the UK selling affordable clothes and other goods. Ñow the scheme is upon us, we feel we must open up Oxfam shops to asylum seekers. We cannot allow a group of asylum seekers to stand staring at an Oxfam shop at a few items of clothing that they might be able to afford, but can't buy be cause we won't accept their vouchers.

But suppose, for instance, we take a £10 voucher from an asylum seeker for a suit that costs £9.99 or less. If one of our shop volunteers gives back as much as a penny change, Oxfam will be in breach of the contract and may be booted out of the scheme.

Sodexho says the contract was written to home office policy. Yet the home office says it is not illegal to give out change. Surely this is a case for joined-up government? It's certainly a case for moral government.
Michael Vincent
Oxford

 The home office says the way to survive when you're living on vouchers worth only 70% of the breadline is through judicious use of the £10 cash allowance. When we ask how asylum seekers are supposed to use public transport, the home office says the £10 can cover that expense. When we ask how people who cannot work, and who may be without friends or family, can access recreation facilities, we are told the £10 will cover it.

When we ask how asylum seekers can make the most of what little they have by using the best value shops and markets if these do not accept vouchers, we are reminded again of the £10.

There is one question which even the home office cannot answer. How can £10 a week - £1.43 a day ever hope to cover all these essential needs?
Fazil Kawani
Refugee Council

fields.headline: Victims
fields.trailText: I was a press officer at the Equal Opportunities Commission when Kamlesh Bahl became chair under the first ever open recruitment process (Law society accused of sex and race bias, March 15). Imagine our horror when our heroine turned out to be a power-mad bully.
fields.body:
I was a press officer at the Equal Opportunities Commission when Kamlesh Bahl became chair under the first ever open recruitment process (Law society accused of sex and race bias, March 15). Staff there were excited about the arrival of a young black woman who had broken the mould of government appointments from the "great and the good".

Imagine our horror when our heroine turned out to be a power-mad bully. One of her first victims was Valerie Amos, the best ever chief executive of the EOC and a black woman. If Kamlesh Bahl plays the race card in her dispute with the Law Society it will be an insult to those thousands of black people who really do face discrimination at work.
Fiona Fox
London

fields.headline: The Angel of Islington
fields.trailText: I was saddened to hear of Nicolas Walter's death (Obituaries, March 13), as one who greatly valued - and invariably agreed with - his lucid critique of all religion, not least through his regular contributions in the Guardian and Statesman's letters columns.
fields.body:
I was saddened to hear of Nicolas Walter's death (Obituaries, March 13), as one who greatly valued - and invariably agreed with - his lucid critique of all religion, not least through his regular contributions in the Guardian and Statesman's letters columns.

Nicholas lived latterly at the top of an Islington building famous for its vigorous nonconformity. For his "saintly" struggle up and down those four flights without the use of his legs, but as much for his huge contribution to British humanism and so many humane causes, I give thanks, along with many others. If he will forgive the epitaph, for once, Deo gratias for the Angel of Islington.
Canon David Partridge
Emsworth, Hants

 With huge and ever-increasing losses and no discernable market Rover has all of the attributes of a highly successful dot.com company (Venture group swoops for Rover, March 16).
Mike Richards
Milton Keynes
m.richards@open.ac.uk

 Why doesn't Brian Warren (Letters, March 16) just buy an extension lead like the rest of us?
Sioned-Mair Richards
Caerfyrddin

 I am less concerned about the make-up of Leeds United's team than that a JP is unfamiliar with the concept of innocent until proven guilty. (Letters, March 16). Bringing the profession into disrepute?
Ian Davies
Norwood Green, Middlesex

 If marriage is such a wonderful thing and so central to society, why am I, as a gay man, not allowed to celebrate it (Blunkett bid to halt section 28 revolt, March 15)?
Paul Patrick
Burnley, Lancs
paul.patrick1@virgin.net

fields.headline: Living Marxism and the Serbs
fields.trailText: Your coverage of the libel case brought by ITN against LM (Poison in the well of history, March 15) gives no indication of the real losers from the bizarre twists and turns of LM's politics: its own supporters.
fields.body:
Your coverage of the libel case brought by ITN against LM (Poison in the well of history, March 15) gives no indication of the real losers from the bizarre twists and turns of LM's politics: its own supporters.

Ten years ago, when I first joined the party, LM was a vibrant intellectual and polemical magazine which could draw on a national network of hundreds of supporters. In recent times, people like myself have had to stand back and watch as the organisation, its discussions and activities, have been closed down and party leaders have switched from calling themselves die-hard communists to espousing the virtues of the free market.

While Mick Hume, Claire Fox and others at the top were building up a coterie of followers in the academic and media world, we were being told: "Our aim is social revolution." Yet within a short time the party was declared finished and anyone who expressed any vaguely leftwing sympathies were ridiculed as being old-fashioned "liberals", "Trotskyists" and sometimes even both.

As for the ITN libel case, I imagine that the judgment probably was unfair, but it is difficult to suppress a certain feeling of grim satisfaction at the imminent demise of Mr Hume's cynical magazine.
Robert Leader
Nottingham

 Ed Vulliamy makes a number of statements and insinuations about me. Two are correct; the rest are false. Mea culpa, I am, as alleged, both a Serb and an employee of the Economist Intelligence Unit. Alas, though, I have never been associated with LM, Living Marxism, or any Serbian or Yugoslav government agency, I have never authored any attacks, "virulent" or otherwise, on "bloody liberals". Vulliamy also falsely attributes to me a rant about non-Serbs, bizarrely in the form of internal company email from 1995 that "came his way". You really should consider using reliable sources and more capable computer hackers.
Laza Kekic
Economist Intelligence Unit

 Mick Hume, LM's editor, has portrayed himself as a brave advocate of conviction politics against the might of the organisations and states. Nothing could be further from the case. Far closer is the picture Ed Vulliamy describes of the victory of ITN over Living Marxism as that of truth over politics and dilettantism.

I gave a talk at Leeds University in the early months of the Bosnian war, and the Revolutionary Communist Party turned up there too. They distributed gory photographs of atrocities committed by "Croats and Muslims" and disputed any strategy or pattern of the Serbian actions other than a natural defence against "fascism". (Their evidence, not that it made any difference to them, was some 50 years old, from the second world war.)

Their aim was to stifle debate on the issue, to bury the criticism of what they saw as a "near-socialist" regime, in a cynically calculated bombardment of misinformation and propaganda. For them, "truth" was a bourgeois notion, political power was the higher cause. Such was clearly the strategy behind the LM article.

It is lucky for the political sheep who follow not just the tawdry politics of LM, but also the tawdry politics of the Times and the foreign office, that there are indeed some journalists, if rather fewer academics, prepared to put their reputations on the line over such issues.
Martin Cohen
Editor, the Philosopher

 Ed Vulliamy has clearly never learned that it is the winners who write history, and a victory for history is not necessarily a victory for justice. How does he expect a magazine with a maximum circulation of 12,000 to find and fly over witnesses when they can clearly hardly afford a decent lawyer?
Michael Caines
King's College, London
michael_caines@hotmail.com

 I wonder whether Ed Vulliamy's Serbophobia has not affected his sanity, just as anti-semitism does to others. He argues that it is a "mutated strand of anti-semitism" to criticise the Muslim takeover in Bosnia or Kosovo and that the "Muslims were the Jews of Bosnia". I cannot think of any less apt comparison. Muslims account for a fifth of the world population and they have dozens of independent states. The Jews of Europe, by contrast, were a small minority everywhere, and had no independent political power or aspirations.

Vulliamy calls the Serbs "tinpot Nazis of the Balkans". However, it was not the Serbs who initiated the break-up of Yugoslavia, but the Germans (who dominated the EU) and the Croats. Serbs in Bosnia and the newly created state of Croatia had no alternative but to make their dispositions. They did many of the wrong things because they lacked a political leadership after decades of dictatorship other than the detritus of the Communist party. They are now the main victims, with a million refugees and tens of thousands of dead.
Alfred Sherman
London

 Not content with winning its libel action, ITN is threatening to enforce its judgment against LM magazine and its editor. Presumably ITN believes in a free press. If so, why make that freedom conditional on payment of £375,000 damages and costs?
Jon Holbrook
London
Jon.Holbrook@ukbar.com

webTitle: US troops seize guerrilla arms caches in Kosovo

fields.headline: US troops seize guerrilla arms caches in Kosovo
fields.standfirst:
UN Kosovo home page

NATO

Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: American troops in Kosovo raided hideouts along the boundary with southern Serbia, seizing arms and ammunition, in a crackdown against ethnic Albanian extremists. Military spokesmen said yesterday that nine suspects were detained.
fields.body:
American troops in Kosovo raided hideouts along the boundary with southern Serbia, seizing arms and ammunition, in a crackdown against ethnic Albanian extremists. Military spokesmen said yesterday that nine suspects were detained.

The raids reflect increasing western concern about groups of hardline ethnic Albanians who have crossed into Serbia and provided Yugoslav forces with a pretext to harass and intimidate the local population of the Presevo valley area, which contains at least 60,000 ethnic Albanians.

About 6,000 ethnic Albanians have fled the Presevo region since last June, including hundreds last week. Many seem as wary of the guerrillas as they do of the Serbian forces which are reportedly building up in the area.

About 300 troops of the US 1st infantry division, serving with the Nato-led K-For international peacekeeping mission, used helicopters and armoured vehicles, in the swoop on Wednesday. They seized more than 200 uniforms, 22 crates of rifle and machine gun ammunition, two mortars, 28 hand grenades, seven rifles, six land mines and other military supplies, a US statement said.

The operation was part of a US "interdiction strategy" to prevent cross-boundary activity by insurgent groups from Kosovo, it said. The sites "were being used as [caches] for weapons, ammunition and supplies" for "fringe or extremist elements in Kosovo, Macedonia or the Presevo valley".

"The search operations will continue in these areas until they have been thoroughly cleared," the statement said. A K-For statement added: "Any insurgent activity that endangers the progress achieved in Kosovo will not be tolerated."

The raids were welcomed by the British government. Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, told MPs yesterday that Nato "would not allow hardliners on either side to undermine the future of Kosovo".

Nato officials said the uniforms seized included black and red insignias of the "Liberation Army of Presevo, Medvedja and Bujanovac", named after three predominantly ethnic Albanian towns across the boundary in southern Serbia.

The guerrillas are reported to bear a striking resemblance to the now disbanded Kosovo Liberation Army (KLA).

Washington has warned leaders of the ethnic Albanian majority in Kosovo that it will not come to the aid of ethnic Albanians in the Presevo area across the boundary, should the Serbs retaliate for the guerrilla incursions.

The United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, yesterday accused ethnic Albanian extremists - former members of the KLA or members of the new group - of provocation and incursions in southern Serbia.

"It is clear that it is the Albanians who are now the cause of these provocations," he said in Paris, adding that he was discussing with various countries the need to send more police and troops to Kosovo. France is to deploy an additional 150 soldiers, while Italy is sending 360 more.

President Bill Clinton and the French president, Jacques Chirac, have called for a ministerial meeting of the six-country Contact Group to discuss ethnic violence within Kosovo, particularly in the divided town of Mitrovice.

fields.headline: Don't blame the critics
fields.trailText: Jonathan Romney is correct in asserting that the notorious Peeping Tom effectively ended Michael Powell's career (Stabbings in the dark, March 15). But it is unjust to impute the blame for this to the hostile critics of the film in 1960 - of whom I was one.
fields.body:
Jonathan Romney is correct in asserting that the notorious Peeping Tom effectively ended Michael Powell's career (Stabbings in the dark, March 15). But it is unjust to impute the blame for this to the hostile critics of the film in 1960 - of whom I was one.

You do not seriously think a film which received such a barrage of notices attributing all manner of sensational perversions to it would have failed to be exploited as loudly and widely as possible by its distributor and exhibitors - or to find an audience? What killed Peeping Tom was the pressure brought to bear on Nat Cohen, boss of Anglo-Amalgamated, which produced and distributed the film in Britain, by members of his own trade.

A few days after Peeping Tom opened, the late Robert Clark, head of Associated British Picture Corporation, in whose ABC cinemas Peeping Tom was showing, told me at a Variety Club lunch: "We've put Nat in the doghouse until he gets rid of that piece of pornography."

The Variety Club was the film industry's establishment, as well as a major charity-raising machine, and its officers feared their chances of appearing in the honours list would be jeopardised by association with such a film. Within weeks, according to Powell's autobiography, Million-Dollar Movie, Nat Cohen, "scared out of his tiny mind" had "cancelled the British distribution". The film critics got the blame; Powell got effectively blacklisted for life; and Nat Cohen died without ever getting a knighthood.
Alexander Walker
London

fields.headline: One planet too many
fields.standfirst: Holst said no to Pluto. That should be that
fields.trailText: Hugely cheered at the Proms, recorded and re-recorded, Anthony Payne's reconstruction of Elgar's third symphony is generally hailed as a triumph. And now we are to have a "completion" of Holst's suite The Planets to rope in Pluto, which wasn't discovered until 13 years after the composer put down his pen after writing the last dying notes of Neptune.
fields.body:
Hugely cheered at the Proms, recorded and re-recorded, Anthony Payne's reconstruction of Elgar's third symphony is generally hailed as a triumph. "Elgar's 3rd", as it is now familiarly called, is claiming its place in the repertoire alongside his 1st and 2nd. Anyone heard to mutter during a standing ovation that this music is not really Elgar's is by definition a spoilsport. And now we are to have a "completion" of Holst's suite The Planets to rope in Pluto, which wasn't discovered until 13 years after the composer put down his pen after writing the last dying notes of Neptune. The commission which the music director of the Hallé orchestra, Kent Nagano, awarded to Colin Matthews has propelled the composer and orchestra and their concert in May on to broadsheet front pages, which cannot be bad for attracting audiences. Anyone who wonders what Holst - who given the chance to incorporate Pluto, declined - might make of these proceedings is no doubt a spoilsport too.

But once it becomes fair game to second-guess a composer, where will this business end? Take the four last songs of Richard Strauss - now the biggest audience puller in classical music: why are there only four, when there might have been six or eight? Or Brahms's 28 variations on a theme of Paganini, and Beethoven's 33 on a theme by Diabelli: why not ask Mark-Anthony Turnage to round them both up to 50? Or wheedle Thomas Adès to expand Moussorgsky's Pictures from an Exhibition to accommodate works by Picasso and Hockney? If dead composers do not have rights, all this is possible. It makes one value the solid good sense of Vivaldi, a composer not often commended now, who wrote so many concertos that no one could ever wish to add to them; and who stapled his most famous work to a finite four seasons. Try to market Vivaldi's Five Seasons, completed by Michael Nyman, and audiences would simply laugh at you.

Probably.

Try to market Vivaldi's Five Seasons, completed by Michael Nyman, and audiences would simply laugh at you. Probably.

fields.headline: Less than frank
fields.standfirst:
Mr Livingstone's error does not look fatal

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone has not been exposed as a liar and a cheat. He has not been taking bribes, lining his pockets or selling access to power. He is not guilty of sleaze. But he has done wrong - and that could cost him dear.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone has not been exposed as a liar and a cheat. He has not been taking bribes, lining his pockets or selling access to power. He is not guilty of sleaze. But he has done wrong - and that could cost him dear.

His most obvious offence is a lack of candour with the registrar of MPs' interests: he failed to reveal all he should have. When his moonlighting moved from the one-offs of 1996 to the regular contracts of the last couple of years, he should have 'fessed up. He did not. It is not a crime to have earned £220,000 in 20 months; indeed, some of Mr Livingstone's City audiences would doubtless admire his industry. But he should have come clean, detailing the figures to the standards watchdog. He says his writing and speaking work was, by definition, in the public domain and that the figures for Localaction, his company, were clear to see in its official accounts. But that is feeble. He should have declared that information on the form provided to MPs. Even if, as he says, the rules themselves were constantly changing, he knew the principle underpinning them: that if the 1990s epidemic of sleaze is not to be repeated, and if self-regulation is to work, then MPs must submit to full disclosure.

The would-be London mayor's second offence is perhaps more serious. This is a man who has consistently attacked New Labour in part for its failure to bite the socialist bullet of tax. He believes in the principle of taxation, with rich people obliged to pay more. Yet he created a paper company, Localaction, in order to pay less. It was legal, to be sure. But it was tax-avoidance, just the kind of fat-cat trick Mr Livingstone surely deplores. This makes him a hypocrite, demanding the well-off pay their share, and yet finding a loophole for himself.

The political impact will probably not be enormous. A poll published yesterday, taken before these matters had been fully reported, found him with a still-colossal 45-point lead. If he can prove that a Labour trick lay behind the original complaint to the standards commissioner, then he may even turn this episode to his advantage. He can also make the fair point that he used the money not to live the high life, but to fund his own political efforts. But it does weaken his claim to be a straight-shooter, made of different stuff from all the other politicians-as-usual. If Mr Livingstone does end up losing that advantage, that £220,000 will have come at a high price.

webTitle: Iraq says a flat no to new UN arms deal

fields.headline: Iraq says a flat no to new UN arms deal
fields.standfirst:
Deputy PM says Baghdad could talk directly to US and Britain

Iraq: special report
fields.trailText: A United Nations security council plan to end the 10-year-old conflict with Iraq is dead in the water after being rejected by the Iraqi deputy prime minister, Tariq Aziz.
fields.body:
A United Nations security council plan to end the 10-year-old conflict with Iraq is dead in the water after being rejected by the Iraqi deputy prime minister, Tariq Aziz.

In the most categorical statement yet from the Iraqi government since the UN resolution was passed in December, Mr Aziz dashed American and British hopes by describing the UN resolution as "stillborn" and "unworkable".

UN resolution 1284 offered a deal under which the sanctions imposed on Iraq would be lifted if UN weapons inspectors were allowed into the country and gave Baghdad a clean bill of health.

The head of the new UN weapons inspectorate, Hans Blix, is putting together a team in New York and is expected to forward a detailed plan to Iraq next month. But Mr Aziz, a longstanding member of President Saddam Hussein's government, was uncompromising about the UN resolution during an interview with the Guardian on Wednesday.

"This is not a solution. It goes nowhere. We would get back into a vicious circle. I would be an idiot to recommend it to the leader. I am not a fool," he said.

Mr Aziz called for Britain, which originally proposed the resolution, and the US to enter into direct dialogue with Iraq. Both have refused to do so.

Iraq's position had appeared to be softening during the past two months, with the country's representative at the UN seemingly ready to compromise on the resolution. The US and British governments also took as a positive sign the fact that Iraq did not object to the appointment of Mr Blix.

But the Iraqi government line has suddenly hardened. Mr Aziz expressed no confidence in Mr Blix, saying that he failed to stand up to the US and Britain when he worked for the previous weapons inspectors in Baghdad. "We have decided to resist. We have no other choice," Mr Aziz said.

The Iraqi government is confident that it can hold out because the mood of the international community towards sanctions is changing, with a growing number of western governments being subjected to public pressure over the harsh humanitarian consequences of the UN measures.

Iraq's borders are becoming increasingly porous and several countries are re-establishing normal diplomatic ties. Mr Aziz was delighted by the extent of in-fighting within the security council that has left the US and Britain increasingly isolated in their handling of the Saddam regime.

The Iraqi government does not expect any deal before next year. The Iraqi foreign minister, Mohamed Said Sahaf, in a separate interview, said: "The UN is going to be prevented from taking any serious step until they see the result of the American election. Then we will reach the crossroads. At that juncture, the majority will be leaning towards a political solution. I believe the political solution will prevail."

US and British intelligence sources say that while they are satisfied that Iraq no longer has nuclear weapons, it still has relatively small amounts of biological and chemical weapons, and possibly some missiles. The previous arms inspectors were withdrawn in 1998, claiming that Baghdad was failing to cooperate.

Mr Aziz denied having any weapons of mass destruction. "When you make allegations that Iraq is hiding biological weapons, you have no evidence," he said.

"A helicopter with the right equipment can trace any biological or chemical particles. It can cover tens of thousands of square miles, and they had such helicopters flying all over Iraq for years, but still they say that Saddam has biological weapons. Where is the evidence?"

His main complaint was that the UN resolution was so ambiguous that the new weapons inspectors would never be satisfied, and that Iraq would have the worst of both worlds: the sanctions still in place and the inspectors back in Baghdad. In such circumstances, he said, Iraq might as well continue to show as much ingenuity as possible to survive under the sanctions.

He was confident that the sanctions would eventually be lifted. The Iraqi government might accept a compromise in which the sanctions were lifted simultaneously with the return of weapons inspectors to Baghdad. It would also insist that the inspectors' remit was tightly drawn.

The Labour MP George Galloway yesterday delivered a truckload of medicine to the Red Crescent headquarters in Baghdad, in defiance of the British government and the UN sanctions committee's refusal to allow him to fly the £115,000 worth of supplies direct from London to Baghdad.

Mr Galloway told the Red Crescent staff and government officials: "We will not stop until this great crime [sanctions] is stopped and this great stain on the US and Britain is expunged."

fields.headline: Airships can help detect landmines
fields.trailText: They move silently. They do not vibrate. They fly low and slow and they can stay in the air without refuelling for 15 hours. Airships could be the perfect platform for sweeping the countryside for concealed landmines.
fields.body:
They move silently. They do not vibrate. They fly low and slow and they can stay in the air without refuelling for 15 hours. Airships could be the perfect platform for sweeping the countryside for concealed landmines.

Richard Branson's Lightship Group - which runs airships as film platforms for sports events - has gone into partnership with Dera, the defence research agency, to develop a new way of looking for landmines lurking in 900,000 sq kms of former battlefields.

Landmines kill or maim 25,000 a year. There could be 70 million unexploded mines in the world's old battlefields, from Kosovo to Mozambique, covering an area the size of France and Germany combined.

Lady Symons, minister for defence procurement, said: "The Red Cross estimates that someone, somewhere, is injured or killed by landmines every 20 minutes. This really is appalling."

The Mineseeker project began with Mr Branson, who said the idea came to him when watching the evening news. He approached the defence research agency, which was also thinking about faster ways of surveying a landscape for hidden death, and offered one of his airships as a testbed. The first trials have shown that an ultra-wide band radar system mounted on a steady platform underneath an airship can bounce signals off the ground. Landmines are mostly of a characteristic size, and symmetrical. Whether metal or plastic, the radar beams can pick them up and return a characteristic reflection.

The real challenge, according to Sir John Chisholm, chief of Dera, is handling the data. An ultra-wide band radar system dumps the equivalent of the data content of the entire British Library into the airship's detectors every second. But powerful computers and sophisticated mathematics mean the signals can be digitised and scanned for tell-tale echoes as they happen.

Experts calculate that landmines somewhere in the terrain may account for up to four times as much valuable land being closed off because their exact locality is not known. In theory, said Sir John, a systematic radar sweep should reveal where the hazards really are. Then, farmers could get back to safe fields and mine clearance experts would know where to begin looking systematically.

Dera and the Lightship Group are to spend the next 18 months refining the detector system and perfecting a protoype.

fields.headline: Tycoon pledges £12m for city academies
fields.standfirst:
Businessman offers cash to scheme for failing inner city schools

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: A millionaire businessman closely associated with Conservative education reforms yesterday jumped to the defence of the government by promising £12m to revive failing inner city schools.
fields.body:
A millionaire businessman closely associated with Conservative education reforms yesterday jumped to the defence of the government by promising £12m to revive failing inner city schools.

Peter Vardy, head of one of Britain's largest car retailers, offered the cash to kick-start David Blunkett's controversial plan for a string of city academies which will report directly to the department for education and employment and be outside the control of local councils.

Although the initiative has been labelled "half-baked" by town halls and teaching unions, Mr Vardy hailed the plan - similar to the last government's city technology colleges - as a wonderful idea designed to help those most in need.

Mr Vardy has a strong philanthropic history - his charitable Vardy Foundation, which contains his private shareholding in Reg Vardy plc, has already supported Sunderland university's school of arts and design, and recently helped build schools and churches in Ethiopia, Bolivia and Moldova.

Eleven years ago Mr Vardy, whose Sunderland-based company has 80 car dealerships around the country, gave £2m to set up Emmanuel city technology college in Gateshead, which achieves some of the country's best GCSE results.

Backed by business, charities and churches, the new city academies are designed to change the face of education in inner cities - although councils fear they are designed to begin the process of removing schools from local education authority control.

The academies will be allowed to change the length of the school day, specialise more and pay teachers more. The first is due to open in September next year.

Mr Vardy, 53, a practising Christian, said he wanted to cooperate with councils. He was offering £12m to help build or convert six schools preferably in the north-east.

While areas of high unemployment, such as Newcastle's west end, Sunderland and Teesside, are priorities, Mr Vardy said he would go where the need is greatest.

But he said he hoped to find other partners so that more schools could be developed. "To be able to build six more Emmanuel colleges must be a tremendous opportunity for parents, students and anyone interested in education."

Sir Cyril Taylor, chairman of the technology colleges trust, said businesses welcomed Mr Blunkett's plan and were already volunteering partners, although Mr Vardy had made the first concrete offer. But he suggested that converting existing schools was more practical than building new ones because of prohibitive costs. This raises the prospect of the department for education and employment taking over failing inner city schools and handing them over to trusts, or companies, which will run the new academies.

Born in Houghton-le-Spring, near Sunderland, and educated at Durham School, Mr Vardy is regarded as a tough businessman with a strong social conscience.

He said: "It's nice to put something back into the north-east because we have been very successful in the region. As a Christian, I am keen that students are given a good moral education as well as a good academic education."

webTitle: Parents win right to sue council over sex abuser

fields.headline: Parents win right to sue council over sex abuser
fields.trailText: The parents of four children who were sexually abused by a teenager placed with them for fostering won a seven year legal battle yesterday for the right to sue the council which persuaded them to take him into their home.
fields.body:
The parents of four children who were sexually abused by a teenager placed with them for fostering won a seven year legal battle yesterday for the right to sue the council which persuaded them to take him into their home.

The House of Lords unanimously ruled that the couple, who can be named only as Mr and Mrs W, can claim compensation from Essex county council.

The parents and children tried to sue the council and the social worker in the case after learning that the council knew when it placed the 15-year-old in their home that he had been cautioned by police for an indecent assault on his three-year-old sister and was being investigated for an alleged rape.

The parents had stipulated when signing up to foster that they would not accept any child who was a known or suspected sex abuser.

But the council cited earlier cases in which courts had ruled that local authorities could not be sued over the way they handled their child care duties.

In 1997 a high court judge struck out the parents' claims but allowed the children's to go ahead. The following year the court of appeal upheld both decisions.

The teenager spent a month with the family in 1993, during which he subjected the three girls and one boy, aged between eight and 12, to sexual abuse.

The children were all diagnosed as suffering from post-traumatic stress disorder.

The parents blamed themselves and both suffered severe depression. They felt unable to go on working as foster parents and Mr W could not continue as a youth worker. Their marriage broke up.

A psychiatrist's report said: "The effect on the family as a whole has been devastating. From a previously well-functioning family, their functioning has deteriorated markedly. They have lost employment. Their marital relationship has deteriorated and both parents have had increased illness since the disclosure of these events."

The parents lost in the lower courts for the same reason that the families of the Hillsborough football ground disaster victims were denied compensation.

The House of Lords held in the Hillsborough case that "secondary" victims - those who did not suffer the assault or accident themselves - could claim compensation for their psychological trauma only if they saw the incident with their own eyes or came upon the scene soon after.

The parents' QC, Allan Levy, argued that they were "primary" victims of the disaster because they had played a part, although unintentionally, in bringing the abuser and the abused children together.

Lord Slynn of Hadley, delivering judgment, said previous cases did not rule out this interpretation.

"I am not persuaded that in a situation like the present the parents must come across the abuser or the abused immediately after the sexual incident has terminated."

The ruling means only that the parents have the right to take their case to court.

They will still have to satisfy the trial judge that they are entitled to compensation.
