fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Footballers bailed
fields.body:
Footballers bailed

Two footballers charged with threatening behaviour were yesterday remanded on bail until April 4.

Stockport County defender Tony Dinning, 24, and Sheffield United defender Michael Brown, 23, were arrested last week after an alleged bust-up at a pub in Manchester, the city's magistrates heard.

The players and company director Paul Stringer, 28, are charged with threatening behaviour, while Stringer is also accused of assaulting police. The crown dropped a charge of affray against him and Dinning.

Drug may halt memory loss

The effects of old age could be slowed by the discovery of a drug which reverses memory loss, according to a study published yesterday in Science magazine. People suffering from Parkinson's disease, schizophrenia and other illnesses could also benefit, scientists believe.

The drug, ABT 431, reversed working memory loss when it was tested on monkeys by scientists from Yale university school of medicine in the US. Scientists now want to conduct clinical trials.

Man questioned on baby's death

Police in Cumbria yesterday arrested a man in his 50s over the discovery of a baby's body on a rubbish tip 10 years ago.

The police repeated an appeal they made in December, the 10th anniversary of the find, asking for anyone with fresh information to come forward. Following that appeal an anonymous caller left a message, and detectives are keen for them to call again.

A council worker found the charred and mutilated remains of a boy, aged 12-18 months, on the tip at Redhills in Millom on December 1, 1989.

The child's identity and his cause of death were never established. - John-Dominic Clare

Judge to rule on Shayler case

An Old Bailey judge will rule today on whether the Guardian and Observer newspapers should be forced to hand over information they allegedly hold on the former MI5 agent David Shayler.

Both newspapers are fighting separate applications for production orders issued by special branch, which is investigating allegations that the former spy has breached the official secrets act. Lawyers for the newspapers have argued that the orders are an infringement of freedom of expression.

Racing pigeons' sound barrier

Concorde was yesterday blamed for confusing the homing instincts of racing pigeons.

Shockwaves created by the jet as it breaks the sound barrier are claimed to make the birds go deaf. The pigeons are thought to recognise low-frequency sound to map their route.

Jon Hagstrum, a geophysicist at the US Geological Society, in California, makes the claim in New Scientist magazine.

A council worker found the charred and mutilated remains of a boy, aged 12-18 months, on the tip at Redhills in Millom on December 1, 1989. The child's identity and his cause of death were never established. - John-Dominic Clare Judge to rule on Shayler case An Old Bailey judge will rule today on whether the Guardian and Observer newspapers should be forced to hand over information they allegedly hold on the former MI5 agent David Shayler. Both newspapers are fighting separate applications for production orders issued by special branch, which is investigating allegations that the former spy has breached the official secrets act. Lawyers for the newspapers have argued that the orders are an infringement of freedom of expression. Racing pigeons' sound barrier Concorde was yesterday blamed for confusing the homing instincts of racing pigeons. Shockwaves created by the jet as it breaks the sound barrier are claimed to make the birds go deaf. The pigeons are thought to recognise low-frequency sound to map their route. Jon Hagstrum, a geophysicist at the US Geological Society, in California, makes the claim in New Scientist magazine.

webTitle: Greenhouse rock boosts growth rate of plants

fields.headline: Greenhouse rock boosts growth rate of plants
fields.trailText: Plants grow better when there is music in the greenhouse, according to scientists at the University of Sussex.
fields.body:
Plants grow better when there is music in the greenhouse, according to scientists at the University of Sussex.

Wallflowers, busy lizzies, carrots and mung beans exposed to Meatloaf's Bat Out Of Hell for seven days grew measurably faster and stronger than plants cosseted by Rachmaninov's piano concerto No 2. But Peter Scott and a student, Ruth Davies, of the university's botany department may have a disappointment in store for people planning a heavy metal diet for their petunias.

It may not be the music - it may just be the extra energy cascading from the speaker units. They used a CD player which played the same music for seven days on end, and then chose their three experimental records.

Vegetables liked Meatloaf. Bat Out Of Hell increased both germination rate and root and shoot growth across a wide range of plants. Rachmaninov took them nowhere. Unfortunately there is unlikely to be a horticultural hit parade.

Dr Scott, who will present his results to a meeting of experimental biologists later this month, suspects it is the energy of the sound that gets the growth going, not the music itself. He thinks the sound boosts growth by producing heat.

webTitle: Relics of Scott's last journey to go on show

fields.headline: Relics of Scott's last journey to go on show
fields.trailText: The sealskin overshoes worn by Captain Scott on his disastrous last expedition to the South Pole are being conserved at the National Maritime Museum, and will go on display for the first time this year.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, Arts and Heritage Correspondent
fields.body:
The sealskin overshoes worn by Captain Scott on his disastrous last expedition to the South Pole are being conserved at the National Maritime Museum, and will go on display for the first time this year.

The shoes, patched and with almost all the seal fur worn away, are mute witnesses to the appalling journey which led to the death of Captain Oates, 88 years ago today, in a vain attempt to save the lives of the rest of the team.

On March 17 1912 Captain Scott wrote about Oates, in his journal: "He slept through the night hoping not to wake, but he awoke in the morning. It was blowing a blizzard. Oates said 'I am just going outside and I may be some time." He went out into the blizzard and we have not seen him since. We knew that Oates was walking to his death, but though we tried to dissuade him we knew it was the act of a brave man and an English gentleman."

Oates was suffering, like the rest of the men, from starvation, scurvy - which had caused an old war wound to break open again - and advanced frost bite. "The agony he must have been in is impossible to imagine," David Spence, curator of the exhibition, said yesterday. "In order to keep going at all he had to keep his feet frozen - if they had thawed he would have been unable to stand at all."

The cruel conditions were ideal for conserving objects: the shoes, like most of the other material recovered, are in remarkable condition.

The shoes were found beside Scott's body, and brought back, with other items, including Scott's journal, by the admiralty exhibition which had to wait six months during one of the worst recorded Antarctic winters before going in search of the men. The expedition never found the body of Evans, the first to die, or Oates, but they found Scott, Bowers and Wilson dead in their tent, just 11 miles from base camp, food and shelter. They collapsed the tent, and heaped snow over it as a tomb.

The exhibition will trace the journeys of early polar expeditions, particularly the race for the South Pole between Captain Scott and his Norwegian rival, Roald Amundsen. Scott's team died after the bitter discovery of Amundsen's flag flying at the pole.

"Ironically there was a Norwegian member of the admiralty team, Tryggve Gran, and when the others went in he stayed outside out of respect. He took off his own skis and made them into a cross outside the tent, and then skied back on Scott's skis - and we found those skis in a Norwegian skiing museum, which is lending us them for the exhibition," Mr Spence said.

The shoes were among many objects passed by the Admiralty to the National Maritime Museum when it was established in the 1930s. The two men will come closer in the exhibition than they did in life: the Oslo museum is lending a wealth of Amundsen material, including his flag.

The Greenwich team was interested to learn the Norwegians' view of the rivals: "They thought Amundsen a thorough professional, who trained rigorously and became fantastically skilful in using skis and handling dogs. Scott, they thought, was extremely brave, but essentially a gentleman - and an amateur."

webTitle: Birmingham targets 300 tower blocks for bulldozer

fields.headline: Birmingham targets 300 tower blocks for bulldozer
fields.standfirst:
Britain's housing problem explained

DETR: the government's housing policy
fields.trailText: First they decided to pull down that ultimate symbol of post-war brutalism, the Bullring shopping centre. Now Birmingham city council has taken demolition to its heart by signalling the end of another great Sixties institution - high-rise living.
fields.body:
First they decided to pull down that ultimate symbol of post-war brutalism, the Bullring shopping centre. Now Birmingham city council has taken demolition to its heart by signalling the end of another great Sixties institution - high-rise living.

Faced with a multi-billion pound repairs backlog, it is drawing up plans to demolish up to 300 tower blocks - the largest number in any English city - and replace them with more conventional low-rise homes. The council, which is the biggest municipal landlord in the country, believes it is throwing good money after bad by spending tens of millions propping up the troublesome, system-built blocks, which cost considerably more to maintain than conventional homes.

Its far-reaching proposals form part of a prospectus presented to the government outlining plans to transfer all 90,000 council homes in the city to a series of "social companies", which will be partly run by the tenants themselves.

The companies, unlike the council, will be able to raise money for repairs - and for future housebuilding - by borrowing on the open market, using projected income from rents as security. But the tower blocks are seen as a financial liability.

Graham Farrant, Birmingham's housing director, says demolition is a popular choice among some tenants, although others still preferred high-rising living. He insists tower blocks fulfilled a need in the 60s. "The name of the game then was to build as many flats in the shortest possible time - the driving forces were speed and efficiency - but now the agenda has changed, and people are more concerned about the quality of their environment."

He added: "Forty years ago there was a lot of optimism - streets in the sky and all that - but in reality they turned out to be rather different with people complaining of social isolation. They can be very effective if they are well maintained and in the right location. But in the wrong place they can be very unpopular - they can move very quickly from one extreme to the other."

A contrite city council has not been afraid to admit past errors. One town hall report has spoken of the need for a concerted effort to "remedy the mistakes of the past ... moving forward from the concrete jungle." Sixties planning, it concluded, produced a physical environment that did not stand the test of time.

Sir Michael Lyons, Birmingham's chief executive, has said past errors, such as the soon-to-be demolished Bullring, and the city's maze of dual-carriageways, should be openly acknowledged. "It is cause to be humble," he added. "The people responsible for the city in the 60s were not idiots, they were not malevolent ... they thought they were building for the needs of the time."

But errors have proved expensive. Birmingham now has a housing debt of well over £600m, fuelled by the cost of maintaining high rise homes.

fields.headline: National Roundup
fields.trailText: Man's head found by railway line
fields.body:
Man's head found by railway line

Police have launched a murder inquiry after a man's decaying head was discovered in a bag at the side of a railway line near a Derby industrial estate. It was found by a man taking a short cut across the line on Wednesday afternoon.

The body has yet to be found. A home office pathologist carried out a postmortem examination on the remains at Derbyshire royal infirmary.

It is understood an expert in dental forensics was called in to help possible identification. A forensic entomologist - expert in insects - was also understood to have been requested to determine how long the head had been on the railway embankment.

A police source said: "At this stage we do not even know if the decapitation was the cause of death." Officers were in contact with colleagues in Lincolnshire investigating the disappearance of a restaurateur.

But early forensic tests eliminated the possibility of the head belonging to 25-year-old Rumel Iqbal Baker. Two men, Mark Falco, 39, and William Wharton, 55, both from the Lincoln area, are in custody accused of his murder despite no body being found.

£26,000 for 'disaster' holidays

A group of holidaymakers was yesterday awarded a total of £26,000 compensation for a luxury break that turned into a disaster. Two elderly couples and a family of four had paid £7,000 each to travel by Concorde to Barbados in December 1998.

When they arrived at the four star Tamarind Cove hotel in St James for the 10-day holiday they found workmen's rubbish, cement mixers and wires hanging out of the walls, Central London county court heard.

Businessman Brian Sullivan, 56, his wife Jean, 52, and their daughters Nicola, 20, and Tara, 21, from Lymm in Cheshire, were awarded a total of £12,000 for loss of enjoyment and inconvenience.

Farmers Ronald Constantine, 72, and his wife, Prudence, 67, from Devizes in Wiltshire, were awarded £9,000, and retired quantity surveyor Gordon Laurie, 78, and his wife Thelma, 75, of Milton, Cambridgeshire, were awarded £5,000.

They claimed the damages from tour operator Super- lative Travel, but the compensation is to be paid by the hotel. The holiday company was ruled to have booked the trip in good faith.

Judge Kenneth Zuker said the hotel was disorganised and inefficient. "This was an expensive package in a hotel where high standards could reasonably be expected."

Deft gadget puts kettle in hot water

Waiting for the kettle to boil could soon become a thing of the past with the launch today of a new kitchen appliance which provides boiling water at the turn of a tap.

The device, named Boiling Point, was one of a selection of new products to be unveiled at the Ideal Home Show at Earls Court, west London.

The urn-like dispenser, which fits under the sink, refills and reboils automatically.

It can be fitted and working in 20 minutes and requires no plumbing experience to fit, plugging into a 13 amp socket, according to Leicester-based manufacturers Hotta (UK) Ltd.

The Design Council chief executive, Andrew Summers, said: "Boiling Point is one of the most innovative products and services created in Britain for the new millennium."

Other inventions on display include DrainSmart, a device which fits on to pipes to filter out leaves and a vegetable drainer which clips on to pans to remove the need for a colander.

Dyson also demonstrated its hands-free automatic vacuum cleaner which uses 50 sensors to navigate its way around a room.

The event continues until April 9.

How to get your pint quickly

More than two-thirds of bar staff have regularly and deliberately ignored customers, according to a survey published yesterday.

Bar staff questioned for the report said customers who banged on the bar were most likely to be ignored, followed by shouters, whistlers, finger clickers and money wavers.

Female bar staff also revealed that male customers who flirted outrageously with them were likely to be ignored for the whole evening.

The research, commissioned by Guinness to coincide with St Patrick's Day today, does offer a few tips to thirsty drinkers on how to get served quickly.

According to the 1,220 bar staff interviewed the key to rapid service is a good position, a pensive worried expression, and a polite approach.

Guinness advised customers to:

 Select your bar position with care - almost half of bar staff (47%) recommended standing directly opposite the till as the bar staff must return there after each sale;

 Lean over the bar at 45 degrees - two-thirds felt this was the optimum angle. Any further and it is too close, any less implies not being that thirsty;

 Adopt a "rabbit in headlights look" - 30% of bar staff spot anxious looking customers. Looking too calm can indicate that a customer has already been served;

 Point to the person next to you as being next in line - a quarter of all bar staff said they would return to you next;

 Nod knowingly - 70% of bar staff claimed they give a quick nod to a customer to let them know they are on their way. Get your nod in first in their direction and they will feel obliged to serve you next.

Judges cut £4m fine for oil spillage

The court of appeal yesterday reduced to £750,000 a record £4m fine imposed on Milford Haven port authority over the Sea Empress oil tanker spillage.

The authority had argued that the fine - four times higher than the previous largest for pollution - was "far in excess of that which was proper or fair".

Lord Bingham, the lord chief justice, Mr Justice Alliott and Mr Justice Newman were told that the fine imposed by Mr Justice David Steel at Cardiff crown court in January last year had put the viability of the authority at risk.

More than 72,000 tonnes of crude oil were spilt at the entrance to Milford Haven estuary after the tanker ran aground in February 1996 in the wake of a navigational error by an inexperienced port authority pilot.

The disaster contaminated 120 miles of Welsh coastline and necessitated a £60m clean-up operation.

Lord Bingham said in judgment that the appeal court fully appreciated the trial judge's reasons for regarding the spillage as a very serious case calling for a substantial penalty. The judge had failed to give full credit to the authority's plea of guilty and had also failed to consider the possible impact of the £4m fine on the authority's ability to perform its public functions. The fine was "manifestly excessive".

Ted Sangster, managing director of Milford Haven port authority, said: "The fine is one which we can pay without threatening the long-term future of the business. Lessons have been learned and changes have taken place in reducing the risk of this happening again in the future."

Mall fined £100,000 for boy's death

A shopping centre was yesterday fined £100,000 at Manchester crown court for an accident in which a six-year-old boy was crushed to death.

Samuel Adams, from Altrincham, Greater Manchester, was killed by an 18 stone balustrade propped up against a wall at the Trafford Centre. It fell on him as he played on a stage in October 1998.

The Trafford Centre had earlier pleaded guilty at Trafford magistrates court to breaching the health and safety at work act. It was also ordered to pay £13,000 court costs.

Andrew Long, prosecuting, told the crown court that departmental managers at the centre were unclear about their health and safety duties.

Andrew Sander, for the centre, said the management had to accept there had been inadequate delegation about whose duty it should have been to replace the balustrades.

The judge, Mr Justice Penry-Davey, said: "It should have been obvious that large heavy items propped at an angle and unsecured could fall."

Samuel's parents, Paul, 36 and Dawn, 35, described the fine as paltry. - Helen Carter

webTitle: RUC bomb find foils St Patrick's Day attack

fields.headline: RUC bomb find foils St Patrick's Day attack
fields.standfirst:
Three men held after fertiliser device discovered as cars are stopped near Mandelson residence

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The RUC believes it has foiled a St Patrick's Day attack after intercepting a Real IRA bomb near Northern Ireland secretary Peter Mandelson's official residence in Hillsborough, Co Down.
fields.body:
The RUC believes it has foiled a St Patrick's Day attack after intercepting a Real IRA bomb near Northern Ireland secretary Peter Mandelson's official residence in Hillsborough, Co Down.

Detectives were questioning three men last night after finding 500lbs of home-made explosives when they stopped two cars late on Wednesday. One is a former republican prisoner released last year under the Good Friday agreement. Another lost his brother in an IRA punishment attack.

Police swooped after a long-term surveillance operation, dealing a serious blow to the dissident republican group. The home-made bomb, which had fertiliser as its key component, was not primed, but security sources were anticipating an imminent attack.

Intelligence sources believe the intended target was a security base. There have been increasing fears of an attack at Palace Barracks in Holywood, Co Down, with several republicans seen in the area recently.

The cars were stopped on the Belfast to Dublin road, which passes near the republican heartland of south Armagh. Security sources say the intentions of paramilitaries there are increasingly difficult to read.

Those held are believed to have been en route to west Belfast to put together a bomb similar in type and size to the device which devastated Omagh, Co Tyrone, in August 1998. It killed 29 people in the single worst atrocity of the troubles.

The former prisoner was on the Irish National Liberation Army wing at the Maze. He was jailed for five years for sending letter bombs to Ulster Unionist leader David Trimble and UK Unionist party chief Robert McCartney, but was freed two months after sentence.

Security sources believe the Real IRA was behind two bombing attempts last month. The terror group, formed in October 1997 after the IRA split over political strategy, is still on the ceasefire it called shortly after the Omagh bombing.

Its operatives were disturbed when planting a device at Shackleton Barracks at Ballykelly, Co Londonderry. The bomb, placed against quarters where 30 soldiers were sleeping, failed to explode properly.

A rocket launcher was then found near a security base in Dungannon, Co Tyrone. It was of a type never before seen in Northern Ireland.

The Continuity IRA, the only dissident group not on ceasefire, had been blamed for those attacks. But it later denied involvement.

They were worried whether security was being sacrificed for expediency.

fields.headline: Shark suits give swimmers speed
fields.trailText: Imitation shark skin was unveiled yesterday as the latest weapon in the battle to allow the world's top swimmers to register record speeds.
fields.body:
Imitation shark skin was unveiled yesterday as the latest weapon in the battle to allow the world's top swimmers to register record speeds.

Swimwear manufacturers Speedo have produced a revolutionary swimsuit which mimics a shark's skin, using a biomimetic (imitating nature) process. It allows swimmers to glide through water faster.

The swimsuit is covered in dermal denticles, tiny v-shaped ridges that cover a shark's skin.

Denticles allow water to flow smoothly over the shark's body, reducing drag while increasing speed. Some sharks can swim at 40mph.

A team of world class swimmers have tried the swimsuit and, it is claimed, found that it increased their overall times by 3% - a considerable improvement in a sport where split seconds can make a difference between winning and losing.

Ian Ferguson, chairman of the Shark Trust at the National Marine Aquarium in Plymouth, said: "The dermal denticles improve the efficiency of sharks in the water, allowing some of them to swim enormous distances with very little energy.

"We have been wondering how long it will take people to catch on to this idea and make use of it. The same technology could be used in yachting and other sports. The denticles are adaptations that sharks have had for many millions of years."

Initially, 6,000 suits are to be produced for the world's top swimmers and could be used in the Olympics. Most will be fitted using body scanning techniques, allowing a skin-tight match to the contours of a swimmer's physique.

A retail version of the shark swim suit is expected to go on sale this year.

webTitle: Surgery unlikely to aid 'the English Patient'

fields.headline: Surgery unlikely to aid 'the English Patient'
fields.standfirst: Difficulties of reviving Longbridge may lead to mass redundancies and reorganisation into a sports car specialistRover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: BMW's radical surgery on what German executives snidely dismiss as the English Patient is unlikely to inspire a recovery of what is an already very sick car company.
fields.byline: Mark Milner  in Munich and  Kevin Maguire
fields.body:
BMW's radical surgery on what German executives snidely dismiss as the English Patient is unlikely to inspire a recovery of what is an already very sick car company.

Carving up the body of Rover into small bits when the rest of the motor industry is merging appears to make little sense and may spell doom.

If BMW, the world's 14th biggest car firm, could not deliver the economies of scale and productivity gains needed to secure Longbridge, what chance a group of venture capitalists?

The Alchemy Partnership's first big idea is to change Rover's name to the MG Car Company but it will take more than a shiny new badge to avoid this acquisition crashing.

City buccaneer Jon Moulton may be about to discover that saving an ailing motor manufacturer is trickier than reviving Fatty Arbuckles restaurants and Fads DIY stores.

Pessimistic union leaders are braced for thousands of redundancies and fear, by the time Alchemy comes to sell it on after five or six years, it will be a shadow of its once great self.

Under the agreement with BMW to be finalised over the next six weeks, Alchemy will take the Rover cars - the 25, 45 and 75 models plus the old Mini and the MGF sports car.

The plan centres on the division of the two main manufacturing plants: Longbridge with 8,500 jobs and Cowley with 3,500. At present Cowley makes the 75 executive model, Longbridge the smaller 25 and 45 models while work is already some way down the track at the West Midlands site to build a production line for the new Mini.

As part of the deal agreed in principle between BMW and Alchemy the German carmaker will continue to supply the latter's MG Car Company with 75 models produced at Cowley.

Though the move will mean BMW retains more responsibility for Rover than it might ideally like, it ensures production and sales of the 75 will not be hit by more potentially damaging disruption. BMW will also provide support to help establish the 25 and 45 models.

However, work on the new Mini assembly line at Longbridge is to be halted and the machinery transferred to Cowley with BMW stating yesterday it expected the new car to be in showrooms by early summer of next year.

Perhaps as importantly as what was said in the Munich announcement, was what was not said. No mention was made of the "jewel in the crown" Land Rover, Freelander, Discovery, Defender and Range Rover four-wheel drive vehicles coming out of the Solihull plant, which employs 10,000. These models are hugely popular.

BMW may yet hang on to Solihull, rebranding it as the BMW Range Rover. But T&G transport union chief negotiator Tony Woodley's disclosure that a potential bidder is already waiting in the wings suggests the company could be persuaded to sell if the price was right

The four-wheel drive range would fit nicely into virtually any of the big companies, appealing to country weekenders with money to spend as well as parents on the school run. Ford is said to be interested.

Yesterday's BMW announcement gave little direct indication of the impact on Longbridge jobs as Alchemy pledged to "employ a significant workforce".

But "significant" redundancies are the likely outcome as the new owners struggle to turn huge losses into profits.

Longbridge's employees produce an average of 21 cars each a year compared with 33 across Rover as a whole - making the plant one of the most inefficient in Europe. Nissan, the most productive, churns out 98 per worker.

While Alchemy, with BMW backing, will be able to get the existing model range to market the key will be its appetite and ability to develop its own models thereafter.

One possibility would be for it to share the burden by, for example, taking another manufacturer's model on which to build a new car. That would solve one of the problems with which Rover has struggled - it had nine models for just 500,000 vehicles a year.

"The new company will focus on development of a state of the art British-built product range worthy of the sporting heritage of the MG name," said Alchemy.

Union leaders fear it will produce the 25, 45 and 75 models while buyers can be found and concentrate any future investment on sports cars.

They claim Alchemy may turn out to be little better than asset strippers, imposing redundancies and selling off surplus land.

When the "for sale" sign goes up for the business in five or six years, it may be a specialist MG sports car company that is put on the market.

webTitle: Britain bottom of table for child well-being

fields.headline: Britain bottom of table for child well-being
fields.standfirst: Ministers under pressure to act quickly as researchers stigmatise Britain as the worst place to be young in the entire European Union
fields.trailText: Britain is the worst place to be a child in the European Union, according to a study of child poverty published today.
fields.body:
Britain is the worst place to be a child in the European Union, according to a study of child poverty published today.

The study, by Unicef researchers for the Institute of Public Policy Research, indicates that the UK comes last among all 15 EU countries on three of seven specific indicators of child well-being, and is below average on a further two.

Britain's bottom ranking, below poorer countries including Portugal and Greece, has heightened pressure on the government to move more quickly to fulfil its pledge to tackle child poverty, described by the chancellor, Gordon Brown, as a "scar on the soul of Britain".

He is expected to announce in Tuesday's budget further measures to direct money to poorer children, but child poverty campaigners are urging ministers to accelerate the drive to end child poverty within 10 years instead of the promised 20.

Child poverty in Britain has trebled in the past 20 years and four in 10 British children are born into low income households, according to ministers. In a second study today, carried out for Unicef, specialists at the London School of Economics calculate that Labour's present policies will lift 1m children out of poverty but leave 2m in it.

The IPPR study, published in its journal, New Economy, finds the UK comes bottom of the European league in the number of children in poor households, the number in homes where no adult is working and teen pregnancy rates.

In Britain, 32% of children live in poor households, compared with 13% in Germany, 12% in France and an EU average of 20%.

An increase in child poverty (defined as the number of children living in households with under half average income) was common across the EU in the 1980s and 1990s, according to the report's authors, John Micklewright and Kitty Stewart. But the UK experienced an above-average rise - over 40% between 1986 and 1991 - despite having the average GDP per head.

At the top of the league, Denmark has the smallest proportion of children in poor households - just 5% - while Greece and Portugal had the fewest children in workless households.

The UK also does badly on the two educational measures included in the parcel of seven indicators. Only Portugal, Greece and Luxembourg have a smaller proportion of 16-year-olds in education, and seven countries do better than the UK in maths results for 14-year-olds.

The UK's child mortality rate is only marginally lower than the EU average of 7.5 per 1000.

However, Britain outstrips all other EU countries but Sweden on the seventh indicator - child deaths in traffic accidents. The UK average is 2.9 deaths per 100,000 five to 14-year-olds, compared with an EU average of 3.6.

The figures, the most recent available, date from 1993-96 and therefore represent the situation Labour inherited when coming to power in 1997. However, the researchers argue that the findings indicate the size of the mountain the government has to climb if it is to fulfil its child poverty pledge, issued by Tony Blair last year.

Lisa Harker, IPPR research director, said: "We should not underestimate the enormity of the task ahead. Child poverty is not a problem that can be resolved overnight, nor in one single budget. The government will need to be bold if it is to hold its head up high in Europe."

The Child Poverty Action Group said the figures added weight to its call for faster measures to eradicate child poverty. A spokesman, Geoff Finister, said: "There is now a clear case for the government to step up its efforts. We believe a 10-year programme would be more satisfactory."

According to government figures, 750,000 children have been lifted out of poverty as a result of its reforms. Ministers have focused on using work as the lever to lift families with children out of poverty, rather than raise benefits. A range of measures, notably the working families tax credit, have been used to help parents into work and to make work pay for those already in low income jobs.

The chancellor is expected to unveil in the budget details of an integrated child credit, under which the current raft of state allowances for children - with the exception of child benefit - will be brought under a single banner.

By next year, even before the new machinery is in place, the poorest families should be receiving £45 a week for each child, which government officials insist amounts to the most generous state help for children ever.

The Liberal Democrat social security spokesman, Steve Webb, said the new figures showed "what a divided society Britain had become after 20 years of the Conservatives. A lot of these measures are either indicators of a divided nation or, like child mortality, symptoms of a divided nation."

While the government was right to set about tackling child poverty as a priority, it was too concerned with using work as the route to solving the problem. "There will always be a proportion of workless households in any conceivable future, and the question of benefit levels has to be part of the answer. This report shows many dimensions of poverty and we have got to take a multi-dimensioned approach."

webTitle: Wild promises as Sir Peter returns

fields.headline: Wild promises as Sir Peter returns
fields.trailText: Having done everything else in theatre, Sir Peter Hall is going back to his roots: for the first time since Waiting for Godot in 1955, he's back in fringe theatre, in London's perennially cash strapped and critically admired Gate Theatre.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy,  Arts and Heritage Correspondent
fields.body:
Having done everything else in theatre, Sir Peter Hall is going back to his roots: for the first time since Waiting for Godot in 1955, he's back in fringe theatre, in London's perennially cash strapped and critically admired Gate Theatre.

"He's a maverick, this is a maverick kind of place, and nobody else had asked him," Gate director Mick Gordon said.

"We discovered we were both interested in the same play, which nobody else would touch, so we rang him up and asked him and he said yes immediately - he's loving it."

Last year, after seeing the Sir Peter Hall Company evicted from the Old Vic in a change of ownership, and warning that he was going to decamp to America to be able to work and breathe, Sir Peter set up a new organisation to keep a wintry eye on what he denounced as Labour's miserable underfunding of the arts.

This year the ex-director of the Royal Shakespeare Company and ex-director of the National Theatre - and who has a long list list of stage, screen and opera productions in all the starriest theatres of the world -is finding out for himself how tough it is down among the grassroots.

The Gate is having an exceptionally virulent attack of its endless cash crisis - Mr Gordon said that if the theatre does not secure an extra £20,000 by the end of next week it may have close for part of next year.

But Sir Peter is guaranteed the theatre's standard director's fee: £200, for the entire three-week rehearsal period of Cuckoos, the show opening for previews next Tuesday. "That's a cheque, mind - he'll have to pay tax on it."

Cuckoos is a new translation by Colin Teevan - a friend of Mr Gordon's, and head of drama at Queen's University in Belfast - of a five-year-old Italian play by Giuseppe Manfridi. It is a black comedy. That is absolutely all Mr Gordon will say about it.

"It's not that Peter will come round and break my legs, it's just that he has forbidden us all to say one word more, it would spoil the surprise," he said.

But he dismisses reports that it concerns corpses, doctors, and "coitus ad infinitum on the living-room floor" as wide of the mark, but refuses to give any further guidance. "It's absolutely outrageous. Wild. Come and be shocked."

This year the ex-director of the Royal Shakespeare Company and ex-director of the National Theatre - and who has a long list list of stage, screen and opera productions in all the starriest theatres of the world -is finding out for himself how tough it is down among the grassroots. The Gate is having an exceptionally virulent attack of its endless cash crisis - Mr Gordon said that if the theatre does not secure an extra £20,000 by the end of next week it may have close for part of next year. But Sir Peter is guaranteed the theatre's standard director's fee: £200, for the entire three-week rehearsal period of Cuckoos, the show opening for previews next Tuesday. "That's a cheque, mind - he'll have to pay tax on it." Cuckoos is a new translation by Colin Teevan - a friend of Mr Gordon's, and head of drama at Queen's University in Belfast - of a five-year-old Italian play by Giuseppe Manfridi. It is a black comedy. That is absolutely all Mr Gordon will say about it. "It's not that Peter will come round and break my legs, it's just that he has forbidden us all to say one word more, it would spoil the surprise," he said. But he dismisses reports that it concerns corpses, doctors, and "coitus ad infinitum on the living-room floor" as wide of the mark, but refuses to give any further guidance. "It's absolutely outrageous. Wild. Come and be shocked."

webTitle: VAT move lifts hope of free museums

fields.headline: VAT move lifts hope of free museums
fields.trailText: The government's goal of free admission to all national museums and galleries by 2001, which had seemed doomed, may now be back on track.
fields.body:
The government's goal of free admission to all national museums and galleries by 2001, which had seemed doomed, may now be back on track.

An amendment to an obscure clause in VAT rules emerged yesterday as a possible solution to the impasse, which has caused the culture secretary, Chris Smith, acute discomfort.

His pledge of free admission for all to the 23 national collections shortly after Labour came to power was seen as a bold sign that the government was serious about social inclusion. But it was resisted from the outset by a small number of charging institutions led by the Science Museum who claimed that the compensation package was inadequate.

They insisted they would lose out twice because they would no longer be able to claim back their VAT. While Mr Smith was able to push through free admission for children last year, and an extension to pensioners will come into effect next month, the final move to universal free entry seemed beyond his reach.

With falling attendances figures already blamed on the psychological impact of charging by such institutions as the Natural History Museum and the V&A, museums themselves were also bitterly divided.

But a novel solution championed by the national arts collections fund, which has worked with the department of culture on the proposal, could circumvent the problem.

Under section 33 of the VAT act, local authorities and a number of organisations including the BBC are allowed to recover their tax. "It should be a fairly simple procedure," the fund spokeswoman said. "It applies to a very limited number of institutions so there is no question of customs and excise being swamped. The treasury could quickly and easily add the names of the 23 national collections to the list. The powers are there."

The treasury is seen as the real obstacle.

A department of culture spokesman said it was exploring the issues with customs and excise.

webTitle: 40m sheep to be tagged to monitor transmission of BSE from cattle

fields.headline: 40m sheep to be tagged to monitor transmission of BSE from cattle
fields.standfirst: What's wrong with our food? - special report
fields.trailText: The government is to tag all Britain's 40m sheep as scientists demand more screening to check that BSE has not leapt from cattle.
fields.body:
The government is to tag all Britain's 40m sheep as scientists demand more screening to check that BSE has not leapt from cattle.

The measures are expected to be in place by October to stave off threats of legal action by the European commission to ban all live sheep exports for the country's alleged failure to enable livestock to be traced back to the farms of their birth.

The government wants to prove that there could be no repeat of the BSE in cattle fiasco when for years there was no watertight tracking system to find out the provenance of cows that fell ill.

A commission official has told animal welfare activists led by TV scriptwriter Carla Lane that the government had told him that the "permanent marking" of all sheep and goats involving tagging would be in force within months.

A letter signed on behalf of Robert Coleman, director general of the commission's health and consumer protection directorate said his officials would "monitor the compliance" by Britain and would not proceed with legal action "providing the proposed timetable for regularisation is adhered to."

Ms Lane, director of the Protesters Animal Information Network, which opposes all live sheep exports now topping 1m animals a year, said: "The government is breaking the law. Farmers are not supposed to get subsidies unless they have proper traceability on their farms.

"There is a growing worry about BSE in sheep and if it is in sheep, God help us all."

Leaders of the industry which provides about 385,000 tonnes of sheep meat to consumers and receives £300m each year in so-called headage payments on sheep through the common agricultural policy, last night disputed whether BSE could appear in sheep.

They also warned the cost of implementing the scheme could prove another body-blow to hard pressed farmers but some conceded measures to ensure traceability of food could help farmers survive any further collapses in public confidence.

Scientists in Britain and Europe have been concerned about the possibility of BSE in sheep for at least four years. Although there is no evidence this has happened outside the laboratory, the government's spongiform encephalopathy advisory committee which advises on both measures against both BSE and its human form, variant CJD, have called for more checks on sheep brains for tell-tale signs of the disease.

Minutes of a meeting held last month and published yesterday state that the committee "agreed further work needed to be done on screening of sheep for evidence of infection by the BSE agent but concluded that at present there was no need for further public health controls".

John Thorley, chairman of the National Sheep Association, said yesterday there was little likelihood of BSE in sheep.

In addition, most people ate sheep as lambs between six and 10 months old, when the evidence suggested that BSE took years to develop. But he warned the industry could not bear excessive costs.

Henry Lewis, an official at the meat and livestock commission, said: "We have to be whiter than white and endorse a more rigid regime of indentification and traceability."

webTitle: Parents face jail for failing to stop truancy

fields.headline: Parents face jail for failing to stop truancy
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Parents will now face the ultimate sanction of being sent to prison for up to three months for failing to make their truanting children attend school, under a crime bill published by the home secretary, Jack Straw, yesterday.
fields.body:
Parents will now face the ultimate sanction of being sent to prison for up to three months for failing to make their truanting children attend school, under a crime bill published by the home secretary, Jack Straw, yesterday.

The fines to be levied on parents found guilty of failing to secure their children's attendence at school are also being raised from a maximum of £1,000 to £2,500.

But ministers have decided to go further for the first time and threaten the use of prison as well to deal with the problem of 80% of parents failing to turn up in court in truancy cases.

The powers in the criminal justice and court services bill published yesterday are part of a package of measures designed to boost the credibility of alternatives to prison, to reform the probation service and tackle the link between drugs and crime.

The bill will allow an expansion in the use of electronic tagging, including making it a condition for release from prison on licence and to introduce a new generation of monitoring equipment which will enable the law enforcement authorities to track the movement of convicted criminals, such as stalkers or sex offend ers, to stop them going near their victims.

These "exclusion" powers, which use tagging to prevent offenders visiting specified locations, are being put on the statute book now despite the fact that the introduction of this new technology is at least two years away.

Although trailed many times, the home secretary has shelved for the present plans to tag children as young as 10.

Mr Straw said his bill would also introduce a new "drug abstinence order" under which the courts will have the power to order a proven drug abuser using heroin, cocaine or other class A substance to stay clean from between six months and three years with regular drug tests on pain of a further penalty.

The bill also contains the power for compulsory drug testing of suspects arrested by the police and it confirms that this will not be used to test for cannabis but for class A drugs.

The home secretary said yesterday that similar powers will not be introduced to tackle the link between alcohol and particularly violent crime but said a white paper on controlling licensed premises would be issued soon.

Under new powers, offenders who breach the terms of their community penalty orders more than twice will face an immediate prison sentence of three months unless there are exceptional circumstances. More than 30,000 offenders are involved in breaking the terms of their probation orders and other sentences each year and the home office confirmed that such tougher enforcement could lead to an extra 15,000 in prison each year - adding 3,000 to the current daily prison population of 65,000.

The home office says this will add £60m to the annual prison bill.

Although Mr Straw has abandoned his plan to rename the probation service, the names of the various court orders are to be changed. So a probation order will be known in future as community rehabilitation orders, community service orders will become community punishment orders and combination orders are to be called community punishment and rehabilitation orders.

The home secretary said the bill was a key part of the government's continuing programme to clamp down on crime and to deal with its causes as well. He recognised that some of the measures were tough but said they were necessary to cut the proven link between hard drug abuse and crime.

The Liberal Democrat home affairs spokesman, Simon Hughes, said last night that new government figures showed that police numbers would fall by over 2,600 by the time of the next election. For the first time the home office has published a three-year prediction which estimates that by the end of March 2001 police numbers will have fallen by 2,658 since May 1997 despite the introduction of Mr Straw's crime fighting fund which will enable 5,000 extra recruits to be taken on in the next three years.

The shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, warned that, in a time of rising crime, the bill would fail unless there were sufficient police to implement the measures.

Penalty points

 £2,500 fines and possible jail for parents of truants

 Drug abstinence orders and compulsory testing of suspects for class A drugs

 Massive expansion of tagging including "tracking"

 Jail for breaches of community penalties

 Ban on convicted sex offenders working with children

 Roadside checks on drivers' licensing records

 New national probation service

 New children and family court advisory service

fields.headline: It's the way you sell 'em
fields.standfirst: Ever wondered why ads always have at least three blokes in the pub together, or why car commercials always feature a snaking mountain pass? It's because all adverts are bound by a host of unwritten 'rules'.  Belinda Archer explains
fields.trailText: Ever wondered why ads always have at least three blokes in the pub together, or why car commercials always feature a snaking mountain pass? It's because all adverts are bound by a host of unwritten 'rules'. Belinda Archer explains
fields.body:
Last week the latest Tango ad was banned. Why? Because it broke one of the great "rules" of advertising: don't encourage anti-social behaviour (it provoked playground bullying and shouting down megaphones into people's ears). Being banned is only one pitfall in the adversising world - the other big one is to have a terrible ad. But thankfully for advertisers there are plenty of strict guidelines laid down by the Independent Television Commission, the TV ads watchdog. And, unbeknownst to most of us, there are also the unwritten rules, guaranteed to keep clients happy and watchdogs at bay. Ignore them at your peril...

1. Always have at least three guys in the pub

Never use just one bloke on his own in a beer ad. Adfolk have long since learnt that this would imply he has no mates and is a sad loser. Similarly, two blokes are to be avoided - this might suggest unwanted homosexual overtones. No, the formula for beer advertising is three or more fellas in a jolly, sociable drinking environment. (The ITC actually outlaws the depiction of one man with a pint, claiming solitary drinking encourages alcoholism).

2. Always have two Cs in a K

The C stands for, well, a rude word for the female genitalia. The K stands for kitchen. This tried and tested approach to advertising washing-up powder or dishwasher detergent or any of the household cleaning products that tend to be exclusively targeted at women has worked for years. Happily, the formula is losing its supporters these days, but is still in evidence in ads for the more traditional fmcg (fast moving consumer goods) giants.

3. Always use that demo

"Demo" is short for "demonstration", and should be deployed by products which supposedly require a bit of explaining, usually by "experts" in white coats. Think Bounty kitchenroll, where a glass of water is poured onto the improbably ultra-absorbent paper. Think also any number of beauty and hair products - these invariably involve a sciencey bit, in which far-fetched computer graphics "demonstrate" the product at work.

4. Never, NEVER, use red

"Sanpro". You can trust adland to come up with a nicely sanitised word for what they see as a highly embarrassing market sector (namely, ahem, sanitary products). You must, of course, never, ever use red in this kind of advertisement. Oh no. You should always depict menstrual blood in a lurid blue - because red is, well, just too realistic and gruesome and therefore quite unacceptable in the shiny, Happy Family, pain-free world of adland.

5. Use that mountain pass

In car ads, you should always insist on an extended "packshot" (lingering product close-up) of your vehicle in one of three settings: snaking mountain pass, improbably lush Tuscan countryside, or field of flames. The trick is to get several shots of the motor being driven by some smug bloke along an impossibly windy road. The same rule applies to ads for tyres/petrol/oil.

6. Keep smiling

Received wisdom suggests that food ads should always: (1) feature a close-up of the product - preferably steaming invitingly, and (2) feature the person/people about to eat it smiling. You don't see glum faces in food advertising - glum doesn't sell, and suggests that said product isn't very appetising. Compare and contrast car ads, however, where you'll never see anyone grinning behind the wheel (considered to be too irresponsible).

7. Don't use too many words

The number of words on a normal billboard-sized poster should never exceed seven, according to the late, great adman David Ogilvy. That's the most that people can read when whizzing past in their cars, apparently. Ogilvy also said that printed ads shouldn't use white words on a black background, because the human eye is used to black on white via most other printed materials.

8. Tell people what to do

Research shows that website banner ads should say 'click here'. Otherwise, people won't. The response rate rockets by 400 per cent if there's a button. Which just goes to show how most rules about advertising are based on the entirely valid assumption that people are stupid.

9. Use lots of typefaces

The world of direct marketing is littered with apparently proven theories on how to create effective junk mail. Numerous studies show that using lots of bolds and italics will send your readers reaching involuntarily for their chequebooks. Another rule suggests that every letter should have a P.S. - rather than making you look forgetful, it increases the effectiveness of your message.

10. Ignore the rules

In advertising, the goldenest rule of all is to not follow the rules. Advertising fails to be effective if it is formulaic, and ads creatives pride themselves on trying to break with tradition as much as and as often as possible. If, unlike the boys and girls at Tango, they can get away with it.

fields.headline: Behind the screen
fields.standfirst: Lucy Rouse's TV gossip
fields.trailText: Lucy Rouse's TV gossip
fields.body:
Tittle-tattle this week comes from Montreux - the dreamy Swiss location that is home to the likes of the comedy festival, many an advertising industry booze-up and, of course, the Rose d'Or. It's a glamorous setting for yet another TV festival taking place in May - this time for comedy and entertainment programming.

In TV circles, Montreux is the place where entertaining egos stage-manage announcements about their latest unbeatable TV idea. Two years ago it was ITV's turn to ask "Who Wants to be a Millionaire?" of the assembled media pack, and last year BBC2's surreal League of Gentlemen won a top award.

This year could be Channel 4's turn. Just as the industry grew tired of asking what impact chief executive Michael Jackson will have on the channel (he joined just over two years ago), Channel 4 output has flooded onto the shortlist for those prestigious roses (they come in silver and bronze, as well as gold).

The more patriotic amongst us should be pleased to know that the Brits have got 27 programmes shortlisted for awards - almost a third of the 90 nominations. The US got just 14 nominations, while Germany has ten and Canada has nine. That'll teach them.

But back to Channel 4. It has comedy and entertainment hits such as Spaced, Trigger Happy TV, Something for the Weekend (well, some people liked it) and So Graham Norton all up for gongs. The stiffest competition is likely to come from the BBC which has wheeled out some great shows like The Royle Family and The Vicar of Dibley for competition. But hang on... Both those shows are made by external producers. The BBC has got Harry Enfield Presents Kevin's Guide To Being A Teenager shortlisted. But even that's made by independent Tiger Aspect. And anyway, wasn't it a cuttings job?

 Lucy Rouse is editor of Broadcast Magazine

fields.headline: Who are you?
fields.standfirst: What the Barclays ad says about you
fields.trailText: What the Barclays ad says about you.
fields.body:
The ad: This giant of a commercial for Barclays bank casts Sir Anthony Hopkins as a superstar leading a shiny superstar's life in a beautiful mansion with a stunning girlfriend. Throughout he delivers a stylish rant on man's obsession with bigness. When we eat a burger it's a Big Mac, he says. We go on the Big Dipper at the funfair and watch the Big Bad Wolf on TV. He then ponders the day ahead and how he is going to "a big meeting with some big cheeses from the big studio and we are going to talk big bucks". The endline concludes: "A big world needs a big bank".

Personality: The ad is not written for any particular individual target audience, but for anyone who uses a bank - for both existing Barclays customers and non-customers.

Financial status: You could just be someone with a humble cheque account or deal in stocks and shares through Barclays stockbrokers. The range is extremely broad.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Jagged Prayer | The Capitol Story
fields.body:
At last, some genuine alternative comedy. Robert Smith's script for Jagged Prayer (11.30am, Radio 4) eschews tradition by featuring wit, intelligence, learning and joie de vivre. He came to radio the hard way, spending years honing his one-liners in a Dominican monastery (perhaps that could be written into future light entertainment commissions). His plot turns on Father Jack lying face down in a lake with his head bashed in and Aquinas's Summa Theologica weighing him down. But Detective Inspector Cromwell (played by Timothy Spall) is an Anglican... Stan Freberg recalls in The Capitol Story (10.0pm, Radio 2) how

Johnny Mercer started the company on $15,000 in the middle of the second world war. Mercer's immediate problem was a desperate shortage of shellac, eventually solved by offering customers a free record in exchange for an old one. The melted down rejects then kept production going. Mercer's first big earner was Cow Cow Boogie, for which he paid Ella May Morse $50.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Fantastic Voyage | Dark Star | The Big Lebowski
fields.body:
Fantastic Voyage

(Richard Fleischer, 1966)

9am, Carlton Cinema

Perky sci-fi adventure with an intrepid team and their submarine shrunk to almost nothing in order to operate from the inside on a comatose defecting scientist. There are many hazards to negotiate in the journey's one-hour time limit: the attack of the white corpuscles, inner-ear storms, and a saboteur. Craggy Stephen Boyd is the pilot, and Donald Pleasence, Arthur Kennedy and Raquel Welch among those on board. Must be ripe, one would imagine, for a computer-generated remake.

Dark Star

(John Carpenter, 1974)

10pm, FilmFour

More sci-fi. Carpenter's cheap space comedy debut was unfavourably compared to Kubrick's 2001, but goes down in cosmic history as the forerunner of the Alien series. Producer and co-writer Dan O'Bannon (who also plays one of the four spaced-out hippy astronauts trying to find their way back to earth) went on to write the script for Ridley Scott's interstellar horror. The jokes about drugs and surfing wear thin, but there's a sense of space being very dark indeed... Carpenter can't play it for laughs indefinitely.

The Big Lebowski

(Joel Coen, 1998)

10pm, Sky Premier

Wonderful, wacky Coen brothers' comedy which filters a noir plot (complete with kidnap, mistaken identity, sexual attraction and a severed toe) through the confused consciousness of hippy throwback the Dude, aka Lebowski (Jeff Bridges).Helping him navigate the dangerous world of his rich, objectionable namesake (played by David Huddleston), when he'd rather be smoking weed and going bowling, is the hilarious double act of John Goodman's cracked Viet vet ("You're entering a world of pain") Walter and Steve Buscemi's dopey Donny. But effortlessly stealing the show is John Tutturro's stunning cameo as Jesus, the feared lilac-clad demon of the local bowling lanes.

fields.headline: A real messy business
fields.trailText: Troubleshooter | Dirty Work
fields.body:
As venture capitalists are in the news today for buying bits of poor, old Rover - who suddenly sounds like a dead dog - I would like to pass Sir John Harvey-Jones's views on to you. I wouldn't know a venture capitalist if he had it written round his hat but, in his previous incarnation as chairman of ICI, Sir John must have had the occasional Tio Pepe with one.

In Troubleshooter (BBC 2) he was talking to Alex Kitchen, an endearing enthusiast who suggested that a venture capitalist might lend him a million pounds to finance his brainchild, a motorised golf buggy. Ice formed on Sir John's upper slopes. He said: "If venture capitalists give you a million, they'll take your balls as well." Alex muttered a mutinous interest in selling them for that much. Sir John wagged a God The Father finger under his nose. "If I come back and find you've sold your bloody knackers to a venture capitalist, I'll have you." He was clearly going to say he'd have his balls but, of course, they'd already be in hock. You could not call it a warm-hearted endorsement.

Alex Kitchen owns a light engineering factory ("Things for trains, planes, boats. Things that stop milk floats blowing up"). TV is a very educative medium. I didn't know milk floats were prone to explode. We can only hope that Alex stays in business. That is the point of the series, survival. He has, however, a fascinating and distracting hobby, inventing things. Sir John describes him as "Buzzing off ideas like a bloody shooting star", and views the results with a jaundiced eye. It is, however, hard for any grown man to resist a motorised golf buggy and it was a treat to see the two of them, beetling about the greens under a blue and white sky.

Since his last Troubleshooter series Sir John has had two strokes, which gives peculiar poignancy to his advice "Hang in there as long as you bloody can".

Like Falstaff, whom he rather resembles, he leads his little army of British manufacturers, mostly with ramshackle muskets, into a battle which many have fled. His threnody over the needlessly dead was resonant: "All the skills, all the ability, all the investment, all come to nothing. What a tragic waste! What a ghastly monument to the way we manage our industrial affairs in Britain".

There must be a slim volume - Sir John is a great believer in trimming back the fat - in his advice to industry. It could be called, after one of his most memorable, if confusing, injunctions, "Get your bloody ducks in line!"

Dirty Work (BBC 1), the new Marks and Gran series, is a Welsh caper. Why does your heart sink at the words? It is filmed in Cardiff which Laurence Marks describes, rather to my surprise, as the Rio de Janeiro of the UK. As writers they have always seemed to be rooted so deeply and fruitfully in the east end of London, which is rarely mistaken for Rio. Dirty Work has a curious, ghostly resemblance to Randall and Hopkirk (Deceased), which is revived tomorrow, being about two detectives, one of them dying. Neil Pearson runs around a great deal, pursued by Hwyel Bennett at the top of his voice. "One day," said Pearson, interrupting a woman in childbirth, "you'll laugh about this." Not, however, this week.

webTitle: Former Welsh Labour leader to quit assembly

fields.headline: Former Welsh Labour leader to quit assembly
fields.standfirst: Devolution in Wales: special report
fields.trailText: Alun Michael, the former Welsh secretary and home office minister, is to resign his seat in the Welsh assembly and stay on as an MP in a bid to pick up the threads of his Westminister political career.
fields.body:
Alun Michael, the former Welsh secretary and home office minister, is to resign his seat in the Welsh assembly and stay on as an MP in a bid to pick up the threads of his Westminister political career.

His decision, announced in Cardiff yesterday, comes just five weeks after his dramatic resignation as Labour leader in Wales and will make him the first assembly member to stand down since devolution less than a year ago.

Under assembly rules Mr Michael's departure will not trigger a byelection.

He was elected under the proportional representation system used to choose top-up candidates from regional party lists and will be replaced by the second name on Labour's list for mid and west Wales, Delyth Evans, a former BBC and HTV journalist. Ms Evans worked on the BBC's World at One and PM programmes before becoming a policy adviser and speechwriter to the former Labour leader John Smith. She will take her seat in the assembly from May 1.

Mr Michael, who has represented Cardiff South and Penarth since 1987, has been considering his political future since resigning as first secretary of the national assembly during a no confidence debate on Labour's handling of European funding for Wales last month.

The general committee of his constituency party have been urging him to stay on as their MP and Mr Michael consulted widely with family, friends and party workers before deciding to return to Westminster.

The decision marks the end of an often turbulent chapter in his political career after being pressed by Downing Street to take on the job following the downfall of the former Welsh secretary Ron Davies.

Mr Michael said yesterday that he remained a passionate advocate of devolution and that he was leaving the assembly without bitterness.

He added that while he could make a continuing contribution in the assembly there was always a danger that a former leader could become "an irritation and a negative force".

Rhodri Morgan, who took over as first secretary following Mr Michael's resignation last month, said: "Alun has done an enormous amount to getting the assembly up and running, very often working under great pressure."

fields.headline: Yesterday
fields.trailText:
Good day
Cheltenham MP Nigel Jones, who enjoyed lunch with the Queen Mother on the big race day at his local racecourse. The Liberal Democrat MP, who was slashed in a sword attack seven weeks ago at his surgery, enjoyed lobster, ham salad and cheese, but was unable to get any tips. "She gave us no hint at all about who to back but she has possibly got a large bet on an outsider," he said.

fields.headline: Cardinal Kung
fields.standfirst: Catholic cleric condemned to 30 years in jail for defying communist China
fields.trailText: Cardinal Ignatius Kung, who has died in the United States aged 98, spent 30 years in Chinese prisons and labour camps for his opposition to state control of religion.
fields.body:
Cardinal Ignatius Kung, who has died in the United States aged 98, spent 30 years in Chinese prisons and labour camps for his opposition to state control of religion.

Born in Shanghai, he came from an old Catholic family. His spiritual home was the Shanghai suburb of Xujiahui, a part of the Yangtse delta that had been the centre of Catholic worship since the early 17th century. He studied for the priesthood and was ordained in 1930 at the age of 28. In 1949, he was appointed Bishop of Shanghai and apostolic administrator to the dioceses of Nanjing and Suzhou, just days after the foundation of the people's republic.

Kung was closely connected with the Legion of Mary, set up in 1949 by the apostolic nuncio, Antonio Ribero. After Ribero was expelled from China in September 1951, Kung continued to oversee the activities of the legion, a lay movement which reacted in much the same way to Communist rule as the Catholic Church had in the face of 19th-century imperialism.

The Chinese Communist party attempted to deal with religion not by eliminating it, but by creating "patriotic", or government-sanctioned, churches, free from outside influence. It was not quite so hard for Protestants, with the history of European Protestantism behind them, to declare independence from the rest of the world and follow the "three self movements" - self-government, self-support and self-propagation - although there were bitter arguments and many dissident groups of Protestants emerged.

For Catholics, the problem was more acute. Early in the Korean war, some Catholic priests in Sichuan, followed by the vicar-general of Nanjing, began to call for a break with imperialism and the outside world, a move that was condemned both by Pope Pius XII and Ignatius Kung. Despite his life-long defence of the pope and papal authority, Kung was not unresponsive to political movements, but it was his opposition to the local "patriotic" Catholic Church, and his refusal to allow its members to receive the sacrament, that led to his arrest in September 1955.

He was held without trial for five years, occasionally being brought out and paraded around Shanghai, where, according to his nephew, he defiantly shouted "Long live Christ the King, Long Live the Pope". Finally, in 1960, he was sentenced to life imprisonment for "leading a counter-revolutionary clique under the cloak of religion."

Kung's fidelity was recognised by Pope John Paul II, who secretly proclaimed him a cardinal in 1979 while he was still in prison (it was not until 1991 that he was able to receive his red biretta in person at the Vatican). In 1985, after 30 years in prison - and long campaigns on his behalf by religious and human rights groups, and diplomatic pressure from Cardinal Sin of the Philippines - he was released, a very sick old man.

In 1988, he was allowed to go to America for medical treatment, but the compassion of the Chinese Communist party was limited; his passport was withdrawn in 1998, leaving him a permanent exile.

 Ignatius Kung Pinmei, priest, born August 2 1901; died March 12 2000

webTitle: I didn't shop Ken Livingstone, says Mr JC Jones of Shepshed

fields.headline: I didn't shop Ken Livingstone, says Mr JC Jones of Shepshed
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: The first evidence of a dirty tricks operation in the race to be London mayor was emerging yesterday as questions were asked about who was behind the damaging exposure of Ken Livingstone's failure to declare to parliament more than £158,000 of income.
fields.body:
The first evidence of a dirty tricks operation in the race to be London mayor was emerging yesterday as questions were asked about who was behind the damaging exposure of Ken Livingstone's failure to declare to parliament more than £158,000 of income.

Two disclosures yesterday cast doubt on what initially appeared to be a straightforward complaint from a member of the public to Elizabeth Filkin, parliament's standards commissioner, which led to Mr Livingstone being ordered to apologise to parliament for not disclosing the earnings made from speeches and newspaper articles.

The first is the revelation that the original information which led to the complaint, apparently from a student, came from the former press officer to Mr Livingstone's main rival and the official Labour candidate, Frank Dobson.

The second and more serious allegation, that the student was put up to making the complaint, was put in private to Alan Williams, the deputy chairman of the commons standard and privileges committee, last night.

The revelation, which contradicts everything the student was saying yesterday and which came from an MP opposed to Mr Livingstone, suggests that someone else wrote the letter and got the student to sign it.

Attempted set up

Neither disclosure detracts from the substance of the findings of the Commons standards and privileges committee that Mr Livingstone broke parliamentary rules in not declaring the cash - but they do point to an attempt by opponents to set him up.

Adrian McMenamin, Mr Dobson's former press spokesman, said last night that he was the source for a story published in the London Evening Standard on December 1 last year which released details of Mr Livingstone's fees for speaking engagements. Mr McMenamin said that the story did not appear until after he had left the Dobson camp to become a special adviser to the Welsh secretary, Paul Murphy.

It was these disclosures that were used by a John C Jones of Shepshed, Leicestershire to form the basis of his complaint to Ms Filkin - since he quotes the Evening Standard article.

The former Millbank official briefed journalist Hugh Muir believing that Mr Livingstone had clouded important details of his financial affairs which should be made public during the selection battle to win Labour's candidacy for London mayor.

In the Evening Standard article, carried for only one edition in a paper not known to be a big seller in Shepshed, the then Tory spokesman for London, Shaun Woodward, said he planned to ask Ms Filkin why Mr Livingstone had not declared fees for speaking engagements in the members' register.

But no letter of complaint was sent by Mr Woodward. On December 19, the day after he defected to the Labour Party, a letter was sent to the standards commissioner in the name of Mr Jones.

Mr McMenamin said: "I was the source of a story in the Evening Standard but I didn't have anything to do with the complaint. I have never met John Jones, or Shaun Woodward for that matter."

Mr Jones himself denies that he ever put in a complaint at all.

A research associate in the mechanical engineering department at Loughborough university, he told the Guardian yesterday: "I have obviously been set up. I am trying to work."

After being bombarded with press queries Mr Jones, who is completing his PhD, issued a statement through the university. "None of this is anything to do with me, all I can think is someone else has written this letter of complaint and used my name and address.

"When I received the letter from the Commons authorities I called the commission as I didn't have the faintest idea what it was all about. I told them it wasn't me who had written the letter of complaint, that I knew nothing about it."

Neighbour Eileen Start, chairwoman of Shepshed Labour Party, said she was bewildered by the affair, and found it hard to believe that anybody locally would want to set Mr Jones up in this way.

Students at the university said there was no history of any student group getting involved in stunts or hoaxes to attract publicity or get back at people in the university. Mr Jones' department closed ranks. Neither the Labour nor Conservative parties have registered student bodies on campus this term.

The university made no official comment beyond releasing Mr Jones' statement. But one official said privately: "We've got to believe him, if he says he has nothing to do with it there is nothing else we can say."

But this is where the information from the MP - who does not want to be named - appears to contradict this version. He is convinced that Mr Jones did sign the letter of complaint but did not write it.

Demand for inquiry

Mr Livingstone, meanwhile, demanded an inquiry.

"There will have to be an investigation into this matter and the timing before the London elections," he said last night.

The irony of any possible attempt at subterfuge is that it would have been unnecessary: the decision condemning Mr Livingstone was taken independently by the committee.

Mr Livingstone still has an overwhelming lead among Londoners in the race to become mayor, according to an ICM poll published yesterday.

He enjoys more than 60% support just over a week after joining the campaign as an independent, a poll in the Evening Standard shows. Two disclosures yesterday cast doubt on what initially appeared to be a straightforward complaint from a member of the public to Elizabeth Filkin, parliament's standards commissioner, which led to Mr Livingstone being ordered to apologise to parliament for not disclosing the earnings made from speeches and newspaper articles.
