fields.headline: Michael Gilliam
fields.standfirst: BBC producer of children's charity appeal triumph
fields.trailText: Michael Gilliam, who has died aged 71, was the BBC producer who masterminded the world's most remarkable fund-raising operation, the annual Children in Need appeal. He was also instrumental in promoting the work of the radio and television gardener, Alan Titchmarsh.
fields.body:
Michael Gilliam, who has died aged 71, was the BBC producer who masterminded the world's most remarkable fund-raising operation, the annual Children in Need appeal. He was also instrumental in promoting the work of the radio and television gardener, Alan Titchmarsh.

Born in Dorking, Surrey, he was a nephew of Lawrenze Gilliam, whose distinguished BBC career was an inspiration to Michael. However, his own first step in broadcasting was via the single-handed operation of a mobile recording van. Wannabee stars could hire the converted wartime ambulance to visit their home for a recording session in their own front room. One of his early discoveries was Winifred Atwell playing on a battered old piano.

Good-looking and photogenic, Michael possessed a superb voice that the microphone loved. He became a local television news reporter for BBC Midlands and then had a spell in BBC local radio. In 1968, he was seconded to the Libyan government for four months to help create their national television service. Back home, he soon joined the group of producers at Broadcasting House responsible for editing Radio 4 programmes such as Today and Start The Week.

An enthusiastic gardener himself, Michael realised there were many people who wanted advice on what to do in their gardens at weekends. Together with Alan Titchmarsh, he presented and produced Down To Earth, one of the most successful programmes in the history of Radio 4, despite being only five minutes long. The programme also launched Michael's career as an author of gardening books and articles.

He then became radio producer for charitable appeals, including The Week's Good Cause, and joined the team of executive producer Mark Patterson, the creator of the Children In Need programme. It was Gilliam's work which persuaded, cajoled and inspired enough BBC heads to co-operate in the launch of Children In Need. This laid the foundation and gave inspiration for Live Aid, Band Aid and Comic Relief, as well as the ITV versions of similar charitable programmes.

Michael noted early on how radio charity appeals were often uninspiring in their presentation, and he transformed the "programme take" by insisting that charities use a celebrity to make their point. This was soon perceived as a showbiz status symbol, and artist's agents began volunteering their clients' services.

But Michael's efforts cost him, and in 1981 he collapsed at work with a serious heart condition. After recovery, he returned to work for Children In Need, but took early retirement in 1987, happily enjoying himself in his magnificent garden, painting exquisite portraits in oil and visiting great art exhibitions.

He returned to radio as producer of my Adventure programme on Radio 4, where we had two hilarious years covering everything from diving for Captain Kidd's treasure to learning to fly Concorde.

Michael is survived by his wife, Gillian, and children Nicholas and Amanda.

 Michael Gilliam, broadcaster, born August 6 1928; died March 3 2000

fields.headline: Roy Henderson
fields.standfirst: Baritone and singing teacher whose life spanned a century of music
fields.trailText: Roy Henderson, the great baritone and singing teacher, has died aged 100. He was best known as an interpreter of Delius, but his long and rich musical career included singing with Elgar, performing at the first Glyndebourne season and teaching Kathleen Ferrier. He was also a passionate sportsman, playing cricket (a crafty spin-bowler) and football (a tenacious goalkeeper).
fields.body:
Roy Henderson, the great baritone and singing teacher, has died aged 100. He was best known as an interpreter of Delius, but his long and rich musical career included singing with Elgar, performing at the first Glyndebourne season and teaching Kathleen Ferrier. He was also a passionate sportsman, playing cricket (a crafty spin-bowler) and football (a tenacious goalkeeper).

Born in Edinburgh, his father was a Congregational minister who became principal of Paton College, Nottingham. Roy attended Nottingham high school, became captain of cricket and served in the Artists Rifles from 1917-19. It was then that he learned to sing in public, practising what was to become a flexible and immaculate voice during late-night sentry duty.

In 1918, he won a government grant of £150 a year to study at the Royal Academy of Music, where he began to record - by bellowing into a large acoustic horn. In 1925, he burst on the music world with a staggering performance of Delius's Mass Of Life, sung from memory at very short notice at a Royal Philharmonic concert in the old Queen's Hall. As Delius himself acknowledged on a signed photograph: "To the unequalled interpreter of Zarathrustra".

Thereafter, Henderson was regarded as the ideal baritone for all Delius works, especially Sea Drift, and also for Vaughan Williams's Sea Symphony and Serenade To Music, composed for Sir Henry Wood's jubilee in 1938. His repertoire also included all the Elgar oratorios and choral works.

Henderson began to sing minor roles at Covent Garden, but his real operatic career began at Glyndebourne in 1934, singing Count Almaviva in The Marriage Of Figaro at the opening night - and then at every season until the second world war. Other roles included Guglielmo, in Cosi Fan Tutte, Papageno, in The Magic Flute (his two favourite roles), and Masetto, in Don Giovanni. When the musical director Fritz Busch queried Roy's engagement - "We know he can sing, but can he act?" - John Christie, Glyndebourne's founder, replied: "Of course, he can act. He's a cricketer."

The concert world of the 20s and 30s consisted largely of music clubs, Masonic and City dinners, and choral societies. On Saturdays, the 8.30am train from Euston was often laden with singers bound for weekend choir concerts in Lancashire and Yorkshire. Depending on the weather, we sometimes had a chance to play golf before a concert. It was a healthy way to "clear the tubes", with Roy using his half-sized putter, which he had once snapped in two after a missed putt.

Roy and I often met at such festivals. In Elgar's Apostles there are three bass roles, and Roy and I alternated as Jesus and Peter, while Norman Allin would sing Judas. Once, at a Three Choirs performance at Hereford in 1930, Elgar himself took a piano rehearsal. All went normally until the marvellous Judas solo of his betrayal. Norman Allin was halfway through, singing magnificently, when Elgar burst into tears. Leaning on the piano lid he said: "I can't go on". The rehearsal stopped. I had never seen him in such an emotional state. It was a moment which Roy and I never forgot.

Roy was a perfectionist and took meticulous care about everything. He had to know how and why things worked. He started to teach singing while still a student, and later became chorus master of the Nottingham Harmonic Society, conductor of Huddersfield Glee and Madrigal Society (1932-39), the Bournemouth Municipal Choir (1942-53) and founder-conductor of the Nottingham Oriana Choir (1937-52).

During the second world war, he was prominent in promoting the work of the Council for the Encouragement of Music and Arts, and maintaining musical life in difficult conditions. It was at a performance of Elijah, in Runcorn in 1942, that he first met Kathleen Ferrier - there on her first engagement. Henderson reported: "It was a good voice but too dark, and she kept her nose buried in the score. I told her to learn her words and throw away the book." Kathleen, who went on to become one of the great singers of the century, was so impressed by Roy's performance that she asked him for lessons - his ability to take on young singers, and give them polish and distinction, marked him out as a teacher.

After the war, Roy continued his concert work, which included recitals at the first Edinburgh festivals in 1947 and 1948. He was also in demand as an adjudicator at international competitions and master-classes in Canada and Holland. He retired from the concert platform in 1952 to devote himself full-time to teaching. His career blossomed again, in his 100th year, when a CD of some of his earlier recordings was released. A Centenary Recital, which includes A Shropshire Lad and lesser-known English songs, has already sold more than 1,000 copies.

A man of integrity, Roy was a staunch friend and devoted to his family. He was also a keen fisherman and cook. He died at the Musicians' Benevolent Fund home in Bromley. His wife Bertha, whom he married in 1926, died in 1985, and he is survived by a son and a daughter; another daughter predeceased him.

 Roy Galbraith Henderson, singer, born July 4 1899; died March 16 2000.

Sir Keith Faulkner wrote this obituary before his own death in 1994. It has been revised

fields.headline: Christie Willatts
fields.standfirst: Mapmaker whose land surveys of Britain aided social policy
fields.trailText: Christie Willatts, who has died aged 91, was recruited by the wartime government to run a geographic information system in the days before the term itself was invented. He was well qualified to do so. He had been the organising force behind Britain's first land utilisation survey. From 1941, until his retirement in 1973, he used his energy, unrivalled knowledge and skill as a presenter of geographical facts, to help planners and decision-makers across Whitehall do their job better.
fields.body:
Christie Willatts, who has died aged 91, was recruited by the wartime government to run a geographic information system in the days before the term itself was invented. He was well qualified to do so. He had been the organising force behind Britain's first land utilisation survey. From 1941, until his retirement in 1973, he used his energy, unrivalled knowledge and skill as a presenter of geographical facts, to help planners and decision-makers across Whitehall do their job better.

Born into a Berkshire farming family, Willatts took a first-class degree in geography in 1930 at the London School of Economics (LSE). There, Professor Dudley Stamp recruited him to run the survey he had conceived of land-use across Great Britain. Willatts recruited and enthused thousands of volunteers, writing their instructions, supplying their maps, and then checking the results. He did this by travelling the country by motorcycle and sidecar with fellow geographer Edna Green, whom he married in 1937. When the government requisitioned the survey offices at LSE, he commandeered a barrow to wheel all the maps and records to Bacon's, their printers in nearby Fetter Lane. When these were blitzed, Willatts set up a drawing office in his own home.

Using his experience from the land utilisation survey maps, he supplied the ministry of agriculture with a national map of land fertility, key information in the drive to expand wartime food production. From this start he provided government ministers with a growing stream of maps and geographic advice to officials. His intellectual integrity was such that, when told by the air ministry before the war not to show airfields on his land-use maps, he asked if he was to commit academic perjury (in this case, he did).

The skills he imparted to an able, faithful, and, in the early days, largely female, team of cartographers and researchers found many uses. The team produced a wide variety of maps to help explain and illustrate government and royal commission reports, including the Buchanan report, Traffic In Towns (1963), and the Maud commission report on local government (1969).

His team's work was distilled into a planning atlas of England and Wales aimed at bringing basic geographical facts on resources and their use, and the attributes and activities of the population, to the notice of decision-makers. Today, these maps of the housing conditions, industry and new towns of England and Wales in the 50s and 60s demonstrate, all too clearly, just how much has changed.

In 1946, at a sensitive time for the future of Palestine, Willatts was seconded to the Anglo-American government committee of inquiry regarding the problems of European Jewry and Palestine to edit a series of maps on the resources and geographical potential of the country which formed part of the committee's report.

The Royal Geographical Society awarded him the Gill Memorial in 1950 for research, and he was appointed an OBE in 1958. He helped to found, and later became an honorary member, of the British Cartographic Society.

Willatts was a steadfast member of the Church of England in his home village of Horton, near Slough. His activities as churchwarden and good neighbour became, with his three children, the centre of his life after the death of his wife in 1979.

 Edward Christie Willatts, geographer and cartographer, born July 4 1908; died January 8 2000

fields.headline: Madeleine Lindley
fields.standfirst: Bringing together children and good books
fields.trailText: When Madeleine Lindley, who has died of cancer aged 52, was a primary school teacher specialising in literacy, she was frustrated at how long it took to choose and find good-quality children's books. So in 1988, after a decade in teaching, she began selling books to schools - working out of the garage at her home in Oldham.
fields.body:
When Madeleine Lindley, who has died of cancer aged 52, was a primary school teacher specialising in literacy, she was frustrated at how long it took to choose and find good-quality children's books. So in 1988, after a decade in teaching, she began selling books to schools - working out of the garage at her home in Oldham.

Three years later, she was joined in the business by her husband, Mike. Today their business, Madeleine Lindley Ltd, has an international customer base, an annual turnover of £5.2m and employs more than 30 people at the Book Centre, a purpose-built showroom in Oldham.

Born in Manchester, Lindley went to Chadderton grammar school, married at 21, and, after the birth of her two daughters, went to Manchester university to gain a degree in education. She became a primary teacher, specialising in literacy.

Starting the Book Centre in Oldham was a way in which she felt she could provide a service to bridge the gap be tween the best children's literature and children in schools. Highly respected in the field of education and hugely knowledgeable, Madeleine was often a source of advice and comment on good children's books for agencies of the department of education and employment and other institutions, as well as publishers.

She wanted every child to become a committed reader, and wanted to help teachers provide schoolchildren with the best children's books around. With more than 8,000 children's books published every year, she was an exceptional source of advice to the thousands of teachers who visited the Book Centre.

There, often over a cup of coffee, Madeleine and her staff helped teachers meet the demands of the curriculum by providing the best picture books, novels and poetry available. She also offered teachers the opportunity to meet many of today's great leading children's writers, such as Allan Ahlberg and Anne Fine. The events she organised were always a marvellous and inspirational celebration of children's literature.

Charming and charismatic - and always glamorous - Madeleine's warmth and positive attitude soon turned professional relationships with publishers, teachers and authors into real friendships.

She is survived by Mike and her two daughters, both of whom work at the Book Centre with her son-in-law.

 Madeleine Lindley, children's bookseller, born March 26 1947; died February 11 2000

There, often over a cup of coffee, Madeleine and her staff helped teachers meet the demands of the curriculum by providing the best picture books, novels and poetry available. She also offered teachers the opportunity to meet many of today's great leading children's writers, such as Allan Ahlberg and Anne Fine. The events she organised were always a marvellous and inspirational celebration of children's literature. Charming and charismatic - and always glamorous - Madeleine's warmth and positive attitude soon turned professional relationships with publishers, teachers and authors into real friendships. She is survived by Mike and her two daughters, both of whom work at the Book Centre with her son-in-law.  Madeleine Lindley, children's bookseller, born March 26 1947; died February 11 2000

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Six charged for Russia's bombs
Six suspects have been charged in connection with the bombings of blocks of flats in Moscow and two other Russian cities that killed about 300 people last year, officials with Russia's Federal Security Service said yesterday.
fields.body:
Six charged for Russia's bombs
Six suspects have been charged in connection with the bombings of blocks of flats in Moscow and two other Russian cities that killed about 300 people last year, officials with Russia's Federal Security Service said yesterday.

They added that the explosives used in the blasts were produced in the Chechen city of Urus- Martan.
AP, Moscow

Kohl witness stays silent
A key figure in the slush fund scandal surrounding Germany's former chancellor Helmut Kohl refused to testify to MPs yesterday. Horst Weyrauch, 67, who allegedly managed a web of secret accounts, claimed the right to remain silent.
AP, Berlin

Teachers march in protest
Thousands of teachers seeking "more means" to educate and the resignation of France's education minister Claude Allegre marched across the country yesterday. The teachers' protest drew some 200,000 people, according to LCI television.
AP, Paris

German pupil shoots teacher
A 16-year-old school pupil repeatedly shot a teacher in the head and then shot himself, police in south Germany said yesterday. Both suffered life-threatening head wounds, authorities in the Bavarian town of Brannenburg said.
AP, Rosenheim, Germany

Boy's savaged arm reattached
Surgeons in America yesterday reattached a three-year-old's arm after it was torn off by his uncle's pet Bengal tiger. Jayton Tidwell, whose arm was ripped off between the shoulder and elbow, was said to be in a serious but stable condition after 11 hours of surgery.
AP, Houston

webTitle: Bolshoi dances on edge of disaster

fields.headline: Bolshoi dances on edge of disaster
fields.standfirst:
Unable to shore up its unstable walls and foundations, Moscow's ballet and opera showcase is asking the world to help

Bolshoi Theatre, Ballet and Opera site
fields.trailText: Despairing that state funds will come through in time to rescue Moscow's Bolshoi theatre by shoring up its crumbling foundations, the Bolshoi's general director is putting out a plea to theatres around the world for urgent help so that one of Russia's great cultural institutions is not forced to close.
fields.body:
Despairing that state funds will come through in time to rescue Moscow's Bolshoi theatre by shoring up its crumbling foundations, the Bolshoi's general director is putting out a plea to theatres around the world for urgent help so that one of Russia's great cultural institutions is not forced to close.

According to Vladimir Vasiliyev, essential repairs to the 19th century building have been postponed so long that he is now living in daily fear of some disaster.

As long ago as 1987, a detailed survey concluded that the theatre should shut immediately so major structural repairs could be carried out, alongside a comprehensive rewiring, refitting and restoration programme.

The intervening years of political turmoil in Russia and chronic money shortages have meant the work has not begun.

Last weekend water began to seep through the ceiling of the lavish 19th century building, home to ballet and opera companies. A few months ago the electricity failed in the middle of a performance and the theatre-goers had to be guided out by torch light.

"These problems are trifles compared to what could happen," Mr Vasiliyev said. "If the walls subside we will have a serious problem; we will have no choice but to lock our doors."

Ill-advised architects built the theatre on a swampy patch of land in the heart of Moscow, and since its opening night the building has been troubled by the threat of subsidence. During a performance in 1902, the walls of the auditorium began to sink, wedging shut the doors to all the theatre boxes. The audience had to clamber over barriers to get out.

No one knows how seriously the foundations have deteriorated in the 13 years since the last survey, and thorough research into the problems cannot be conducted while the building is in use.

A smaller, sister theatre to the Bolshoi is partly built, and when this is completed the productions are meant to move there for the duration of the renovation. But acute funding problems have halted building work at the new site and it is unclear when it will resume. Weary theatre officials do not expect the new building to be finished before 2002. Until it is ready, the Bolshoi's rebuilding cannot begin.

The theatre's problems are common to almost all of Russia's great cultural institutions as they struggle to adjust to the realities of post-Soviet funding. The government has promised to pay the £110m cost of the sister building and to provide £220m for the Bolshoi's restoration. But long delays in providing the final £34m for the new theatre have produced the current standstill. Mr Vasiliyev does not expect this money soon.

"Russia faces an extraordinary amount of problems. There's widespread need - pensioners aren't paid and people live in terribly bad conditions. Reconstruction of the Bolshoi represents a massive hole in the budget which [the government] cannot fill."

Mr Vasiliyev has been forced to come up with his own fundraising ventures. Supported by the UN cultural agency, Unesco, he has organised an "international day of solidarity" with the Bolshoi on March 28, the company's 224th birthday. Theatres round the world are being invited to donate any profits from that night's box office to the Bolshoi coffers.

The glittering interior of the Bolshoi's gilded auditorium gives no hint of the deprivation backstage, the shabby, cramped dressing rooms and the communal shower rooms - reminiscent of a run-down youth hostel - where world famous ballet and opera stars have to prepare for their performances. Beneath the stage a stray ginger cat climbs on massive pieces of outdated production machinery from before the second world war.

Mr Vasiliyev, a former ballet star who this month celebrated his fifth anniversary at the helm of the Bolshoi, is deeply frustrated: "Our equipment and technology is outdated, the sound equipment isn't good enough and the lighting system needs to be replaced," he said.

"The staging of our productions becomes more and more difficult.

Crumbling culture

State Historical Museum , Red Square Moscow: Full of Tsarist and Stalinist memorabilia. Under repair for more than 10 years, but less than a third restored.

Tretyakov Gallery , Moscow: Showcase of Russian art. Constant delays in paying museum staff. No money for acqusitions.

State Literature Museum : Full of manuscripts by writers including Tolstoy,Chekhov. and Dostoevsky. No money for the expansion of exhibition halls, so most of the collection remains in storage.

Konstantin Stanislavsky Museum , Moscow: It pays tribute to the creator of the Method approach to acting. Building was flooded when the central heating exploded.

St Saviours of Nereditsa , Novogorod: No money to restore 12th century frescoes.

Prince Yussupov mansion, Archangelskoye: Grandiose museum with family's art collection. Shut for 10 years because no restoration funds.

webTitle: Plotters won't unseat me, boasts Indonesian leader

fields.headline: Plotters won't unseat me, boasts Indonesian leader
fields.standfirst:
Wahid warning seen as strategy to keep military chiefs under civilian control

Indonesia and East Timor: special report
fields.trailText: The Indonesian president, Abdurrahman Wahid, has claimed that disaffected senior military officers are plotting against him - but insists his massive popular support means they are destined to fail.
fields.body:
The Indonesian president, Abdurrahman Wahid, has claimed that disaffected senior military officers are plotting against him - but insists his massive popular support means they are destined to fail.

"I know several military commanders are gathering strength to stand against me," Mr Wahid told a television phone-in. "It does happen. [But] I have nothing to worry about - the people are behind me. If someone is supported by the people, he should not be afraid of anything. Let [the commanders] face me."

At least a dozen generals who were sidelined in a recent reshuffle of 74 senior officers in favour of pro-Wahid reformers are known to be unhappy with the president's increasingly active role in day-to-day military matters.

Lieutenant General Djadja Suparman, a close ally of the recently suspended senior security minister and former armed forces chief General Wiranto, is seen as the leader of the cabal.

Shortly after being ousted from his command of the elite strategic reserves (Kostrad) he issued a thinly-veiled threat against the president.

"It's dangerous, very dangerous if [Kostrad] soldiers get mad, as now they're deployed in every corner of the country," he said.

Several Kostrad colonels, annoyed by the decision to replace Gen Suparman with Major General Agus Wirahadi kusumah, the most vocal advocate of reform, have adopted a strategy of passive resistance towards their new commander.

"It's clear there is growing resentment within sections of the military at what they see as the president's constant interference in their internal affairs," a western diplomat said.

But most analysts discount any immediate threat of a coup. They believe that the president's statement was part of his longer-term strategy to bring the Indonesian military firmly under civilian control.

The national police chief, Lieutenant General Rusdihardjo, played down the president's warning.

"Thus far I have not yet seen any efforts to overthrow the government," he said. He added that most potential plotters are now based outside Jakarta, making it very hard to stage a successful coup.

In the last month there have been signs that the military is coming round to the idea of civilian supremacy in government.

Admiral Widodo, the first non-army general to become armed forces chief, told a recent parliamentary hearing that the military is willing to relinquish its 38 seats in the 500-member lower house of parliament, but not in the upper house.

He added that this year's defence spending would focus on the navy and air force in a bid to tackle escalating piracy and illegal fishing.

Army sources say the special forces, Kopassus, responsible for much of the repression during the Suharto regime, are to be cut by more than 10% to about 5,000 troops.

But analysts say there is still much reform to be done, particularly with regard to funding. The military has dozens of unaudited businesses through which it raises tens of millions of pounds every year.

There has also been little movement to scrap the network of regional territorial commands, which for decades have been used to dampen the political aspirations of the rural masses.

webTitle: Porn tsar to save Utah from sex

fields.headline: Porn tsar to save Utah from sex
fields.trailText: In the state of Utah, people who want to watch popular films but don't want to see bare bodies in their living rooms can pay a video rental firm $5 (£3.20) to cut out the sex scenes.
fields.body:
In the state of Utah, people who want to watch popular films but don't want to see bare bodies in their living rooms can pay a video rental firm $5 (£3.20) to cut out the sex scenes.

The success of this venture - and growing concern about the accessibility of pornography in Utah - has led to a bill to give the state the nation's first "pornography tsar".

Michael Leavitt, the governor of the conservative state, will today sign the bill, which brings the obscenity and pornography complaints ombudsman into being next January.

"If the state legislature is looking for a way to improve the world, this is not an illogical way to strike a blow. Time will tell if it is a good use of state money," he said.

The ombudsman will have similar powers to those of the drugs tsars in the US and Britain, including formulating policy, acting as a link between the legislature and law enforcement officers and becoming a focal point for concerns about porn. The tsar will also be responsible for prosecuting offenders and arbitrating in disputes about pornographic displays.

Utah already adopts some of the strictest rules on anything relating to sex. Abstention is the only form of contraception that can be discussed legally in state school classrooms. Prisoners are not allowed to receive copies of Playboy or any publication that contains pictures of nude women and children using public libraries are restricted from access to any website containing nudity.

While the American Civil Liberties Union has questioned whether there is any point in creating the new post, some Utah residents clearly feel it meets a need.

The video company in American Fork which has cut sex scenes from movies such as Titanic, found enormous demand from parents who did not feel they could watch such films in front of their children.

But most residents of Utah accept that two of the major channels of pornography, the internet and cable television, are more difficult to patrol.

webTitle: US throws 'predator' kids to the wolves

fields.headline: US throws 'predator' kids to the wolves
fields.standfirst: Juvenile offenders are increasingly ending up in adult prisons jails. Rehabilitation ignored as Americans run scared of juvenile crime
fields.trailText: Juvenile offenders are increasingly ending up in adult prisons jails. Rehabilitation ignored as Americans run scared of juvenile crime
fields.body:
The day's consignment of young suspects arrives by van at a side entrance of Baltimore's monolithic courthouse and they clank through the corridors, each one shackled to the inmate ahead, like a noisy, disconsolate centipede.

They are almost all black, mostly under 18, and heading for the adult courts where, despite their age, they will be tried and sentenced as adults. It is a practice increasingly common in a country that is less and less inclined to view youth as a mitigating factor for serious crimes.

According to new statistics recently published by the US justice department, the number of under-18 defendants sentenced to long prison terms in adult prisons more than doubled between 1985 and 1997. At the same time, the number of juveniles locked up in cells with adult criminals while awaiting trial or serving short terms has more than quadrupled.

Meanwhile, the goal of rehabilitation within the juvenile system has been quietly sidelined. Brutal conditions have been unearthed in a series of youth detention centres and boot-camps around the country. Hearings were underway yesterday into a private facility in Jena, central Louisiana, after a judge found its inmates were being treated "no better than animals".

Part of the problem is a chronic lack of funds, but the tougher treatment of child offenders is also the result of an underlying shift in policy during the past decade. Feeling threatened by the spectre of escalating juvenile crime, almost every US state has passed legislation making it easier for young suspects to be transferred out of the juvenile courts into the less-forgiving adult penal system.

The policy shift was triggered by a sharp increase in violent crimes committed by young offenders during the late 1980s. This youth crime wave was accompanied by academic theories that the US faces a new generation of "super-predators" - young Americans growning up in broken, drug-riddled homes who have no scruples nor fear of authority.

These doom-laden predictions have yet to materialise, and youth crime rates have been on the decline for several years. Yet the politically expedient trend towards harsher treatment for young offenders has continued.

On Tuesday, Californians voted by 62% to 38% to go down the same road. From now on, prosecutors - not judges - will decide whether children as young as 14 should be tried in the state's adult courts and face adult sentences. Maryland passed similar legislation a few years ago and, as a consequence, David Addison, a public defender at the Baltimore courthouse, has had increasing numbers of his juvenile clients swallowed up by the state's adult jails.

"Before, the system was based on treatment and rehabilitation," Mr Addison said. "In the last five to 10 years, there has been a big rush towards 'let's provide punishment and let's protect society'."

It is a move that has drawn stark criticism from human rights groups. Rob Freer, an Amnesty International spokesperson, said: "It is inconsistent with international standards, and those standards have been adopted by almost every country in the world in the international Convention on the Rights of the Child, which 191 countries have ratified. Only the USA and Somalia have not."

The adult system is nothing if not punitive. Under-18 inmates are five times more likely to be sexually abused in an adult prison and eight times more likely to commit suicide.

At any one time, there are usually about 150 juveniles in the 200-year-old Baltimore city detention centre fortress, whose scandalous conditions were the subject of a damning report by Human Rights Watch last year. Its young inmates spend an average of six months there awaiting trial.

Mark Soler, a civil rights activist from the Washington-based Youth Law Centre said it was the worst prison he had seen in 20 years. "The level of violence is scary. Incarcerated juveniles call it a dungeon, and it is like a dungeon," Mr Soler said. "It's like something out of Dickens."

Joey N, a 17-year-old detention centre inmate said simply: "This jail's crazy." His adult cell mates threw faeces at him until he begged to be put in solitary confinement. Another 17-year-old prisoner, Terence B, told Human Rights Watch: "You need to get the juveniles out of here. We can't handle what the adults can handle. We ain't ready for that."

The US juvenile justice system was established just over a century ago on the grounds that young offenders were more open to rehabilitation than their elders and should be treated differently. Now that concept is in full retreat across the country.

Proponents of "get-tough" policies say the rethink is necessary because juvenile criminals have become far more violent. Michael Bradbury, a district attourney in California's Ventura county who backed Proposition 21, the bill that on Tuesday allowed for more severe punishment of suspected juvenile offenders, argues: "Times have changed. Juvenile truancy has been replaced with violent rape and murder. We need to adapt the law so that youths who commit adult crime do adult time."

However, many criminologists argue that the new policies simply do not work. Studies in New Jersey and Florida found that recidivism rates are highest among juveniles transferred to the adult jails.

The get-tough school of thought, however, believes that the high recidivism rate among violent juveniles merely confirms the original decision to send them to adult prison. According to John Dilulio, the Princeton criminologist who coined the phrase "super-predator", the new breed of young offender is not amenable to rehabilitation. "They are remorseless," Mr Dilulio said. "They lack empathic impulses; they kill or maim or get involved in other forms of serious crime without much consideration of future penalties or risks to themselves or others."

"They" also seem to be overwhelmingly black. In Maryland, 73% of the juvenile offenders transferred to the adult courts are black; by contrast, the state's overall population is 27% black. "If they're white, they are more likely to be sent for treatment," Mr Addison said. "If they're black, they are more likely to go to a correctional facility."

With the recent downturn in juvenile crime, less is heard of the "super-predators" these days, but they continue to cast a long shadow on the US judicial system.

In California, it is hard to get elected by advocating more lenient treatment of young criminals.

During the past decade, state expenditure on prisons has risen by nearly a third; spending on higher education, meanwhile, shrank 18%.

Joey N, a 17-year-old detention centre inmate said simply: "This jail's crazy." His adult cell mates threw faeces at him until he begged to be put in solitary confinement. Another 17-year-old prisoner, Terence B, told Human Rights Watch: "You need to get the juveniles out of here. We can't handle what the adults can handle. We ain't ready for that." The US juvenile justice system was established just over a century ago on the grounds that young offenders were more open to rehabilitation than their elders and should be treated differently. Now that concept is in full retreat across the country. Proponents of "get-tough" policies say the rethink is necessary because juvenile criminals have become far more violent. Michael Bradbury, a district attourney in California's Ventura county who backed Proposition 21, the bill that on Tuesday allowed for more severe punishment of suspected juvenile offenders, argues: "Times have changed. Juvenile truancy has been replaced with violent rape and murder. We need to adapt the law so that youths who commit adult crime do adult time." However, many criminologists argue that the new policies simply do not work. Studies in New Jersey and Florida found that recidivism rates are highest among juveniles transferred to the adult jails. The get-tough school of thought, however, believes that the high recidivism rate among violent juveniles merely confirms the original decision to send them to adult prison. According to John Dilulio, the Princeton criminologist who coined the phrase "super-predator", the new breed of young offender is not amenable to rehabilitation. "They are remorseless," Mr Dilulio said. "They lack empathic impulses; they kill or maim or get involved in other forms of serious crime without much consideration of future penalties or risks to themselves or others." "They" also seem to be overwhelmingly black. In Maryland, 73% of the juvenile offenders transferred to the adult courts are black; by contrast, the state's overall population is 27% black. "If they're white, they are more likely to be sent for treatment," Mr Addison said. "If they're black, they are more likely to go to a correctional facility." With the recent downturn in juvenile crime, less is heard of the "super-predators" these days, but they continue to cast a long shadow on the US judicial system. In California, it is hard to get elected by advocating more lenient treatment of young criminals. During the past decade, state expenditure on prisons has risen by nearly a third; spending on higher education, meanwhile, shrank 18%.

fields.headline: Killer's sentence: cut into 100 pieces
fields.trailText: A Pakistani judge yesterday convicted a man of murdering 100 children and sentenced him to be strangled with an iron chain, chopped into pieces and dissolved in acid in front of the parents of his victims.
fields.body:
A Pakistani judge yesterday convicted a man of murdering 100 children and sentenced him to be strangled with an iron chain, chopped into pieces and dissolved in acid in front of the parents of his victims.

The grisly sentence for Pakistan's worst serial killing comes after a trial in which Javed Iqbal, 38, at first admitted the killings and produced a diary of his crimes before retracting his confession.

"Javed Iqbal has been found guilty of 100 murders. The sentence is that he should be strangled 100 times," Judge Allah Baksh told the court in Lahore. "His body should be cut into 100 pieces and put in acid, as he did with his victims."

The judge, apparently guided by Islamic Sharia law, ordered that the death penalty should be carried out in a large park in Lahore by the Minar-i-Pakistan, a national monument.

Pakistan's interior minister, Moinudeen Haider, criticised the sentence. "This will be challenged in the high court. Such punishments are not allowed," he said. Iqbal's lawyer said he would appeal.

Although Sharia law governs some aspects of Pakistani life, including a ban on alcohol and laws on blasphemy, there are no public punishments. The death penalty is carried out privately in prisons.

A 17-year-old boy was sentenced to death as an accomplice and two other men accused in the case were jailed for 14 years.

The horror of Iqbal's killings emerged in December when he wrote an anonymous letter to police claiming he had been killing runaway children and dissolving them in acid for months in his home in a slum near the Ravi Road in Lahore. "I have killed 100 beggar children and put their bodies in a container," he wrote.

Police found vats of acid in his house, human bones from two bodies and piles of children's clothes.

Despite a manhunt in which dozens of people were detained Iqbal eluded police for a month. He was arrested only after he walked into a newspaper office to give himself up. "I am Javed Iqbal, killer of 100 children," he told staff. "I hate this world, I am not ashamed of my action and I am ready to die. I have no regrets. I killed 100 children."

Iqbal said his killings were in revenge for brutal treatment received at the hands of the police after his arrest in the past.

He produced a 32-page diary detailing his sexual abuse and murder of the victims and including children's photographs.

Pictures and television footage of weeping parents poring over piles of children's clothes recovered from his home stunned Pakistani society, which began to question the depth of its concern for its vast, impoverished underclass. Some of the victims had been missing for more than six months before their parents reported their disappearance to police.

Last month Iqbal withdrew his confession and pleaded not guilty, saying he had invented his story to highlight the problems of runaway children. Before he was led away yesterday he repeated that he was innocent. No forensic evidence linked him to the crime and no more bodies were found.

fields.headline: Pilgrim rituals
fields.standfirst: More than 2m Muslims round off the Hajj at Mecca
fields.trailText: Saudi barbers shave the heads of pilgrims in the village of Mina yesterday, as more than 2m Muslims gathered outside Mecca for the closing rituals of their annual pilgrimage, the  hajj.
fields.byline: Bassem Mroue in Mina, Saudi Arabia
fields.body:
Saudi barbers shave the heads of pilgrims in the village of Mina yesterday, as more than 2m Muslims gathered outside Mecca for the closing rituals of their annual pilgrimage, the hajj.

Among the rituals carried out today and yesterday, the first day of the Eid al-Adha feast, was the symbolic stoning of the devil, in which an army of pilgrims dressed in white cast each of seven small pebbles at the Jamarat - three pillars that symbolise the devil.

According to Muslim tradition, it was here on a plain outside Mecca that the devil tried to tempt Abraham into disobeying God by refusing to sacrifice his son, Ishmael.

The pilgrims also circled the Kaaba, a cubic stone structure in Mecca that is Islam's holiest site and toward which all Muslims turn for prayer.

Traditionally, Eid al-Adha, the feast of sacrifice, is celebrated by slaughtering animals and sharing a part of the meat with friends and giving the rest to the poor. - AP

webTitle: Japanese try to cut funds for US bases

fields.headline: Japanese try to cut funds for US bases
fields.trailText: Japan and the US refused to back down yesterday in a military funding dispute that threatens to sour Asia's most important security partnership.
fields.body:
Japan and the US refused to back down yesterday in a military funding dispute that threatens to sour Asia's most important security partnership.

Japan has asked Washington to accept a cut in the $5bn (£3.2bn) that Tokyo pays annually to maintain the huge US military presence on its shores.

Worth more than $100,000 for each of the 47,000 American serviceman in Japan, this money - known as the "sympathy budget" - covers everything from roads to building new bowling alleys for US troops.

These expenses are the most generous in the world and they have continued to rocket even as Japan's financial condition has deteriorated: it has the biggest public debt among the developed nations, and the finance ministry wants a big cut in the military allocation.

But US defence secretary, William Cohen, who is in Japan, said on Wednesday that he would urge Japan's defence agency not to cut a single yen.

"We have gotten good support from [Japan] in the past and I expect we will get it in the future," he said. "I know they are having some economic troubles right now, but host-nation support is very key to us."

The Japanese foreign minister, Yohei Kono, insisted yesterday that US forces should make "streamlining and cost-saving efforts".

The dispute has not helped the two nations show a common security front before the G7 summit of leading industrial nations in Okinawa, the island which is home to the vast majority of US military bases in Japan.

fields.headline: Venezuela hots up
fields.trailText: Venezuela's controversial president, Hugo Chavez, is facing an unexpected election challenge, with a former comrade-in-arms announcing this week that he will be joining the race.
fields.body:
Venezuela's controversial president, Hugo Chavez, is facing an unexpected election challenge, with a former comrade-in-arms announcing this week that he will be joining the race.

Francisco Arias who, with Mr Chavez, was a leader of a failed coup in 1992, says the president has betrayed the original goals of the rebellion.

Mr Chavez was elected by a landslide two years ago after promising social and economic justice for the 60% of Venezuelans who live in poverty. In December the country was renamed the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela after people overwhelmingly voted for a new constitution giving the president sweeping powers.

But Mr Chavez has failed to kick-start the economy. Since he assumed the presidency, another 600,000 people have joined the unemployed.

Mr Arias is the first serious challenger. His candidacy changes political calculations for the May election because he is not part of the discredited establishment.

fields.headline: Trickery suspected after cyanide spill
fields.standfirst: More about the Danube cyanide disaster
fields.trailText: Hungarian politicians reacted angrily yesterday to news that the Australian company partly blamed for a serious cyanide spill in several major eastern European rivers had gone into voluntary receivership.
fields.body:
Hungarian politicians reacted angrily yesterday to news that the Australian company partly blamed for a serious cyanide spill in several major eastern European rivers had gone into voluntary receivership.

Esmerelda Exploration, based in Perth, owns 50% of the Aurul gold mine at Baia Mare in northern Romania, which discharged cyanide-tainted water on January 30. A Romanian state company is a co-owner.

Hungarian media reported that Esmerelda, which has denied any direct role in polluting the rivers or killing fish, had filed for "voluntary administration" - a step which may lead to bankruptcy proceedings.

Zoltan Illes, head of the environment committee of the Hungarian parliament, said: "This is just a trick not to pay compensation."

Following the spill, cyanide spread through rivers in Ukraine, Slovakia, Hungary and Serbia. Two hundred tonnes of dead fish were removed from the river Tisza in Hungary alone. Hydro-biologists believe it could take decades for the eco-system to recover fully.

Kim Strickland, the administrator appointed under Australian law, denied that filing for voluntary administration would automatically protect Esmerelda Exploration from legal action.

"Anyone in the world can lodge a claim," he said, adding: "If I choose to reject some of those claims then the claimants have a right to appeal to a court, or they can pursue the directors."

The Hungarian foreign minister, Janos Martonyi, yesterday confirmed that his government intends to sue the Australian company, along with the Romanian state-owned firm which also has shares in the Aurul mine.

Hungary also intends to claim damages from another state-owned mine at Baia Borsa in Romania, responsible for another spill, of heavy met als, into the Tisza a week ago.

It is believed that the spill is continuing to pollute the region. On Wednesday, a slick up to 25 miles long, and containing metals such as lead, zinc and copper entered Hungary.

A spokesman for the mine confirmed on Wednesday that a further 150 cubic metres (5,300 cubic feet) of contaminated water had escaped from the same reservoir from which 20,000 tonnes of contaminated sludge escaped last Friday. But he called the new leak "insignificant".

A spokeswoman for the Upper Tisza regional water authority confirmed the existence of the latest spill, but said that heavy metal levels in the river remained below the emergency threshold.

The pollution of Hungarian rivers by Romanian mines has created tension between the two governments, which have both turned to the European Union for mediation.

On Wednesday Romanian, Hungarian and Ukranian officials signed a protocol on the prevention of trans-border river pollution. Hungary appealed to the EU earlier in the week to help Romania identify dangerous plants and mines, and then to help pay to make them safe, or to press Romania to close them down.

Publication of a report by UN experts into the cyanide spill is expected next week.

Elections are due in Romania this autumn, and Hungary is keen to avoid damaging the chances of the present government, which includes ministers from the large Hungarian minority in Romania.

fields.headline: DiCaprio stepbrother accused of violence
fields.trailText: The stepbrother of American film star Leonardo DiCaprio was arrested on suspicion of attempted murder and making terrorist threats against his girlfriend, police in California said.
fields.body:
The stepbrother of American film star Leonardo DiCaprio was arrested on suspicion of attempted murder and making terrorist threats against his girlfriend, police in California said.

Adam Farrar was being held yesterday at a Los Angeles jail, sheriff's deputy Boris Nikolof said.

Mr Farrar, 28, who is also an actor, grew up with DiCaprio, 24, in Los Angeles. They became stepbrothers after Adam Farrar's divorced mother married DiCaprio's divorced father.

Mr Farrar was arrested after police were called to the home of a woman in the seaside community of Marina del Rey on Wednesday in connection with a domestic violence complaint, Mr Nikolof said.

Sheriff's deputy Jim Tatreau said Mr Farrar, who mentioned his famous stepbrother to police at the time of his arrest, was being held on $1m (£635,000) bail and was awaiting a preliminary hearing on the charges.

The woman at the centre of the inquiry did not require medical attention. There were no details about the incident and police said that the woman would not be named.

"Due to the sensitive nature of this case, at this time it would be inappropriate to comment regarding the details of the investigation," Mr Nikolof said.

DiCaprio's public relations man, Ken Sunshine, said the actor, who starred in Titanic and The Beach, had "absolutely no comment" to make about the episode. Mr Farrar has had small roles in television commercials and films. It was his appearances in television commercials as a child that inspired DiCaprio to become an actor.

DiCaprio was nominated for an Academy Award for his role in the 1993 film What's Eating Gilbert Grape before Titanic made him a superstar.

fields.headline: Battle of the bottle
fields.standfirst: Tuscany's Castello Banfi helped make Brunello di Montalcino one of the world's most sought-after wines. But now local resentment and rumours of skulduggery are threatening to tear apart this idyllic corner of Italy.  Rory Carroll  reports
fields.trailText: Tuscany's Castello Banfi helped make Brunello di Montalcino one of the world's most sought-after wines. But now local resentment and rumours of skulduggery are threatening to tear apart this idyllic corner of Italy.
fields.body:
The legend of Brunello starts with the day a traveller arrived in the dirt-poor hill town of Montalcino. He wandered past its crumbly houses and into the fields, sniffing the air, poking the soil, inspecting the few olive trees and scribbling in a notebook. The soil was poor and he left. Montalcino resumed its decay.

The locals did not know that the stranger, Ezio Rivella, was euphoric and would soon return. He had found what he was seeking: a corner of the world capable of producing the greatest wine. A freak of nature had gifted the Tuscan town a unique microclimate.

Fast-forward to the present day and wealth oozes from the terraced vineyards, rebuilt medieval castle, the BMWs, polished stone streets and azalea-fringed restaurants. Squalor and emigration are a folk memory to the young people who flock here for money and jobs. Crinkly sommeliers tell tourists how the grace of nature and a centuries-old winemaking tradition saved Montalcino from oblivion.

Its salvation, Brunello, is a rich, powerful wine made from the Sangiovese grape. It is an object of acute desire hailed by connoisseurs and liable to fetch hundreds of pounds a bottle at Sotheby's. Merchants clamour for the right to sell it. Two 1995 vintages have just been awarded five stars.

Demand far outstrips the strictly regulated supply. Those who get to taste it come away drooling adjectives such as intense, full-bodied, fruity, smooth, rich, chewy, velvety, super-ripe, spicy, gigantic. In the battle with the new world, Montalcino stands as a citadel of old world might and venerability.

War chronicles date the town's winemaking to before 1500 and labels tend to be adorned with knights, monks and peasants rather than the legendary Ezio Rivella. Not because no one knows what he looked like, but because he spoils the myth. Rivella arrived in 1977.

The Brunello fairy tale is a story of American corporate power buying up thousands of acres and imposing modern techniques to the horror of venerable but ailing low-quality local producers. Success has been achieved through market research, scientific analysis, mechanisation, high finance, advertising and, above all, money. Tons of it.

The Appennines in the north and Mount Amiata in the south shelter the vineyards from African and winter air currents, but success has whipped up a tailwind they are helpless to block. Competition and greed are threatening the region's newfound wealth and glory.

Rivella was - is - a famed oenologist. He was hired by the Mariani family, an Italian-American dynasty, to find the perfect spot to build a vineyard from scratch. His rovings stopped at Montalcino, an hour south of Siena.

In addition to its mountain protection, it was blessed with an elevation of 900 to 1200ft and a location near the Mediterranean. The result was warm days, cool nights and just enough moisture to nourish a rugged, calcified soil. Just the place to invest $100m.

Biondi Santi, a rival producer, released the first vintage from a clone of the Sangiovese grape in 1870, and established the wine as one of the highest class. Brunello was awarded its DOC classification in 1966, but the region remained largely unknown and unloved until the Marianis arrived. They called their company Banfi, after a Milanese aunt.

The communist mayor and traditionalists watched in stupefaction as Yankee dollars bankrolled a convoy of bulldozers to carve Europe's largest contiguous wine estate: 7,100 acres.

Hugh Johnson, the wine writer, exulted. "The great wine estates of France have nothing to compare with it. In Italy, in Spain - indeed, in all of Europe - it is unique. Even the new world has no wine estate conceived on such a grand scale as the Castello Banfi."

Overlooked by a Romanesque fortress, the rugged landscape became sloping amphitheatres that trapped the sun and allowed proper drainage, supplied by six artificial lakes. Tractors, trucks and generators revved across the green and yellow hills, and hundreds of workers followed in their wake, planting row after row of cement stakes and vines.

No detail was overlooked. State-of-the-art equipment in the winery was fused with casks of Slavonian oak and barriques of French oak that preserved flavour and allowed wines to develop. The three-person harvesting teams that trundled up slopes - one driving, two cutting and picking - became female-only. "We learned that men didn't concentrate as well," says export manager Rodrigo Redmont.

Rivella experimented with 103 clones of Brunello before selecting the six that would catapult Banfi to acclaim. "There was suspicion at first but little by little the locals saw what we were up to and became enthusiastic," says Redmont.

Banfi's first vintage, in 1978, was not well received but refinement and money improved its quality and image through the 80s until it hit the jackpot in 1990, the year in which Banfi's Brunello came of age as far as the international market was concerned. Almost too rich to accompany food, it is taken by connoisseurs as an after-dinner drink. Prices have rocketed.

Its reputation was consolidated in 1995 with another five-star rating. Banfi was here to stay. That year's wine futures were sold out. Prices for the 1997 Brunellos rocketed yet higher. The market was seduced.

Brunello is one of the 20 Italian wines with the prized DOCG patent, which strictly controls its quality and output. For every 100m bottles of Chianti sold each year, there are just 4m bottles of Brunello, which each take five years to produce.

Brunello di Montalcino is Banfi's flagship but other brands such as Rosso di Montalcino, awarded five stars for its 1998 vintage, and Poggio all'Oro, have become fashionable. Banfi has been voted Italian winery of the year five consecutive times. "Unquestionably, the leader in Tuscany is Banfi," purred the Wine News.

It was a fairy tale. Wine flowed down Montalcino's hills, money, jobs and acclaim gushed back up. But the story does not end there. This week the pruners have been out in force, combing the hills while managers at the Castello plotted ambitious expansion. But a sourness is in the air.

The traditionalists still grumble that Banfi has destroyed a way of life with their machines and marketing, but even those who dismissed them as luddites are hesitating at the transformation taking place.

An array of competitors are muscling in on the region in the hope of grabbing some of the magic. From the five or six growers of 40 years ago there are now at least 130, according to Gambero Rosso food and wine magazine. They include wine producers like Marchesi Frescobaldi and Robert Mondavi, as well as insurers like RAS. Land around Montalcino sells well above the average for Tuscany.

Environmentalists fear the scramble will damage the landscape. The Ilix, an ancient and officially protected tree, is disappearing. Hillsides near the monastery of San Antimo have been plained to destruction, says Ference Mate, a resident.

The new generation taking up tourist-related jobs in Montalcino is less than effusive in thanking Banfi. "Sure, they did a lot for this place, but we don't need a great big American company here any more - people would come anyway," says Alessia Salvioni, 27, echoing many.

Fulvio Cristofolini, who owns La Fuga, a four-hectare estate, praised Banfi's quality but worried whether it and other giants would ultimately undermine Tuscany's brand identity.

Most serious of all, whispers are circulating that some vintners are cheating by incorporating grapes from other regions. Merchants are clamouring for more output, prices are high and the temptation is strong, says Piero Antinori, a vintner.

It went largely unreported, but last September the Italian fraud squad seized more than a quarter of a million gallons of southern Italian wine - more than 110,000 cases - that were bottled and falsely labelled as Tuscan wine with the Indicazione Geographica Tipica (IGT) designation. fields.bodyText: The legend of Brunello starts with the day a traveller arrived in the dirt-poor hill town of Montalcino. He wandered past its crumbly houses and into the fields, sniffing the air, poking the soil, inspecting the few olive trees and scribbling in a notebook. The soil was poor and he left. Montalcino resumed its decay. The locals did not know that the stranger, Ezio Rivella, was euphoric and would soon return. He had found what he was seeking: a corner of the world capable of producing the greatest wine. A freak of nature had gifted the Tuscan town a unique microclimate. Fast-forward to the present day and wealth oozes from the terraced vineyards, rebuilt medieval castle, the BMWs, polished stone streets and azalea-fringed restaurants. Squalor and emigration are a folk memory to the young people who flock here for money and jobs. Crinkly sommeliers tell tourists how the grace of nature and a centuries-old winemaking tradition saved Montalcino from oblivion. Its salvation, Brunello, is a rich, powerful wine made from the Sangiovese grape. It is an object of acute desire hailed by connoisseurs and liable to fetch hundreds of pounds a bottle at Sotheby's. Merchants clamour for the right to sell it. Two 1995 vintages have just been awarded five stars. Demand far outstrips the strictly regulated supply. Those who get to taste it come away drooling adjectives such as intense, full-bodied, fruity, smooth, rich, chewy, velvety, super-ripe, spicy, gigantic. In the battle with the new world, Montalcino stands as a citadel of old world might and venerability. War chronicles date the town's winemaking to before 1500 and labels tend to be adorned with knights, monks and peasants rather than the legendary Ezio Rivella. Not because no one knows what he looked like, but because he spoils the myth. Rivella arrived in 1977. The Brunello fairy tale is a story of American corporate power buying up thousands of acres and imposing modern techniques to the horror of venerable but ailing low-quality local producers. Success has been achieved through market research, scientific analysis, mechanisation, high finance, advertising and, above all, money. Tons of it. The Appennines in the north and Mount Amiata in the south shelter the vineyards from African and winter air currents, but success has whipped up a tailwind they are helpless to block. Competition and greed are threatening the region's newfound wealth and glory. Rivella was - is - a famed oenologist. He was hired by the Mariani family, an Italian-American dynasty, to find the perfect spot to build a vineyard from scratch. His rovings stopped at Montalcino, an hour south of Siena. In addition to its mountain protection, it was blessed with an elevation of 900 to 1200ft and a location near the Mediterranean. The result was warm days, cool nights and just enough moisture to nourish a rugged, calcified soil. Just the place to invest $100m. Biondi Santi, a rival producer, released the first vintage from a clone of the Sangiovese grape in 1870, and established the wine as one of the highest class. Brunello was awarded its DOC classification in 1966, but the region remained largely unknown and unloved until the Marianis arrived. They called their company Banfi, after a Milanese aunt. The communist mayor and traditionalists watched in stupefaction as Yankee dollars bankrolled a convoy of bulldozers to carve Europe's largest contiguous wine estate: 7,100 acres. Hugh Johnson, the wine writer, exulted. "The great wine estates of France have nothing to compare with it. In Italy, in Spain - indeed, in all of Europe - it is unique. Even the new world has no wine estate conceived on such a grand scale as the Castello Banfi." Overlooked by a Romanesque fortress, the rugged landscape became sloping amphitheatres that trapped the sun and allowed proper drainage, supplied by six artificial lakes. Tractors, trucks and generators revved across the green and yellow hills, and hundreds of workers followed in their wake, planting row after row of cement stakes and vines. No detail was overlooked. State-of-the-art equipment in the winery was fused with casks of Slavonian oak and barriques of French oak that preserved flavour and allowed wines to develop. The three-person harvesting teams that trundled up slopes - one driving, two cutting and picking - became female-only. "We learned that men didn't concentrate as well," says export manager Rodrigo Redmont. Rivella experimented with 103 clones of Brunello before selecting the six that would catapult Banfi to acclaim. "There was suspicion at first but little by little the locals saw what we were up to and became enthusiastic," says Redmont. Banfi's first vintage, in 1978, was not well received but refinement and money improved its quality and image through the 80s until it hit the jackpot in 1990, the year in which Banfi's Brunello came of age as far as the international market was concerned. Almost too rich to accompany food, it is taken by connoisseurs as an after-dinner drink. Prices have rocketed. Its reputation was consolidated in 1995 with another five-star rating. Banfi was here to stay. That year's wine futures were sold out. Prices for the 1997 Brunellos rocketed yet higher. The market was seduced. Brunello is one of the 20 Italian wines with the prized DOCG patent, which strictly controls its quality and output. Brunello di Montalcino is Banfi's flagship but other brands such as Rosso di Montalcino, awarded five stars for its 1998 vintage, and Poggio all'Oro, have become fashionable. Banfi has been voted Italian winery of the year five consecutive times. "Unquestionably, the leader in Tuscany is Banfi," purred the Wine News. It was a fairy tale. Wine flowed down Montalcino's hills, money, jobs and acclaim gushed back up. But the story does not end there. The traditionalists still grumble that Banfi has destroyed a way of life with their machines and marketing, but even those who dismissed them as luddites are hesitating at the transformation taking place. An array of competitors are muscling in on the region in the hope of grabbing some of the magic. fields.headline: No: 1596
fields.standfirst: Leo
fields.trailText: Leo.
fields.body:
Age: 10.

Appearance: Head cocked endearingly; mouth yapping open in a smile; furry ears flapping.

Everybody say "aaaww!" "People just can't believe", says the mutt's owner, Sara McBurnett, "that anyone would want to harm a creature so sweet and absolutely innocent."

You don't mean . . ? Leo has been murdered in a road-rage incident in San Jose, California.

Leo could drive! You misunderstand. An unidentified motorist, piqued that McBurnett brushed his bumper, plucked Leo from her lap and hurled him into the oncoming traffic. "I keep seeing his little body going under the car," sobbed McBurnett in an interview.

An interview? So the media have expressed sympathy. And some. Leo's grisly end made the front page of the Washington Post and bulletins on BBC, CNN and Reuters. The story's the biggest "since the OJ days", says one US commentator.

A paws célèbre, you might say. McBurnett has received condolences from as far afield as Norway and Australia. More than 60,000 visitors have accessed a website set up in Leo's name.

Has the dogicidal fiend been caught? An Identikit picture of the killer was released yesterday.

I assume the US is handling the manhunt in its usual understated way. Of "America's most hated man", a correspondent to the San Jose Mercury demands, "give him the chair!"

Blimey. This guy is in the doghouse. "There is $100,000 on his head," wails McBurnett, "but it won't bring back my baby boy."

$100,000! That's one popular pooch. The public purse strings have loosened, argues McBurnett, because Leo "has become a symbol. It's so symbolic that such an innocent little fluffy ball of life could be taken by needless violence".

Do say: "A hound slamdunked on the freeway. What a worthy cause."

Don't say: "If you'd been driving carefully, Ms McBurnett, Leo would be alive today."

Not to be confused with: Lassie, Leo Sayer, floods in Mozambique.
