webTitle: No such thing as a free speech

fields.headline: No such thing as a free speech
fields.standfirst: So Ken Livingstone can command £4,000 for an after-dinner speech. But do people really pay to listen to Malcolm Rifkind, and who in heaven's name is Barbara Harmer?  Oliver Burkeman and  Esther Addley lift the lid on the paid public speaking circuit, the ultimate index of celebrity
fields.trailText: So Ken Livingstone can command £4,000 for an after-dinner speech. But do people really pay to listen to Malcolm Rifkind, and who in heaven's name is Barbara Harmer?  Oliver Burkeman and  Esther Addley lift the lid on the paid public speaking circuit, the ultimate index of celebrity.
fields.body:
Whatever else they may say about him, nobody doubts that Ken Livingstone can tell jokes. "He has this extraordinary ability to walk into a room, say 'Margaret Thatcher didn't like me and neither does Tony Blair', and the audience are instantly hooked," says one businessman who has seen the mayoral hopeful perform at a private function. But it was another extraordinary ability that stood out amid yesterday's headlines: from such winning remarks, it emerged, Livingstone had managed to amass previously undeclared income in the region of £100,000 - not so much by touting his services around super-rich global corporations, but by speaking to the likes of the Staffordshire Chartered Accountants, a gathering of insolvency lawyers and the Hertfordshire Chamber of Commerce.

Big money - but nowhere near as big as it gets: the worldwide market in after-dinner speaking has never been healthier. In the months immediately following the Gulf war, General Norman Schwarzkopf - not so adept at the cheeky-chappie audience-wooing, but riding high on his reputation as the saviour of America's international glory - was routinely raking in £110,000 a night speaking to businesspeople hungry to apply his inspirational military anecdotes to the corporate world. At the heady summit of earnings power, though, sits Bill Cosby, whose £190,000 nightly bill eclipses even ex-president George Bush's £75,000 asking price.

But for all the cigar-chomping camaraderie of the circuit, this is a ruthless game and, most fascinatingly for the casual student of celebrity, the ultimate index of fame. Here, more than anywhere else, minor differences in levels of public success are thrown into humiliatingly sharp focus, as the nagging suspicion that your star may be setting is rudely confirmed by a drop in the price you can command. On the lowest rungs, a world away from Cosby, the has-beens and the never-quite-weres can pull in up to £1,500 a night - "the Emlyn Hugheses and the Ian McAskills", as Brendan Barns, director of Speakers for Business, puts it. His agency is one of the four or five that have effectively cornered the market in after-dinner anecdotes, and it paid Livingstone up to £35,000 for 10 speeches, according to the mayoral candidate's revised declaration of earnings. Barns's other clients include John Humphrys, David Mellor, Bill Morris, Sir Bernard Ingham and Sir Malcolm Rifkind.

"Speakers are like stocks and shares - they go up and down," says Barns. "If they're on TV, if they do something outrageous, they're worth more." A reasonably talented MP or former parliamentarian - David Mellor, say, or Edwina Currie - can demand £3,000 to £4,000 long after their ministerial responsibilities are behind them. Jung Chang, author of Wild Swans, has topped £7,500; Terry Waite once commanded £15,000. This is nothing, though, compared to the US market, where wealthy professional organisations and universities in need of an image makeover flock to the Washington Speakers Bureau to book the likes of Baroness Thatcher (thought to be valued at around £35,000 a night), John Major, Schwarzkopf, journalist Bob Woodward, writer and broadcaster Tom Brokaw and former House speaker Newt Gingrich.

It sounds like staggeringly easy money, but Tom Kenyon-Slaney - director of the London Speakers Bureau, another major UK agency - says he rejects numerous approaches from public figures whose estimations of their own worth exceed their talents. "After the last election, I was contacted by about 40 former Conservative MPs, and I'd say we turned down pretty well every single one," Kenyon-Slaney says. "Companies want these people for certain reasons - to entertain clients, to tell them where the economy's going - and frankly the vast majority of MPs are no use to man nor beast in that market."

Like a slightly drunk elderly uncle over Christmas dinner, speakers develop the art of recycling anecdotes at event after event, hopeful that the response will stay fresh. Edwina Currie admits to having a few favourites: "If I'm going up north, they'll get the story about the old lady who stopped me in the loos in a motorway service station and said 'You're from Rochdale', and I said 'No, I'm from Liverpool.' And she said: 'No, you must be from Rochdale because I'm from Rochdale, and I know you.' But if you tell that story down south, it sounds patronising."

One of the better-paid female speakers, Currie has learned from experience that it pays to be selective. She is resolute, for example, that she won't do accountancy firms' dinner-dances, after a bad experience with some drunken accountants some years ago. "The women's groups I speak to are much more ribald than male audiences. If it's a more male event, I find a smile or a funny facial expression will produce the laugh. One has to be more careful with what one says when there are men about."

Prue Leith, another stalwart of the industry, says: "If it's going well, it's a real buzz. But if it's a very hot afternoon and they've been bored rigid at a conference, and you're first on after their big lunch and you just see them dropping off in droves, it's horrible. I often tell them about when I was a food writer on the Daily Mail and I gave a recipe for toffee with 2lb of black treacle instead of 2tbsp. Something arrived on my desk that was quite obviously a bomb, squishy and with wires sticking out; but when the police opened it it was a piece of marmalade toffee with a dental brace and two teeth attached, and an orthodontist's bill. They love those tales of behind-the-scenes disaster."

Sometimes a family connection is all it takes to develop a healthy extra income. For a fee somewhere in the region of £8,000, Washington Speakers Bureau will provide you with Sergei Khrushchev - "entrusted with his father's innermost thoughts during the editing of his memoirs" - who promises to "mesmerise audiences with rich background of behind-the-scenes life in the Soviet Union at the height of its power and influence". Maureen Reagan - "one of the top extemporaneous speakers in the nations [sic] . . . internationally known for her influence on the new world economy", and only incidentally the daughter of Ronald - charges between £6,000 and £9,000.

Some of the most sought-after names on the British circuit, though, are hardly famous at all outside the relatively closed world of professional institute dinners and charity galas. Professor Ken Robinson, a respected educationalist from the University of Warwick, is particularly popular - "he has a unique ability to blend intellectual challenge with stand-up humour", says one figure in the industry. So, even more unexpectedly, is Barbara Harmer, a former hairdresser who became the first woman to pilot Concorde. Sports stars of the present and past are unfailingly in demand; a couple of years ago, the Institute of Directors hired the entire surviving 1966 England football team for a private function, for the bargain price of around £15,000.

But there are signs that politicians are falling from favour; that whimsical anecdotes are out and hard-edged nuggets of strategic corporate wisdom are in. Business and motivational speakers such as Rosabeth Moss-Kanter, a professor at the Harvard Business School, typifies the new trend.

"There's definitely a feeling that with politicians you get so much of them these days that you probably don't want much more of them," says Kenyon-Slaney. "There are exceptions - and Ken Livingstone is an obvious one. He's so charismatic, he has this wonderful ability to communicate; Tony Benn is another - but outspoken figures are very difficult to find now. There are only a handful in the House of Commons who can really command an audience."

Some are attempting to adapt to the changing environment. One Jeffrey Archer (fee: £30,000 to £50,000) is registered with several US agencies, playing partly on his talents as a storyteller and partly on his reputation as the Comeback Kid. His biography on the website of Leading Authorities, a Washington-based speakers' bureau, relates the tale of how bankruptcy and ignominious resignation - the first one, at any rate - were transformed into spectacular wealth and success. His specialism, according to the agency, is "inspiration and motivation".

Premier league: international stars

First division

Speakers: Bill Cosby, Norman Schwarzkopf, Colin Powell.

Typical audience: Top-flight conventions and US charity galas.

Fee: Up to £190,000.

What do you get for your money? Cosby trades in on decades as a successful stand-up comedian and sitcom actor and takes top dollar.

General Schwarzkopf settled for £120,000 a speech after his triumphant return from the Gulf war. The commander "talks about goals, high standards, affording others the ability to learn and his own Rule 13 (When in command, take charge) and 14 (Do what's right)."

Powell, the former chairman of the US joint chiefs of staff, "chronicles a journey that begins with his childhood in the South Bronx, continues through his military career, his experiences as a best-selling author and then culminates with his focus in retirement on the many philanthropic endeavours with which he is involved". He takes home £60,000 for his pains.

First division: best of British

Speakers: Baroness Thatcher, John Major, Jeffrey Archer.

Typical audience: Ivy league universities.

Fee: Up to £50,000.

What do you get for your money? "Lady Thatcher reflects that as we enter the 21st century there is much to be optimistic about: the downfall of communism; the break-up of the Soviet Union; and the advance of liberty and free enterprise. If the 21st century is to be another 'American Century' then the west must find solutions to these pressing questions such as the rise of the Asia Pacific."

Major: "With the arrival of the 21st century national economies have become more interdependent. What will be the effect of the common European currency and how will that new marketplace evolve? Mr Major reflects on this and other issues of interest along with anecdotes to inform and entertain your audience."

Archer offers "inspiration and motivation".

Vauxhall conference: who's he?

Speakers: Commander Keith Hornby-Priestnall, Simon Storer, George Saunders.

Typical audience: Golf clubs, local branch Masonic lodges, private parties.

Fee: £500-£1,000.

What do you get for your money? Hornby-Priestnall: "His most recognised credentials include national chairman of the renowned Allied Brewery trade association and president of the Burton branch of the soldiers', sailors' and airmen's family association."

Storer: "Simon Storer's 10-year involvement with the Channel Tunnel project resulted in his overall expertise and current position as the principal speaker for the Institute of Electrical Engineers."

Saunders: "George is a genuine all-round comedian whose face is often recognised from his many appearances in television shows such as, Lovejoy, The Chief, Hercules Poirot among others."

There are only a handful in the House of Commons who can really command an audience." Some are attempting to adapt to the changing environment. One Jeffrey Archer (fee: £30,000 to £50,000) is registered with several US agencies, playing partly on his talents as a storyteller and partly on his reputation as the Comeback Kid. His biography on the website of Leading Authorities, a Washington-based speakers' bureau, relates the tale of how bankruptcy and ignominious resignation - the first one, at any rate - were transformed into spectacular wealth and success. His specialism, according to the agency, is "inspiration and motivation". Premier league: international stars First division Speakers: Bill Cosby, Norman Schwarzkopf, Colin Powell. Typical audience: Top-flight conventions and US charity galas. Fee: Up to £190,000. What do you get for your money? Cosby trades in on decades as a successful stand-up comedian and sitcom actor and takes top dollar. General Schwarzkopf settled for £120,000 a speech after his triumphant return from the Gulf war. The commander "talks about goals, high standards, affording others the ability to learn and his own Rule 13 (When in command, take charge) and 14 (Do what's right)." Powell, the former chairman of the US joint chiefs of staff, "chronicles a journey that begins with his childhood in the South Bronx, continues through his military career, his experiences as a best-selling author and then culminates with his focus in retirement on the many philanthropic endeavours with which he is involved". He takes home £60,000 for his pains. First division: best of British Speakers: Baroness Thatcher, John Major, Jeffrey Archer. Typical audience: Ivy league universities. Fee: Up to £50,000. What do you get for your money? "Lady Thatcher reflects that as we enter the 21st century there is much to be optimistic about: the downfall of communism; the break-up of the Soviet Union; and the advance of liberty and free enterprise. If the 21st century is to be another 'American Century' then the west must find solutions to these pressing questions such as the rise of the Asia Pacific." Major: "With the arrival of the 21st century national economies have become more interdependent. What will be the effect of the common European currency and how will that new marketplace evolve? Mr Major reflects on this and other issues of interest along with anecdotes to inform and entertain your audience." Archer offers "inspiration and motivation". Vauxhall conference: who's he? Speakers: Commander Keith Hornby-Priestnall, Simon Storer, George Saunders. Typical audience: Golf clubs, local branch Masonic lodges, private parties. Fee: £500-£1,000. What do you get for your money? Hornby-Priestnall: "His most recognised credentials include national chairman of the renowned Allied Brewery trade association and president of the Burton branch of the soldiers', sailors' and airmen's family association." Storer: "Simon Storer's 10-year involvement with the Channel Tunnel project resulted in his overall expertise and current position as the principal speaker for the Institute of Electrical Engineers." Saunders: "George is a genuine all-round comedian whose face is often recognised from his many appearances in television shows such as, Lovejoy, The Chief, Hercules Poirot among others."

webTitle: I don't like my brother. Should I spare his feelings and not tell him?

fields.headline: I don't like my brother. Should I spare his feelings and not tell him?
fields.trailText: Recently my brother got in touch  after 10 years. He came to stay for three days, and I found him unbearable. I would rather have a more honest relationship, but that would require harsh truths to be aired. Should I repress my own feelings to spare his?
fields.body:
My elder brother was taken into care when he was 15 and I was six. He now claims he was abused in care. I was kicked out by my parents when I was 15, and dropped out of school. After many difficult years, I am now fairly comfortable; though I am separated and semi-disabled, I have a good relationship with my 13-year-old son.

Recently my brother got in touch again after 10 years. He came to stay for three days, and I found him unbearable. He is unemployed, and told tales to convince me, and himself, that he is important and popular, and I colluded with him. I would rather have a more honest relationship, but that would require harsh truths to be aired. Should I repress my own feelings to spare his?

Be honest with him

I feel for you. My own family was dysfunctional. Although none of us four siblings ended up in care, we were unloved by our parents and there was always an atmosphere of hidden emotions and things unsaid.

I was kicked out at 16 and my response was to cut myself off from all of my family, bar one brother, as it was easier to cope that way. Only recently, at the age of almost 40, did I speak out to my mother about the damage she caused. It ended my relationship with her, but I have no regrets. I felt freed from past burdens of guilt, longing for approval and love, and self-hatred.

Best of all, my sister also spoke out and it has reunited us. I only wish I'd had the courage to speak out years ago. Perhaps my earlier life would then have been more fulfilled.

I strongly advise you to be open about your feelings. Blood ties do not oblige you to put up with someone you otherwise would not bother with. Why should you spare his feelings at the expense of yours? You will feel better for speaking your mind, but you will feel worse if you say nothing. Make it clear to him that you are still willing to have a relationship with him as long as it is open and honest. Don't feel guilty if he chooses not to take up the challenge.
Name and address withheld

He has to face facts

You must remain true to yourself. You have made your life from the cards you were dealt and your brother has made his. You are not responsible for him having been taken into care, nor for the problems he now faces. He has to learn to live in the world as it is. Part of that world is the fact that he isn't your sort of person.

If you want to maintain the contact he wants, you have to do it on your terms - and so you will have to be honest with him. Whether he chooses to maintain contact once he knows how you feel is up to him. He may just make the effort to behave towards you as you might wish him to - more honestly, for a start.

Why should you be the one to make all the concessions? You wouldn't put yourself out to that extent if he were, say, a colleague, and there are pitfalls in going against your own better judgment just because someone is "family".

It is cliched but true that we are given our relations but can choose our friends. I have a sibling whom I don't happen to like very much. I used to make an effort: when they complained that they hadn't seen me in a while I would make a date; it would almost always be broken by them at the last minute. When I was critically ill and alone in the world, they made elaborate promises of support which weren't kept.

Now I have learned to keep my distance and rely instead on my friends, who love me for the person I am, not for the fact that I am "family". If my sibling and I run into each other, we make civil small talk, and that works fine. I know that the ludicrous thing that calls itself "family" still has a hold - the trick is to learn that it doesn't matter.

What we all need in life are people who relate to who we really are. It doesn't help anyone who is trying to sort themselves out to be "supported" by a tissue of lies. You have a family of your own, who need you. You can't afford to take that risk.
Name and address withheld

Don't feel guilty

It really is difficult to overcome a major rejection in childhood. In my fifties, I still feel the pain of being "sent away" to strangers when I was five and it seems that you and your brother have been similarly damaged. You have overcome this bad start and made something of your life, but your brother has not, so there is no chance of a relationship of equals, supporting each other and contributing to each other's lives. If he kept in touch, it would be all take on his side and all give on yours.

Even so, the blood-tie might make you willing to act as sort of therapist/counsellor and shore him up. Don't fool yourself into thinking this would be possible and don't feel guilty about standing up for common sense. For this, or any other kind of relationship between you, would be bound to fail.

Unfortunately, your pretence of having some positive feelings for him has been bad for both of you. It has made him expect too much and made you feel resentful. That's why nothing but good can come of being straight with each other now. Talk to him gently along the lines of "Look, we're different and we don't get on. Keeping in touch would never work."

Encourage him to be his own master: he could be a great guy, but he has to climb up there himself, possibly with counselling help.
Anne White, Slough

Next week:

My husband and I married last year and have an excellent relationship. But now that we are considering having a child, I have a serious worry which he won't discuss with me. His sister is moderately retarded and I am concerned that there might be a genetic cause. This is a taboo subject in his family; he won't discuss it with me and his parents have simply said that she was deprived of oxygen at birth. This might be the case, but the wall my husband and his family put up against discussion makes me suspect there is more to it. In fairness to me and our children, how can I find out more in case we need genetic testing?

fields.headline: The numbers game
fields.trailText: Oscar's vital statistics
fields.body:
The winners are...

The most honoured films ever, with 11 Academy Awards each:

Ben-Hur (1960)
Titanic (1997)

The only three films to sweep the top five awards (best picture, best actor, best actress, best director, best screenplay):

It Happened One Night (1934)
One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest (1975)
The Silence of the Lambs (1991)

Katharine Hepburn

Winner of four best actress Academy Awards (Morning Glory, 1932/33; Guess Who's Coming To Dinner, 1967; The Lion in Winter, 1968; On Golden Pond, 1981)

And the losers are...

Goodfellas beaten to the best picture Oscar in 1990 by Dances with Wolves.
Raging Bull beaten to the best picture Oscar in 1980 by Ordinary People.
Taxi Driver beaten to the best picture Oscar in 1976 by Rocky. (Martin Scorsese has also failed in four nominations as best director.)
Citizen Kane beaten to the best picture Oscar in 1941 by How Green Was My Valley

Alfred Hitchcock

Nominated for the best director Oscar five times (Rebecca, 1941; Lifeboat, 1945; Spellbound, 1946; Rear Window 1955; Psycho, 1961), but won none.

Age matters

Oldest Oscar winner:
George Burns aged 80, for best supporting actor, in The Sunshine Boys (1976)

Oldest Oscar nominee:
Gloria Stuart aged 87, for best supporting actress, in Titanic (1998)

Youngest Oscar winner:
Tatum O'Neal aged 10, for best supporting actress, in Paper Moon (1974)

Youngest Oscar nominee:
Justin Henry aged 8, for best supporting actor, in Kramer Vs Kramer (1980)

Hosts with the mosts

Most frequent hosts are:
Bob Hope (16 times)
Billy Crystal (7)
Johnny Carson (5)
Jack Lemmon (4)
Whoopi Goldberg and Jerry Lewis (3)

 Dates refer to the year of the Oscar ceremony, not the film's production date.

fields.headline: Thanks? Please, no...
fields.standfirst: Those excruciating winners' speeches: we trawl through  the archives
fields.trailText: Those excruciating winners' speeches: we trawl through the archives
fields.body:
"I want to thank... everybody I ever met in my entire life." Maureen Stapleton 1982, accepting the award for best supporting actress in Reds, 1982.

"I can't tell you how encouraging a thing like this is. I remember the first film I was ever in, in 1915, and here we are in 1969 and I don't know why it took me so long," said tiny Ruth Gordon, aged 72, accepting best supporting actress for Rosemary's Baby.

"In the great wealth, the great firmament of your nation's generosities this particular choice may perhaps be found by future generations as a trifle eccentric, but the mere fact of it - the prodigal, pure, human kindness of it - must be seen as a beautiful star in that firmament which shines upon me at this moment, dazzling me a little, but filling me with warmth of the extraordinary elation, the euphoria that happens to so many of us at the first breath of the majestic glow of a new tomorrow." Laurence Olivier accepting his honorary Oscar, 1979.

"I'm so loaded down with good luck charms I could hardly make it up the stairs." David Niven, winning best actor, Separate Tables, 1958. There were titters in the audience because Niven paused after he said "loaded".

"I would not be standing here if it weren't for two very important men in my life. Two that I haven't spoken with in a while but I had the pleasure of the other night: Mr Rawley Farnsworth, who was my high school drama teacher, who taught me to act well the part, there all the glory lies.

"And one of my classmates under Mr Farnsworth, Mr John Gilkerson. I mention their names because they are two of the finest gay Americans, two wonderful men that I had the good fortune to be associated with, to fall under their inspiration at such a young age. I wish my babies could have the same sort of teacher, the same sort of friends.

"And there lies my dilemma here tonight. I know that my work in this case is magnified by the fact that the streets of Heaven are too crowded with angels. We know their names. They number 1,000 for each of the red ribbons we wear here tonight.

"They finally rest in the warm embrace of the gracious creator of us all. A healing embrace that cools their fevers, that clears their skin, and allows their eyes to see the simple, self-evident commonsense truth that is made manifest by the benevolent creator of us all, and was written down on paper by wise men, tolerant men, in the city of Philadelphia 200 years ago. God bless you all, God have mercy on us all, and God bless America." Tom Hanks, accepting best actor Oscar for Philadelphia, 1993. Paul "Addams Family" Rudnick was subsequently inspired to write the schoolteacher-outing comedy In & Out.

"Man, I feel as though I'm standing on magic legs, in a special effects process shot that is too unbelievable to imagine and far too costly to make a reality. But, here is my mark, and there is where I'm supposed to look and believe me, the power and the pleasure and the emotion of this moment is as constant as the speed of light." Tom Hanks, accepting best actor Oscar for Forrest Gump, 1995.

George C Scott described the Oscars as "a two-hour meat parade," and said that he would refuse the best actor award if he won for Patton in 1970. When his victory was announced, Scott was at home in New York watching a hockey game on TV.

"Hello. My name is Sacheen Littlefeather. I'm Apache and... I'm representing Marlon Brando this evening." So said a young woman in Native American clothes who took the microphone after Marlon Brando won the best actor award for The Godfather in 1972. Brando sent Littlefeather to protest against the treatment of Native Americans in the movies. "I think awards in this country at this time are inappropriate to be received or given until the condition of the American Indian is drastically altered. If we are not our brother's keeper, at least let us not be his executioner." Littlefeather turned out not to be Native American at all.

fields.headline: Gold fever
fields.standfirst: Oscar night - and how to enjoy it
fields.trailText: Oscar night - and how to enjoy it
fields.body:
Sunday week is Oscar night, an evening for long, stupid speeches, long, stupid dresses and short, ugly film producers. How should one get through Sunday night's ludicrous but somehow compelling farce? Judicious use of your telly's off switch and an early night, you may well be suggesting? Just a little more enthusiasm, if you don't mind.

Hollywood producer Julia Phillips recommends a careful blend of stimulants and depressants to make the evening tolerable, which makes good sense if Gwyneth Paltrow gets near the podium with a speech in her hand.

In her memoir You'll Never Eat Lunch in This Town again, Phillips described the cocktail that got her in the right mood for the evening in 1973 when her film The Sting was nominated: "a diet pill, a small amount of coke, two joints, six halves of Valium, which makes three, and a glass-and-a-half of wine."

If the drugs don't work, though, try the Friday Review's guide to the Oscars past and, in a very real sense, present. It will get you in the right frame of mind and answers all the vital questions. Just how syntactically challenged is Tom Hanks? Who the hell was Sacheen Littlefeather and what did she want?

fields.headline: A brief history
fields.trailText: 1927 The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences was founded - by "a handful of film artists and studio visionaries devoted to the improvement and advancement of their craft" according to the official website, Oscar.com, but according to David Shipman in his History of Cinema, it was started by Louis B Mayer in an attempt to prevent unionisation of actors and studio workers.
fields.body:
1927 The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences was founded - by "a handful of film artists and studio visionaries devoted to the improvement and advancement of their craft" according to the official website, Oscar.com, but according to David Shipman in his History of Cinema, it was started by Louis B Mayer in an attempt to prevent unionisation of actors and studio workers.

1929 Tickets for the first Oscar ceremony in May 16, 1929, cost $10 each. There were 250 guests for the banquet held in the Blossom Room of the Hollywood Roosevelt hotel. Films were eligible for competition if they had been released in Los Angeles between August 1927 and June 1928.

Fifteen statuettes were awarded, all of them to men - except for Janet Gaynor's best actress nod. fields.headline: The sweet hereafter
fields.standfirst: Thelma Schoonmaker edits Scorsese's movies and was married to Michael Powell. Michael Ellison met her in New York to talk about the revival of her husband's A Matter of Life and Death
fields.trailText: Thelma Schoonmaker edits Scorsese's movies and was married to Michael Powell. Michael Ellison met her in New York to talk about the revival of her husband's A Matter of Life and Death
fields.body:
The barman picks up the video cassette case lying on the counter of an establishment on Hudson Street, Manhattan. "Ah, it's Led Zeppelin?" Actually, it's not - but his mistake is understandable. Michael Powell's films have always been misunderstood, so why should Stairway to Heaven be any different? This was the name given in the US to the film-maker's 1946 movie, A Matter of Life and Death.

"Michael was furious about the change," says his widow Thelma Schoonmaker, leaning forward in the seat in her editing suite in Martin Scorsese's Park Avenue headquarters. "They said here that they couldn't have death in the title even though there had just been a war in which millions had died." Schoonmaker was six years old when the movie was made.

A Matter of Life and Death was Powell's favourite among his own movies and came 20th last year in the BFI's poll of the 100 greatest of the previous century. "I think the theme of love being about sacrifice and sacrifice about love was very important to him," says Schoonmaker. "It seems to be reaching into people deeply. He didn't have any fear of death himself and that's evident in the film."

It was one of 19 that Powell made in collaboration with Emeric Pressburger, a flight of fancy rooted in earthbound themes where a black-and-white courtroom drama in the heavens holds the key to life and love shot in colour down below. The movie opens with David Niven - almost camp as the sort of Brit that time forgot - as an airman going down in flames without a parachute and sharing his supposedly final words with a female American radio operator.

Powell too chose to travel without a parachute. "He was a magician; he let his imagination run riot; he felt he was absolutely free," says 60-year-old Schoonmaker, elbows on thighs and chin in left hand. There had been triumphs before, such as The Life and Death of Colonel Blimp (Churchill did not approve); and others would follow, including The Red Shoes, which won two Oscars.

But it was Peeping Tom in 1960 (by this time Powell was operating without Pressburger) that blighted a career stretching back to 1925. Today it is acknowledged as a classic but then it was reviled. It was pulled rapidly from cinemas, investors got cold feet and it seemed that taste and the times had no further use for Powell.

"Michael and Emeric were both living in terrible oblivion and felt they had been chucked out," says Schoonmaker. "Their movies were made in a certain time so they has to reflect that time. They got thrown out with the bathwater when the kitchen-sink school of film-making came in.

"They were in the dark for so long, 20 years, a terrible long time, and strapped for cash. But Michael never became bitter. They never stopped believing in their movies."

Fortunately for them, neither did a young man glued to the screen on the Lower East Side of Manhattan. "Michael thought that television was the end of his career but in fact it saved him because Martin Scorsese was watching his movies on television and eventually came to England to find him."

Powell writes in the second volume of his autobiography: "No wonder that when they got me alone and out on a limb with Peeping Tom, they gleefully sawed off the limb and jumped up and down on the corpse."

Little Marty knew nothing of this, indeed knew nothing much about Powell and Pressburger. But he did know that it was worth defying his mother to watch the Million Dollar Movie slot on television, which would show the same film each day for a week. Here he came across their work, and he did not forget it.

Years later, after finishing Taxi Driver in the mid-70s, Scorsese met Powell in London. Powell had seen none of Scorsese's work and the American thought that the Englishman was dead. If he was, Scorsese set about helping to revive him.

Scorsese, whose office walls are home to original posters for Powell and Pressburger films as well as those for his own, says now of A Matter of Life and Death: "It holds up, I think, because of the outrageousness of it. It's a real leap of faith - you either go with it or you don't. And if you do it's both a fantasy and a love story that plays out in the mind of Niven. What happens to him is totally realistic. Powell's vision is a place that's so beautiful to be alive in."

Schoonmaker certainly thought so and she and Powell, 35 years between them, got together in Los Angeles after she received her Oscar for Raging Bull. "I have the best job in the world and Marty got me the best husband," says Schoonmaker, breaking off occasionally to manipulate one of two editing screens where she is working on Scorsese's latest project, a history of Italian film provisionally titled Il Dolce Cinema.

"We had 10 years, that was all, but it was fantastic. I never thought I would get married: I'm such a workaholic. We just married on a whim. He was so vivid, he never wasted anything."

Until Powell died at the age of 84 in 1990 the couple used to spend three months a year at his cottage in the Cotswolds. Now Schoonmaker is lucky if she manages two weeks, such is the frenetic schedule set by Scorsese, to whom she refers on the telephone as "my director". She spends six, sometimes seven, days a week at her desk and in a few months they will be in Rome to start work on Gangs of New York.

"I could do with a little more time to myself but Marty always has another film coming. I can't give up working on this. They become old friends, these films. And I never get tired of Michael's films, there are so many levels to them."

Powell used to tell her sometimes that he never worked such long hours in his day. "He said he was shocked by the hours we spent at it. It's very hard being the mate of a film-maker. It's so exciting but the person at home is not so amused." Then she started looking at Powell's diaries: he would come home at 10pm and settle down to write for a couple of hours. Maybe it was only work when somebody else was doing it.

 A Matter of Life and Death is re-released on March 24.

fields.headline: Great Dictators
fields.trailText: Great Dictators
fields.body:
The latest despot to get the Hollywood treatment is Manuel Noriega in Noriega: God's Favorite, directed by Roger Spottiswoode. So who gets the plum role as Central American pineapple-faced tyrant, convicted drug trafficker, jailbird to be and all-round hombre malo ? Step forward Bob Hoskins.

When it comes to dictators, movers and shakers, central casting is apt to go for the unusual. Need a red-blooded, action-man hero, the very definition of lionhearted, to play Richard the Lionheart? ("War, war, that's all you think about, Dick Plantagenet. You burner! You pillager!" as Lady Edith puts it.) Hollywood chose George Sanders, a man so languid he probably had his martinis stirred for him.

Around him, extras honed their swarthy insults: "May the seven doves rest on your shoulders," proferred a dark-skinned, devious Saladin (Rex Harrison, naturally). "Doves or vultures, you slippery infidel," quoth Sir Kenneth (Laurence Harvey), showing him a thing or two on the slander front.

Trotsky wound up as Richard Burton ("All around the world lies a cold silence. But the truth. They cannot silence that.") Burton's script was written by Nicholas Mosley, son of black-shirted East End rabble-rouser and would-be despot Oswald. Moustachioed peasant mass-murderer Stalin was played by smooth clean-cut consigliere Robert Duvall in Stalin.

America's own preferred Great Satan, Fidel Castro, was played, naturally, by enduring all-purpose baddie Jack Palance in Che! (Palance also put his sneer to work as Attila the Hun in Sign of the Pagan); but who should be the eponymous mountain revolutionary Che Guevara? None other than Omar Sharif, doe-eyed Egyptian bridge expert. He got the best lines: "The peasant is like a wild flower in the forest and the revolutionary like a bee. Neither can survive or propagate without the other. There is one essential difference between us and the bees. In this hive, I will not tolerate drones." And: "It took two years to reach Havana and after only two days, I'm sick of it."

Sharif had been cast in the title role of Genghis Khan, the 12th-century Mongol ruler. But Hollywood preferred John Wayne in The Conqueror. Well he does have quite narrow eyes and a way with Asian ancientspeak: "While I live, while my blood burns hot, your daughter is not safe in her tent." (Oddly, this line would have worked better for Sid James in Carry on Camping.)

Charlie Chaplin was the first Hitler in The Great Dictator (together, they prevented anyone ever wanting to wear a toothbrush moustache again). Hitler later became Alec Guinness and progressed to Dick Shawn, the flower-power dictator of The Producers.

Perhaps we should leave the last word to dictatorial anti-Hollywood director Woody Allen, in the topical words of Annie Hall's Alvy Singer: "What's with all these awards? They're always giving out awards. Best fascist dictator, Adolf Hitler."

fields.headline: No cop-outs
fields.standfirst: When Suzanne Fenn co-wrote Third World Cop, it had to be fast, cheap and real, she tells Justina Hart
fields.trailText: When Suzanne Fenn co-wrote Third World Cop, it had to be fast, cheap and real, she tells Justina Hart
fields.body:
When you're making a film about police and thieves, and the local armourer has to provide a crack police squad to prevent ambush of the film company's stash of weapons, art really is life and it happens on the run.

"You have to be able to move quickly - get in, shoot and get out before too many people are around," says Chris Blackwell, founder of Island records and promoter of Bob Marley, who has set up a small film and music company in Jamaica called Palm Pictures. He's talking about the smash hit Third World Cop, which follows the equally low-budget ragga fairytale, Dancehall Queen (1997) in re-awakening interest in the idea of home-grown film. The "industry" had been in a slump since the 70s following the cult success of The Harder They Come (1972).

"It had a great title and was a project we could get right," he says of his decision to run with Third World Cop. A story of childhood friends, Ratty (Mark Danvers) and Capone (Paul Campbell) who grow up to find themselves on opposite sides of the law, it was made for $570,000 (US) and has become the highest grossing film in the country's history, taking over $500,000 at the box office. Blackwell hopes that his innovative use of digital film will mean he can make two or three similar movies a year with a crew of two or three. Third World Cop - which took 20 days to shoot - involved 47 people, plus apprentices from the Area Youth Foundation, and two police crews.

Jamaica has been described as a land of natural storytellers which spontaneously lends itself to movie-making, so when audiences get the rare chance to identify with their own stories and characters, they participate by making "nuff noise", whooping and heckling and pointing their fingers in the shape of guns at the screen. Third World Cop was sold out for two days after it opened last October. Even Blackwell couldn't get a seat.

"We have to make these films at a very low cost so they can pay for themselves with the Jamaican audience initially, and hope that one of them will catch a much wider market," says Blackwell, who secured foreign distribution deals by emailing the Third World Cop web address around the world. For Brits and Americans who persevere with the patois, Jamaican films can tap you into a raw, sometimes terrifying energy: you come away feeling that you wouldn't last a day on the brutally poor streets of downtown Kingston.

"The film is totally realistic. It was written with real stories. It captures absolutely the authentic texture of life in the Kingston ghettos," says Suzanne Fenn, the film's co-writer and editor. Fenn, who grew up in France, has worked with the likes of Godard and Louis Malle, but a holiday to Jamaica during which she met veteran actor Carl Bradshaw led initially to her involvement in Dancehall Queen, and changed her life. Travelling from LA to Jamaica for the first time, she suddenly felt, "Oh, I remember what I thought life was".

When Carolyn Pfeiffer (an American producer married to a friend of Blackwell's) originated the idea of Third World Cop in 1995 she got Blackwell's blessing but the idea was stillborn without a writer.

"She liked the way I developed the characters in Dancehall Queen and asked me to write the script," says Fenn. "I agreed although I knew nothing about cops, even less Jamaican cops." Since it would be based on a true story, Fenn thought she could handle it. But the man whose life it was based on refused to co-operate. Fenn was rescued by English journalist and biographer Chris Salewicz, but they no longer had a true story to work with.

"Look into the life of Natty Morgan," Bradshaw advised, enigmatically. Morgan was a well-known Jamaican Robin Hood-type character, who had evaded the police for months by living in the swamps. The idea tied in nicely with Jamaican film lore, since The Harder They Come (also featuring Bradshaw) was based around a true story too - of Rhygin, a 40s gunman. Fenn and Salewicz went to meet Jamaican crime reporters and sifted through their files on Morgan and other gunmen.

Blackwell rejected the first draft and Salewicz left to work on a TV project. He was replaced by music video and short film director Chris Browne, who went on to direct Third World Cop. "We interviewed cops for two months, went on picnics with them and their families and entered the Jamaican cop psyche," Fenn remembers. But every time they invented something, Blackwell instinctively didn't like it. "He kept saying, 'You're going to have to gather stories for months and weave them in'. Each time he would stop liking it when we cheated."

Casting took two and a half months because Blackwell was adamant about using "real hard-core original faces" so that Fenn and the casting agent had to hand-pick most of the extras. Musicians Scaredem Crew were cast as the members of the gun-running gang, and several well-known DJs were cast in small parts to add to the sense of authenticity. Third World Cop's intense reggae/dancehall soundtrack was produced by the Riddim Twins, Sly and Robbie.

Trouble brewed as soon as the crew ventured into the ghetto to shoot. "You can't shoot in a ghetto without giving something back because ghetto people are so poor, they'd feel cheated if you did that," says Fenn. On every location, people from the area must be used as extras, and a slice of budget and food given to the community.

"We had heavy adventures," says Fenn. "In one area we paid our location fee to a group of people only to find out on the day of the shoot that they were squatters and that the real owner had not been paid. Another time a marginal element of the community viewed us as a target for extortion and disrupted our shoot for ransom," Fenn adds. The film was edited and the music recorded locally, but Blackwell had to organise the rest of the post-production in LA.

The dangers of working in urban Jamaica are obvious, but for Fenn and crew, the reward is being able to make films in an authentically raw, creative way.

 Third World Cop opens next Friday.

Fenn and Salewicz went to meet Jamaican crime reporters and sifted through their files on Morgan and other gunmen. Blackwell rejected the first draft and Salewicz left to work on a TV project. He was replaced by music video and short film director Chris Browne, who went on to direct Third World Cop. "We interviewed cops for two months, went on picnics with them and their families and entered the Jamaican cop psyche," Fenn remembers. But every time they invented something, Blackwell instinctively didn't like it. "He kept saying, 'You're going to have to gather stories for months and weave them in'. Each time he would stop liking it when we cheated." Casting took two and a half months because Blackwell was adamant about using "real hard-core original faces" so that Fenn and the casting agent had to hand-pick most of the extras. Musicians Scaredem Crew were cast as the members of the gun-running gang, and several well-known DJs were cast in small parts to add to the sense of authenticity. Third World Cop's intense reggae/dancehall soundtrack was produced by the Riddim Twins, Sly and Robbie. Trouble brewed as soon as the crew ventured into the ghetto to shoot. "You can't shoot in a ghetto without giving something back because ghetto people are so poor, they'd feel cheated if you did that," says Fenn. On every location, people from the area must be used as extras, and a slice of budget and food given to the community. "We had heavy adventures," says Fenn. "In one area we paid our location fee to a group of people only to find out on the day of the shoot that they were squatters and that the real owner had not been paid. Another time a marginal element of the community viewed us as a target for extortion and disrupted our shoot for ransom," Fenn adds. The film was edited and the music recorded locally, but Blackwell had to organise the rest of the post-production in LA. The dangers of working in urban Jamaica are obvious, but for Fenn and crew, the reward is being able to make films in an authentically raw, creative way.  Third World Cop opens next Friday.

fields.headline: Girls will be boys
fields.standfirst: When film student Kimberly Peirce heard the tragic tale of Teena Brandon, a young, apparently male Nebraskan murdered because he was actually a girl, she vowed to make a film about it. Emma Brockes talked to her about a movie that became a cause celebre
fields.trailText: When film student Kimberly Peirce heard the tragic tale of Teena Brandon, a young, apparently male Nebraskan murdered because he was actually a girl, she vowed to make a film about it. Emma Brockes talked to her about a movie that became a cause celebre
fields.body:
Kimberly Peirce's biggest concern while making the film Boys Don't Cry was that the audience wouldn't sympathise with her heroine.

Beaten, raped and eventually murdered, the true story of Teena Brandon's short life would appear to demand only the tenderest reception. But to sympathise with her is to make a leap that Peirce wasn't sure a large slice of her audience would be capable of: Brandon was a transsexual, a girl who passed herself off as a boy. In the logic of the Nebraska outpost she came from, she forfeited her right to public sympathy when she shoved a pair of socks down her trousers and started dating the town's girls.

Now that the film has won a Golden Globe award and is nominated for two Oscars, Peirce's faith in a five-year-long project has been vindicated. The good reception that Boys Don't Cry has had, particularly in the conservative mid-west where the story takes place, is only upstaged by the fact that it is Peirce's first film. In April 1994, while enrolled on a graduate film course at Columbia University - she is now in her early 30s - she started reading reports in the press about a hate crime that had rocked a little place called Falls City, way out in Nebraska.

"I was writing another script at the time, based on a true story about a woman who passed as a man during the civil war. Then I picked up the Village Voice and started reading about Brandon." Teena Brandon, or Brandon Teena as (s)he called him/herself, was a popular fixture in Falls City. He drank with the boys, dated the girls, fell in love with a bold young woman called Lana and, when his identity as a woman was discovered, was shot dead by two young men who couldn't process the inverted values that came with his unmasking.

The story was picked up by the New York Times and the New Yorker; a novel and a play were written about it. "I fell in love with a story that was bigger than me," says Peirce. "It was capturing the nation's imagination."

While much of the coverage concentrated on the brutal killing and the "freak" factor of Brandon's sexuality, what interested Peirce was the love story between Brandon and Lana. The film student made a brave move: she caught a plane to Nebraska and, inspired by such prose works as Truman Capote's In Cold Blood and Norman Mailer's The Executioner's Son, began doing some background journalism.

She attended the killers' trials; she interviewed the witnesses; she read every scrap of material on the case until, two years and another visit later, the angle of her story became clear to her. The extraordinary fact about the case, Peirce thought, was that these people weren't east coast sophisticates dabbling with homosexuality, but a young couple from redneck country, heroic enough to love each other even after it emerged that both of them were girls.

Lana, whom Peirce interviewed at length, resents any suggestion that she is a lesbian. Her suspension of disbelief about Brandon's identity is at the psychological heart of the movie. She still alternates her references to his gender. Against the backdrop of an endless Nebraska skyline, this really is the stuff of poetry, of love as the ultimate agent of transformation. When Peirce first came up against it, however, it threatened to blow her whole story.

"I said to Lana, when did you first know that Brandon was a girl? She replied, 'Oh, I knew the day that I met him.' I thought if she knew when she met him, there's no story here. Then she said, 'No, I didn't really know until that day Brandon told me.' Then she said, 'No I didn't really know until later.' "

Lana and Brandon had planned to run away together and when Peirce asked Lana if they meant to go as lovers or as friends, Lana replied, "As friends, of course, because Brandon was a girl." But when Peirce mentioned Brandon's desire for a sex change, Lana said quickly, "Brandon didn't need a sex change, he was always a man to me" As Peirce says, "Whether Brandon is a boy or girl changes for Lana, sentence by sentence. So I have to ask myself, what can I trust? I can trust that she loves Brandon."

Unsurprisingly, the synopsis of a film this complicated, did not excite a bidding war between the major studios. Peirce didn't even set out with idea of making a feature film. She gained her first degree in English and Japanese literature at the University of Chicago, during which time she spent two years living in Japan and working as a stills photographer. After moving to New York's Columbia University, she progressed from stills to making 16mm shorts. One, the Last Good Breath, about two lovers who take turns sacrificing themselves to survive a war, won second place at the Canada international film festival.

When Peirce wrote the script of Boys Don't Cry, it was as her graduate thesis, and she filmed a short version of it. But somewhere around 1995 she began to realise its potential as a feature film. But there were serious difficulties. As well as the challenging nature of its material, Peirce was a first-time director who wanted to retain full creative control. She could have had "high risk" printed across her forehead. "The fact that the movie could not get made made total sense to me," she says. "My culture destroyed Brandon, my culture couldn't make sense of Brandon, I made sense of Brandon."

Peirce frowns under the weight of her mission to inspire awe not disgust for Lana and Brandon. The impression Peirce gives is of an earnest, incredibly hard-working woman, erring on the side of sobriety, but passionate about her material to an extent that makes it hard to imagine how she would handle a story she was less personally involved in.

In the project's early days, Peirce was helped by the casting of Hilary Swank in the lead role as Brandon and Chloë Sevigny as Lana. Swank is superb, utterly believable as a male lead, and Sevigny brings her usual, Plasticine-featured intensity to the role. Both have been nominated for Oscars and Swank won the best actress award at this year's Golden Globes after Fox Searchlight, an arm of Rupert Murdoch's Fox, eventually backed the film on the strength of a 20-minute trailer.

What is most surprising in all this the way the American heartlands have reacted to the film. When it showed in St Louis, Missouri, people poured round Peirce after the screening to congratulate her. "I loved Brandon," a lot of them said, no minor admission, since to make this statement they had had to digest a scene in which one girl wearing a dildo made love to another girl who believed her to be a boy. Yet digest it they did.

"In St Louis there was a question-and-answer session after the film," says Peirce. "The greatest thing that emerged from it was that the audience didn't think of Brandon as a sexual deviant. My aim had been to make him as deeply human as possible, so that people fell in love with him the way that Lana did; so that they didn't think gay, didn't think weird, just thought Brandon. And that's what happened."

They were helped along in this by a shift in American culture that has been symbolised by the public reaction to the Matthew Shepherd case. When Brandon was murdered in 1993, the public outcry was limited. When Matthew Shepherd, a gay student, was murdered in Wyoming last year, the outcry was huge and Shepherd became an icon for everyone opposed to what Peirce calls "the straight white boys picking up guns and taking their frustrations out on people who aren't like them. When Brandon was killed, the country wasn't as aware of its own cultural violence as it is now. Now the corporate financiers are looking at my film and saying, oh my God, you're recognising a problem that's out there. But the problem has been out there."

The story of his life is, Peirce believes, the story of a wounded culture that is only just beginning to look at itself without panicking at what it sees. For a while after the crime, Lana was ostracised in Falls City and moved to live with an aunt in Omaha. She is back at home now, though, has had a baby and is finding that the prevailing sentiment towards her is curiosity not hostility. She did, however, launch a lawsuit just prior to the film's release against Fox for invasion of privacy, which was settled out of court. Peirce is still in touch with her and intends to remain so. "The great thing is that in the end, Lana didn't know anything about gender politics. She was just trying desperately to hang on to something that was beautiful in her life."

 Boys Don't Cry is released on April 7.

fields.headline: Video releases
fields.standfirst: Analyze This | A Midsummer Night's Dream | With or Without You | American Perfekt
fields.trailText: Analyze This | A Midsummer Night's Dream | With or Without You | American Perfekt
fields.body:
Analyze This
Rental and DVD £15.99
Warner Bros Cert 15
***

Billy Crystal is a psychiatrist who gives his card to a very large American-Italian after a bit of bumper-bumping in Manhattan. Robert De Niro is the mob boss having panic attacks who decides to use his services and disrupts his life. Director Harold Ramis's high-concept 90s comedies, Groundhog Day and Multiplicity, were as funny as mainstream Hollywood gets. But both films had a totally original gimmick. The mobster/shrink thing has been done, sublimely, in The Sopranos, which had far more time to develop it, and in Grosse Pointe Blank; so it lacks equivalent freshness.

Analyze This boasts some sharp lines and nice performances, especially from Joe Viterelli as the vast, slow-witted mob sidekick without which no mafia movie is complete (he was also Vinnie the Shrimp in Mickey Blue Eyes). De Niro gets away from his usual kind of mobster role in blubbing Paul Vitti. As he and Crystal communicate across a great divide, the mixture of mobspeak and psychobabble has its moments, like the "hit the pillow" gag. But the silly plot prevents it achieving more than mild mirth.

A Midsummer Night's Dream
Rental
Fox Pathé Cert PG
***

Michael Hoffman sprinkles some fairy dust and gives his film a sumptuous look to match this starriest Dream since James Cagney and co took it on in 1935. But it has longueurs and you can't help feeling the blame lies mainly with the only guy to get his name above the title: Shakespeare.

Long before his Hollywood A-list days, this is the Bard inventing screwball comedy, as fluffy as candyfloss and just as lacking in substance. But if you like the play, you should enjoy this fairly respectful film, although for no apparent reason, Hoffman moves the action to the turn of the 19th century and puts Calista Flockhart on a bicycle.

In an Anglo-American cast where everyone gets to use their own accent, she is the best of the Yanks and, in a scene more McBealian than Shakespearian, gets to mud-wrestle Anna Friel. But Kevin Kline is not my idea of a Bottom, and I speak as a man who once saw Frankie Howerd's Bottom at the Old Vic. No, don't titter.

With or Without You
Rental
FilmFour Cert 18
***

A video premiere that deserves to be noticed. It's made, by the always interesting Michael Winterbottom on a small scale, and is headlined by couch-potato friendly names Christopher Eccleston and Dervla Kirwan. They are a fairly happy married couple in Belfast with one problem: they're struggling to reproduce (and a crowded family dinner table lets you know how big the pressure to be a parent is).

Her old French pen pal (Yvan Attal) turns up out of the blue and his ex (Julie Graham) does her best to tempt the husband off the marital straight and narrow. Eccleston is also chafing at the bit working for his father-in-law after giving up his old job as a policeman, and regular Eccleston watchers will know that when it comes to seething with resentment, he's the current British number one. Events and tangled relationships come to a boil in an involving way in a nicely observed TV film stuffed with believable characters.

American Perfekt
Rental and DVD
Blue Dolphin Cert 15
**

An interesting cast including Tarantino refugees Amanda Plummer and Robert Forster - and David Thewlis, as an unconvincing cockney - turn up in a low-budget road movie. This is the kind of thing that often provides interesting, offbeat little films superior to average Hollywood product, but from interesting beginnings, this one soon becomes too self-consciously wacky for its own good with characters ranging from devious to deranged. It went straight to video and very slowly - Forster made this before the career-reviving Jackie Brown.

fields.headline: Another impossible Mission
fields.trailText: Oh God, is it Brian De Palma time again already? I always get myself into trouble around this time of year. A new De Palma film (well, I say "new"..) is always guaranteed to bring out the worst in me, and that in turn brings out the worst in the more rabid and demented De Palma fans, who can be a scary lot at the best of times.
fields.body:
Oh God, is it Brian De Palma time again already? I always get myself into trouble around this time of year. A new De Palma film (well, I say "new"..) is always guaranteed to bring out the worst in me, and that in turn brings out the worst in the more rabid and demented De Palma fans, who can be a scary lot at the best of times.

Last year I ended my review of his bonehead thriller Snake Eyes with the simple phrase "Burn the negative", which I'll admit was coming it a bit strong, perhaps. To my shame it's the sort of film-criticism I can imagine Josef Goebbels practising, though he'd probably really dig De Palma.

Trouble is, if you meet his fans and say exactly what you think about the most corpulent of the erstwhile Movie Brats - that he's derivative, that he's a misogynist, that he's wasted his undeniable cinematic flair on rehashes, rip-offs and dross for 20 years - then their knuckles whiten around their pints, their pupils dilate and pretty soon they're screaming: "You just don't fucking get it, do you?"

Soon afterwards they'll ambush me in the lavs, when I've got my hands far too full to defend myself, and administer a good Tony Montana-style kicking, or as Brian himself might phrase it, an homage to a good Tony Montana-style kicking.

Well, sometimes. More often the complaints come through the formal channel of the readers' letters page. Not that the kind of people who write to newspapers are any less dangerous than people who wait in dark cubicles for their victims. If the letters aren't actually scrawled in green ink by drooling, two-handed pen-clutchers of drastically limited vocabulary - or done ransom-note style - then the contents often reveal the authors to be potential freeway-snipers who lurk in dark one-room apartments bathed only in the livid green glow of their 10-year-old computers.

Sometimes they get all obsessive and strange on you, as was the case with one reader of the LA Weekly, for which I write each week. This guy had made a case study of everything I'd reviewed - his first letter began, "I've been watching you..." - and went through the list film by film, concluding thus: "Of the 17 films you've reviewed negatively recently, I believe 14 were in fact really good."

To which my reply would be the conventional critic's comeback: "Well, opinions are like assholes. Everyone's got one. Trouble is, no one wants to smell yours." That or "Never apologise. Never explain." Or, from the cheap shelf: "Ner-ner-na-ner-ner!" And I received 10 letters from this guy. At my house.

Since the Weekly, roughly equivalent to a Time Out for Los Angeles, is actually a free paper, it confuses me that people get so worked up about what's in it, but they do. When I gave David Lynch's The Straight Story a lambasting last year the complaints completely overwhelmed the letters page - something which of course filled me with intense pride.

That movie's ad campaign was the kind that prints every 4-star review on the poster - and there were about 20 of them. Seems everyone liked it except me. However the letter-writers wanted absolute, down-the-line positive unanimity for Lynch, with no dissent permitted whatsoever. The needles on the "you-just-don't-fucking-get-it" metre were pushed deep, deep into the red overload zone.

The choicest insult - apart from the usual chestnuts about me being a frustrated screenwriter/haggard masturbator/cultural vandal, etc - came from the correspondent who suggested I should read James Agee, "a DECENT and HUMANE critic." Damn, how did he rumble that I like to spend my off-hours molesting children and strangling small, defenceless and preferably endangered animals of the sweet and cuddly variety? Because I do. Though I've never written a screenplay, which in this town makes me rarer than rocking-horse shit.

And so to De Palma. His new movie, Mission to Mars, stormed the box-offices of the nation in remarkably fine style last weekend, netting a stunning $22m, more than the next four movies combined, and despite largely lukewarm reviews all round.

I think this has more to do with the genre than the director. Mission fits in nicely with characterless, effects-heavy space operas like Armageddon, Deep Impact, Independence Day and Apollo 13. It's set in 2020 and follows the tribulations of the first earthlings to set foot on the red planet. The team is made up of good character actors like Tim Robbins, Gary Sinise, Don Cheadle, and Connie Nielsen, all of whom do a fine job of mouthing tech-heavy lines about "tertiary thrust-boosters" and the like.

One good thing about Mars is that it doesn't bear too many of De Palma's distinctive hallmarks, like brainless Hitchcock rip-offs and chesty babes leeringly photographed. Here he seems more interested in ripping off large sections of Kubrick's 2001: A Space Odyssey, especially in the space travel scenes and in the finale, which is all blinding-white chambers and a doorway that bears a suspicious resemblance to Kubrick's famous black monolith.

Well, at least he's nicking stuff from someone else for a change.

I think the reason I quite enjoyed Mission to Mars is that the abundance of special effects and process shots manages to downgrade the importance of the director. This was the thing that made Mission Impossible quite good fun as well: any director could have made the same movie.

With Snake Eyes however, he was back on the same dumb-ass terrain one remembers from Body Double (or Botty Double, as I think of it), Blood Sisters, or The Fury. The 20-minute opening shot (a cinematic dick-measuring contest with Touch of Evil, Rope and the Copa scene in Goodfellas) was technically impressive, but it was the same kind of vacuous virtuosity detectable in Whitney Houston's version of I Will Always Love You.

Mission to Mars on the other hand is the kind of movie that relies heavily on the second unit and especially on the army of effects specialists, reducing the nominal director to the role of traffic cop, a cog in the machine. A new De Palma film (well, I say "new"..) is always guaranteed to bring out the worst in me, and that in turn brings out the worst in the more rabid and demented De Palma fans, who can be a scary lot at the best of times. Last year I ended my review of his bonehead thriller Snake Eyes with the simple phrase "Burn the negative", which I'll admit was coming it a bit strong, perhaps. To my shame it's the sort of film-criticism I can imagine Josef Goebbels practising, though he'd probably really dig De Palma. Trouble is, if you meet his fans and say exactly what you think about the most corpulent of the erstwhile Movie Brats - that he's derivative, that he's a misogynist, that he's wasted his undeniable cinematic flair on rehashes, rip-offs and dross for 20 years - then their knuckles whiten around their pints, their pupils dilate and pretty soon they're screaming: "You just don't fucking get it, do you?" Soon afterwards they'll ambush me in the lavs, when I've got my hands far too full to defend myself, and administer a good Tony Montana-style kicking, or as Brian himself might phrase it, an homage to a good Tony Montana-style kicking. Not that the kind of people who write to newspapers are any less dangerous than people who wait in dark cubicles for their victims. Sometimes they get all obsessive and strange on you, as was the case with one reader of the LA Weekly, for which I write each week. This guy had made a case study of everything I'd reviewed - his first letter began, "I've been watching you..." - and went through the list film by film, concluding thus: "Of the 17 films you've reviewed negatively recently, I believe 14 were in fact really good." To which my reply would be the conventional critic's comeback: "Well, opinions are like assholes. Everyone's got one. Trouble is, no one wants to smell yours." That or "Never apologise. Never explain." Or, from the cheap shelf: "Ner-ner-na-ner-ner!" And I received 10 letters from this guy. At my house. When I gave David Lynch's The Straight Story a lambasting last year the complaints completely overwhelmed the letters page - something which of course filled me with intense pride. That movie's ad campaign was the kind that prints every 4-star review on the poster - and there were about 20 of them. Seems everyone liked it except me. However the letter-writers wanted absolute, down-the-line positive unanimity for Lynch, with no dissent permitted whatsoever. The needles on the "you-just-don't-fucking-get-it" metre were pushed deep, deep into the red overload zone. The choicest insult - apart from the usual chestnuts about me being a frustrated screenwriter/haggard masturbator/cultural vandal, etc - came from the correspondent who suggested I should read James Agee, "a DECENT and HUMANE critic." Damn, how did he rumble that I like to spend my off-hours molesting children and strangling small, defenceless and preferably endangered animals of the sweet and cuddly variety? Because I do. It's set in 2020 and follows the tribulations of the first earthlings to set foot on the red planet. The team is made up of good character actors like Tim Robbins, Gary Sinise, Don Cheadle, and Connie Nielsen, all of whom do a fine job of mouthing tech-heavy lines about "tertiary thrust-boosters" and the like. Here he seems more interested in ripping off large sections of Kubrick's 2001: A Space Odyssey, especially in the space travel scenes and in the finale, which is all blinding-white chambers and a doorway that bears a suspicious resemblance to Kubrick's famous black monolith. Mission to Mars on the other hand is the kind of movie that relies heavily on the second unit and especially on the army of effects specialists, reducing the nominal director to the role of traffic cop, a cog in the machine. fields.trailText: In a report in early editions, Page 6, March 1, we incorrectly attributed to Monsanto gene transfer experiments from Brazil nuts to soya beans. The company concerned was Pioneer. The work on Brazil nut gene transfer was abandoned because the experiment showed that a known allergen from Brazil nuts was transfered to soya. It was never established, as our article said it had been, that the offending allergen was also passed on to to chickens in soya feed.

webTitle: World Bank accused of nepotism and corruption

fields.headline: World Bank accused of nepotism and corruption
fields.standfirst: New chief economist is brother of the human resources vice-president
fields.trailText: The World Bank was embroiled in charges of nepotism and corruption yesterday after it emerged that the appointment of its new British chief economist, Nick Stern, broke strict rules banning the Washington-based institution from hiring more than one family member.
fields.body:
The World Bank was embroiled in charges of nepotism and corruption yesterday after it emerged that the appointment of its new British chief economist, Nick Stern, broke strict rules banning the Washington-based institution from hiring more than one family member.

Professor Stern, former chief economist at the London-based European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, is the brother of Richard Stern, the World Bank's human resources vice-president. His appointment directly violates a staffing rule that close family members are not eligible for employment.

The appointment has divided staff in the bank. In a strongly-worded internal memo, seen by the Guardian yesterday, the staff association complains that giving a senior bank job to Prof Stern "easily lends itself to a perception of nepotism and corruption in the bank" which hampers its efforts to eradicate graft in the third world.

"With deep regret, therefore, and without comment on the talents of Prof Stern, the staff association believes that the offer of the chief economist's job to Prof Stern must be retracted," the memo says.

Prof Stern, 53, is a distinguished development economist who teaches at the London School of Economics. His appointment to the World Bank, in succession to Joseph Stiglitz, was announced last week. Most observers thought he would enhance the bank's prestige and intellectual clout.

But following the staff rebellion, his appointment now appears to be in doubt. A spokeswoman for the bank said last night that the president, Jim Wolfensohn, was consulting staff to try and win them round. "Over the next 24 to 48 hours you will probably have a sense of what's happening," said the spokeswoman. "But my understanding is that Nick Stern has been given the job."

In response to the staff association's complaint, Mr Wolfensohn, a former Wall Street investment banker, fired off an email - also seen by the Guardian - defending Prof Stern's appointment which, he insists, was free of favouritism.

Mr Wolfensohn says that Prof Stern was appointed on the unanimous recommendation of independent selection committee comprising Mr Stiglitz, Amartya Sen, the Nobel prize-winning economist, and Jeffrey Goldstein, one of the bank's former managing directors, and that no one else at the bank had anything to do with the process.

"I knew of the existence of staff rule 4.01 and was advised by the general council that under article 5, section 5 of the bank's articles of agreement, I, as president, and subject to the general control of the executive directors, had the legal right to waive the application of any staff rule when it is in the best interests of the institution to do so," says Mr Wolfensohn.

"I concluded that on this occasion, and was supported by the board, that the circumstances were such that this is a case where I should exercise my discretion.

"I believed the integrity of the process and the quality of the individual would be sufficient to rule out the reality or perception of nepotism or corruption.

"I can assure you that I stand as strong as ever against them."

The staff association memo points out that, in the past, several staff members have had jobs denied to family members expressly because of the bank's internal rules and that others have been fired when it became known that they had broken it.

Accusing the bank of only applying the rules to "little people" and not "to those in positions of power", it says: "Dual standards of this kind simply cannot be part of the bank."

It goes on to commend Mr Wolfensohn for taking a strong stand against corruption but complains that the appointment of Prof Stern undermines the bank's credibility when dealing with developing countries.

"Nepotism is, of course, a part of corruption. Many of the staff who have communicated with the staff association on this issue believe the appointment of Mr Stern easily lends itself to a perception of nepotism and corruption in the bank . . . The staff association must express its deep disappointment that the bank group management and the board approved this appointment. The association believes it must disassociate itself from this appointment because it represents a flagrant disregard for very important and time-tested rules on the bank.

"It also believes that as this appointment stands it will badly tarnish the image of the bank, threaten the bank by exposing staff to pressure on appointments of relatives, and ultimately demean the ability of staff to speak in a credible way with clients about corruption and hamper our work on issues of governance."

webTitle: BP dumps 'too oily' shield after 70 years

fields.headline: BP dumps 'too oily' shield after 70 years
fields.standfirst: Federal trade commission in talks about blocked Arco takeover
fields.trailText: After 70 years of service, BP Amoco is ditching its traditional green shield logo as part of an international re-branding of the oil and gas concern.
fields.body:
After 70 years of service, BP Amoco is ditching its traditional green shield logo as part of an international re-branding of the oil and gas concern.

The move comes in the wake of this week's flurry of deals which BP continued yesterday with a fresh clutch of transactions designed to placate American regulators and smooth the path for a formal go-ahead of its £17bn take-over of rival American oil group Atlantic Richfield by early next month.

Announcing a $1.3bn deal to buy out minority shareholders in Vastar, one of the largest independent oil and gas producers in the US, where Arco al ready has 82%, and at the same time selling off one of Arco's key storage terminals for $355m, BP Amoco's chief executive, Sir John Browne, said the company was now at an advanced stage in "constructive" discussions with the US federal trade commission.

The FTC was blocking the Arco takeover which was first announced a year ago, and the whole matter looked set to end up in the courts before this week's deal to sell Arco's Alaskan assets to America's Phillips Petroleum for $7bn. Completing the Arco takeover will produce a company capitalised at around billion.

The Amoco brand will continue to be used on forecourts in the US, while the Castrol brand will become the primary name for BP's lubricants after this weeks' £3bn deal to acquire Burmah Castrol. BP executives say the shield logo is too "oily"; image consultants are working on a replacement suitable for the petrol fore courts of the future, where BP expects to be selling a range of products other than fuel.

BP is overhauling pay structures for directors which will see a large portion of rewards linked to the company's performance in relation to an index of 100 global companies.

BP's annual report, published today discloses that Sir John's package of salary and bonuses jumped from $1.5m to $2.35m last year, but on top of this he is also in line for an award of shares worth $4m later this year.

From here, a new long-term incentive plan now being introduced will deliver shares worth another $8m if fresh performance targets are met through until 2002.
