webTitle: RMC chief quits on high note

fields.headline: RMC chief quits on high note
fields.trailText: RMC Group, the world's largest ready-mixed concrete supplier, yesterday announced the decision by chief executive Peter Young to step down and a 15% jump in full-year profits to £304.5m.
fields.body:
RMC Group, the world's largest ready-mixed concrete supplier, yesterday announced the decision by chief executive Peter Young to step down and a 15% jump in full-year profits to £304.5m.

Mr Young will be succeeded by Stuart Walker, RMC's deputy chief executive, on June 30.

The 1999 profits, before exceptionals, were at the top end of analysts' forecasts. If exceptionals, such as the fine imposed by the German federal cartels office, are included then the figure is reduced to £277.3m.

The profits were achieved on an increase in turnover of 7% to £4.7bn. That total does not include any contribution from RMC's acquisition of the Rugby Group which was completed in January.

Mr Young said: "Our underlying performance in 1999 was very encouraging. Our US and rest of Europe segments achieved excellent result."

He said the acquisition of more than 30 companies had supported the result, and was reflected in RMC's £1.5bn investment programme in the year.

RMC's trading profits in its US business almost doubled to £80.1m, reflecting a buoyant American economy and construction market. The next strongest division for RMC was the rest of Europe division where trading profits grew 17% to £92.9m.

RMC's shares rose 92p to 852p.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: After the excitement provided by Lastminute.com's market entry at the beginning of the week, the less fashionable old economy stocks have been moving back into favour.
fields.body:
After the excitement provided by Lastminute.com's market entry at the beginning of the week, the less fashionable old economy stocks have been moving back into favour.

The FTSE closed 110.2 points higher at 6,557.2 - well off its peak of 6,618.2 and held back by the poor showing of technology, media and telecoms stocks: the Techmark index was down 288. The Techmark's slide has mirrored the falling value of the technology-laden Nasdaq.

Europe's biggest internet flotation, World Online, in Amsterdam today could give a clearer indication if this dip in the e-frenzy is going global.

Shares in Lastminute.com almost returned to their flotation price yesterday. Floated at 380p, and hitting a high of 555p on day one, they fell 25p yesterday to 387p. Other Small Cap internet issues remained out of favour, with Netbenefit off 375 at £14.25, Cube8.com down 4p at 19p, and gameplay.com down 160p at 582p.

Among technology issues, Sage Group shed 52p at 783p, CMG lost 442p to £49.58, and Sema Group fell 46p to £13.97p. Durlacher lost 420p to £23.05, Scoot.com fell 37p to 267p, NXT was down 215p at £19.60, and Kewill Systems lost 302p to £28.10.

Telecom and media issues also met with profit taking. Reuters , the top FTSE 100 faller, fell 148p to £12.50p, followed by Telewest , down 43p at 390p.

Symbolising the shift to more traditional stocks was Anglo-American 's 204p rise to £29.45 on the back of a deal expected in the next few weeks which will see Anglo take control of about 70% of Zambia's mining assets.

BP Amoco was also in the black, up 14p at 568p, after confirmation that it is to sell Arco's Alaskan assets to Phillips Petroleum for $7bn, a move which should clear the way for the UK group's stalled takeover of Arco.

Billiton was 45p higher at 298p, boosted by commodity price factors and news of the purchase of a 70% stake in Australia's Grove Aluminium from CSR.

Along with commodities, food and drink and financial stocks performed well. Allied Domecq rose 27p to 288p, while Diageo, also boosted by talk of buy notes from Salomon Smith Barney and CSFB, rose 36p to 440p and Cadbury Schweppes firmed 34p to 408p.

Lloyds TSB rose 69p to 621p, while Abbey National remained well bid, up 75p at 756p, with rumours continuing to circulate that it could be the subject of a bid from Barclays before the end of the week. Warburg was advising clients to buy the former building society, up to 800p.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: ING announces £1.2bn e-spend
fields.body:
ING announces £1.2bn e-spend

Dutch banking group ING yesterday joined the financial services dot.com bandwagon and pledged to spend more than €2bn (£1.23bn) on e-commerce over the next three years.

The group expects this to help double its customer base to 1.5m people but says that profits should still rise 10% in the present financial year despite such hefty spending.

Analysts warmed to the company after the announcement. The group said operating profits in 1999 rose 54% to €3.23bn.

NAPF unveils virtual voting

The National Association of Pension Funds and E-Vote have signed a deal to provide an electronic voting system to the country's institutional investors.

The service is part of a campaign to raise the level and quality of proxy voting by NAPF members, who make up Britain's largest group of institutional shareholders.

The scheme should be live within a couple of weeks, according to an E-Vote spokeswoman. It will allow NAPF members to register electronic proxy votes on companies in which they are shareholders.

fields.headline: Germans join paper chase
fields.standfirst: Safety conscious investors cast off their bonds
fields.trailText: Like all the best love affairs Germany's infatuation with share ownership has been sudden and passionate. This week it reached new heights with the flotation of Infineon, the semiconductor business. The sale broke a number of records - some of which the Frankfurt Börse would rather it hadn't.
fields.body:
Like all the best love affairs Germany's infatuation with share ownership has been sudden and passionate. This week it reached new heights with the flotation of Infineon, the semiconductor business. The sale broke a number of records - some of which the Frankfurt Börse would rather it hadn't.

Until Monday the largest number of trades its floor system had handled in a single day was 532,000 and the highest volume in one stock was 124,000. On Monday the floor system handled 694,000 trades, 239,000 of them in Infineon. Such was the volume of traffic that the system struggled. Though all the deals got done, processing was seriously slowed with many of the banks dealing for clients not receiving the end of day information until late into the night.

The rapturous reception of the Infineon offer - it was 32 times oversubscribed - reflects what has been happening elsewhere. Germany's Neuer Markt, designed to encourage the flotation of hi-tech companies, is a runaway success. Last month alone there were 20 initial public offerings on the Neuer Markt, ironic given that the shortage of hi-tech workers in Germany is forcing the government to consider importing computer programmers.

But why should a country where traditionally the only investment decision was whether to buy bonds or more bonds suddenly succumb to the lure of the stock market in general and to the volatile and potentially risky end of the business - new hi-tech stocks - in particular?

Max Dietrich Kley, finance director of the chemicals group BASF and president of the Deutsche Aktien Institut which promotes share ownership in Germany, reckons several factors are at work.

"One important point is that industry, banks and insurance companies have worked hard to improve the share culture in Germany. There was incredibly low investment in shares as a proportion of GNP. Compared with the US and UK it was ridiculously low."

While one reason was the German investor preference for bonds, Mr Kley believes that the structure and generosity of social security provision was an issue, too.

The younger generation is taking a different approach, however, sceptical about whether the government will be able to maintain the current level of benefits until they retire. "They have seen that in the long term investing in shares makes better returns than anything," according to Mr Kley.

For the internet generation hi-tech stocks provide an additional interest, too. Privatisation has helped, opening up the likes of Deutsche Telekom to investors. DT is planning the flotation of its internet business and its mobile phone operation.

Shift to mutuals

The growth in shareholding has been spectacular. For much of the 1990s just over 6% of Germans held shares directly, reaching a trough in 1996 when the number fell to 3.75m - exactly 6%. Since then it has climbed to just over 5m at the end of last year and the increase is running at about 500,000 a year. The growth of indirect share holding through mutual funds has been even more dramatic, according to DAI. In 1997 some 2.3m people held shares indirectly. Two years later the total has more than doubled to 4.74m.

The growth in indirect share ownership in particular has pleased some observers. "It is a good sign. People who don't have enough money to build up a diversified portfolio directly are going into the [mutual] funds. The percentage of shareholders is rising across the income classes, that is a good sign for society," said one analyst this week.

The shift in sentiment towards equities comes at a time when corporate Germany is opening up even further to investors. The German government is proposing changes to the tax system which will encourage the dismantling of the network of cross-shareholdings which has tended to stifle takeover activity.

German companies incur a capital gains tax of 50% when they sell shares in other German companies. Because many of the stakes were built up years ago the capital gain - and with it the tax liability - is usually substantial.

Banks and insurers will want to sell if the tax regime is lightened or removed. They want the money to invest in their own businesses, while the introduction of the single currency allows insurers much wider geographical scope for investment.

As the log-jam for takeover bids represented by the cross-shareholdings is dismantled investors can expect more of the activity shown so spectacularly by the Vodafone AirTouch bid for Mannesmann - a red rag to a whole market of bulls.

Too much optimism, however, can be worrying. The DAI has already urged investors to adopt a more cautious approach: that Neuer Markt prices are not sustainable and investors should make sure they have a balanced portfolio. So far the love affair has enjoyed only good times. It remains to be seen whether the passion can survive in bad times, too.

As Mr Kley puts it: "We don't want any kind of crash; a correction is OK but not a real crash. But there is so much liquidity about that I am optimistic there won't be a crash."

A growing number of Germans now experiencing a first taste of equity investment will say Amen to that.

fields.headline: Premier Farnell
fields.trailText: Premier Farnell is better known for its doorstopper-size catalogues than its foray into the business-to-business trade on the world wide web.
fields.body:
Premier Farnell is better known for its doorstopper-size catalogues than its foray into the business-to-business trade on the world wide web.

Yet the electronic components distributor's plan to sell parts for anything from cars to computers across the web is what has excited analysts.

The company's annual pre-tax earnings yesterday showed an 8% decline to £92m but that did not stir much interest. The painful and costly merger of Premier and Farnell is considered history now and investors believe it is turning the corner.

The focus was on the leap in annualised online sales from $8m to $35m. More than half of those were to new customers. Talk is of e-commerce sales hitting $80m in a few years.

Ed Wright, analyst at Dresdner Kleinwort Benson, said it was worth "getting excited" about Premier Farnell's investment in e-commerce given its market-leading position and willingness to invest.

But operating profit in its US catalogue distribution division fell 15% to £44.4m in the year and there was an 18% drop to £30.7m in European and rest of world business. The company held earnings steady in the appliance spares and industrial products divisions.

Premier Farnell still has its work cut out improving profits. A pick-up in demand by manufacturers globally for electronic components is expected to put a plank under future earnings.

The group reported a 5% jump in sales to £752m in the year but evidence of the improving electronic components market place came in the fourth quarter when sales surged by 11%.

"They seem to have hit the bottom," Mr Wright said. "They are doing slightly better than expected because the market has begun to pick up."

Then there is a three-year plan to spend £45m to enhance sales, marketing and boost profits. It is needed, given Premier Farnell's earnings have been in decline since 1997 when it reported pre-tax result of £173m.

The final dividend is unchanged at 5p.

webTitle: P&O profits fail to calm cruise fears

fields.headline: P&O profits fail to calm cruise fears
fields.standfirst: P&O Ferries
fields.trailText: Riding the peaks and troughs is nothing new to the first Lord of Britain's financial admiralty, P&O chief Lord Sterling. Yesterday the rollers continued as the market first applauded better than expected results then remembered worries about pricing pressures in the cruise market and rising fuel costs.
fields.body:
Riding the peaks and troughs is nothing new to the first Lord of Britain's financial admiralty, P&O chief Lord Sterling. Yesterday the rollers continued as the market first applauded better than expected results then remembered worries about pricing pressures in the cruise market and rising fuel costs.

P&O shares had been at 959.5p last month when Sterling bowed to the inevitable and agreed to hive off the fabulously successful cruise business leaving the ports, ferries and logistics operations. Yesterday they closed at 613

The new P&O Princess cruise operation will be the second or third largest business of its kind in the world, and if investors don't buy into Lord Sterling's story of huge international growth potential, there is always the takeover potential - and the global number one, Carnival, is known to have made predatory overtures.

P&O said it hoped to complete the spinoff by October and may offer extra shares in New York to whet the appetites of American investors. That news accom- panied the assertion that P&O still intends to float its half-owned container shipping business and will sell its bulk shipping operations.

Additionally the group beat profit forecasts with a £525.4m surplus against £368.9m a year earlier.

Yet the company's shares ended 30.5p lower at 613p in a rising market. Lord Sterling argued vehemently that talk of tumbling cruise prices coming out of the US market was overdone. P & O is not the only cruise shipping company to be planning big fleet expansions (it is increasing capacity by 23%) and analysts are worried that the growth in the number of berths will outstrip demand.

He did admit that the number of early bookings for the final quarter of the year was adrift of the corresponding period in 1999 but then - unlike most other sectors of the leisure business - cruise shipping managed to cash in on the millennium.

He also acknowledged that the group is not hedged against its rising fuel costs and concerns about this have weakened the shares. Indeed Credit Suisse First Boston cut its profit forecast by £20m to £480m though it continued to rate the stock a "buy".

fields.headline: Research chief quits Biotech
fields.trailText: The tribulations at British Biotech continued yesterday when another boardroom clash saw the departure of the group's research director.
fields.body:
The tribulations at British Biotech continued yesterday when another boardroom clash saw the departure of the group's research director.

The company, which two years ago was beset by accusations of drug test rigging, said Alan Drummond was leaving after 12 years because he did not agree with a restructuring of the research operations.

His departure follows a disappointing outcome for some trials on its Marimastat cancer drug which is included in a joint venture deal to finance and develop treatments signed last autumn with Schering-Plough, the blue chip pharmaceuticals group.

A statement from British Biotech denied that Mr Drummond, who had been research director for the last three years, had been sacked or that he was violently at odds with his former colleagues.

"We've change the way in which we are organised to integrate our major products," said Tony Weir, the company's finance director.

"We believe it will make us more effective, more focused on bringing drugs to market. We've not fallen out with him ... Alan believes it will be better to integrate on functional lines than product lines."

Mr Drummond's role will be assumed by Giles Campion, the development director and chief medical officer.

So accustomed has the market become to upheaval at British Biotech that the news left the shares unchanged over the day at 31p. But that is still barely a tenth of their peak of 326p in May 1996, at the height of the last bout of biotech investor frenzy which pushed it to within a whisker of joining the FTSE 100 index.

Shares in British Biotech collapsed after its former head of clinical trials, Andrew Millar, made public his concerns over the efficacy of Marimastat and regulators in the US and UK began to investigate the firm for misleading investors.

webTitle: French lead in Air Liberté bid

fields.headline: French lead in Air Liberté bid
fields.standfirst: Air France reported to be offering £70m
fields.trailText: France's flag carrier yesterday emerged as the frontrunner to take over British Airways' loss-making regional airline Air Liberté.
fields.body:
France's flag carrier yesterday emerged as the frontrunner to take over British Airways' loss-making regional airline Air Liberté.

Air France confirmed it was in talks with BA, saying directors had met to "examine the possibility" of taking over its smaller rival. Sources within the airline said the acquisition of Air Liberté would enable it to expand and diversify its services in France and its overseas territories.

The move would be a triumph for Air France which is caught in a three-way dogfight with the Swiss-based regional carrier, AOM, and Air Liberté for the skies over France.

Air France was reported to have offered BA nearly £70m to acquire the ailing airline. Insiders say Air France's offer was £30m more than AOM put on the table.

Analysts pointed out that deal would see the former state monopoly strengthen its position at Orly airport, occupying 65% of take off and landing slots at Paris's second airport.

At present Air Liberté, which employs some 2,500 people, faces tough competition from Air France and AOM, which is 49.5% owned by SAirGroup, the Switzerland-based aviation grouping that includes Swissair, Crossair, Sabena, LOT in Poland, Tap Air Portugal and a 20% stake in South African Airways.

Earlier this month, SAirGroup retracted a statement which said it was holding talks with BA about buying a stake in Air Liberté.

BA too stands to gain as Air Liberté has proved an expensive drain on resources at the "world's favourite airline".

Union representatives at Air Liberté were expecting a round of economy measures, including the replacement of the airline's 11 Fokker 100 regional jets and four older F28s, and the closure of its route from Paris Orly to Nantes, which suffers competition from high-speed train services.

BA's French division has been embarrassed by the success of the company's German airline, BA Deutsche, which is close to breaking even.

According to the French financial daily newspaper Les Echos, Air Liberté lost Fr680m (£64m) in 1997-98 and Fr250m in 1998-99. In the year which ends this month, it is expected to lose a further Fr300m, after being hurt by the strength of the dollar and the rise in aviation fuel prices.

Meanwhile, British airports operator BAA said that it had sold down its holdings in airport hotels for a £40m windfall.

But the group, which owned eight British hotels outright, made clear the move was not a retreat from hotel investment.

BAA has sold the eight hotels into a partnership, or fund, for £187m, leaving it with a 10.1% beneficial interest. The remaining interest is held by four partners: Scottish Widows, the Coal Schemes, Shell Pension Fund and an unnamed overseas investor.

BAA said the partnership, to be managed by BAA for a fee, would pursue further investment opportunities in airport hotels.

fields.headline: Morrisons stocks up on stores
fields.trailText: Northern-based supermarket group WM Morrison is to create 5,000 new jobs in the next two years with plans to add 20 new superstores. It is looking out for more sites which could eventually take the chain from 101 outlets to more than 150.
fields.body:
Northern-based supermarket group WM Morrison is to create 5,000 new jobs in the next two years with plans to add 20 new superstores. It is looking out for more sites which could eventually take the chain from 101 outlets to more than 150.

"There is bags of room for expansion", said chairman Sir Ken Morrison. He has yet to take the firm - which remains 38% owned by his family - inside the M25 but says opportunities there are strictly limited. "It is not easy. It is already well sewn up by our rivals and sites are expensive."

Morrisons, which was reporting an 11.1% increase in profits to £189.2m and current like-for-like sales up 9.9% on 1999 levels. Sir Ken said that achievement was down to keen pricing and no gimmicks. The store chain was named the cheapest in a recent survey conducted by the retail consultancy Verdict.

"The so-called price wars make good reading" said the chairman. "But they do not always add up to everyday savings for shoppers.

"We watch with interest as prices for a select few products tumble to somewhere near those we have been charging all along."

The improved profits will benefit 22,000 Morrison's workers, from board level to part-time store staff. They will share a bonus payout of £9.9m - up 10% on a year ago.

Morrisons is among the handful of supermarket chains still under investigation by the competition commission.

The company was interviewed by the commission earlier this week and yesterday Sir Ken, 74, said: "We have nothing to hide. We were unfortunate to be drawn into this."

He said he did not expect the commission to suggest local monopolies be forcibly broken up, but that there could be a code of conduct to guide supermarkets in their dealings with small suppliers.

Such a move was necessary "to moderate the excesses of some of the younger people in this business".

Sir Ken added that he still had no intention to follow his larger rivals into internet shopping and home delivery.

"I don't think it is awfully relevant," he added. "People like to smell and see their food before they buy it. And we don't have any plans for home delivery. I started my career doing that and I don't intend to do it again."

It is looking out for more sites which could eventually take the chain from 101 outlets to more than 150. "There is bags of room for expansion", said chairman Sir Ken Morrison. He has yet to take the firm - which remains 38% owned by his family - inside the M25 but says opportunities there are strictly limited. "It is not easy. It is already well sewn up by our rivals and sites are expensive." Morrisons, which was reporting an 11.1% increase in profits to £189.2m and current like-for-like sales up 9.9% on 1999 levels. Sir Ken said that achievement was down to keen pricing and no gimmicks. The store chain was named the cheapest in a recent survey conducted by the retail consultancy Verdict. "The so-called price wars make good reading" said the chairman. "But they do not always add up to everyday savings for shoppers. "We watch with interest as prices for a select few products tumble to somewhere near those we have been charging all along." The improved profits will benefit 22,000 Morrison's workers, from board level to part-time store staff. They will share a bonus payout of £9.9m - up 10% on a year ago. Morrisons is among the handful of supermarket chains still under investigation by the competition commission. The company was interviewed by the commission earlier this week and yesterday Sir Ken, 74, said: "We have nothing to hide. We were unfortunate to be drawn into this." He said he did not expect the commission to suggest local monopolies be forcibly broken up, but that there could be a code of conduct to guide supermarkets in their dealings with small suppliers. Such a move was necessary "to moderate the excesses of some of the younger people in this business". Sir Ken added that he still had no intention to follow his larger rivals into internet shopping and home delivery. "I don't think it is awfully relevant," he added. "People like to smell and see their food before they buy it. And we don't have any plans for home delivery. I started my career doing that and I don't intend to do it again."

webTitle: Dow rallies 500 points in largest ever one-day gain

fields.headline: Dow rallies 500 points in largest ever one-day gain
fields.trailText: A fresh buying spree gripped investors on Wall Street yesterday, producing the biggest one-day points gain on the Dow Jones index ever witnessed.
fields.body:
A fresh buying spree gripped investors on Wall Street yesterday, producing the biggest one-day points gain on the Dow Jones index ever witnessed.

At the same time, a fresh wave of money poured into technology stocks sending the Nasdaq composite index soaring and illustrating once again that US investors at least do not see any threat to the so-called new economy from rising oil prices and a likely increase in interest rates.

At the close in New York yesterday, the Dow Jones was 499.19 points higher at 10,630.6, building dramatically on the 320-point gain seen on Wednesday producing a gain of almost 8.5% in the space of 48 hours.

While the advance on the Dow earlier this week saw a corresponding slump on Nasdaq as investors switched funds out of internet-related stocks and into "old economy" blue chips, the technology-rich Nasdaq composite jumped nearly 3% to 4,717.29 points yesterday - bringing to an end three days of losses which have seen almost 10% wiped off this index.

Before the latest rebound, the Dow had fallen almost 15% since the beginning of the year despite the fact that it now includes both software giants Microsoft and chip maker Intel. Nasdaq, meanwhile, was up almost 25% before the "rotation" back from new to old economy investments began.

Wall Street analysts noted that American retail investors, as a breed, have become pro grammed over the past four years of the bull market to "buy on the dips" - rushing into the market whenever prices go through a correction.

There were widespread predictions yesterday that the narrowing of the performance gap between the Dow and Nasdaq indices would soon resume, given the appalling performance over the past year by such stalwart US companies as Wal-Mart, Home Depot and Coca-Cola.

But despite the corrective trend, the extraordinary volatility of the markets is bound to set off fresh alarm bells within the US Federal Reserve as the central bank's chairman, Alan Greenspan, prepares to raise borrowing costs once again in an attempt to cool the roaring economy.

The authorities have made no secret of the way in which they fear that a casino mentality has developed in the US equity markets - a perception which will not have been altered by the vigour with which the country's army of online stock market speculators are now rushing into the Dow's constituents.

The divergence between old and new economy stocks in the US has been labelled the "split market".

This has been mirrored in the British market where companies such as mobile chips designer ARM Holdings and palm top computer maker Psion have leapfrogged long established companies, such as cigarette maker Imperial Tobacco and drinks group Allied Domecq, into the main FTSE 100 index.

fields.headline: Five books about City Girls
fields.standfirst: Take a girl, a career, an odd boss or two, a flat in London, a commitment issue, a boyfriend, a break-up, one, two, or even three good friends, a cunning plan, a few parties, bad hangovers and a happy ever after. It's all in City Girls, the publishers' new friend.
fields.trailText: Take a girl, a career, an odd boss or two, a flat in London, a commitment issue, a boyfriend, a break-up, one, two, or even three good friends, a cunning plan, a few parties, bad hangovers and a happy ever after. It's all in City Girls, the publishers' new friend.
fields.body:
Jenny Colgan turned it into an official genre with Amanda's Wedding (HarperCollins, £5.99), by earning a record £1m for her first-ever novel. The formula is foolproof really, as long as you pay homage to your Bridget Jones crossed with Jilly Cooper ancestors. Colgan's heroine is not sure what her employers do: her time is much more valuably filled with falling in love, getting pissed with her mates and scheming to save a friend from his horrible fiancee. Hoorah for red wine and mates, and boo to posh restaurants and blondes.

Buy it at BOL

It's a genre that lends itself well to imitation. The Temp, by Serena Mackesy (Arrow, £5.99) scarcely wavers from the ground mapped out by pioneer Colgan, except that the love story is a little more in the background, and the career a little more in the foreground. After the break-up (started on page 20) and the recommended amount of sleepless nights , we get the friends and the scheme in quick succession, before falling in love and sudden promotion happen almost simultaneously (perhaps this is the replacement for the prerequisite simultaneous orgasm of the 1980s).

Buy it at BOL

Surprise is the main element missing in all these books. Freya North has turned herself into the queen of City Girl romances: her books are all called Chloe, Sally or (this one) Cat (Random House, £10). Cat works for the Guardian Sports desk, so she must be fantastically intelligent, dither about boyfriends, and display no noticeable sense of humour about her life, men, or visible panty lines. Go on, surprise us Freya. Kill them all off in a burst of machine-gun fire on page 366. Oh well. Don't then. Cat ends up successful, with a bloke.

Buy it at BOL

Sadly, humour is all too often the other element our young City-Girl writers have decided to skip. Jane Green makes the commitment issue the centrepiece of Mr Maybe (Penguin, £6.99), and gives her heroine a job in PR. It takes Libby 400 pages to realise money is not as important as love (who needs 40 days fasting in the desert when you've got Jane Green), and she manages to do so without chipping her nail polish once. Admirable.

Buy it at BOL

If only they were all like Marian Keyes' Last Chance Saloon (Penguin, £4.99), whose characters don't care about nail polish or promotion (although Tara is obsessed with finding a truly indelible lipstick) and are more bothered with good conversation, their mates and chucking crap lovers. Office romances, London flats and hangovers are all we need, along with a few good snogs and a football game. City-Girl readers aren't looking for answers to the eternal questions, just a few suggestions on how to pull, and a quick laugh. Deliver it, please.

Buy it at BOL

webTitle: To Cut a Long Story Short by Jeffrey Archer

fields.headline: To Cut a Long Story Short by Jeffrey Archer
fields.standfirst:
(HarperCollins, £16.99) The fallen Archer's latest collection of short stories, described in his own unique style
Buy it at BOL
fields.trailText: Deluded self-publicist unwittingly pioneers new literary genre by writing his autobiography as a collection of fictional short stories.
fields.body:
The master storyteller slid his Mont Blanc fountain pen into the inside pocket of his Savile Row suit and sighed. "Where did it all go wrong?" he said to himself, as he got up from his hand-tooled leather armchair and paced over to the panoramic windows of his penthouse which commanded the finest views in the whole of London.

As he stretched lazily, his gold cuff-links, engraved with the famous Grantchester crest which had been bestowed on his family in recognition of years of tireless public service, glinted in the late-afternoon sunlight and drew his attention to the the giant Millennium Wheel that dominated the London skyline. "Damn it," he muttered. "I once had a vision for this city, too."

But Jeffrey was not a man to dwell on the negative: after all, he still had a contract to write a book of short stories. "I'll show them all what they're missing," he mouthed grimly. His mind drifted back to happier days, and a kernel of an idea emerged. "I had a wonderful time at Oxford University," he mused, "but just imagine if I hadn't been there at all? A court case that collapsed because the expert witness's qualifications didn't stand up to scrutiny would be a neat twist." That was the first story taken care of.

The master storyteller was on a roll. All he needed was a series of dramatic life events that had never happened to him and he had his latest collection in the bag. Within hours he had knocked out a second tale about a very rich man who only pretended to have lost all his money. How he chortled at that one.

Succulent aromas wafting in from the kitchen disturbed his creativity and reminded Jeffrey of the fragrant Mary, the bedrock of his life. How could any man do anything to hurt such a woman? But just suppose there was such a man - a man who liked his mistress to dress as a whore while they had sex in an NCP car park in Mayfair. Story three was in the bag.

Within a week the book was finished. There was the story of the publishing scam based on the price of an advert in a brochure for a Conservative party fundraiser; there was the smug, untalented artist who lived off the generosity of his hard-working family; there was the legal financial con; there was the man who ruined his career on a sexual impulse; there was the man who fell for a get-rich- quick scheme; and finally, there was the high-powered businessman who was about to be forced to resign from his job and secretly hankered after the simplicity of a tramp.

"Hmm," said Jeffrey, admiring the neatness of his joined-up writing on the final manuscript. Making up stories really isn't very difficult at all.

And if you really are pressed, The digested read, digested:
Deluded self-publicist unwittingly pioneers new literary genre by writing his autobiography as a collection of fictional short stories.

fields.headline: Cider House Rules
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Jam-packed with incoherent moral positions, bulging with pseudo-issues, and all rendered entirely inarticulate by its own choked-up tearfulness.. gurning, emoting, self-regarding gibberish
fields.body:
The Cider House Rules is a very odd, glutinous sentimental drama, like an episode of The Waltons about incest, race and abortion.

It is directed by Lasse Hallström, with a screenplay by John Irving, taken from his own bestseller, and has picked up a raft of Oscar nominations, including one for the excellent, much-patronised and underrated Michael Caine.

But, revisiting it now, five months after its UK premiere at the London Film Festival, it just seems odder than ever, jam-packed with incoherent moral positions, bulging with pseudo-issues, and all rendered entirely inarticulate by its own choked-up tearfulness. A good two hours consisting, almost literally, of nonsense - gurning, emoting, self-regarding gibberish.

Set during the second world war, the film tells of boyish Homer Wells (Tobey Maguire), who has been brought up in a Maine orphanage by kindly but stern Dr Larch (Michael Caine), who presides over a set-up which is also a lying-in hospital and abortion venue. Yearning to get out into the wide world, Homer gets a job on a farm picking apples and pressing them for cider. Here he falls in love with Candy (Charlize Theron) while her boyfriend Wally (Paul Rudd) is away at war.

Maguire is cute, as is Ms Theron, who, at one stage, is shown reclining languorously unclothed so as to make clear that, to paraphrase Julia Roberts in Notting Hill, she does her own ass-work. Michael Caine has presence and style, but his American accent sounds like he's doing an impression of Loyd Grossman's Canadian mother-in-law.

This movie combines brazenly manipulative sentimentality - picturesque sick kiddies at the orphanage - with the bizarre deployment of difficult, adult issues. For example: it tackles race. Or does it? Picking apples in Maine is clearly intended to have softer connotations than, say, picking cotton in Virginia. When Homer goes to stay at the apple-picking farm, he is the only white worker among the blacks, thus "making history" as the head worker Mr Rose (Delroy Lindo) coyly observes, though Homer has a special relationship with the white folks in the big house that his co-workers do not enjoy. They're all billeted in a dormitory called the Cider House: Homer and the blacks sweetly sleep in rows of beds just like the orphanage kids. Is the infantilising effect of that deliberate? Difficult to tell.

Anyway, the workers are furious about the patronising rules posted up for their behaviour by the white boss and burn them (although the one about not using cider press machinery while drunk sounded pretty reasonable to me). But that's as far as the racial analysis of capital and labour goes. Otherwise, the workers are utterly deferential to their employers and their employers' friends, with Mr Rose's daughter exchanging sisterly hugs with Candy and accepting from her charitable gifts of clothing.

The movie tackles incest. Or does it? Homer frowningly discovers a terrible case of this, but, in the end, the perpetrator's contrite attitude allows the film smoothly to confer on him a tragic, almost noble status.

The movie tackles abortion. Or does it? Homer starts the film sternly pro-life and bitterly opposes the abortions Dr Larch carries out. In the end, some tough experiences in the real world turn his opinions around, but this conversion is glib and shallow, with nothing at stake emotionally or dramatically.

In the end, all these dark themes are disposed of in favour of a weird, feelgood atmosphere. Maybe Hallström and Irving were striving for eccentric humanist optimism. But the effect is evasive, unwholesome and deeply creepy.

fields.headline: Magnolia
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: a sprawling, howling miasma of strangeness, and some may find incontinence and indiscipline in its sheer length... But there is a compelling darkness in Anderson's film, a Mood Indigo of desperation
fields.body:
With Magnolia, Paul Thomas Anderson establishes himself as one of the most exciting and distinctive directors around.

His new film contains the convulsive emotional hurt and sweeping visual style that characterised Hard Eight and Boogie Nights, and is an anthology of broken lives - each interleaving with the other in a lattice of ill omen and disquiet. It is an ensemble picture like Tarantino's Pulp Fiction or Altman's Short Cuts but, with the device of a deadpan prologue about the nature of coincidence, makes manifest the curious nature of its own very individual world. It is an excursion into the universe of Ripley's Believe-It-Or-Not urban myth that prepares us - just about - for the uproarious biblical finale with which Anderson spectacularly discharges the unbearable tension and anxiety which has built up over the preceding three hours.

Among the characters are Earl Partridge (Jason Robards), a wealthy television producer, very ill and breathing his last: grouchy, unpleasant, in a lot of pain and profoundly unreconciled to his impending death. He is attended by Phil, a male nurse played by Philip Seymour Hoffman - an actor whose name on the billboard always demands attention. As it happens, this is a reserved and almost reticent performance by Hoffman, who is the only character not eaten up with angst and self-doubt.

Earl is also attended by his young wife, Linda, played with raw anger and self-loathing by Julianne Moore. Linda is experiencing a horrifying emotional about-face in her relations with Earl: she married him, lovelessly, for money but now realises she has actually fallen in love with him. She has been surprised, not by joy, but by the most terrible anguish.

Earl produced a long-running TV general knowledge quiz show of stupendous awfulness called What Do Kids Know?, which pits a team of grown-ups against kid prodigies and is an inspired metaphor for the inter-generational incomprehension and rancour that pervades the film. The quizmaster himself is Jimmy Gator, played by the incomparable Philip Baker Hall, whose face has solidified like lumps and rivulets of molten lava into the weary face he now presents to the world: wrecked and ruined and haggard (there is actually a clever sequence showing the show's gestation, and showing Gator getting older), and grotesquely inappropriate to the icky, perky little catchphrases the show has accumulated over the years.

Perhaps the outstanding performance is Tom Cruise as Earl's estranged son, the deliciously slimy Frank Mackey, a "motivational speaker" who runs a series of sex-advice seminars which are simply Nuremberg rallies for single guys. Entitled Seduce and Destroy, his sales pitch is a misogynist demagoguery, with individual lessons on "How to Turn That 'Friend' Into a Sperm Receptacle" and his message is that women must be subjected and humiliated before they do it to you, and that all sexual relations must be put on a permanent war footing.

With the slogan "Respect the Cock and Tame the Cunt", Cruise is a mixture of Hugh Hefner, Billy Graham and Adolf Hitler, and this strutting, ranting creation is something to put alongside the brutish Chad in Neil LaBute's In the Company of Men or Matthew Broderick's nice teacher Mr McAllister in Alexander Payne's Election. Once again, it shows that in American cinema and culture, sexual relations have, in a sense, become the new cold war. (Frank is evidently a magnification of real life sex hucksters, but it cannot be long before someone starts Seduce and Destroy for real. I suggest Paul Thomas Anderson copyrights and suppresses the whole horribly catchy idea the way anti-racist groups have bagged "hate.com".)

The poetic keynote to the film comes from Earl's grizzled death-bed lament about "the goddam regret". Don't be afraid to regret, he says, "use that regret any way you want." Magnolia is a dark and bitter poetry of regret, enunciated in a theatre of regret, in the grammar of regret, and clothed in the style and rhetoric of regret. It is a great wail of regret, with the terrible admission that real lives can be played out in a drama of anguish and waste, and that looking this full in the face at the end requires existential courage of the sort few of us have.

Magnolia is a sprawling, howling miasma of strangeness, and some may find incontinence and indiscipline in its sheer length and Anderson's love of bringing the soundtrack up to ear-bashing levels over the dialogue - particularly in the opening 10 to 15 minutes. But there is a compelling darkness in Anderson's film, a Mood Indigo of desperation.

The quizmaster himself is Jimmy Gator, played by the incomparable Philip Baker Hall, whose face has solidified like lumps and rivulets of molten lava into the weary face he now presents to the world: wrecked and ruined and haggard (there is actually a clever sequence showing the show's gestation, and showing Gator getting older), and grotesquely inappropriate to the icky, perky little catchphrases the show has accumulated over the years. Perhaps the outstanding performance is Tom Cruise as Earl's estranged son, the deliciously slimy Frank Mackey, a "motivational speaker" who runs a series of sex-advice seminars which are simply Nuremberg rallies for single guys. Entitled Seduce and Destroy, his sales pitch is a misogynist demagoguery, with individual lessons on "How to Turn That 'Friend' Into a Sperm Receptacle" and his message is that women must be subjected and humiliated before they do it to you, and that all sexual relations must be put on a permanent war footing. With the slogan "Respect the Cock and Tame the Cunt", Cruise is a mixture of Hugh Hefner, Billy Graham and Adolf Hitler, and this strutting, ranting creation is something to put alongside the brutish Chad in Neil LaBute's In the Company of Men or Matthew Broderick's nice teacher Mr McAllister in Alexander Payne's Election. Once again, it shows that in American cinema and culture, sexual relations have, in a sense, become the new cold war. (Frank is evidently a magnification of real life sex hucksters, but it cannot be long before someone starts Seduce and Destroy for real. I suggest Paul Thomas Anderson copyrights and suppresses the whole horribly catchy idea the way anti-racist groups have bagged "hate.com".) The poetic keynote to the film comes from Earl's grizzled death-bed lament about "the goddam regret". Don't be afraid to regret, he says, "use that regret any way you want." Magnolia is a dark and bitter poetry of regret, enunciated in a theatre of regret, in the grammar of regret, and clothed in the style and rhetoric of regret. It is a great wail of regret, with the terrible admission that real lives can be played out in a drama of anguish and waste, and that looking this full in the face at the end requires existential courage of the sort few of us have. Magnolia is a sprawling, howling miasma of strangeness, and some may find incontinence and indiscipline in its sheer length and Anderson's love of bringing the soundtrack up to ear-bashing levels over the dialogue - particularly in the opening 10 to 15 minutes. But there is a compelling darkness in Anderson's film, a Mood Indigo of desperation.

fields.headline: Rien Sur Robert
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Without ever being especially moving or involving, this elegant urban chamber comedy moves along at a brisk, exhilarating clip
fields.body:
Sited in the highly-strung, disputatious world of Parisian literary life, Pascal Bonitzer's Rien Sur Robert follows Didier (Fabrice Luchini), a jobbing intellectual academic in early middle age, who is obsessively jealous of a younger, more successful writer. Moreover, his girlfriend, Juliette (Sandrine Kilberlain), has left him for a silly, vulgar TV producer who is making a fantastically dull documentary about Iceland - and then he falls for the fascinating and troubled Aurélie.

Without ever being especially moving or involving, this elegant urban chamber comedy moves along at a brisk, exhilarating clip.

fields.headline: Ordinary Decent Criminal
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: With its fatuous sentimentalisation of violent criminals, and its saucer-eyed belief in the suave, comic sexiness of gangsters with guns, this boring and unfunny movie is never believable for a micro-second
fields.body:
Ordinary Decent Criminal is a very ordinary film - a gangland caper about Michael Lynch (Kevin Spacey), loosely based on the real Dublin gangster Martin Cahill, whose story was brought to the screen in 1998 by John Boorman as The General. Lynch is supposed to be lovable because he is nothing to do with the IRA.

With its fatuous sentimentalisation of violent criminals, and its saucer-eyed belief in the suave, comic sexiness of gangsters with guns, this boring and unfunny movie is never believable for a micro-second. (In real life, hard men with shooters kill and maim innocent people and their business is usually drugs; in the Mickey Mouse world of this film, Kevin Spacey and his ersatz-Irish homies wave their guns around without ever hurting civilians, and he steals a Caravaggio painting. Sweet.)

This film wastes the talents of a first-rate cast, including Linda Fiorentino, Helen Baxendale and Stephen Dillane.

webTitle: Being John Malkovich review – bonkers but brilliant

fields.headline: Being John Malkovich review – bonkers but brilliant
fields.standfirst: It may be the year’s weirdest plot - man finds door into John Malkovich’s head - but the result is an outrageous comedy of the purest gold, a sustained nirvana of giggling
fields.trailText: It may be the year’s weirdest plot - man finds door into John Malkovich’s head - but the result is an outrageous comedy of the purest gold, a sustained nirvana of giggling
fields.body:
There are some films with a premise so simple and so unanswerably brilliant they make all aspiring screenwriters slap their foreheads with envy and self-loathing. Six years ago it was: "Of course... a moving bus... with a bomb that explodes if it goes under a certain speed! Why didn't I think of that?"

Now it can only be a case of: "Of course... a failing puppeteer who works on the 7½th floor of a Manhattan office-building and accidentally discovers a tiny door that leads directly into John Malkovich's head! Why didn't I think of that? It's been staring me in the face!"

Being John Malkovich is the outrageously funny new movie from director Spike Jonze, with a screenplay by Charlie Kaufman, whose every scene, every line, every narrative refinement, every exquisitely hand-tooled joke and sight-gag is of the purest gold. Jonze and Kaufman take us on a cheeky raid behind the enemy lines of thinkability in the cinema, into the realm of the six impossible things the Red Queen believed before breakfast.

John Cusack plays Craig Schwartz, a sweaty, unshaven puppeteer, miserably resentful that no one appreciates his street theatre art, and forced to ply his trade in New York's uncaring thoroughfares. Finally compelled to find a day job, he becomes a lowly filing clerk on a bizarre, secret quasi-mezzanine floor of a skyscraper, a place where the ceilings are four feet high and everyone goes about their business bent double. Here Craig meets and falls abjectly in lust with the mysterious Maxine, instantly forgetting about his homely wife, Lotte, a pet shop attendant who brings home sick parrots and conflicted chimps.

It is one of this film's sly reversals and pre-emptive strikes that it is Cameron Diaz who is cast as the dowdy wife - with "no-make-up" make-up and unflattering perm - while Catherine Keener is the other woman, her innate sexiness effortlessly surviving having to walk around like Groucho Marx.

Their three lives are changed by the discovery of this magic portal, the door that leads into the consciousness of one of the grooviest, classiest, campest celebrities on the block. For a Warholian 15-minute session, they can see what Malkovich sees, feel what Malkovich feels; they experience him sorting through his mail, ordering a new periwinkle-blue shade of bathmat in that fluting, mellifluous voice - before they are ejected ecstatically onto a grass verge by the New Jersey turnpike.

The film effects a terrifying mise-en-abîme when John furiously discovers what is going on and demands to go through the door himself into his own mind, with astonishing results. But not before Lotte has discovered she kinkily enjoys being John Malkovich while he is having actual-reality sex with Maxine: "It's as if the portal is vaginal," breathes Lotte wonderingly. "It shows John's feminine side."

This film comes as close as it is possible to get to a sustained nirvana of giggling, a hovering delirium of comedy. It's like breathing in nitrous oxide, making you feel liable at any moment to float away. It has a Woody Allen-ish quality - and Cusack's performance is not that far from his lead in Bullets Over Broadway - but not so much Allen's films as the playful short stories. It has something of the F Anstey of Vice Versa, and the Gore Vidal of Myra Breckinridge and Myron, and also a little of The Truman Show and EDtv.

Being John Malkovich brings a light touch to the important things it says about the ballooning cult of celebrity, how the aristocracy of the famous bombards us with gilded, gorgeous lives and hyper-real existences from every screen - subtly encouraging us to believe not merely in the inferiority of the non-famous existence, but its relative unreality. And in doing so, it returns us to the childlike reverie, as we look down at our hands, arms, and the tapering perspective of our bodies, of what it is like to be someone else. And further, to wondering what it is to be ourselves.

The choice of John Malkovich himself is inspired: he treats the role with a sporting lack of pomposity and yet absolute seriousness. In doing so, he has magnified his reputation and career a thousandfold. (For 10 minutes after the house lights went up, and I gently came down, I tried to think of any British name with the class to bring off the same tightrope act. Someone with grandeur and style, a premiership celebrity player who is simultaneously able to make a knight's-move away from, and above celebrity. Being Ian McKellen?)

Put simply, Being John Malkovich just has to be one of funniest, cleverest films of the year, a Fabergé egg of comic delight.

fields.headline: The best puppeteer scene
fields.standfirst: Being John Malkovich
fields.trailText: Being John Malkovich
fields.body:
New York. Having explained to his wife Lotte (played by Cameron Diaz) that he can't get a good puppeteering job because he "raises issues", Craig (played by John Cusack) takes his show on to the streets. Except his isn't an ordinary puppet show - it's the story of the love affair between Heloise and Abelard, a nun and priest in medieval France. The puppets stand in separate rooms, their voices narrated by a tape of Craig and Lotte.

"While we enjoyed the pleasures of our uneasy love," begins Heloise, "and abandoned ourselves to fornication, we were spared God's severity."

"Say no more," replies Abelard, "and cease from complaints which are so far removed from the true depths of love."

An excited little girl approaches, turning to her father.

"Look! A puppet show."

"OK," he says, "but just one minute - mommy's waiting."

Heloise continues.

"Even during the celebration of mass, when our prayers should be pure, lewd visions of these pleasures take such a hold upon my unhappy soul, and my thoughts are filled with wantoness instead of my prayers."

The puppet moves towards the wall, her hand to her breast.

"Sometimes my thoughts are betrayed by my body."

"I took my fill," says Abelard, "of my wretched pleasures. And this was the sum total of my love"

Both puppets dry-hump the wall. The little girl looks on, open-mouthed. Her father suddenly glances round.

"You motherfucker!"

The father punches Craig, then stamps repeatedly on Abelard and Heloise.

See also: The Double Life Of Veronique, Lili, Pinocchio

Don't see also: Puppet Master (I through IV)

Pointless trivia: Being John Malkovich director Spike Jonze's real name is Adam Spiegel.

fields.headline: Gayle forces pace before showers
fields.trailText: BC Pires Perhaps understandably, the West Indian selectors picked for the first Test a line-up of batters more given to graft than gusto. Even so, it was slow going.
fields.byline: BC Pires in Port of Spain
fields.body:
Zimbabwe's captain Andy Flower last week lamented the absence of Brian Lara, saying that Zimbabwe wanted to beat Lara, not just the West Indies.

It was the kind of comment Trinidadians label "talking fat" since no one - least of all Flower, probably - really expects the Zimbabweans to beat even a Lara-less West Indies, but after a severely rain-shortened first day, in which West Indies were reduced to 79 for three, Flower's bluster may seem a trifle less windy. The score could easily have been 72 for four had Trevor Gripper held an easy catch at forward short-leg to remove the nightwatchman Curtly Ambrose.

The dream start to Zimbabwe's first West Indian tour continued with an important toss yesterday that allowed Flower to send in on a green wicket a West Indian side whose batting line-up recently has been more famous for collapsing than scoring monumental totals. Perhaps under- standably the selectors picked a line-up more given to graft than gusto. Even so, it was slow going.

Tidy bowling from Henry Olonga, Heath Streak and Mpulelelo "Pom" Mbangwa made runs hard to come by. Only one boundary was scored in the first 23 overs and for a full half-hour the score stood defiantly at 19.

After Adrian Griffith went for a duck, lbw to Heath Streak off the third ball of the day, any serious batsman could be forgiven for concentrating on staying in rather than scoring quickly. The debutant Chris Gayle applied that formula in concentrated form, labouring over 37 balls to take his score past two. After hitting Mbangwa for the first of six fours, however, he loosened up and raced, relatively speaking, to 33 before being run out by Brian Murphy just before lunch.

Gayle was the hare at the wicket compared to Sherwin Campbell's tortoise, who went to lunch having scored nine off 69 deliveries. Even Shivnarine Chanderpaul, who can take as long to get off the mark as others do to reach their 50, outscored Campbell, who had nine when rain interrupted play at 12.54pm, nine minutes and 13 balls after lunch.

Play resumed at 5.20pm and the rest seemed to have refreshed Campbell, who made as many runs in the first seven minutes of the last session as he did in the whole of the first session.

Chanderpaul must not have woken up properly, though: he was out flashing at an unspectacular ball that would have ended up in the wicketkeeper's hands without his nick.

fields.headline: Hard-wired into music
fields.standfirst:
Richard Alston Dance Company
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
Rating: * * * *
fields.trailText:
Richard Alston Dance Company
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
fields.body:
Richard Alston's choreographic imagination is hard-wired into music, and the inspiration for his triple bill is self-evidently drawn from its eclectic trio of scores (Handel, Brahms and Steve Reich).

However, in the work that forms its heart, A Sudden Exit, we do not just witness the radiant physical chemistry between rhythm, melody and dancers for which Alston is famous, but also the unfolding of a more interior story.

The piece is set to Brahms' late piano music (from Ops 118 and 119), whose concentrated melodic lines are a dance-maker's gift. The music is haunted by a kind of absence, which Alston picks up in the opening solo (danced by Martin Lawrance), where movement that is bold and elastic repeatedly wavers or turns in on itself with a sense of loss. Lawrance is joined by Pari Naderi, who marks his moves with an almost maternal strength and watchfulness.

Three others join in, but their rapt duets and trios keep being broken off, leaving Lawrance rejected and literally empty-handed. The closing solo is as rawly affecting as anything Alston has made.

The exposed nerve endings of this work are cushioned by the two sunnily extrovert dances which flank it, the first of that, The Signal of a Shake, is set to Handel's concerti for organ and orchestra. The essence of the music is captured with a wonderful sureness, Alston's dance striding along with the same deep muscular purpose and playing with the same bright detail.

There is also an atmosphere of peculiar tenderness in the piece, which is set in the first elegant tumbling duet, where every lift and gesture vibrates with a lingering touch.

As the dance builds through densely structured ensembles and brilliant display, this sensitivity remains, which means that a piece that is essentially a virtuoso showcase is also a study of beguiling, unfaked intimacy.

Alston's dancers (a very young and talented group) look exultant in this, as they do in the closing work, Roughcut, a setting of Reich's New York and Electric Counterpoints. Blithe cascades of movement finish off an evening in which Alston's creative energies seem to run at their most free and triumphant. When he is this good, he is hard to beat.

 Until tomorrow. Box office: 0171 960 4242

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: High street sales at 18-month low
fields.trailText: Britain's shops and stores suffered a post-millennium hangover last month as consumers stayed away from the high street and caused the sharpest drop in retail sales for more than 18 months.
fields.body:
Britain's shops and stores suffered a post-millennium hangover last month as consumers stayed away from the high street and caused the sharpest drop in retail sales for more than 18 months.

With prices recovering a little after discounting in the winter sales, retailers saw the volume of sales drop by 1.2% in January following two months in which the pace of spending had prompted fears of a rerun of the late 1980s boom.

Some sectors of the high street posted small increases in sales volumes, with department stores reporting volumes up by almost 1%.

However, the price war among supermarkets failed to prevent a 0.9% decline in food sales, while outlets selling household goods recorded a 3.7% decline in business.

In the three months to February, thought a better guide to the underlying trend than one month's figures, the volume of retail sales was 1.8% higher than in the previous quarter and 5.5% up on the same three months a year earlier.

The figures from the offiice for national statistics showed that spending growth had returned to the levels seen last autumn, with little signs so far that the four increases in base rates since September are having much impact on an environment in which consumer confidence is strong and the housing market in parts of the country is surging.

City analysts had been expecting some reaction to the spending spree around the turn of the year, but were surprised by the extent of the fall.

However, some still believe that the underlying strength of demand will persuade the Bank of England's monetary policy committee to raise interest rates further.

webTitle: Carpetbagger Hardern returns to Nationwide fray

fields.headline: Carpetbagger Hardern returns to Nationwide fray
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Michael Hardern, the butler and self-styled carpetbagger-in-chief, yesterday renewed his attack on Nationwide building society with the launch of a fresh campaign aimed at forcing it to convert and pay windfalls.
fields.body:
Michael Hardern, the butler and self-styled carpetbagger-in-chief, yesterday renewed his attack on Nationwide building society with the launch of a fresh campaign aimed at forcing it to convert and pay windfalls.

Mr Hardern, who has twice tried and failed to force the Nationwide to convert to a bank, hopes to use the power of the internet to rally supporters. He has launched his own website, hardern.com, which carries resolution forms which members can print off, sign and return to him. He is also targeting West Bromwich building society.

The move comes almost exactly a year after the 43-year-old staged a musical "happening" outside his home involving Hare Krishnas, a tom-tom drummer and a penny whistle player to announce that he was retiring from carpetbagging duty. "I'm moving on. I've shown people what they can do. They can get on with it," was what he said then.

Yesterday Mr Hardern was unapologetic about his return to the fray, saying that following attempts by other carpetbaggers to take on the Portman, Skipton and other societies, someone needed to "keep plugging away" at the sector.

Mr Hardern has drawn up five resolutions for which he is seeking support, including one calling on each society to take steps to convert to PLC status and distribute free shares to members, and another demanding the removal of the societies' chairmen.

There is also a resolution that calls on the two societies to change their names to "Nationwide/West Bromwich members want windfalls, free shares and conversion to a PLC from a building society" - a proposal he insists is serious.

Mr Hardern admits that his chances are slim. The Nationwide does not have to put a conversion resolution to its members until 2001 at the earliest after defeating a demutualisation campaign mounted by Mr Hardern in 1998.

His biggest challenge will be to recruit enough supporters before the deadlines for resolutions to be received, which are April 4 in the case of Nationwide and March 31 in the case of West Bromwich. Mr Hardern said his conversion resolutions only needed the backing of 50 eligible members for them to be put forward for consideration. But Nationwide said this was incorrect and that the number was now 500 following new anti-carpetbagging measures introduced by the government late last year.

fields.headline: Law Society deputy chief suspended
fields.standfirst:
Solicitors' body vehemently denies allegations of race and sex discrimination after vice president is found guilty of bullying staff

Law Society
fields.trailText: The Law Society yesterday suspended Kamlesh Bahl, its vice president, from its council after a damning report from a panel headed by a former law lord found her guilty of bullying staff.
fields.body:
The Law Society yesterday suspended Kamlesh Bahl, its vice president, from its council after a damning report from a panel headed by a former law lord found her guilty of bullying staff.

The report , by Lord Griffiths and two members of the employment appeal tribunal, found that Ms Bahl, 43, treated staff in a way "at times demeaning and humiliating, and at other times offensively aggressive".

The inquiry found that she subjected staff to "verbal onslaughts, which we believe she used as a management tool to dominate the staff and stamp her authority on the organisation".

On one occasion, the report said, she attacked a senior official in front of the society's president and secretary general in "a terrifying verbal onslaught and a wholly unacceptable way in which to speak to any member of staff".

An abridged form of the report will go out to the 80,000 solicitors in England and Wales who are members of the society. They will decide at an extraordinary general meeting next month whether to expel Ms Bahl from the council.

If she is expelled, it will end her hopes of becoming president in July. She had been expected to step into the president's chair unopposed as the first woman and first ethnic minority solicitor to lead the profession.

The complaints of bullying were lodged through the MSF union by Russell Wallman, the society's director of policy, Barbara Cahalane, director of communications, Jonathan Goldsmith, international director, Jean Johnson, director of human resources, and Ann Frazer, a member of Mr Goldsmith's team.

Last night Ms Bahl told Channel 4 news that the complaints, which dated back to September 1998, were only brought to her attention in February 2000. "They were stockpiled and allowed to fester, put together with a wider agenda and that agenda was to remove me from office."

She accused the society of breaching an agreement reached with her lawyers that no decision about suspending her would be taken at yesterday's meeting.

Ms Bahl's suspension comes a day after she launched a race and sex discrimination claim at an employment tribunal against the society, its president Robert Sayer, the secretary general Jane Betts, and Ms Johnson, claiming the complaints had been handled unfairly.

The society responded: "We entirely reject the outrageous allegations of racial and sexual discrimination made by Ms Bahl. The society will defend itself vigorously against any such charges. Nothing should obscure the fact that the real issue here is bullying in the workplace."

Eileen Pembridge, chairman of the society's equal opportunities committee, said Ms Bahl's claim that her "face didn't fit" because she was an Asian woman was wrong. "That's always been in her favour and the reason why so many of us were so well-disposed to her for so long."

One former insider said: "I sense there will probably be quite a lot of support in the profession for Kamlesh because she's tried to kick ass."

Ms Bahl argued at the inquiry that her firm and direct style was necessary to achieve the reform needed to bring the society into the 21st century.

The inquiry has cost the society more than £500,000, with Ms Bahl's legal fees estimated at around £200,000.

fields.headline: Lloyd's scorns fraud claim
fields.standfirst:
Insurance market denies trying to palm off its losses on unknowing newcomers

Lloyds
fields.trailText: Lloyd's, the insurance market, yesterday hit back in court at allegations that it operated a 10-year fraud to suck in new investors and fleece them for billions of pounds.
fields.body:
Lloyd's, the insurance market, yesterday hit back in court at allegations that it operated a 10-year fraud to suck in new investors and fleece them for billions of pounds.

QC Charles Aldous poured scorn on the notion of a conspiracy and said some of those now suing the market had been "innocently and unnecessarily" drawn into the case. Opening the Lloyd's defence in the high court, Mr Aldous said there was no evidence to support claims that senior market figures had tried to recruit new investors - known as "names" - in the 1970s and 1980s in order to land them with the bill for £4bn of asbestos-related insurance claims.

"There was no such misrepresentation, let alone fraudulent," he told Mr Justice Cresswell. Far from hiding the truth about asbestos claims from the market, Lloyd's set up a "top level working party" and circulated its findings to hundreds of insurance syndicates.

"There is no basis for alleging any information was withheld from the market," he said.

"Many of those [senior Lloyd's figures] wrongly alleged to have been dishonest in this case lost a substantial amount of money . . . and they did so on the very same syndicates. Many, indeed, increased their underwriting during the very period the names allege the fraud was at its highest.

"We submit this is the most telling evidence against the names' case. There is no sense in a fraud if it is the fraudsters who lose the money."

But when pressed by Mr Justice Cresswell, Mr Aldous conceded that there had been "fault lines" in Lloyd's during the period in question, with practices such as the running of "baby syndicates" for the benefit of Lloyd's insiders and the taking of secret profits by agents supposedly working for the names. Mr Aldous said he did not defend baby syndicates.

Lloyd's is facing in court 231 names who are refusing to pay the £51m they owe for their Lloyd's losses on the grounds of fraudulent misrepresentation by Lloyd's between 1978 and 1988. Earlier this month, Simon Goldblatt QC, for the names, told the court that Lloyd's had known for years that it faced possible bankruptcy because of claims for asbestos-related illnesses, and had decided to recruit more investors to share the burden, without spelling out to them the risks involved.

He named 33 top Lloyd's figures from the period, including former chairmen Sir Peter Miller and Sir David Rowland. But yesterday Mr Aldous said: "We now have 33 elderly people singled out and wrongly accused of dishonesty . . . Very little logic has been applied in the selection of the 33 . . . For the most part all we have is just a list of people in senior positions . . . with just the bald assertion that 'they must have known', but quite what it is, is not said."

He hit out at "wild and irresponsible" circulars drawn up by certain names' action groups which had drawn other names into spending money they could not afford on fighting the case. He said "rumour and suspicion have fed upon [each other]," with Lloyd's documents subjected to the "minutest textual analysis".

There have been references to secret societies and codenames. One of these - "Foldrug" - was mentioned by Mr Goldblatt as having appeared in Lloyd's paperwork.

Mr Aldous said "there is in our submission nothing in this". It was probably "an acronym, not a codeword," with UG standing for "user group".

Overall, he said, when one "cut through the hyperbole . . . it's difficult to understand what they're basing their case on".

Lloyd's "global accounts" for those years gave the big picture, he said, but the detail was in individual syndicate accounts, and "syndicate after syndicate reported it was affected by asbestos".

Mr Aldous said: "If members were unwilling to study syndicate accounts, they should never have joined Lloyd's in the first place."

fields.headline: A repertoire of greatness
fields.standfirst:
Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra/Seiji Ozawa
Royal Festival Hall, London
Rating: * * * *
fields.trailText: It's hard to say what makes the Vienna Philharmonic sound so special. Where many of the great international orchestras strive for a clean sonic perfection, the VPO has remained resolute in its retention of "imperfect", non-globalised features. That initially jarring, reedy oboe sound, the idiosyncratic, penetrative trumpets, and the unconventionally subtle horns - all are somehow the necessary grains of sand that produce the most lustrous pearls of orchestral sonority. From the mountainous power of the double basses to the sumptuous intensity of the first violins, this is an orchestra made up of individuals. Providing, of course, that they are male: a lone harpist apart, the VPO is still a defiantly men-only affair.
fields.body:
It's hard to say what makes the Vienna Philharmonic sound so special. Where many of the great international orchestras strive for a clean sonic perfection, the VPO has remained resolute in its retention of "imperfect", non-globalised features. That initially jarring, reedy oboe sound, the idiosyncratic, penetrative trumpets, and the unconventionally subtle horns - all are somehow the necessary grains of sand that produce the most lustrous pearls of orchestral sonority. From the mountainous power of the double basses to the sumptuous intensity of the first violins, this is an orchestra made up of individuals. Providing, of course, that they are male: a lone harpist apart, the VPO is still a defiantly men-only affair.

The rapport between players, most obvious in the knowing smiles and winks that pervaded the Josef and Johann Strauss encores, does not just create an immediate sense of involvement and excitement. When you remember that this is the orchestra that premiered so many 19th-century masterpieces, and that is part of a unique lineage back to the great Viennese composers, a performance by the VPO becomes the most powerful of authentic musical experiences. Its current tour with Seiji Ozawa presented an all-Brahms programme, and both the works in the first half - the Tragic Overture and Variations on a Theme by Haydn - were first performed by this orchestra in late 19th-century Vienna.

Ozawa's interpretations were remarkable only in how unremarkable they were. Groomed in the best post-Karajan style, Ozawa played the Tragic Overture at an unrelenting, appropriately reverential tempo, whilst the Variations were conventionally worthy. Only the last movement of the Fourth Symphony demonstrated any interpretative iconoclasm, with Ozawa's rubato unusually flexible in the slower variations.

And yet Ozawa's blend of conservative musical manners and athletic podium prowess allowed the orchestra to reveal the strength of its living, breathing relationship with this music. The coda of the Fourth Symphony's first movement was a breathtaking combination of fire and finesse. The VPO has Brahms's complex syncopations in its blood, so each voice, from the thunderous basses to the peals of timpani, was clearly focused within the overall screwing-up of contrapuntal tension. At the end of Ozawa's stately second movement, the cellos' shaping of Brahms's rippling arpeggios was the kind of moment of isolated brilliance that comes from years - centuries - of dynamic tradition. Even without the profoundest of insights from its conductor, the VPO, in this repertoire, still provides the richest of orchestral experiences.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

webTitle: Upstarts are dealt sharp FTSE lesson

fields.headline: Upstarts are dealt sharp FTSE lesson
fields.trailText: These are strange times. It is accepted wisdom that being booted out of the FTSE 100 index is bad news, while promotion to the stockmarket's equivalent of the Premier League will boost your share price.
fields.body:
These are strange times. It is accepted wisdom that being booted out of the FTSE 100 index is bad news, while promotion to the stockmarket's equivalent of the Premier League will boost your share price.

The vast amount of cash in tracker funds - about a fifth of the cash now managed by institutional shareholders - will automatically be forced to chase the newcomers, to ensure their portfolios remain truly representative of the index, which sends their share prices higher.

Simultaneously, they bail out of those being relegated, with the opposite effect.

Such has been the case for years. That is why companies facing relegation - such as Whitbread in recent weeks - embark on lobbying campaigns among City investors and analysts in last-ditch atempts to inject a little life into their shares and so retain their FTSE status.

When venture capital group 3i bid for the investment trust Electra last year, chairman Sir George Russell admitted that at least part of the rationale behind the bid was a determination to cement 3i's FTSE 100 position.

So the events of the past week, the biggest FTSE 100 upheaval since the index was started in 1984, have been nothing if not unusual.

Without exception, the largely unknown newcomers which burst into the big league - and represent the new economy - have registered a decline in their share prices.

Meanwhile, the old economy stocks, which included some of the best known names in corporate Britain, have put on something of a sprint.

Two of the nine new entrants - Nycomed Amersham and Celltech - have lost more than a fifth of their value since being named as new members of the FTSE 100 nine days ago. Only two - Cable & Wireless Communications and Emap - have lost less than 15%. The FTSE 100 index, meanwhile has climbed by 1.4%

The biggest gainer has been a truly old-economy, politically incorrect outfit - Imperial Tobacco, purveyors of Player's Navy Cut, up 15.3% to 507p.
