fields.headline: Shadows of delight
fields.standfirst:
City of Birmingham SO/ Simon Rattle
City Hall, Birmingham
Rating: * * * *
fields.trailText: For the past 10 years the City of Birmingham Symphony Orchestra has been charting music's voyage towards the 21st century in its epic Towards the Millennium series. As a grand finale it offers three concerts, each containing a work commissioned to mark the occasion. If Judith Weir's We Are Shadows (the second of these three new works) has anything to tell us about humanity's collective feelings on reaching Y2K, it isn't a comforting message. The texts, taken from Ancient Chinese and Latin poetry plus inscriptions on Scottish tombstones, are full of dread and nervous humour. Life is a shadow; not even death is certain. One may end up reincarnated as something hideous - like a rat's liver, one Chinese poet whimsically suggests.
fields.body:
For the past 10 years the City of Birmingham Symphony Orchestra has been charting music's voyage towards the 21st century in its epic Towards the Millennium series. As a grand finale it offers three concerts, each containing a work commissioned to mark the occasion. If Judith Weir's We Are Shadows (the second of these three new works) has anything to tell us about humanity's collective feelings on reaching Y2K, it isn't a comforting message. The texts, taken from Ancient Chinese and Latin poetry plus inscriptions on Scottish tombstones, are full of dread and nervous humour. Life is a shadow; not even death is certain. One may end up reincarnated as something hideous - like a rat's liver, one Chinese poet whimsically suggests.

As in a lot of Weir's work, the emotions in We Are Shadows often seem to be kept at a distance, or at most expressed obliquely. The music often drums or fidgets anxiously, as though waiting for a catastrophe that never materialises. On the face of it the language seems familiar - surprisingly so: at several points I was reminded of Holst, or even the quirkier Vaughan Williams. But the handling of the sounds, the connecting of the gestures, is disconcerting, elusive.

One thing one can say for certain is that it is beautifully written. The orchestration is masterly, and always slightly surprising in the way it brings colours together - mostly strikingly liquid flutes and quietly growling tuba. The writing for the choir, and particularly for the children's voices, was just as impressive - secure, polished singing there from the City of Birmingham Chorus and Youth Chorus. It left me with a strong desire to hear We Are Shadows again - it plainly has much more to reveal.

In fact I would have sacrificed Messiaen's immensely long, vastly scored Eclairs sur l'Au-Delà for an opportunity to hear the Weir once more, despite the luscious performance by the expanded CBSO under Simon Rattle. Messiaen's last work is mostly very slow and, despite some stunning orchestration, weirdly uneventful. Either one buys into Messiaen's idiosyncratic religious philosophy or one doesn't. For the initiates I'm sure it was bliss. For me the sounds were sporadically attractive, but as a whole baffling.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible
fields.bodyText: For the past 10 years the City of Birmingham Symphony Orchestra has been charting music's voyage towards the 21st century in its epic Towards the Millennium series. As a grand finale it offers three concerts, each containing a work commissioned to mark the occasion. If Judith Weir's We Are Shadows (the second of these three new works) has anything to tell us about humanity's collective feelings on reaching Y2K, it isn't a comforting message. The texts, taken from Ancient Chinese and Latin poetry plus inscriptions on Scottish tombstones, are full of dread and nervous humour. Life is a shadow; not even death is certain. One may end up reincarnated as something hideous - like a rat's liver, one Chinese poet whimsically suggests. As in a lot of Weir's work, the emotions in We Are Shadows often seem to be kept at a distance, or at most expressed obliquely. The music often drums or fidgets anxiously, as though waiting for a catastrophe that never materialises. On the face of it the language seems familiar - surprisingly so: at several points I was reminded of Holst, or even the quirkier Vaughan Williams. fields.headline: Freeserve put on the defensive
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Freeserve, Britain's largest internet service provider, yesterday sought to reassure investors about its growth prospects despite admitting that the shift toward unmetered access could rip a hole in the company's bottom line.
fields.body:
Freeserve, Britain's largest internet service provider, yesterday sought to reassure investors about its growth prospects despite admitting that the shift toward unmetered access could rip a hole in the company's bottom line.

Chief executive John Pluthero welcomed the advent of unmetered access across the industry but conceded the company would have preferred it not to have arrived so early in Freeserve's life.

"If this had happened a year ago I would have been worried," Mr Pluthero said. "If it had happened a year from now I would be completely unconcerned.

"Part of me says it is fantastic that it is happening now because it will encourage people to spend more time on the internet but part of me also says we haven't quite got the job done yet."

Zoom, the online retailer owned by Arcadia and run by Eva Pascoe, boss of London's pioneering Cybercafe, became the latest to join the fray yesterday offering free unlimited access for a one-off £10 charge.

Freeserve is offering customers unmetered off-peak access for £6.99 a month of which £5.99 will be kept by British Telecom. The additional cost to Freeserve of handling calls means that each customer will be subsidised to the tune of £2 a month. That would amount to almost £4m a month if the company's entire subscriber base switches to the offer.

At the same time Freeserve will lose incremental revenues from its share of call charges.

Shares in Freeserve, which reached 921p in early March, have been battered by the move to unmetered access and added 3p yesterday to 590p.

Freeserve yesterday reported third-quarter revenues of £5.1m, 36% higher than the previous three months. The loss before tax narrowed slightly from £3.6m to £3.5m.

The company is keen to present itself as a portal business which in the medium term will depend almost entirely upon advertising and, more importantly, e-commerce and said the two now account for 55% of turnover. The rest is from Freeserve's share of call revenues.

"You want a strong access base which you can leverage for e-commerce but you can't make money from purely be ing an ISP which some of our competitors misread," Mr Pluthero said.

He also said talks had been held with most of the large sports organisations including the Premier League and governing bodies for horse and greyhound racing to discuss internet broadcast rights as part of the drive to improve content.

Mr Pluthero sought to reassure investors and said the effect on revenues from unmetered access would only be short term as wholesale prices of telephony fall and e-commerce and advertising revenues take off.

"There is a chunk of connectivity we lose which feeds through to the profit and loss account but all of these people will be using the internet more and e-commerce and advertising will increase as a consequence. How quickly those two lines cross is difficult to predict," he said.

Freeserve had 162.8m page impressions in February, up 48% on November, and 1.8m active registered accounts, up by 16% on the previous quarter. The company said e-commerce revenues were double those from advertising and added that financial services were generating the most cash.
